Initially I had problems getting it to work the way I wanted with Adobe Premiere Elements, but I discovered additional controls in APE that allowed me to adjust the sound level to an acceptable one. I would imagine that a microphone like this would need some kind of amplifier, and that would be a welcome addition. However, with the right microphone placement and voice level, the quality is very clear.

There's a lot to recommend this chip. First, and most impressive to me, I was able to read the ingredients without a bio-chemical dictionary at my side. The ingredients are all regular foods and not added chemicals for color, preservation or taste. As the name implies, they're made with black beans and backup up with corn, oil (canola & sunflower) brown rice flour, flax seed, and some other seeds and flavorings. In other words, you know what you're getting and it's gluten free.My wife and I tried them, and they taste ok. I tried them with basil tomato soup (dipping) and plain. The taste was a little bland but not offensive. As such, they'd probably be good with a more tasty dip with onion, clam, garlic, chives, or even humus. Also, with dietary restrictions on certain foods, especially those containing gluten, they would be a good addition to any party where guests may not be able to have regular chips. Sodium content is 80mg, which isn't bad for a single serving of 5 chips, but with 4 servings 320mg may be a bit high for some.Often people confuse healthy, which these chips certainly appear to be, with low fat/calorie. The basic serving of 5 chips is 130 calories with 6g of fat. One serving isn't going to break anyone's scale, but the problem with chips is that one serving usually isn't what anyone eats. Calculating the Weight Watchers value, it was 3 points—not bad; not great. Better to fill up on carrots and celery sticks.So overall, the chips appear to meet high healthy standards, and each serving is reasonable as fat, sodium, and calories are concerned, but these chips are not to be gobbled up wholesale. The taste is unremarkable and a chip might be recommended as a shovel for bean dip or other dips with distinctive flavors.

I got the Tektronix TBS 1202B with the primary focus of working with experiments using the Raspberry Pi computer and different experimental boards with which I would be able to work on some hardware/software projects. While the Tektronix Courseware Raspberry Pi Labs was intended for the  TBS1000B-Edu series, there's nothing preventing them from working on the regular TSB 1000B series other than the fact that you pay a little more for the non-Edu version. ( Some Edu editions of software restrict commercial development; so I assumed that hardware may have similar restrictions.) So, the software element of the oscilloscope is vitally important.In setting up the TBS 1202B, I went through the recommended verification steps, and I was able to test and connect the probe to generate the square wave. (See photo) Further in verification, I found that all of the calibration tests on the 2 channels had been passed. Also I noted that the oscilloscope was running the 3.25 version of the firmware. (FV:3.25). As the instructions indicated I checked the latest version of firmware and found that it was FV:4.0; so I downloaded the file for updating the firmware, placed it on a flash drive and plugged it into the front of the oscilloscope. Using the Multipurpose button, I selected the correct software (TBS1KB.TEK) and pushed the update button. (See photo.) The docs indicated this would take several minutes and I'd get a response on the screen when the update was complete. Using two different flash drives and waiting over an hour, nothing happened, and I still have FV 3.25. In the FAQs, I when a user indicated a similar problem updating to 3.25, the suggestion was to change the file name to TBS1KB.TEK. Obviously that didn't work either. Furthermore, 75% of the readers indicated that the response was NOT helpful. So here's a problem that Tektronix had prior to FV 3.25 that still persists as users attempt to update to FV 4.0. Not a good sign. My computers and mobile devices have updates all the time. My PC seems to have a Windows update almost every time I turn it one; so updating software should not be a mystery and as impossible as I experienced.The documentation is quite good, and it runs fine on FV 3.25. Further, the software running in the Tektronix TBS1202B works great and has good HCI and UX. I like the way the menus work and how the Multipurpose knob is used to select items on the excellent screen. I haven idea why Tektronix lets the firmware update persist, but until they get it fixed, I'm stuck with the old version.

I don't suppose that paper towels that look tough are a lot different than those that don't, but I felt pretty good about tackling tough jobs with this towel that I'd probably feel less secure using the white ones on the roller in the kitchen. For example, cleaning up grease spots on my workbench or cleaning up a bathroom sink and shower after using heavy powder cleaners like Ajax has turned regular paper towels into shredded rags. Would the same be true with WypAll L10 Disposable Wipers? After testing the towels on both projects--sink and workbench--I found that they held up just fine and did not dissolve or tear when using powerful cleaners that strongly suggest wearing rubber gloves when applying.Seizing the opportunity, my wife suggested a number of projects to try out the towels on for a thorough review. In the back of our house we have a large picture window that looks over a small meadow, a woods and a pond. From this view we watch the seasons and various and sundry critters from the woods and sky. We like to keep it clean so that we miss nothing. The outside takes a scrubbing wand and squeegee with liberal amounts of water, and the inside requires window cleaner and a paper towel. One of the problems that other paper towels have had with window cleaning is that something that goes into the makeup of the towel mixes with the window cleaner and tends to leave a filmy residue. The window is clean, but the residue is visible, and so my hope was that this towel would not leave the residue. Unfortunately, it did. So while it was gang-busters on the tough jobs, it did not prove to be the cleaning towel I'd hoped for when it comes to window-cleaning.I like the handy Kleenex type pull-out for the towels. Roll towels can easily get knocked over and roll around the garage or other work places, but the boxed ones are easy to keep in place and retrieve single sheets. So for tough jobs, I highly recommend these towels

In the past I've not had much luck getting into Jonathan Kellerman's character, Alex Delaware and the stories related to the shrink-detective. However, the opposite was true, initially, with Grace Blades, the heroine of his latest novel. Her father killed her mother and so she ended up as the book's title, "The Murderer's Daughter." In a series of foster homes, she finally hits pay dirt in a home run by an eccentric (in a Ma Kettle way) woman, Ramona, who lives on a ranch, and here she seems to be set until she's old enough to be on her own. It turns out that Grace is a pretty smart cookie as tested by a psychologist named Malcolm Bluestore (Dr. Bluestone.) Between the home schooling materials that Bluestone brings and her eagerness to 1) learn and 2) be left alone, Grace flourishes academically while not having to attend school.The story is told on a back-and-forth timeline; so we know early on that Grace (Dr. Blades) is now a clinical psychologist living in a small house in Malibu and practicing in West Hollywood; both in the LA area. She's like this magic psychologist since everyone she sees recommends her to their friends and seem to recover from whatever problem they had when they first went to see her. While she may have minimal relationship skills in her own life, her skills as a shrink are phenomenal. Her idea of a relationship with a man is a quickie in the dark corder of a hotel parking structure.  In fact, there's a point where most men with her predilections would be described as "creepy," but some may consider that "liberated" for a woman. Or maybe the reader is supposed to understand that given Grace's terrible relationship issues in her past, her current behavior reflects a biological need met by someone who cannot handle relationships with men (or anyone else.)Grace gets her undergraduate degree from Harvard (naturally) and her Ph.D. in clinical psychology, from USC, which may sound like a step down—way down from Harvard. (Since USC is ranked #18 nationally in clinical psychology and nearby UCLA is ranked #1, why did Grace go to USC? Well, that's where Dr. Bluestone and his wife work; that's why!) Along the way, Grace picks up skills in Krav Maga—Israeli combat fighting technique used by the IDF— and how to shoot a gun. So by the time we meet her as a successful clinical psychologist, she can handle herself as a combo Kung Fu Mama, Annie Oakley and highly effective head-fixer.The drama as a thriller begins when Grace humps a guy in a parking garage who shows up the next day as a patient.  Ach du lieber Gott! What would Freud say? Anyway, to make things more interesting, this same guy is one she knew as a kid when he and his brother and sister were brought to Ramona's foster home-ranch. The next thing you know, the guy gets killed and Grace has to jump into the role of Sherlock Freud. Her suspect is quickly identified, and so she's off to Berkeley to find and stop him from further evil.At this point, a little after halfway through the book, things bog down. It gets about as interesting as an insurance seminar as Grace enters a holding pattern waiting for the book to reach 364 pages. It finishes with a flourish, but the very end seems to add a bit more creepiness to Grace's already creepy personality—outside of the clinical setting. Up to a point I very much enjoyed the book, and I was hovering between 3 and 4 stars and decided that I'd like to see more of Grace with a little less perfection (perfect scholar; perfect therapist) and a little more humanity with human relationship (some kind of relationship that spans more than two drinks and a whoopee.) The sweet relationship between Malcolm Bluestone and his wife was quite well done and bringing out the character of Ramona was equally adroit. Grace needs a bit of a makeover, but only the perfection and creep.

This is the first set of earrings with manufactured or "lab" rubies I've got for my wife. In the past, she's had emerald earrings that were a gift from our son that he got in Columbia and I've purchased a ring with real rubies from Israel. The real rubies and emeralds are nice, but the manufactured ones are essentially the same aluminium oxide-based stones. The perfection of the manufactured rubies is a giveaway that they're not natural—a natural ruby with the clarity and perfection of these would be worth a fortune.In most of the jewelers where you would find comparable earrings (e.g., Zales, Jareds), the prices ranged from lower to higher, and without having the actual earrings in hand it's difficult to compare. Also, if you purchase rubies for earrings, the settings are typically yellow or white gold instead of sterling silver. However, sterling silver is fine compared to other metals. You have to keep it polished, but I'm perfectly happy with sterling silver over gold.In order to compare these earrings with earrings made with real rubies, I took a picture of the earrings on and made a copy and superimposed the image of a real ruby. The difference in the price is significant ($126 vs. $8,500), but the appearance was not that much. However, suffice it to say, that while these earrings are not going to be confused with the ones sold at Harry Winston's, for the price, you get your money's worth. You can judge for yourself from the attached picture. (I superimposed a $4,266 ruby in an earring on the image on the right.)

Some things are just easier to write in a notebook than a computer or computer tablet. Tablets are too much of a hassle to type on, and often what I need to take notes on are emanating from my computer in the form of online classes. (I'm a big edX and coursea MOOC fan.) The big notebooks (8.5 x 11) are fine if you have the entire desktop to yourself, but I share mine with a computer with a 27" monitor, a smartphone on a tripod, a scanner and an embarrassing amount of other gizmos. This little spiral bound notebook is about half the size of a regular notebook and fits right on top of my mousepad, but leaving enough room for my wireless mouse.When I've signed up for yet another MOOC course, I'm able to take notes, and because the wire binding is cloth-clovered, it doesn't get tangled up in the wires or anything else on my desktop. All of the pages are perforated in case I want to tear one out, and in the front is a plastic divider with page-holders on either side. (You can fit several loose pages in the holders.) A cloth loop on the front holds a ballpoint pen, positioned so that the pen can be fully inserted without sticking out the top or bottom. (See photo.)

At some point in time, Swiffer products began to accumulate in our cleaner cabinet. We have wet, dry and dusters plus I don't know how many more. So, what do we need another one for? It turns out that this new one called "Sweep and Trap" solved a problem we've had for years and never thought about. The dry Swiffer cleaning cloth is not any different (that I could discern) from our old Swiffer used for dry floor cleaning. (We have two stories of hardwood floors, and so there are plenty of surfaces for a dry Swiffer.) This new one has a rotating "sweeper" that picks up bulkier items and throws them into a holder that can easily be opened over the trash for discard. It's like a carpet sweeper for hardwood floors and dry Swiffer combination.Of course we do have vacuum cleaners (...we're not savages...) and they're used on a regular basis to pull up the debris that accumulates from living as well as visits from our grandchildren. Sometimes, however, we get little dry spills -- chopped nuts, leaves from an indoor tree, and dust bunnies -- (wet cleaners against dust bunnies result in what appear to be hairy drain clogs.) Neither the dry nor the wet Swiffers get  leaves, so, I was very happy to see that the Sweep & Trap pulled in  leaves and clung to everything from a pesky wrapping wire to dust bunnies (see photo).One of the most difficult areas to clean is under the TV and desktops with computers. Even in this day and age of WiFi, we still have wires everywhere. When using a vacuum cleaner (or a wet Swiffer), I'm afraid of getting electrocuted or breaking connections, but the wires are a favorite hiding place of dust bunnies and need to be attacked vigorously. Finding a dry solution in the Sweep and Trap was most welcomed, and while still a pain in the neck to clean around wires, this new Swiffer really helped.In looking at the negative reviews, it appears as though Swiffer listened to them and made adjustments. As to the gap between the rotating blades that toss the larger chunks into the holder, they added a "cow-catcher" in the blade gap. My experience indicates the Sweep & Trap does a good job, and in tight corners and around wires, this is a big plus. (See photos) Any manufacturer who listens to reviewers has my vote, and so kudos to Swiffer.Finally, in looking at the instructions, I found them in both English and French. Being a Francophile I was happy to see a French translation, but my initial reaction was, "Que pensaient-ils?" If only marketed in the US and the Canadian province of Quebec, that makes sense, but in the U.S. market, I'd think that Spanish would be a better second choice for instructions. (Of course they may have been thinking that having a French translation makes house cleaning look more chic--with the little green sneakers the pictured model has on--"Cela semble raisonnable.")

Not too long ago, I had a loose nut on my lawn tractor, and I did not have a wrench that fit the nut. So I looked up the size in the tractor's manual and headed down to the hardware store and bought the wrench socket-holder and then (separately) the socket. It tightened up the nut, and I haven't had a problem with it since. That's why I like this 8-in-one set. While I don't need and/or use a socket wrench much, when I need one, I really need one. For one who seldom needs any wrench,  I can recommend this set of two ratchet wrenches. That's because every nut has a fitting size wrench, and this set of 8 standard non-metric sizes covers most of what I'll ever need. What's more, instead of taking up the space of 8 wrenches, this set fits well with just 2.The wrenches are made for what feels like a good grade steel, and the reversal switch on the ratchet makes it easy to tighten and un-tighten nuts and bolts using the ratchet. The two different sized wrenches is more useful than I realized as I was unable to get the larger of the two (4 sizes) wrenches in a confined space where a smaller nuts was set. The wrenches work on hex, square, 12-point, E-torx, partially rounded and spline heads. The eight sizes (inches) are: 5/16, 3/8, 7/16,1/2, 9/16, 5/8, 11/16, 3/4. Usually, more than enough of what I would need both in terms of sizes and head shapes.The only downside is that I like the open crescent wrench too. The obvious answer is to get an adjustable crescent wrench (what I have) but it is big and bulky. Besides, I was drilled to only use the proper wrench size and not depend on adjustables. That may have been a bit too extreme for the casual user like myself, but given that this set is not adjustable, I'm not too concerned one way or another.

Sometimes what appear to be cliches either are not what they appear to be or they just work. In the Killing Kind by Chris Holm, I was happy with the strange brew of characters, some of whom appeared to be "types" expected in this kind of book. The basic premise of the book is that the hero, Michael Hendricks, an ex-Afghanistan vet, makes a living by killing killers. He has a wheelchair-bound buddy, Lester, who was in the same black flag unit with him in Afghanistan when his unit was wiped out by an IDE. Michael and his friend learn of people for whom a killing contract has been put out and they find the target and negotiate a big fat fee to knock-off the killer before the target is killed.The happy jumble of characters (and the book's premise) are thrown into a gunny sack with a plot, a wonderfully memorable villain -- hired to kill Michael -- and a couple of FBI agents, and shaken.  Special Agents Charlie Thompson (female) and Henry Garfield (a guy -- not the cat) are the FBI agents that become involved. Charlie suspects that someone (whom she identifies as the 'ghost') is shooting the shooters, but others in the Bureau (including the mildly misogynistic Garfield) aren't buying it, and they want to focus on the more routine kinds of investigations conducted by the FBI.The usual kind of bunk served up with this cast of characters is a clash between the hero and "the girl" who become lovers in the end after they have dispatched any number of villains. The girl's partner becomes bros with the hero, and Lester and Michael now have a solid contact in Federal law enforcement and their business thrives. Ta-da! (Not even close.) The book takes off with encounters between two killers the bad-guy killer and the good guy killer. The FBI gets into the act and the bad guys cannot allow their button men to be dispatched so well and frequently, and pretty soon our hero is up to his neck in adversaries.In any event, I think that you'll enjoy this book, and I hope that the author will send this unlikely hero out on other missions in future publications.

I got this shaver for one reason: trimming my beard. I have one of those beards that takes off like a free-range chicken, growing everywhere very fast. On top of that, grays have entered the mix of facial locks, and so if I don't do something about it, it looks too much like the two-tone British Jacob Sheep whose brown and white fleece are used in making yarn with different natural hues. My scissors just weren't hacking it for controlling my beard, and my ears were in danger of becoming casualties of my shearing efforts.Noting that the Philips Norelco S7720/90 7700 Shaver comes with a trimmer, I got it. The three-rotary head pulls off easily, and you pop on the trimmer in its place. Then you adjust the trimmer to one of five positions, ranging from short to long. It suggest that you start with the long, and pulling downward, trim you beard. So with it in the long position (5) I started a combing downward motion as the instructions said. Before I noticed, I had created a mess of trimmed hair on my chest and in the sink--not much, but enough to let me know it was working. I decided to go a little shorter (4) and after more trimming (more like combing) I got it just the way I wanted.You can use the trimmer without the comb attachment if you want, but the comb acts as a trim-guard that ensures that my beard is at a constant length. Once you have the comb attachment set to the right length you want, you can forget about it. Just pop it on the shaver, and comb downward for a nice near shave.I had not planned on using the three-head rotary that distinguish Norelco shavers, but I needed to shave the high-cheek and neck beard; so I tried it out. It was like there wasn't any blade in it it was so quiet and smooth. So kudos for the shaver too. It comes with a tub to keep the rotary heads nice and clean; so I can use it for cleaning, but the trimmer I'll have to clean with hot water and brush. That's ok since I plan on beard shaving once per week (or when needed) and I can clear it easily enough by hand.So, overall, I like this system, and even though I got it for one thing, beard trimming, I'd recommend it for regular shaving as well.

On a recent trip my wife purchased a number of antique silver earrings for gifts for the many women in our family. A lot of the jewelry today is made from silver-plated metal of unknown origins, and the antique jewelry apparently had the best chance of being genuine silver rather than a mystery metal. So, when I saw the Sterling Silver Twisted Hoop Earrings on Amazon, I thought she might like them.They certainly were as advertised, and not only did they look good on their own, they looked right with her other silver jewelry as well. (When you put inferior silver next to good quality silver, the difference is magnified.) So, everything worked as hoped.The only thing that my wife believed would help would be longer piercing stems. The current stems are relatively short and make the hoops stand out perpendicular to the ears—that may be a style choice by the designer—but my wife preferred ones that would lay flat and horizontal to the ears. Otherwise, they look great. (See picture.)

My wife is the big tea drinker in the family, and I'm a coffee guy who occasionally has tea. First, off, my wife saidTaylors of Harrogate Yorkshire Tea was "knock-it-out-of-the-park" good. She loves tea and is super picky. So that recommendation went a long way with me. When I tried it, I like a medium brewed tea--medium seeped. I let it seep until it had the right tan/brown color and then drank it without any cream, sweetner or anything else. It was just right for my tastes.Second, after the first cup, I decided to see if I could stretch the bag for a second cup, and it worked like a champ. The second cup was identical to the first. (I decided to forego further dunkings lest I appear to be too big a cheapskate. ) Years ago when I was at Cambridge, I came to enjoy the afternoon teas, and I certainly will consider re-instituting that practice with my tea-loving wife!

By and large I enjoyed this book, and as long as you can put up with some of the more banal stereotypes and borrowed imagery I think you will too. The bad guy is a character named "Mongo" and for the life of me, I could not disassociate him from the bad cowboy of the same name who slugged his horse in Mel Brooks' "Blazing Saddles." That aside, Mongo is a shrewd and efficient killer, and the story starts with his murdering a movie star, one Catherine Delure, and her manager. Very creative in that the reader knows the how the murder occurs, and we follow the NYPD detective as he tries to unravel the mystery first in New York City (where the murder takes place) and then in Los Angeles -- in Hollywood and Malibu. The investigation pits NYPD detective Jeb Barker against both the killer and the NYPD bureaucracy. Naturally, Jeb is a mustang (who drives...yes...a Ford Mustang) and even though he is an effective detective, he's always running afoul of the bureaucracy and shooting people who are really, really bad — like a puppy-kicking, parks-in-the-handicap-zone, child molester.As Jeb moves through the investigation, he encounters  Ms. Delure's housekeeper who refers to her late employer as "Miz Delure" sounding not unlike Hattie McDaniel who played "Mammy" in "Gone with the Wind"-- however, the housekeeper has an Eastern European name; imagine a crazed Cloris Leachman playing "Mammy," and you'll see the clashing images that wracked my mind. Later,  the author introduces a butler whose name is "Cedric" — that's about as close to "Jeeves" as you can get! Finally, the hero, Jeb Barker, tells the reader that he doesn't like "rap" music and the clothes the rappers wear--pants falling off and jangling medallions. He likes "country" music. Ok, we get it. The author, James Neal Harvey, is an old white guy. All the hero had to say was that he liked country music, and it is assumed that he doesn't like rap, hip hop and the genre of music favored by the young. (Back in the day, we were assured that listening to Elvis and Little Richard would doom our wretched souls to the deepest corners of hell.) Likewise, had the hero liked rap, we would assume that he did not favor country. Way to go Harvey!  Add to the great American divide.These dumb and lazy stereotypes of the politically correct rednecks aside, The Big Hit is an exciting read, and Harvey is a skilled storyteller. However, it's like having a wonderfully clean and ironed shirt and then smearing mustard all over it for no good reason at all.

Tribest Sedona Combo SD-P9150-B Food Dehydrator looks like a microwave oven, but it is anything but. If you've ever bought dried fruit or jerky, it may have been processed in some kind of food dehydrator like this one. Since I like dried fruit as a healthy snack, the Sedona dehydrator seemed like a good choice. After reading the instructions and making sure that all of the packing material was out of the dehydrator, I gave it a test.It comes with nine mesh trays that you put the food on to be dehydrated and a closed tray to catch any drip along with a debris mat on the bottom. It has an upper and lower dehydrating compartments, and I wanted to begin testing by taking out all of the mesh trays except one to use and place the closed tray in the middle for a drip catcher. Then I planned to use only the upper compartment for the test.I tested it with three fruits: an apple thinly sliced, a banana sliced into three length-wise parts and a mango sliced as thin as I could. (They can be slippery and difficult to slice thinly--even with a sharpened knife.) The instructions that came with the dehydrator suggested that I add a little cinnamon and sugar to the banana as it lost taste when dried. I did the same with the apple slices but left the mango as-is. I set the suggested temperature (in Fahrenheit) to 110 and set it on the RAW mode. The RAW mode keeps the temperature at or below the set temperature while the FAST mode oscillates above and below the set temperature. It suggested checking it at 2, 4 and 8 hours. After 2 hours it was still pretty un-dehydrated, a little more after 3, and at 4 hours I took it out. The banana slices had shrunk considerably and the apple slices were pretty close to dry, but the mango was still very juicy, but drier to the touch. The banana still had moisture and with the cinnamon and sugar tasted like a rich candy.  The apple slices were almost chips but not quite, and the mango slices were like eating mango that didn't drip. The bananas and apples were hard to put down and were gone in short order. The mango was ok, but nothing very special. (A longer drying period was needed.)You have to read the instructions carefully to get everything set the way you want, but on my first try, it went quite smoothly. So, it's about like setting a microwave in terms of complexity.  The operation manual has several good recipes, but online I found hundreds of recipes for drying different kinds of food. One of the surprising practices in food drying is preparatory marinades. They sound really good, but if my experience is any measure, I just took fresh fruit and sliced it up with a little cinnamon and sugar. So if you want simple, it can do that quite well.Perhaps the most important thing about food dehydration I had to learn is the time it takes. Since the Combo Sedona dehydrator looks like a microwave oven, one can easily think that it's working in the same timeframe. It is not. To give you an idea, I want to make dried onion rings. It takes between 18-30 hours of dehydration; so you have to get used to the idea that this device is not for whipping up a quick afternoon snack, unless you plan a day ahead. So Wednesday's snacks should be made on Monday or Tuesday.

I got this set for my two grandsons who love to swim. The problem with children's fins and facemarks is the fit: especially the face mask. The U.S. Divers Youth Flare Jr Silicone Snorkeling Set Fun Blue Large 3-6 was tested by a 6-year old and a 10-year old, and they fit them both just fine. The 6-year old did say that he had a problem getting his face mask to fit right, but after he did, it worked as advertised.The kit comes with the kind of face mask that Jaques Clouseau used in his ocean explorations, and includes both eye coverings and a nose fitting; much more appropriate for snorkeling than the old round ones we used to have. They were guaranteed to leak. What turns out to be one of the best features of this kit is the carrying bag that comes with it. It looks like an oblong backpack with a netting cover so that damp equipment is less likely to mildew or get stinky during storage. It's much easier to manage than the two fins, face mask and snorkel separately. The materials are well crafted and seem to be lasting.Most importantly the kids played in the pool using them and did not want to get out when it was time to leave.

Alliterative titles tend to belong in the children's sections of libraries or in the old serial dramas they used to show in theaters in the 30s and 40s. So the title Sierra Skullduggery --or Sierra Sidewinders, or Sierra Swindlers--it doesn't matter; the author was going for alteration--is only generally related to the story. So why even bother with a western title of this assumptive ilk? First of all, you can find gems in unexpected places. Some of the early noir novels by Charles Willeford were westerns (Deliver me from Dallas!) and so were some of Jim Thompson's novels--(Pop 1280 ).  I'm not a big  Louis L'Amour or Zane Grey fan, but every now and again, I'll read a western for a change of pace.This one involves an ex-gunfighter, ex-confederate soldier turned freight hauler in the area around Placerville, Auburn and Sacramento. (The three towns form a triangle with Sacramento in the west and both Placerville and Auburn in the Sierra foothills.) The ex-rebel is now married and his freight hauling business is running smoothly, and he has put his gunslinger past behind him. However, an evil Yankee captain during the Battle of the Wilderness had gunned down men in his unit after they surrendered and was now available to get shot by some mysterious men who want to hire the hero, Tom Patterson. The bad Yankee captain was a tempting target, but the Union Army had  cashiered the man and thoroughly dishonored him and both sides in the Civil War had committed atrocities (cough-cough-Andersonville) and so Tom figured to leave all the past behind. Then to make matters worse, the mysterious men decided to kidnap his wife to encourage Tom to take the job, and the story is off and running.The story is fun, the wife turns out to be quite self-sufficient and it's characters are well drawn. However, in the middle of the book, while Tom is on the run, he encounters a former slave who is eking out a life as a prospector. The former slave claims, "Had a good life, but damned Yankees had to make me free and ruin it all." The hero is a former rebel and the first black man he meets is wishin' fer dem good ole days when he was a slave. Seriously!!?? This isn't western noir; it's redneck re-write.The rest of the book and story reads like an episode of the old TV Show "Gunsmoke." In fact, the story is pretty good, but it's like introducing a main character as one who is a fervent Nazi and then saying, "otherwise he's a pretty good guy" and ignoring the fact for the rest of the novel. Either Jerry Drake, the author, is wholly clueless and historically blind, and Amazon Encore, who published it never proofread it for idiotic content, but slavery (on the whole) was not viewed  by slaves and former slaves as a decent way to survive.There's an old saw about how to make lead into gold; you heat up the lead and stir it without thinking of the word, "rhinoceros" and soon the lead will turn into gold. That same is true with books: it was hard to finish it without thinking of the word "redneck" or "racist" but that was what happened. The book just wasn't the same after that.

When I first tried a Nutri-Grain Cereal Bar, I cut it in half and gave the other half to my better half. It struck me that the divided bar looked exactly like a Fig Newton. First I tried Apple, and liked it a lot. Next, I tried the Blueberry, and it too was good and tasted blueberry enough to know what it was. Finally, I sampled the Strawberry. It was ok, but it had more a generic sugar-based goo taste than the taste of real strawberries--more like strawberry preserves that (despite best efforts) don't exactly taste much like fresh strawberries either.The bars are wrapped in a generous crust of whole wheat that has a cookie-like flavor--reminded me of oatmeal a bit--not overly sweet.  Again, think "Fig Newton" but in a whole wheat wrapper rather than a Fig Newton one.Next, I pulled out my mobile iPhone app and scanned one of the cereal bars for WeightWatchers information. It came up with 3 points for the whole thing and the following breakdown:Fat: 3g (no trans fat!)Fiber 3gCarbohydrates: 24gProtein 2gFurther information for diabetics indicated 1.5 carb exchanges and .5 fat exchanges. It also shows a stamp from the Whole Grains Council indicating 8 grams of whole wheat per serving. Each bar has 120 calories.Overall, they taste good, and they have a very good after-taste. I like the fact that they're whole grain, and so while clearly not an organic food, they seem very healthy.

First off, let me say that I am not a professional wood-worker or carpenter. However, I have all kinds of things in and around the house that need attention or adjusting where I use power saws--rotary, jigsaw, and chain. Recently, I've been working on fence gates and my deck. In both cases I had to use my jigsaw for cutting off over-long wood screws and replacing bowed or broken planks and dividers in my wood deck.I had recently purchased some Bosch blades for my jigsaw--one set for wood and another for metal. The later I needed for shortening wood screws that protruded in the gate, and cutting through metal with a jigsaw  -- even using a great blade -- is a chore. The saw bucked like a wild bronco and while it finally did the job, it was not fun.As part of the deck maintenance, I bought some extruded aluminum stair edging. I got the six-foot strips that had to be cut in two for my 36-inch steps. This was a perfect test for the Blade Runner because cutting through L-shaped extruded aluminum can be a jolting experience. There was no drama as the provided aluminum cutting blade zipped right through it. (The Blade Runner comes with blades for cutting wood, aluminum, steel, ceramic tile and scrolling.)The BladeRunner is easy to set up, including the guide bars and the miter gauge. Since I had recently bought new Bosch T-shank blades for my jigsaw, I found that I could use the same set for the Blade Runner.  It also comes with a connector for an exhaust hose for blowing out sawdust, but I did not use it since the hose was not included with the saw.It's easy to carry and move, and it's small enough for the relatively narrow workbench I have in the garage. The on-off switch is located in the front right leg housing and is easy to quickly switch on or off. It even has a little saw blade drawer in the front. I don't know how practical it would be for a lot of heavy-duty cutting, but for the kind and amount of cutting I do, it's the perfect table saw.

We have a TV where we also have our exercise equipment. When we walk on the treadmill, we like to watch TV while enduring the costs of healthy exercise. The treadmill is not hugely loud, but it is loud enough that we miss a lot of the audio from a TV program. This Bose CineMate 15 Home Theater Speaker System seemed like a solution to grinding out the walking and being able to hear.We have a big flat-screen Panasonic TV in the exercise room, and the Bose system is designed to re-route the sound from the TV's speakers to the hefty pair Bose provides. The small long speaker goes in front of the TV, and the big woofer (think tower PC, 1995) is placed off to the side. For some reason our Panasonic had none of the audio-out ports for using the connectors provided; basically an RCA pair and a fibre optic connector. (Earlier we had tried to add a wireless headset, but we ran into the same audio-out problem.) So, I had to plug in the speakers to the cable box using the optical connector, and it worked fine.What I was unable to accomplish was to sync the universal remote to the TV via the cable box. Since the speakers go through the cable box, I tried to sync the cable box. In the list of devices provided, Bose includes a list that seems to do a pretty good job of exhausting all of the different devices--including two types of AT&T cable boxes. (And Frontier cable, which took over some of our programming in cahoots with AT&T.) Using the Bose remote, I can turn the speakers on and off, but the TV is completely controlled controlled by the TV remote. Why? We had a nightmarish problem getting the TV and the cable box synched up on our old remote, but as far as I'm concerned, I'm good with a remote for the Bose speakers and one for the TV. For me, it actually simplified things. All I have to do is to use the TV remote to turn on the TV & cable box and then use the Bose remote for turning on the speakers.Ok, so how does it sound? For me, it did not seem to do much for the sound except that I thought that I heard things coming our of the woofer that I didn't realize were being sent from the TV station. Then I realized that I had on both the TV sound and the Bose sound; so I muted the TV and heard the Bose system really for the first time. By switching back and forth, I was able to see that the Bose CineMate 15 Home Theater Speaker System really did make a clear difference.  Getting better sound than what you get from the speakers built into and shipped with a standard TV may not seem like a huge leap since the TV speakers are generally so-so (especially for audiophiles.) However, once you get used to the added sound quality supplied by the Bose system, not a lot of people will ever again be satisfied with their standard TV speakers.One problem I wish they'd fix is that somewhat convoluted way that you have to use to set it up. I wish you could just plug it in without having to mess with the remote or anything else. In fact I wish they'd dump the remote and have the whole thing just play after plugging in the speakers to the TV. The power supply in the speakers could be handled with a simple analog switch--an on/off button with no remote.

I had begun reading this book slowly because of time constraints and other projects, but at some point I could not put it down. It's the kind of book that will make a cross-country flight go by in the flash of a gunshot and keep you up at night. Recently, I had finished an equally fascinating non-fiction book, and often after reading a well-written book, whatever comes next pales by comparison. Not this one.Sometimes best-selling authors get into a hackneyed, predictable style, but "Woman With a Gun" by Phillip Margolin reflects a master storyteller at the top of his game. If you like the classic whodunit mysteries, this one will knock your socks off, but I tend to favor more the novel noir of the Jim Thompson and Charles Willeford genre. This novel has a touch of both--keeps you guessing and is populated by flawed and interesting characters.A literary and cinematic effect of late are ones that jump around timeframes. Such an effect can be disconcerting or add interest. This book jumps between current day (2015) and 10 years ago (2005). It starts with an eager beaver wannabe novelist in NYC who sees a photo of a woman with her back to the camera holding a gun in a wedding dress at a MMoMA exhibit. She is so taken with the photo, she plans to write a novel based on the photo. It turns out that the photo was taken of a woman shortly after her husband was murdered on their wedding night in 2005. Then the story shifts to 2005 and the investigation of the homicide in a little Oregon town south of Portland. So, while starting with 2015, the first half of the book involves the people and characters during the original homicide and its investigation in 2005. Then the second after picks where it started with the budding novelists leaving NYC and traveling the Oregon to research the original homicide to get background and ideas for her novel based on the woman with the gun.The characters are well-drawn, the plot is a hoot and even the romances are believable and add spice to the story. However, it is not Portlandia, but more of a love affair with small seaside towns on the Oregon coast and the city of Portland. So while many of the characters are dark, conflicted and interesting, the setting are not.A major clue is in the photograph on the cover, but don't try to figure it out. It's subtle but there.

Fire and Movement: The British Expeditionary Force and the Campaign of 1914 by Peter Hart chronicles the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) for the last four and a half months of 1914. Made up of only four infantry divisions (organized into two corps) and a calvary division, the BEF was minuscule (around 80,000) compared to the giant armies of both the French and Germans numbering in the millions. Much of the British thinking about war was based on the Boer Wars ending in 1902 with a British victory. In fact, the Second Boer War is considered by some as the first total war where the British crushed the Boers (Dutch Afrikaners). Field Marshall John French, who had distinguished himself as the commander of a calvary division in the Boer War was appointed to lead the BEF in France and Lord Kitchener as Secretary of State for War, given overall responsibility for the army.The first major  BEF action in 1914 was the Battle of Mons, where the British have been characterized as mowing down legions of German troops, despite being hopelessly outnumbered. After their heroic stand, they are finally forced to retreat because of terrible losses due to overwhelming odds. In addition, the French have skedaddled and left their right flank hanging in the air. We learn from Hart that the French had informed the British of their withdrawal; the problem lay in the BEF's hopelessly incompetent staff organization and their inability to communicate information. While it is true that the Germans lost about 2,000 troops to the British, 1,600, the Germans were attacking machine guns, relatively accurate rifle fire and artillery. (Some reports claim a 10-1 British-German loss ratio, which do not jive with the best available facts.)  After the initial German victories, the Allies retreat, and the BEF ends up all the way south and east of Paris. One problem that Hart points out is that the British are not very good at retreating because their entire military philosophy is based on "offensive thinking." They muddle through the retreat suffering heavy losses in killed, wounded and captured, but the BEF no longer is the same BEF that came to the continent. The BEF commander, John French realizes that he cannot use the dashing calvary advances (least of all a charge) so loved by dim-witted calvary officers, and he proves to be equally inept at either organizing a competent staff or using a good staff organization to run a modern army. Hart points out that the long British habit of blaming the French for their own failures does not hold true, and even worse, the British often celebrate failure (such as the retreat to Paris) as a virtue.Throughout the book, Hart again and again debunks history of the BEF based on a one-sided view, and gives the French full credit for beating off the German advances. At the same time, he gives the BEF full credit where due as well, such as holding off the Germans in the First Battle of Ypres, and the very real adaptations the British made in light of their experiences in 1914.Hart is not a Monday-morning quarterback by any stretch of the imagination. Instead, he takes a detached view of the events, gathers volumes of evidence and goes about showing the reader how decisions were made. No one going into WWI knew how it would play out. The Germans seemed to have had the best idea and be the best prepared. For example, their trench mortars and hand grenades were very effective for the trench warfare that quickly developed. The British improvised, but in 1914, at least, they had no such weapons except those the soldiers improvised themselves.The book is a carefully woven quilt told through the eyes of the soldiers, their leaders and the staff on both sides. Using letters, journals, written commands and diaries, Hart both illustrates and explains what it was like to be a British soldier in the conditions of attack, retreat, and stuck in the trenches in Flanders in and around Ypres. You also get to see the German soldier's view who fought against the British. They believed that the BEF had been well-trained in aimed shots in quick succession using their Lee Enfield rifles. That was true, but I did not get the impression that Hart believed the training in actually hitting a target was important as was rapid fire the BEF soldiers had mastered. One of the stranger episodes related by the author is the use of the Royal Naval Division concocted by Winston Churchill. Navy reservists were gathered together to act as temporary infantry and sent to Antwerp to keep it out of German hands. They were given guns and brief instruction on how to load and fire them. One night an old white cow was lazily grazing in no man's land and the RND, thinking it was the Germans, blasted away at the cow, and after thousands of shots, the cow wandered off without a scratch. Perhaps the practice devoted to aimed fire actually had more impact than realized. (Most of the RND either ended up in POW camps or interred in Holland. Relatively few were wounded, but the author notes that Churchill's overweening confidence in his grasp of military strategy would lead to other doomed missions later in the war--Gallipoli in particular.)Overall, Hart's work is the best I've seen depicting and explaining not only the role of the BEF in 1914 but doing so in a book that was hard to put down. He corrects many of the popular misconceptions, the "Miracle on the Marne" being one. He gives French General Joffre full credit for realizing the mistake the Germans make in opening a flank and skillfully exports that opening by shifting French troops from the east to west. The Germans are forced all the way back to the Ainse. So, far from being a "miracle," it is simply excellent application of sound military principles employed by Joffre. The BEF happened to be available to help exploit a gap between German armies, and this they do with what had been considered a beaten army. Quickly, the stalemate on the Ainse line gives rise to the opportunity to attack the other's western flank, which each side attempts to do, leading to the misnamed "race to the sea."By the end of the year, opposing forces are facing one another in positions that will be little changed by 1918 when the war ends. The BEF is in Flanders supporting the Belgian army on their left and the French army on their right. A new model army being forged by Kitchener is still in the making and won't be available until the next year.A set of 12 maps is spread throughout the book and are essential for following the ebb and flow of the ever-changing battlefield during 1914. The BEF begins near the Maubeuge fortress behind the Meuse, based on  a 1920 Ordnance Survey map and ends up near Ypres in December 1914 shown on a 1924 Ordinance Survey map. Other Ordinance Survey maps used are from 1932  and 1923. As an aside, I also used other maps of the 1914 battles and kept seeing "BEF: French." That makes it look like the BEF is part of a French army, but "French" is simply the name of the BEF commander.Also, a 16-page set of B & W photographs accompany the book. Hart's description of the clay mud in Flanders is so accurate that when you look at the photographs of the 1st Cameronians in the trenches at Houplines and the 11th Hussars in the trenches at Zillebeke (in Ypres area) they show exactly what Hart describes in their damp misery. The flatness of the terrain in Flanders shows why the troops (and officers) were forced to dig holes in the mud and muck to protect themselves from artillery and machine gun fire.

I got this for my new HP Envy with Windows 8.1 and a touch-screen. Without much trouble I was able to quickly move my finger along the screen to create a drawing. However, after a short while, I found I could no more make a decent shape with my finger than I could in the first grade where we had actual finger paint. I could not use the French curve or other tools for drawing aids with my finger. I imagine that most artists have some kind of drawing pad and stylus, and so I loaded up SketchBook Pro 7 on my iMac and used the wireless mouse as a drawing tool. Immediate improvement. All of the tools worked fine--different brushes, pens, pencil as well as the ellipse and straight ruler, French curve and all other tools.The tools are arrayed in an odd sort of collection. There's the "lagoon" in the lower left corder where a quarter circle has the icons for interface controls, tools | views,  brushes, colors, edit and files. When you click the icon, a circle of icon selections appear and you drag the mouse from the center to the icon you want. This was very difficult to do with a touch screen, but simple for a mouse and I imagine a stylus. You can place another menu bar across the top that has similar controls as the lagoon. It's a lot easier for me to use, and if it gets in the way of the drawing, it can be removed and you still have the lagoon.Since almost all of my artwork is for the web, I was interested in getting the hexadecimal values for the colors. That was the only thing they did not have (or have it so well hidden I could not find it.) The color menu (on the Mac) has 5 different color mixing/choosing options from a color sphere with an adjacent slide bar to a box of crayons. The color slider shows the RGB colors in decimal values, and they can work for specifying text and object colors using the format rgb(220,20,60) or if HSL (HSB) hsl(348, 83%, 58%) coding. (Would it kill them to have the hex value too?) Anyway, just about everything I want to do with color is available. This include a Copic color menu with icons that when selected show the complimentary color (great idea!) and two "color pucks," of fill and stroke colors. The fill  (color) puck will display a wheel and square color selector if you hold down the mouse on it.As a non-artist, I really felt that I could do more with this tool for free-hand drawing than with any other drawing tool I've used. I've seen what artists can do with this tool, and it's amazing. It seems to have been designed with artists in mind and not dabblers like myself. If they'd only package an artist with SketchBook, I'd be over the moon!

A while back I saw a story on TV about a guy who went into the baggage claim areas in airports, selected a bag and walked off with it. The security camera showed the thief selecting black canvas covered bags that looked like most of the other bags that came down the bag carrel. The theft-prevention expert explained that luggage selected by thieves was generally those kinds of bags that would not cause second-notice by anyone else who had a similar bag. So if someone walked right by you with your stolen luggage, you wouldn't notice until it showed up missing. Even then, you'd probably think that the airlines lost it, and if you did report it lost or "missing," it's unlikely you'd think it stolen.So, when I saw the Double Dutch Club Safari Ride 20 Inch Hardside, Elephants, I knew that it was not a bag any thief would dream of stealing. First of all, it is unique, and if I saw another in an airport, I'd know it was mine. Second, it looks like something a 9-year old girl would load up with clothes and kid-stuff that isn't worth stealing. Finally, it has a hard side that I can use either for carry-on or checked. I like the hard shell bags since they give better protection so that a bottle of after-shave gets broken it won't give the rest of your clothes an over-colonged aroma. The wheel arrangement is the kind I like too. The bag can be turned sideways to easily move down the aisle. It has sufficient room inside and a little bag for cosmetics (candy-flavored lipstick?) and what-not.Finally, the pièce de résistance is the pink cover that comes with the bag that acts as a bag cover--the design looks like the logo on a college sweatshirt. So the combination appears to be an irresistible combination of girly-girl design armed with it's own wardrobe, exposing the little elephant design underneath.So, instead of smirking at this bag--embrace it. It's very practical, well-designed, and has little elephants that even Democrats cannot resist.

All of my photo devices are now digital, and I needed something to print out photos.  The Epson Expression Premium XP-620 Wireless Color Photo Printer with Scanner works very well to print out these photos, and while it has several other uses (printer, scanner, etc.), I got it for and use it for printing our photos. (I have a laser printer for written documents that require printing.)At the outset let me say that once it's set up, it works fine with a wireless connection. However, it took me almost half a day to set it up. The instructions look very simple with big numbers showing the steps. I made it to Step 2 before I got stuck. The control panel on the front is used to configure the printer, and following the steps I selected what I thought were the correct configuration steps. When I got to the end, it would not let me configure it. So I turned it off, and when I turned it back on, it let me finish the configuration. Following the installation of the 5 ink cartridges that come with the printer, which you need to be careful to collect all 5 when unpacking. (Treat these carefully; a replacement set runs $40 on Amazon).  I loaded standard 8.5 x 11 paper I use with my laster printer. It was a bit awkward because Inside the printer tray is a "cassette tray" for smaller size paper  used with different photo sizes for frames.I skipped Step 5 to connect to a Fax line, and went to Step 6 to install the software on my Mac with the latest OS X. It turns out that the CD that comes with the printer doesn't work with OS X. (C'mon!--the instructions are printed in French on the other side! The French love Macs!) You're instructed to go to a URL to download the drivers for the Mac. Ok, I can deal with that, but once I arrived at the site, I got a list with every printer driver Epson makes; which is close to 2 billion. (Maybe a little less.) Why not have a picture of the printer with the linked type, a single button that says, OS X drivers? Anyway, after fishing for the correct drivers, I downloaded and installed them all.Then, I went to the control panel, made the WiFi link to my ISP and tinkered some more with the control panel. I still don't know if everything was done correctly in the control panel because they seemed to be out of sync with the instructions (such as they were) and configured it for my WiFi and planned use of the printer. I also configured the driver on my iMac, which was pretty simple.I opened up a photo file (.jpg) and re-sized it in Adobe Fireworks, and printed it over the wireless connection. It worked perfectly. You have to pull out the feeder tray when printing, but that's ok with me. It was simple and it worked.Not leaving well enough alone, I noticed a section called "Mobile printing" on the instructions for iOS/Android. So I scanned the coded image, and my phone loaded up the Epson app for printing. It was easy to get to the printing part and selecting the print and the printer, but I could not get it to print. Easy to set up but not too easy to use. Eventually, I got it to do what I wanted but I should not have to arm wrestle the software.There's always been a software lag behind hardware, and some manufacturers just don't pay that much attention to the software. On a scale of 1 to 5, the printer is an engineering marvel is definitely a "5", but the software is only a "1." In a day and age where printers are making less and less sense with image display and distribution handled (in full color) using PDF files, you need a good reason to even consider a printer. The scanners are handy for taking old printed materials and digitizing them for Internet distribution and overhead display, but fewer uses are justified for a printer; especially one with awkward UI/UX. What you get for $100 is an amazing piece of multi-function hardware, but three refills of the printer ink exceeds the original hardware price.We are approaching a time when managers who insist on paper copies of anything other than meeting agendas, are considered not only wasteful but Luddites or Neanderthals to boot. I like the ability to use this printer for printing pictures for personal use and sharing with the shrinking number of friends and relatives who are not part of the Internet. The scanner helps to make documents available for  Internet sharing, but the software makes it such a chore to operate the brilliant hardware design that it is less and less worth the bother. I implore Epson to incorporate user-testing and work with HCI/UX developers. Otherwise, there may be even fewer people who are willing to plunk down $100 for the machine and $40 for the ink refills.

For years now I've used Sennheiser headsets, and I much prefer their over-the-ear headphones to anything in-the-ear. They're a bit hefty, but they work fine. Their cords are rather long, but that's not a big problem and they have the advantage of being able to plug in just about anywhere and reach me. However, when I use them to go on a walk the cord has to be wrapped up and tied.In trying out the AmazonBasics On-Ear Headphones, I was mainly concerned with their sound quality compared to my Sennheisers. They are (much) lighter, the headphones are smaller,  they can be twisted flat for easier storage or toting in the black bag that comes with the headphones, and they cost about $7 less than my Sennheisers. Two things that struck me about these AmazonBasics is their sound quality and comfort. On taking them for a walk plugged into my iPhone, it was like not having any headset on at all. That's how light and comfortable they are.These do not have the sound quality of the Bose QuietComfort 15 Acoustic Noise Cancelling Headphones, but they cost about $285 less than the Bose. I did not believe that you could get a decent set of headphones for $15, but you can. At that price I can get one for home and one for the office. These are truly a member of the elusive group of products known as a  "good deal."

This book is an easy one to read and come away wringing your hands about the Bush-Obama policies in "America's longest war." The quote, "As the result of two successful campaigns, of the employment of an enormous force, and of the expenditures of large sums of money," the secretary of state observed, "all that has yet been accomplished has been the disintegration of the State . . . and a condition of anarchy throughout the remainder of the country" , nicely sums up the current situation. That statement was not uttered by Condoleezza Rice or Hillary Clinton or John Kerry, but instead by Spencer Cavendish, Marquis of Hartington, the British secretary of state for India in 1880. I have no doubt that in 1989, the Soviet foreign secretary harbored similar sentiments, and the American public today certainly would not disagree."One Million Steps," however, is from the worm's eye view of war boiled down to the platoon and squad level. Bing West, a former Marine grunt from the Vietnam War era examines both the context of the war and the consequences of the different policies and leaders. He takes a tiny section of Helmand Providence not far from the Pakistan border in southern Afghanistan. West chose the unit he did because the Marine of the 3/5 had the highest casualty rate of any fighting unit in Afghanistan.  Ideally, the Marines would like to have a war with clear objectives, no civilians to get in the way and the right support in terms of weapons and supplies. (Iwo Jima springs to mind.) Of these, the Marines only had the last one--weapons and supplies.Objectives were divided between battle and "nation building," but the 3/5 focused on battle. Their job was to fight the Taliban and win the hearts and minds of the Afghans living in the area. Most were farmers growing poppies for opium, alternating with corn for food. (The opium tar brought in four-fold the income that corn does.) The Bush administration decided that we didn't need another War on Drugs to lose; so the policy was to leave the poppy and marijuana fields alone. However, in Taliban areas, the opium trade was their main source of income, and while the Marines could not destroy the poppy crops (policy-wise), they could make the Taliban pay dearly for it. And that's exactly what they did.The entire action centers around farmland next to the Helmand River where the Marines are on daily patrols to confront and kill Taliban. The main destructive weapon used by the Taliban is the IED, clay jugs of explosives set off by trip wires and wooden pressure plates connected to small batteries. The clay jugs and wooden pressure plates are invisible to mine detectors. Often, when one would go off injuring or killing a Marine, the taliban (part-time taliban) and Taliban (the pros) would attempt to surround and kill the Marine patrol. Generally, the tactic did not work because of superior tactics, training, firepower and organization of the Marines, and several Taliban would be wounded or killed.After patrol experience showed that Marine snipers attached to the patrol were more successful at killing Taliban, they became a regular part of the patrols. To counter this tactic, the Taliban would set up further away from the Marines so that they would not be picked off by snipers and kept their heads down until the Marines were close enough to be hit by machine gun, mortar or PRG fire. This is the exact opposite of Giap's tactic of "fighting close to the belt" so that the Americans could not use their superior fire power to bomb or shell the NVA. That's exactly what the Marines did; they'd call in a 60mm mortar attack, helicopters and the converted cargo planes bristling with guns -- canons, mini-guns and rockets. In addition an F-16 could be called upon to drop 500 lb bombs on Taliban positions. The air support also acted as aerial intelligence--they were able to radio the Taliban positions along with a high tech blimp that was downlinked to portable computers. The daily aggressive patrolling effectively kept the Taliban at bay, but as everyone on both sides knew, the Marines would be going home, and the Taliban would still be there.As a book on small unit tactics and experiences in Afghanistan, I've not seen the equal to this. Bing West does all he can to divorce what the average grunt must do to achieve his military and warrior goals from the larger political and humanitarian goals--and that of "nation-building." At one time the Marines had to pass a request for artillery support through an attorney--this included the company's mortars--before a fire mission. So on many levels, this book could have been insanely frustrating, but instead West brings it together around the role of the "warrior" in the Marine Corps--their culture and history. So no matter what you may think of the policies of "America's longest" (and expensive!) war, the Marines are doing what they've alway been doing in their long and storied history: aggressively fighting enemies, and despite losses and setback, they do it well.

I tested the Linksys USB 3.0 Ethernet Adapter on a brand-new HP Envy running Windows 8.1. The installation using the enclosed CD worked easily. I plugged in the Adapter to a USB 3 port and ran a speed test provided by my ISP, AT&T. The speed showed:Down: 18.11 MbpsUp: 1.93 MbpsThen I shut down the computer, unplugged the adapter and restarted it. This time I connected into it to my wireless provided by the same ISP. This time I got:Down: 11.34 MbpsUp: 1.95 MbpsA governor of some sort keeps the upload speed to around 2 Mbps; so that was not expected to change. However, the speed with the adapter was an improvement of about 38% over the wireless. Obviously, if your computer has an ethernet connection built in, the adapter isn't going to be a big help. Further my old MacBook Pro yanked a speed of 23 Mbps from the same wireless, which was faster than the wired or wireless on the Envy. So, the speed is not only determined by the speed of the connected service, it's also determined by the computer you're using. Be that as it may, newer, lighter laptops may only provide narrow USB3 connections, and if you want a wired high speed port you're out of luck unless you have an adaptor than can slip into a USB3 port and make the wired connection. This product was shown to do the trick.As a side note, Linksys needs to do a much better job with the software needed to download in cases where the computer has no built-in or external CD drive. I went to their Web site to download the driver needed, but I was unable to do so because their site was so convoluted. It was easy enough to find the Linksys USB 3.0 Ethernet Adapter on the site, but when I attempted to download the driver for the adapter, I could not do so. HCI and UX are not options! They are necessities.

I really wished I had liked these better, but while nice and coconutty, they were a bit oily for my taste. I have a great deal of respect for products with the Fair Trade mark, which means that children aren't exploited in the agriculture work with the coconuts. It's also USDA 100% organic and non-GMO (Genetically Modified Organisms); so with full confidence that I won't be poisoned by chemical insecticides, grow a tail due to unknown genetic modification, or exploit a child in Borneo (or wherever...)I was fully ready to have a nice 60 calorie  treat. They're about the size of a piece of candy from a Whitman's Sampler, and if you're a Weight Watcher, they have a 2 point calculated value.The main ingredient is organic tapioca syrup, followed by two coconut ingredients and includes hemp seed and chia seeds. However, my taste buds focused on the coconut tastes which came through but only mildly so. Taken together, I got a slight coconut gum ball with an oily texture and only a little taste. A regular piece of coconut right out of the shell is more tasteful.Overall, while I applaud Nutiva's dedication to providing food that won't kills us or pay starvation wages to agriculture workers, I just wished it tasted better.

I love color, but I usually use hexadecimal values in putting together color schemes for display on a Web site. The computing part I understand. The Datacolor SCK200 SpyderCHECKR 24 is a big step in the direction toward professional color use, and it is designed for photographers, of which I count myself among the enthusiastic amateurs. So getting this is a step in getting better pictures beyond what I can do with Photoshop Elements on "automatic fix."The quality of the colors on the board are brilliantly displayed, and I was careful not to smudge any. First, I created a DIY light box for placing the CHECKR 24 in for taking a test photo. Next, using a GoPro still and an iPhone 4S still, I took a picture of the 24-square color board. I used diffused light from the top and both sides with ambient light in the front where I had placed the camera. Then, I downloaded the Datacolor software, and using a magnifying glass to make sure that I copied them correctly, I entered the serial numbers. (It turns out that if you leave in the dashes, the software does recognize the black-on-silver numbers-- that are easy for superman and others with X-ray vision to make out. Note to Datacolor: Make the serial numbers bigger and more readable like the 8 digits below the serial number.)Once the software was downloaded and installed, all I had to do was to drag in the photos (that I had imported to my computer), and it automatically created a preset for me. When you drag in the photo of the color card, you might find that you have to do some horizontal and/or vertical flips in your prep software. (I used Adobe Fireworks.) Then you drag the sides so that the color in the little squares correspond to the color in the squares in the photo--pretty easy once your realize that you don't drag the tabs but the sides. Since the software knows that the colors should match, it can set up the presets that you can load into Adobe Lightroom (which I used) or Photoshop or even Photoshop Elements or some other software photographers use for getting color and lighting right.I used a Mac with OS X Mavericks, and I was unable to locate where the presets were stored. The path supplied by the software went into oblivion. However, since I saved the presets as Lightroom settings, when I opened Lightroom, I was able to find them under User Presets. In this way I could load the presets up with the photo of the color squares synched to the presets the SpyderCheckr software used when I dragged the digital file into SpyderCheckr. Of course the real test comes you use the same camera with the same lighting conditions and take a picture of something else in the same light box (or tent). The presets should make adjustments to your photo so that the colors are just right.Any good photographer (including a striving amateur) knows that the right lighting makes the right photograph. However, you can't always get good lighting or the right lighting. However, using Datacolor and SpyderCheckr and programs like Photoshop and Lightroom, you can make huge improvements. As more and more amateurs click away with their digital mobile devices, more and more images are going to be from these sources. Professional photographers are clearly a different breed and know the importance of using the kind of adjustments that are afforded by Datacolor SCK200 SpyderCHECKR 24. However, the same products are also a big help to us lesser lights who keep trying to improve our digital photos.

This book gets off the ground quickly, but at times it got into a briar patch of characters with names American readers may find complexing. However, for a serial killer novel, this one takes a unique turn. It asks, in effect, is torture in battle is justified? For example, if torture will save the life of a kidnapped child or defuse a dirty bomb set for a nuclear detonation -- is it justified?Some American readers may be put off by what appears to be anti-Americanism; but it really is not. There are stereotypes and date mistakes (for example working for Macintosh (Apple) in 1978 when the Mac didn't debut until 1984. In '78, the Apple II was just getting off the ground.) The musing of "How  does America generate so many serial killers?" is just plain dumb. As a country of 300 million, the US has its proportion of nut jobs just as does Sweden and the rest of the world. (Sweden's population of 8 million requires very few such killers to equal that of the US.)There's good humor as Americans mis-pronounce Swedish names, but Swedes probably do the same with American names; so enjoy a view of Americans from the perspective of another country.The killer (Kentucky Killer) is narrowed down early as having something to do with a special "torture group" that Nixon set up during Vietnam, but we know from POW reports that the North Vietnamese were not exactly operating under the rules of the Geneva Convention. However, we're supposed to be the good guys, and when we're not, we hear it loudly from those who expect more of us. The killer goes to Sweden, and so we're invited along on the investigation. In some places, I wondered whether the author was padding the story, but overall, it trudged along to a very vivid and surprising ending.

My workbench is organized with power tools, wrenches, screwdriver sets, plus various and sundry saws, hammers, sanders and pliers. However, there are more times than I can count that I've needed a good pair of scissors. Try cutting sandpaper with pliers or a box cutter. They need to be heavy duty, durable and (in my case) fit into my multi-holed tool-holder. Scotts 18982 Miracle-Gro Titanium 8-Inch Detachable Shear (to me they're just hefty scissors) have been tested on blister packs, sandpaper (used on painted surfaces) and cardboard boxes. It goes through them like a knife through warm butter.Several other happy consequences have come from having my own shop scissors. I don't have to use the ones in the kitchen junk drawer, I don't have to run all over the house looking for scissors or getting into my wife's sewing tools. Given that they're a Miracle-Gro branded tool, they were probably designed for garden and flower work. Maybe so, but they're not leaving my workbench.

I am a flosser, and I don't like it. Every evening I pull out my waxed floss and go to town on my pearly whites. This is not something I relish, but I need to save all my teeth. So, when I saw the Waterpik Cordless Professional Water Flosser, I jumped at it. (Honestly, I could care less about the Nano Sonic Toothbrush that comes with it, but more on that later.) Following the instructions I charged it, filled up the water reservoir with luke warm water and started Niagara Falls in my mouth to the sink. You're supposed to hold the Flosser at a 90 degree angle so that the water flosser head is at the correct angle with your gums, but if you do that, there's no way that the torrent of water coming out of your mouth is not going to dribble all over the Water Flosser and your arm (I don't care what the picture shows of the correct use of the Flosser; in the real world, your arm and the Water Flosser are going to be drenched.) Then, just when you're getting used to the idea, it runs out of water and ends water flossing. Its water capacity is described as "45 seconds." That's right on the button. You get drenched for 45 seconds at a throw.Initially, I was thinking 1 Star with the tag line borrowed from Hobbes "... solitary, poore, nasty, brutish, and short." However, I so detest the necessity of string flossing, that I kept testing up. Knowing well in advance that I was in for 45 second of arm-drenching, I concentrated on the most sensitive areas in the back of my mouth. First of all, it blasted out food particles; which is its primary job. Second, it felt sooooo good on my gums that I didn't want it to quit. A gum massage compared to the assault by my string floss.As for the charging, I had no problems. After an hour's charge, I flipped the "intensity" switch to II (2) and blasted away for 45 seconds. I don't know how many times I could have done that before the charge failed, but since I have to stop every 45 seconds to refill it with water, I have the patience for only a few refills. They suggest starting with the lower intensity I (1), but that didn't seem to do very much at all. Don't waste your time on I; go to II and while you don't get the fire hose blast that some prefer, you get enough water jet speed to knock out hidden food particles between your teeth.Now about the Nano Sonic Toothbrush that comes with the flosser: It's small and handy; perfect for travel. Up until now, I've never taken my electric toothbrush with me on trips. I just leave it in the charger at home. The Nano Sonic Toothbrush runs on a single AAA battery and fits nicely in my shaving kit. My other electric toothbrush comes with a big travel carrier, but it's too big and bulky. So up until now, I just use a standard hand powered toothbrush on trips. Now, however, I take along the Nano Sonic Toothbrush.The system comes with four flossing heads; two standard, one with bristles, and one with a fine stream attachment. There is a single detachable brush for the Nano Sonic Toothbrush.

We were having company when these arrived, and so we had ditched all of the well-used dish towels that decorate our kitchen and substituted these. Talk about putting on the dog! The color orange is a lighter-tinted burnt orange--rich and sturdy. (Not orange-is-the-new-black orange used for time in stir or trash pick-up for community service.) The brown-gray accent stripe is just the right complementary color with these towels. Growing up we used to call these tea towels, "guest towels"  and my mother stored these in some unknown corner of the linen closet where she brought them out only when we had guests.Using these towels as kitchen towels may sound barbaric, but I realized that most of the dish towel use in our kitchen was drying our hands--not dishes. With really nice towels like these, we add a joie de vivre to a corner of our everyday lives. Somehow they didn't seem right for everyday bathroom hand towels (Canon towels have that job already taken), but their rich bright presence in the kitchen where we spend a lot of time lit up the place. So instead of occupying a dark corner of our linen closet, these towels add a welcoming warmth of our kitchen. (Rougher dish drying  duties are relegated to our more proletarian dish towels that lurk in a less prominent corner.)Now here's the best part: they can be laundered in your washing machine. You don't have to pay a bundle to have them dry cleaned (which strikes me a pretty creepy for towels that may come into contact with our China), but you can wash them with using delicate setting on the family washer. So, for a little over 40 bucks, you get two towels that make you feel special every day, impress your guests who wanter into the kitchen and provide a needed function in your kitchen.
