When I got the Belkin Car Charge and Navigation Mount it was for a hands-free talk for an iPhone 5S. However, it turned out to be more. First of all I tried it in three different models of cars in three different years; a 2000 Infiniti G model, a 2006 E350 Mercedes-Benz, and a 2011 GLK 350  Mercedes-Benz, and it was functional in all. It was a little wobbly in the Infiniti, but it worked fine both as holder and charger. The two Mercedes had build-in GPS systems but the Infiniti did not, and the driver of the Infiniti used her iPhone 5S for GPS. So we took it out for a test, and the GPS voice was loud and clear and so too was the GPS map (more features of the phone's GPS apps than the mount). However, the last thing a driver should do is to look down at a moving GPS image held firmly below the driver's line of view unless fully stopped. As it turned out, the driver never looked down, but listened to the GPS instructions to get to her destination. A phone call test was also made and it held the phone while the driver talked without taking her eyes off the road.Getting the mount into the car's cigarette lighter was simple enough for the E350 and Infiniti, but the GLK's lighter is in a little box with a sliding wooden top. It is very low on the panel, and I wasn't sure whether it would fit or not. It did. Getting the iPhone onto the mount was very easy only IF you remove the case. (In the test, the case was an Otterbox Defender, which is medium bulky--more than the Commuter and less than the Armor models.) As a general admonition, if you have a case around your iPhone, plan on removing it for use in this mount.While the mount fits pretty snugly in the two test Mercedes, the wobbliness of its hold in the 2000 Infiniti is not a necessarily bad thing. Easy enough to tap a single phone call, but not a very good platform for text messaging while driving. So, I would judge any text messaging difficulty in an automobile mount a positive feature. Of course, while being guided by GPS or chatting away with a friend while paying attention to driving with both hands on the wheel, your unit is charging. A fully charged phone, especially in case of an emergency, is a very good thing.The grip for the phone can rotate from horizontal to vertical, and that's most important to keep the phone from blocking access to any of the other switches on the car you need--like seat warmers switches. You can also adjust it for making one-touch phone calls, and selecting music. However, most of the selections you should make should only be single-taps, and not browsing through what tune to play next. (For those of you who are unaware, distracted driving accounts for more fatal accidents than drunks now; largely due to smartphone use.) So set it on playlist or your favorite Pandora mix before you start and don't change it until you've stopped. The clamp mount makes that pretty easy.

For years my wife has had a combination of body and hand lotions, and I've always associated the various feminine preparations with the general realm of beauty products. Nivea Cocoa Butter Body Lotion is subtitled--"Intensively Hydrates Skin" and that's what I needed. With age (and yard work) I found that my skin (especially hands) were getting dried out and beginning to crack. So getting a skin hydrator seemed like a good idea.So I plunked it down on my desk and started using it. Every now and then my wife would pop in and pump some on her hands too; so it became a family hydrator. After having used it for several weeks, it seems to work. At my age I don't think I'll suddenly have pretty skin, but at least I want it to reduce the drying out, and it seems to do that ok.In looking at the ingredients, Cocoa Butter, is listed as Ingredient #12. Actually, #12 is listed as Theobroma Cacao (Cocoa) Seed Butter. Since ingredients are listed in order of proportion of the product, the other ingredients are some kind of "helpers" to create the lotion. The first three ingredients are Water, Glycerin and Isohexadecane. That third one was new to me so I looked it up and found:  Isohexadecane is a high purity, iso-paraffin emollient and solvent used in cosmetics and beauty products.More importantly, it was found to be safe for your skin.  Likewise, the other "helpers" that make up the Nivea Cocoa Butter are included as part of the lotion delivery system, added moisturizers or perfumes.It's recommended for Dry to Very Dry Skin, and it contains Vitamin E. In a light to rich scale, it is right in the middle, which probably is a tad lighter than I need, but it still works ok. It just requires more use than would be required by a somewhat richer lotion.

For years I used Pelikan ink, and while it has a rich mark on paper, it was a tad thick. As a result, I'd have to clean my pens frequently to open up the ink flow. After I got a new Waterman pen, I decided to try Waterman ink, and while not as thick as Pelikan, it does not have a weaker mark on paper. It definitely does not jam up as easily. Any ink is going to stop up a fountain pen when it dries up, but with thicker inking components, it happens more often and leaves a bigger chore.I also tried the Waterman with a Japanese Pilot Fountain Pen. The Pilot is a wonderfully operating pen with a thick nib and the Waterman ink flowed quite well without overflowing and leaving a Rorschach test  on the paper. (The flaw with the Pilot is that the cap and body have a sharp divide.)Without sounding too much like a commercial for Amazon, finding Blue/Black in can be a challenge. If you can find ink in a store at all, it is likely to be blue or black, and if you want Blue-Black, you'll have to buy a bottle of blue and black and mix them. However, Amazon does have Waterman Blue/Black. (I did manage to find Mysterious Blue Ink [Encre Bleu Mystére] by Waterman when looking for Blue/Black, and it's pretty close.) It's a lot easier just to get it from Amazon.

Graphic artists who insist on using absolute values for their Web page designs drive me nuts. Static size elements in a design inevitably come to a bad end--on smaller screens, half the page is missing and on larger screens, the design sits in the middle of the display like a postage stamp in the middle of a white wall. (On certain size screens, their designs are beautiful, though--and I'm sure that more than a few artists are miffed by the fact that the world does not agree on one screen size so that their designs can be appreciated.) This was before mobile computing with smartphones and tablets. With the exponential growth of mobile computing devices, all graphic design for the Web is now "responsive web design"--or at least it should be. Clarissa Peterson sets out to introduce beginner's on how to get started in responsive design.In reading Peterson's book, I'm reminded of Jennifer Tidwell's admonition to Web page builders—  It's not about you!Many designers and developers somehow think that their creations should be appreciated as graphic or software design exemplars and not a useful tool for the user. Responsive web design responds to the users device; so, designers should get the idea right away that their designs must conform to a diverse technological environments and not some ideal canvas dimensioned for their creations.Given my own background as a programmer I've migrated to PHP sniffer programs for determining user agents (devices) and grouping content into phone, tablet and desktop sizes. I've  come to depend on jQuery Mobile for creating sites for non-desktop displays. So while I'm not a designer, I've a good deal of experience dealing with the issues that Peterson tackles. I've just considered the issues from a different angle.For a beginning Web designer, I think that Clarissa Peterson has hit the designer sweet spot. She has set her focus on using CSS3 and HTML5 (...and a smidge of  JavaScript) to introduce graphic designers who want to design Web sites. Divided into four parts, the book covers:I. Foundations of Responsive Design (What is it and responsive content)II. Creating Responsive Websites (Basic HTML and CSS, including media queries, and using images.)III. Working Responsive (Workflows)IV. Designing Responsive Websites (Typography, navigation, headers, performance)At almost 400 pages, the coverage of the different topics and details is not unsubstantial, and beginners will get enough to have a solid grounding. The topics are well chosen, and since no two Web designers on earth can agree on much, some may want more of some and less of others. Peterson assumes right off the bat that the reader has some inkling about HTML, and that may prove to be more dangerous than assumed. It's not until halfway through the book that she talks about some different Web development tools like Dreamweaver, but I think that she'd be well-served to show readers right off the bat how to create, save and store HTML files and related content using a text or browser editor.The writing level is clear, and Peterson provides lots of links to appropriate articles on a topic that is not fully covered. I think that spending a page or two on how hexadecimal values are translated into RGB colors would be useful. There are examples where a hex value is used in illustrations, but for most designers, it's Greek; so a quick introduction would be useful. Some examples have mixed problems. In one example (p. 292), the author shows how a decorative typeface may look good on a desktop but not on a mobile device. The point being made is an important one, but the example uses ALL CAPS that looks pretty bad on both desktop and mobile!The author's UX background is apparent, and I think it's the kind of background that is valuable to Web page designers. It helps designers to focus on the user rather than just  artistic creativity and design concepts. Often the lesson is that a good responsive design will go unnoticed by the user who plows through the site trying to find a good deal of a pair of shoes.

Mattel's Wrecky is one of those toys that does a lot for a kid, but it leaves a lot for a kid to do--up to a point. It's for 3 years and up, but I have no idea at which age kids turn to more sophisticated toys, and our grandson is 7; so while he gets a kick out of this toy, I think that he represents the higher limit.This toy has anthropomorphic characteristics. It talks, laughs and even farts and shows other human-like attributes such as wondering if it's "break time" yet. It has siren sounds and flashing green and red lights in its eyes/windshield. The voice reminded me of one of those from the Disney movie, "Cars," and whether or not that was intentional or coincidental is anyone's guess.The toy has three modes; Hauling, Bulldozing and Wrecking. In the Hauling mode, it drives forward, and I tested it on both hardwood floors and thick carpets. It works fine on both surfaces. In Bulldozing mode, it charges up against whatever is in front of it after a preliminary shuffling. The box shows what looks like a brick wall made of plastic bricks (not included), but I'm sure a sibling's Leggo creation, doll house or Lincoln Log cabin would suffice. When it smacks into a structure it makes a comment initiated by sensors in its bumper. Finally, it has a Wrecking mode. In this mode, after releasing the dump bed, it spins around and as it does so, the plastic wrecking ball on the plastic chain extends outward like a knight's mace. (Watch out flower vases!) What has resisted the bulldozing will surely be knocked flat by the wrecking mode. If that's not enough, it dances (on grave of the wrecked Leggo castle or the cat who cashed in life #9 after being accosted by Wrecky) while accompanied by its own music. For some, this may appear to be a tad creepy.This is a great gift for grandparents to give their grandchildren. Not only will the kids have fun with after playing with all of those educational toys piled on by doting parent, it's payback to their own kids who gave them prematurely gray hair. The "Buddy Manual" is quite good, and I would suggest parents put it in a place where it can be retrieved. It runs on 4 'C' batteries (included), and they can be preserved by turning the switch to the "Off" mode. It has 3 battery modes--on--off--demo. The last is for people to test it in stores.The controls are two shell plastic smoke exhaust pipes on either side of the truck. Depending on the mode, pushing the stacks forward or back will put it through one of its routines. I'm sure the kids can figure it out without the manual, and they'll have fun until mom and/or dad keep forgetting to get it new batteries.

As far as Dennis Lehane novels go, this is  story-telling at his best. In fact, The Drop has all of the ingredients I like in a novel; clear fully developed characters and a good story that moves along. Irish Catholics in Boston can get depressing very quickly. Most depressing is the fact that the churches are being consolidated and thanks to pedophile priests and a blind eye hierarchy from bishops to cardinals, the Boston Catholic churches are going broke paying off law suits and losing the faithful. Add that to the drunken and pugnacious stereotype of the Irish what little charm that is found in that same stereotype, thins quickly.However, Lehane does not play on any of the Irish stereotypes, but instead tells a tale of fear, control and redemption -- perhaps a peculiar type of atonement that comes from saving a puppy. The good old days of mob bosses like Irish American Whitey Bulger  who vied with the Italian mob for territory and riches in Boston are still around, but now the Chechens, Latinos and other  ethic groups control a hunk of the loan sharking, betting and all other illegal businesses associated with the Italian mob popularized in the The Godfather. The story centers around a bar run by two ex-connected guys from the old days who blinked when the Chechens brought in their brand of violence. Marv's bar is now owned by Chechens who use it as a drop.The focal point of the book is a bartender named Bob Saginowski who attends the neighborhood Catholic Church. He works in Marv's bar, and at one time (pre-Chechen) he was part of Marv's crew.  But now Bob is just a bartender and is perfectly content being one. Each week, the money from the bets and any other funds the Chechens need to be temporarily deposited are dropped at Marv's bar, and the bartender drops the envelops into a chute where they land in a box at the bottom of the chute. Chechen runners come by and pick up the week's bets, payoffs and other funds at the drop.One day Bob and Marv are  robbed by two two masked men--one skinny and one fat. They were described as the number "10". They take $5,000. Now the problem is not that the amount of money but rather the fact that it  belongs to the Chechen who own the bar. The boss, a man named Chovka is going to want that $5,000 back. Bob and Marv lost the money; so they are held responsible. This worries Bob. The investigating detective is Evandro Torres, a former homicide detective, now demoted to robbery. Torres hints that maybe the bar is a drop, but Marv acts as though he doesn't understand and Bob tries to be helpful by pointing out that one of the masked men wore a non-working watch on the inside of his wrist.Besides Bob, Marv and Chovka, Lehane introduces Nadia whom Bob meets as he saves a severely mistreated puppy from her trash can. She is not well developed as a character, and I wish she had been. In lieu of finding out more about Nadia,  we meet a truly evil character, Eric Deeds, whom Nadia had dated at one time. Lehan describes Deeds in terms of action and mindset that reminds me of some of Jim Thompson's undramatically evil characters. Eric Deeds is as snake-like as any dangerous man in literature. Lehane takes the reader into his life and fully describes him, but leaves out enough so that we don't truly know him or trust him. He was the man who beat the puppy and threw it into the trash.Lehane is masterful in weaving together the different events and characters that make up the story. In the movie version that will be released by Fox Searchlight films, the main characters are played by Tom Hardy, Noomie Rapace (The original girl with the dragon tattoo) and the late James Gandolfini (Sopranos). Just for the fun of it, see if you can figure out which actor plays which character before you look at the trailer. Then see if you were surprised as I was.

Good grief! Little certainly can write. Reading Little is like eating bon-bons. They're really good, and even after eating too many, you don't care, you just want more, even if you're staying up much later than you promised yourself you would. Elizabeth Little's "Dear Daughter" is a mystery with multiple layers of intrigue, the most interesting being the dual query, "Who's my mother/Who am I?" The story centers around Jane Jenkins, a Paris Hilton /  Kim Kardashian  type celebrity, who is one of those singularly unaccomplished people chased by the paparazzi to get photos of them doing nothing of merit--for which tabloids pay big bucks.Jane is convicted of murdering her mother, an idea that has passed through the mind of a daughter or two. However, after 10 years in the joint, her lawyer is able to get her sprung because of the mishandling of evidence by the LA's forensic lab.  Jane decides that she'd be well-served if she discovered the real killer of her mother. Shortly before the murder, she had been in the next room and overheard her mother arguing with an unknown man and a couple of key words are uttered that are Jane's only clues who killed her mother--if it wasn't Jane herself. (Sometimes booze and dope can cloud one's memory, and Jane isn't absolutely, positively....well maybe she did take the shotgun...but she doesn't think so.)So the saga begins. Jane wants to avoid the celebrity chasers, and so while trying to find out about her mother, she also has to avoid the reporters, bloggers and a host of other creeps who make their living (and probably their own selfhood) by writing, tweeting and gossiping about those who live to get tweeted, written and gossiped about. All of this happens in a wonderfully written surround of words and phrases that Little wields with aplomb. For example, when stopped by a cop, she writes about her heroine "putting on her best these aren't the droids you're looking for" face. Not only is that a perfect example of modern culture and what we're expected to understand as a reference, but it describes the culture itself. (This, as opposed to "Cry 'Havoc!', and let slip the dogs of war.")Somewhere around the middle of the book, I began having trouble of keeping track of who's who and what's what, and the story seemed to droop. However, after the middle, it picked up a head of steam and finished on a very strong, have-to-stay-up-late to finish note. Little weaves a complex story filled with great writing not uninteresting side characters, and a story that meets the expectations of a good mystery, albeit a bit convoluted in places. Her Jane Jenkins character is fully drawn and believable in her own shallow sharpness.All in all, Elizabeth Little writes the way I wish more writers would. Her imagery brings alive a culture that is one that we embrace and are embarrassed by all at the same time. We subscribe to the New Yorker and Economist, but volunteer to go the super market where we get in a long line just so that we can browse through US, People and the National Enquirer. Our celebrities are participants in the most banal "reality" shows that have nothing to do with reality, and their stock in trade soars with a publicly released sex video. However, even (or especially) the most hot shock chick on TMZ.com has a mom and mom-daughter issues.I look forward to more mysteries by Elizabeth Little, and I wholeheartedly recommend "Dear Daughter." The little dip in the middle and similar plot over-complexities are sporadic and minor, but in the future, I hope to see less of those and more of what Elizabeth Little does so well--describe and add whatever amounts to literary eye candy that she spreads like diamonds throughout the book.(An interesting note in the acknowledgements and end notes are "Mom, it's fiction" and "Mom, it's not about you.") Ok.

The gizmos that come with the GoPro Hero3 Black are nice and solid products. This one, while I was able to get it to do the job of holding the camera to the tripod, (not by GoPro) was just a cheaper quality. When I tightened the hold, the camera was still a bit loose and I never was able to get it to the point where it "locked" the camera in one position. As soon as I tightened the screw, I felt it begin to strip the threads; so I didn't tighten it further. When that happens, it's usually cheap metal components that have not been (and never will be) sufficiently hardened to snug up an angle.  If you need a low-cost adapter for a GoPro Hero3 Black, this product will work, but if you plan on doing a lot of tripod work with your GoPro Hero3 Black, you might want to pay a little more and get one made of more substantial materials.

It's pretty difficult to get excited about a kit of markers, some cleaners and an eraser, but they all did their job well, and so I'm happy to recommend them. A while back I got a white board that I put up next to the exit door to the garage. On it, I put reminders of what I needed to take with me--mobile phone, keys, lunch, etc. The board also has little magnets where my wife and I can affix coupons. I got some color markers at a dollar store, and they didn't exactly work well. They looked faded and I had to scrub messages on the white board with them. In no time, the board was pretty messy, and the eraser that came with the board was a little bitty one affixed to the head of the marker that came with the board.Rather than buying what I needed piecemeal, I got this kit, and everything in it worked fine. First, I used the eraser to get as much of the old stuff off that I could but some of the older (more stubborn) markings were still there. Since my white board had never been properly cleaned, the spray cleaner had to be applied more than once with a paper towel to wipe away the old markings, but it did a great job. The new markers were clear and the red, green, blue and black colors distinct.This is one of those handy things that takes care of business with no muss or fuss. If it's what you need, this one works fine.

I'm not sure whether this is exactly what most need for either modern business or education. It is decidedly for paper and only paper--along with paper-marking instruments. You could get more than one spiral bound notebook clamped in and lots of loose sheets of paper that are easily and well-organized. In that respect it looks like the ideal organizer of school or business meetings.  If that is how your business works, you're in luck--especially if it operates on technology that existed before smartphones, tablets and USB drives.For me, the lack of a pocket for a USB drive, some cables and a plug-in recharger for a smartphone or tablet--or even a small laptop--dates this binder. The way the handle is positioned, the materials in the binder hang downwards. If you hazarded putting a tablet in the binder, its weight would be pushing against the material that houses the zipper. From the weight and apparent quality of the cloth, it wouldn't be long before your iPad or Surface came bursting out and crashing on whatever surface you happen to be over. There is a netted catch-all pocket for pencils, pens (quills?), erasers, yellow markers and paper clips. I suppose you could stash a USB drive there and secure a small tablet in there along with your smartphone, but it's little more than a netted sack that is hardly purpose container forbuilt-for the kinds of technology found in modeled education and business.Of course for those of you who live in a paper and pen world, it's no so bad.

To describe something as "casual elegance" sounds pretty much like a cliche, but in the case of these placemats, the description is apt. For a small summer dinner party with friends, these mats are the perfect compliment to anything from a stir fry prepared in a wok to a barbecue. They have both the delicate strands of bamboo that held together with blue and gray threading give them the substance to handle hot plates and silverware without looking either tacky or something used for the previous meal when the kids had a food fight. It's nice to find something so simple yet so nice.

2:34 MinsFor this review I used two cameras. One  recorded the review itself as the tripod held the camera (an iPhone.) The second camera showed what the iPhone looked like while making the review. (Sort of like dual reflecting mirrors.) You can see how stable the picture is made by the iPhone because it was held in place by the tripod. The other camera I hand-held.

Bagmen is a lot of fun, and while I found a few missteps, there weren't many. The story centers around Victor Carl who happened into the job of a "bagman" -- the guy (or gal) who is so named for delivering bags of cash to different individuals in a position to influence the outcome of an election, drop a criminal charge or get the water treatment plant built in a certain district. This can be anyone from a union boss to a priest. Victor has come up in the world from a mere lawyer (forever with an ear open to the sound an ambulance carting off a potential client) to the loftier and more rarified air of a guy who collects from the rich and gives to the corrupt. The rich have their will implemented and the corrupt get paid.One of the enigmas of the story lies in the love/hate relationship that Victor has with his position. He can clearly see it is no less sordid than what he had been doing as an attorney, but he runs into the rich crowd whom he simultaneously detests and wants to be a part of. He beds (or gets bedded by) women for whom power is a drug, and sex is a strange concoction of control and pleasure to a point some would consider perversion. (Not Victor, though.)The most interesting characters are not the corruptors or the corrupted but the bagmen who have their own set of rules and ways of being. One, named 'Stony' is a second generation bagman and more or less takes Victor under his wing. Early on, Victor gets into big trouble as a suspect in a homicide, and the bagmen's camaraderie quickly turns sour and Victor is on the outside looking in. However, he is quickly accepted back into the bagmen fraternity—one of those missteps I mentioned--and the story continues.  Stony comes across as sort of a Yogi Berra kind of philosopher and avuncular figure to Victor, but as the reader finds out, Stony has his rules as a bagman, and the first one is to look out for Number One (himself.) So it's important to understand Stony's rules and to realize that he's not kidding.The dilemma for Victor is where to draw the line—believe it or not a moral line (and we're talking about a lawyer?). Some nice people have been murdered, and Victor has a strong moral sense about their being killed (and possibly ending up the same way himself. ) As the story unwinds morals keep getting in Victor's way and he even wonders if he's on the right side, even though all sides in the political battle do little more than voice hollow platitudes. (How can you be on the wrong side of a platitude?)William Lashner's humor is wry and unrepeated--it sparks like a firefly and you either get it in a blink or miss it. Victor Carl is stuck with being a hypocrite or lashing out against the hypocrisy that has become his bread and butter. His cynicism is not too deep because his expectations of the human race were never too high to begin with. Nevertheless,  he is nagged by the possibility that some decency wouldn't hurt all that much and too much evil spoils life for everyone. So, in a glib sense of right and wrong, he still lances windmills and Lashner's tale of Victor Carl is one of great fun and mystery.

With a book like this, it's easy to do one of two things; 1) Detest it and get snarky, 2) Declare a 'new voice' and over-praise it. I hate to get snarky, and this is an easy book to dismiss as drivel, and I can provide several reasons why. Likewise, I dislike declaring a 'new voice' or revolutionary thinking for a collection that shows little evidence of much new or revolutionary. However, I do think that the author, Lindsay Hunter, has something truly new: the voice of the Wal-Mart worker; at least female worker. I'm not referring (necessarily) to the women who work at Wal-Mart, but the underpaid, undereducated and just plain invisible women and their men who work at such jobs. According to economic demographic trends "these" people may be what becomes of the working and middle classes.Other writers have used the kind of out-of-their-mind-and-on-to-the-page writing without a lot of in-between grammar gumming up a pure thought. For example, Jack Kerouac:" And think, Sal, when we get to Pennsy we'll start hearing that gone Eastern bop on the disk jockeys. Geeyah, roll, old boat, roll!» The magnificent car made the wind roar; it made the plains unfold like a roll of paper; it cast hot tar from itself with deference - an imperial boat. I opened my eyes to a fanning dawn; we were hurling up to it. Dean's rocky dogged face as ever bent over the dashlight with a bony purpose of its own."( from On the Road (1955);)So the free flow of thought is not new and certainly not literary heresy, and in some places Lindsay Hunter sounds right:"Her momma was the town skank. Everybody knew. So you couldn't take her all that seriously when her girl went missing. Stay home all night for once, ourown mommas would whisper to each other, swat each other on the arm.You so bad. I know it." (from A Girl)Women writers who knew both sides of the track have created major works, but they seem to have voices that transcend themselves. For example, Sylvia Plath wrote:"Look what can happen in this country, they'd say. A girl lives in some out-of-the waytown for nineteen years, so poor she can't afford a magazine, and then she gets ascholarship to college and wins a prize here and a prize there and ends up steering NewYork like her own private car. Only I wasn't steering anything." (The Bell Jar--1971)However, while the stories seem to emanate from women who might seem to have Wal-Mart lives, it's hard to tell whether or not Hunter has. In a few of the stories the dialect stumbles on good grammar and generates a sense of fraud. Further, Hunter does a lot better job in describing than she does "inside the head and voice telling" Her Nixon story didn't work for me and some of the other where she talked from the inside didn't either.In some places where the author seemed to think it was a good idea to use clever formatting (Our Man) or ALL CAPS (my eye-brain is still screaming from THAT). (Cigarette companies used to print health warnings in ALL CAPS to make them difficult to read.) If you have something to say, gimmicks will not help.All in all this book is a mixed bag. O. Henry wrote "flash stories" and a recent issue of the New Yorker was full of them. They're just short, short stories, and I think they have their place in American literature--past and present. Lindsay Hunter has picked an important voice and does a good job in communicating that voice and even the culture. She needs a lot a work on her storying telling.

I like the  Wireless AC750 Portable Router and Charger by D-Link, known as the DIR-510L. It has a few issues, but I'll get to those later. I tested the personal router on an iPad Mini, regular iPad and an iPhone. ( I have no idea how it works with an Android or Surface device.) Trying to follow the paper Guide that comes with the device proved very difficult in the 5-point font they used to print it in. So, the very first thing I recommend doing is to read the Quick Install Guide online at:(Google up  Quick Install Guide DIR-510L for the URL--I cannot put it here.) It has three basic types of connections:1. Broadband Router with Ethernet cable2. Mobile Router Setup (Requires 3G/4G USB adapter) //Not evaluated3. Wi-Fi HotspotI first plugged in an ethernet cable, fired it up and connected two iPads and an iPhone to the DIR-510L.  The default password is a blank; so you're advised to create your own password.  Anyway, it worked fine and all of my "i" devices wirelessly connected simultaneously. (The manual suggests that you connect no more than 5 devices at the same time.) If you do not have a wireless router, this will allow you to connect all of your "i" devices.  However, most ISPs like Comcast and AT&T include a wireless router. However, what I did find invaluable is the new found ability to plug in a USB drive into the DIR-510L and open it on my iPad. For me that's huge!Next, using my own wireless router as a "hotspot" I unplugged the ethernet cable and re-connected my mobile devices to the wireless DIR510L wireless connection that appears in my Wi-Fi Settings on my "i" devices.  That worked too, and it's the important one. Every Thursday I meet a friend at Starbucks and use the mobile hotspot they have there. (Some people use our Starbucks as an office with their laptops, tablets and mobile phones all arrayed on the postage-stamp size tables there.) One feature of the DIR510L is that it can add a layer of protection against unwanted intrusions. In Starbucks, everyone there has the Starbucks wireless connection code; including some jerk trying to get information form your mobile device. By connecting my DIR510L to the Starbucks wireless and then my iPhone to the DIR510L, I'm using the password that I set up on the DIR510L as a firewall against intrusion.Most of the configuration is done online at a D-Link URL. There you enter your Admin Password and some other configuration chores. Fear not; once it's done; it's done. However, you do need one more thing, and that's the app, "mydlink SharePort."  With the SharePort you can access Documents, Folders, Videos, Music, Photos and "Favorites" from storage devices attached to the DIR510L.The DIR-510L includes a WPS button for wireless devices with WPS. Since the "i" devices don't have WPS, I could not test it. However, they do have WPA/WPA2, and from what I could gather, WPS security is a lot less secure than WPA. In fact, I found several online articles suggesting that you avoid WPS. I'm no security expert, and so I wouldn't bet the farm of any of the available security measures. Nevertheless, I checked to make sure that my devices were secured by WPA2--it was done automatically in connecting to the DIR-510L and that's on top of the DIR-510L security. (A big red warning labels comes with the DIR-510L that lets you know that your device is subject to unauthorized access unless you have WEP, WPA or WPA2.)Finally, the DIR-510L charged my devices. I just moved the switch to "Charger" and plugged in the power cord to my iPad. I watched the battery go from 85% to 90% indicating a positive charge. (I didn't wait for it to hit 100%.)Overall, I really like the DIR-510L, and my reservations are small, but I do not believe to be petty. Like everyone else, I want good security, and from what I've seen about WPS security, they probably ought to drop it and provide more instructions on using WPA or include WPA2 as part of the DIR-510L. Another problem is with their Quick Install Guide. Why print it in 5-point fonts? That's absurd! Either put it in standard size print (about 12pt) or just provide an online address. Third, who's bright idea was it to print the labels in white on a white background? The labels for the button positions (e.g. 'CHARGER') and sockets and idiot lights are all white on white. Here's what I suggest: give all of your designers a piece of candy that gives them the runs, and then write the antidote in white ink on white paper. See how they like it. Otherwise, it's a nice design. Finally, not counting the value of an online PDF file with all of the documentation, I had a lot of trouble working out the configuration process using the necessary online link. Is there some way that the configuration (all of it) could be put into the SharePort app? Then it would be available all the time.All-in-all, the DIR-510L offers a lot as a personal router, device charger and USB drive access for "i" devices. Once past the initial setup, it's pretty easy to use and provides a lot of functionality. This is one device that has MORE features than expected and worth every penny of it.

We have mice, and my wife goes nuts whenever she spots the their droppings. We've used traps (both spring and electronic) and even poison. (I couldn't bring myself to put out the poison packets, but the mice gnawed their way into the package with the poison and did themselves in.) So when I saw the Tomcat Super Hold Mouse Glue Board, I had to try it.Right off the bat I caught a little mouse. The poor thing was struggling and looking at me like I was going to help him get unstuck. I picked up the trap and covered the mouse with a big maple leaf and carefully put it in the trash. I didn't want to have the thing stick to the side of the trash can. Tip: Put the trap into a bag before putting it in the trash.I put two in the garage where we've had mice move into my car's air filter for warmth. The first one caught something that kicked over the trap after apparently getting caught and kicking free. I assume it was a bigger mouse or even a chipmunk. Anyway, it seemed to mess up the stickum in the trap. I put another one next to it, figuring that it would have more difficulty getting away from two, but so far the only thing that it's caught is a big black spider.  I replaced the one where I had caught the first mouse but so far nothing.At this point in time, the traps are batting 250, which doesn't sound bad, but the real fact is that only 1 out of 4 has caught a mouse.  In all the years I've been battling mice, I've caught more with peanut butter and the old-fashioned Victor spring traps than any other. I don't like the spring traps because they get yukky with mouse blood and guts and will swat your fingers while setting if you're not careful. My electronic trap worked exactly once, and I like it a lot except for that fact that it quit working after the first mouse.Of all of the mouse trap systems I've used, this one is the easiest if you don't count the suffering of the mouse.  However, it only works some of the time, and while simple, I wish the mouse didn't have to suffer. Like all mouse catching systems, you want to dispose of the caught mouse as soon as possible so it won't get smelly.

The older you get, the more your skin dries out. If you work outside doing yard work or garden work--or just about any physical work with your hands (other than writing reviews), your hands get banged up and dried up. In the past I've used L'Occitane after shave and shaving cream and like them both. However, for my hands I've used Burt's Bees Salve (A Farmer's Friend), and still like it. However, I like this Shea Butter Ultra Rich Body Lotion for dried up, banged up hands too.The lotion comes in a pump bottle with braille dots on the front label. (A nice touch for the blind.) It's easy to apply, and I've got to learn to pump a little less because it does not take much.  If you leave it on for a little while, it is absorbed into the skin and your hands don't feel greasy or sticky--just give it a good rub and wait a little while.The ingredients look like the contents of a Gilbert Chemistry Kit, but the top three are water, shea butter and glycerin--nothing lethal.I have no idea what the other ingredients are for but assume that they are a combination of scents, stabilizers, and moisturizing agents.Overall, the product works as advertised, and while my main purposes of use have to do with aging skin and rough hand work, it is recommended as a general hand moisturizer for purposes of appearance.

I poured White Cheddar Seasoning on my popcorn, and loved it. Poured a little more because it took more than just a little. Great stuff. Everything would have been hunky dory had I not looked at the label. Each serving is 1/4 teaspoon, and each serving has 75mg of sodium. So 1 teaspoon has 300mg of sodium, and even if you're not on a low-sodium diet, that's a lot of sodium.The other ingredients besides cheddar cheese and salt for taste are onion and garlic powders, and it does contain milk and soy in case you have a problem with either one of those. A teaspoon only has 8 calories zero fat, carbs, sugars or protein; so you can gobble this stuff up without getting fat. Also, the vitamin count is 0%--not healthy or unhealthy.One thing that has bothered me about food labeling is what counts as a "serving." A teaspoon, tablespoon, cup or some other whole measure makes sense, but 1/4 teaspoon (or 0.8g)? Where does that come from? If you go to buy breakfast cereal, the serving sizes are all over the map--for Cereal A, the serving size is 1 cup and for Cereal B, it's 3/4 cup. There are no standards that I can fathom, and so when you buy anything, you better check what the marketing folks have decided is a "serving." Why is that important? Consider this: A low-sodium diet is 2000mg of sodium per day. A little over 6 and a half teaspoons of of Kernel Season's White Cheddar Seasoning will put you at your max. On the other hand, 24 plus "servings" sounds like a whole lot more, but it is only 6.6 teaspoons that generates 2000mg of sodium. Partial units make me believe that they're up to something sneaky.So be careful with this stuff. It really tastes good and is easy to over-indulge.

The BonJour 16-piece Dinnerware Meadow Rooster Stoneware Set is a delight to the eye. The colors are very bright and vibrant and the French countryside design appeals to my tastes. So I was more than happy when I first opened the box. I knew of "stoneware" and somehow associated it with some kind of rough and tumble version of 'china' invented in the 1950's in the U.S., but I was dead wrong. It turns out that stoneware was first used during the Shang Dynasty (c. 1600-1046 bc), and invented by the Chinese. These dishes are made in China, and so you might say that the manufacturer has a long history of making stoneware, especially the fine stoneware used in making dishes. (Ironically, what we call 'china,' is 'Bone china' made, in part, from bone ash and was invented in England in 1748.)The 16-piece setting is made up of 4 dinner plates, 4 small plates (salad, desert), four bowls (cereal, soup, salad) and four mugs. Besides the big colorful country rooster, the dinnerware is decorated with a scattering of wild flowers and greenery and another chicken and chick.As much as I liked the dinnerware, it still had two final tests; microwave and dishwasher. Our dishwasher is super modern, but it will destroy dinnerware that is not "dishwasher safe." After washing, the dishes were as good as new.(No cracking or color fading.) Then, I tested heating water in the microwave. No cracks or hairlines developed at all nor was the color faded.Overall, I really liked this set. It might be tabbed 'fine informal.' It's not the plain Jane stuff that some people use everyday nor is it the dinnerware to haul out for company. It's the kind of everyday dishes that is nice to have meals on.

Since I received this for a Vine review, I wanted to give it a tough test. The kids are grown and gone, and so we don't have the grass-stained, roll-in-the-mud, wear-way-too-long-favorite outfit that kids seem to have. However, I had several very good pairs of colorful (argyle) socks shrunk to baby size, and I've been leery of washing the new ones except by hand in Woolite. For this test, I threw in a pair. Then I gathered up the mealtime linen (colorful and made of cotton) and dishtowels and my yard clothes and decided that those were the worst of the worst colorful things.My wife informed me that we have a high efficiency washer and I'd better check to see if this Tide is appropriate for our washer. It is. Then my wife went through the standard motions to wash the test clothes and linen (that's really cotton). (I'm not some misogynistic cretin who insists that doing washing is women's work. Rather my wife believes that I will break our washer if I touch it--it's sort of hi-tech, and even though I fix her computer I am not allowed to use the washing machine by myself--or even at all.)Once the wash was done and dried, I went through every piece. Everything was clean and it smelled nice--perhaps a little too nice in a "fresh chemically" way. Suggestion to Tide: lighten up on the 'Clean Fresh Scent' -- there's a difference between unscented 'Fresh and Clean' and chemically induced 'Camouflaged and Clean'. If Tide really does work, and you dry your clothes on a clothesline outside, then you get the real 'Fresh and Clean' scent, and it's way better than the chemically induced version. (Clean clothes coming out of a dryer usually smell warm and clean, but if they're stinky, you know that they're not quite clean.)Other than a few stains that still clung to a dish towel, everything else looked very good. Best of all, my socks didn't shrink. Tide does make an unscented version (Free and Gentle), but I'm not sure if it's for cold water or not. I'll have to look into it, and in the meantime, I'll just use the now-perfumy napkins, dish towels and yard clothes.

These leggings are pretty good. I'm 6' tall and they aren't long enough in the Medium which is kind of a deal breaker for me but doesn't diminish the quality of the legging at all. They're also actually really made for curves of which I do not fully fill out. If you're curvy and feel like you need a little extra space than usual leggings offer than definitely go for these

My wife and I burn through iPhone chargers like crazy. Not because we lose them but because they seem to last about 10 minutes before they get frayed or stop working. I think it's because we use the phone while it's plugged and the angle that requires you to hold it at puts pressure on the cord near the phone. In any case, this Belkin cord is so sort that that is impossible. I picked it up for precisely the reason that I think a lot of people would be unhappy with it. But it works great to connect your phone to your laptop. Here's the hoping it will last longer than the longer ones...

Amazon is clearly getting in the business of making and selling certain household staples for which brand does not matter much. It reminds me of Costco's Kirkland products. In fact, I just read that Amazon was expanding into private label clothing as well. In any case, these towels are one of those products. Who cares what brand made your dish towels? You just care that they soak stuff up or dry off your hands. These do that job just fine. So I give them five stars. I take away one star because they are a completely gross color. Who wants mustard yellow anything?

My first reaction to these goggles was how LIGHT they were. I've used minimalist goggles before--I really like the Speedo vanquishers but these are probably half the weight? On top of that, they are high quality, and work well. I'm not sure what they have to do with Michael Phelps but whatever. The only downside is if you like to wear your goggles tight, these can really dig into your sockets. There is not much excess padding or rubber so it can feel a bit painful. But otherwise, I like 'em. They're my new daily swim goggle.

I live in Texas, which like California is in the middle of a multi-year drought. Last year I purchased Scotts Turf Builder Bermuda Grass Seed and it completely brought a small grassed area of my yard back to life after many failed reseeding attempts--and very little watering. But I didn't know that Scotts made one that required even less water. So far I've used this to path a few holes, and already with no rain, it's begun to sprout. I'm going to use the rest for miscellaneous areas of the yard. Some of my reading suggests that this seed is not good for pasture animals so I will be putting it outside of the fenced areas.

Last year I purchased Scotts Turf Builder Bermuda Grass Seed and it completely brought a small grassed area of my yard back to life after many failed reseeding attempts. I used this Sun & Shade mix to seed a full pasture which is not accessible by my animals- half of the pasture is exposed to full sun all day and the other half is under shade so I've had difficulty finding a seed variety that will grow evenly throughout. I put the seed out 5 days ago and I swear it's already started sprouting. The seeds spread evenly with no clumping and seemed to absorb into the soil entirely with just one watering.Word of warning- this mix contains Fescue seed which is toxic to goats, sheep, cattle, and horses

This is a $100 watch--which is still a decent amount of money--but the price must be kept in mind in terms of any sort of review. This is not a luxury timepiece, this is not some fine piece of hand craftsmanship. Amazon says its an $800 watch but I'm not sure who would possibly pay that. All that said, this is a mid-level, good looking watch.My first reactions:-It's big. Really big-The gold coloring is darker than I expected. It looks more like rose gold-100M water resistant--though I certainly wouldn't take it diving-The band has plenty of extra space (I'll need to take some links off to be able to wear)-Has a nice heft to it.-The date is weirdly crooked/aligned at an angle. It can be hard to see on the wrist.-The blue button on the side is an interesting splash of color.-The case and packaging is actually quite impressive.All of which is to say, if you're looking for a watch for yourself this might not be a bad choice. I probably wouldn't buy it for a watch lover though.

Look I'll just come out and say it: This is the single greatest candle that's ever existed. It does in fact smell like buttered bread--the most delicious, warm buttery bread you've ever smelled. Have you ever been to The Old Spaghetti Factory? You know those big warm loaves of bread they bring out on the board with the two crocks of butter? This candles makes your house smell like it is filled with those. It's not some gross Subway sandwich yeasty smell. It's fully baked...like you're above to shove a piece into your mouth after watching the butter melt into it.I seriously love this thing. It even smells good when it's not lit.PS: I don't eat bread and so my love of this candle may be influenced by my cravings.

As someone who is utterly addicted to our Sonos, I was curious to try out Bose's unit. I used to have one of the Bose Alarm Clock/Stereos and loved it. This is a great effort. It''s easy to set up, syncs with your phone, laptop, ipad and internet radio. Great sound (as expected) and solid workmanship. Unlike a Sonos it has it's own remote which is a nice touch. For those of you who are looking at Sonos, this is roughly the equivalent of a Sonos PLAY1 (which also sell for $199). I don't have any other pieces of the Sound Touch so I can't tell you how it fares as system, but I would guess fairly well. I would definitely consider this as a strong Sonos competitor.

Great little pair of headphones. The flat cord is less likely to get tangled in my experiences. The ear unit is a solid, two color piece of plastic (meaning no rubber cover can fall off). The input plug is an L shape, which is nice but can be inconvenient for some phone cases. My only complaint would be the somewhat lame name. Why would you name your headphone brand iFrogz? I would think literally any other name would work better.

This is a decent sleeping bag with one major exception: it doesn't have a bag/stuff sack to put it in. I find it highly unlikely that anyone is going to need a 20 degree, cinch up mummy bag where portability isn't going to be an important factor.Otherwise, the bag is solid. It's roomy but can cinch up well. The construction and fabric is durable and strong. It looks good and the yellow zippers make it stand out enough to recognize easily.
It's a tote with a pun on it (in case you didn't get the joke it's because pretzels are twisty). There's not much more to say here other than that the bag does its job. And for that, I am grateful.

I use these gloves to put acid in my salt water pool--which I have to do about every 5 days. A 100 pairs for $9 is a much better deal than any I saw at Wal Mart so I was pleased. I want them to be cheap since I'm immediately throwing them away after using them for maybe 20 seconds. I'm not allergic to latex but frankly these feel better and are easier to get on and off. Anyway, solid deal for a solid product.

Honestly, I'm not quite sure why this surge protector is $20. Because it has a $100,000 insurance policy? I have serious doubts anyone will actually be collecting on that anytime soon.Otherwise, this feels just like a slightly heavier duty surge protector than one would normally see. It's metal. It seems like it could do alright on a porch or in a workshop. But at the end of the day it's still a surge protector and the only really new or special thing about it is the sliding covers.

So far this razor has been solid. I haven't used it for the full 30 days that Philips says in the manual is the suggested trial period for testing the razor. What I can tell you is this:-It charges fast-It gives a close shave-It can work even with cream or gel-It's got a neat digital display with all sorts of helpful data/alerts-It's design is fancy and innovativeThose are the good things. The less good:That fancy design is better in theory than in practice. For instance, you can charge it in the cleaning base...but the base is HUGE. It's not as easy to plug in as you would like either. You have to press down on the top (which then pops it up) and then push it back down in the razor to charge. Except you have to do it several times because it doesn't always go in. The cleaning solution that goes in the base--you have to peel off the wrapper before putting it in. Why not just have the base puncture the wrapper like a Glade Plugin? (That's in fact how I though it worked and try to force it through several times).The final note? This razor is nearly $200 on Amazon! The list price has it as $309.99!! Who on earth would pay that much? Look if Apple had a razor that's probably how much it would cost. But it would be absolutely flawless. None of the things I complained about would exist and there'd be 10 other intuitive improvements I'm not even aware are missing added on there to make it the greatest shave in the entire world.

I've had  at least a half dozen memory foam pads over the years from many different brands. This Classic Brands topper feels neither any better--but definitely not any worse--than any of the others. Other than the very tight packaging that took a bit of time to get it out of the book, I have no complaints. It does its job: makes your mediocre mattress much more comfortable (though I would argue that the foam toppers are better than the fully memory foam mattress). But since this one does not offer any particularly special features, I might suggest shopping around for price on similar specs.That brings me to my next point: Why isn't there any feature differentiation? Why not make it with a cover? Why not put a brand or a logo on it? Why not make it some other color than yellow sponge? Of course, a big piece of foam you put on top of your mattress is not exactly the most inspiring designer canvas but it does seem weird how little changes there have been to this type of product over the last ten years. Especially for something that runs nearly $150.

I wanted to love this carpet cleaner but it's terrible. Assembly and set up are easy as is adding water and cleaner to the tank. It also looks cool. The problem is that it just doesn't work well.I vacuumed my carpet twice before I started to use the carpet cleaner and at first things were great. Squirt the cleaning solution, vacuum it up. Easy peezy. I thought things were going along great until I stopped the machine and noticed I'd gone through nearly the entire tank of cleaning solution and the dirty water tank was nearly empty! What happened to all the dirty water? I removed both tanks to investigate and the machine dumped water all over my carpet. Then I moved the carpet cleaner off my carpet and discovered it literally vomited clumps of dirt onto the carpet. (I'm not gross I swear I had my carpet professionally cleaned a couple months ago.) Look, I understand you need to vacuum your carpet before you use a carpet cleaner, but this is meant for pets and it can't handle a little pet hair from my short haired dachshund? Now my carpet is dirtier than it was previously and I had to lug my heavy Hoover Power Scrub Deluxe Carpet Washer, FH50150, out of the garage and start all over again. If you're in the market for a carpet cleaner, check out that Hoover. It's heavy but it's a beast and works way better. I'm sorry for cheating on you with a Bissell, Hoover, please forgive me.

I never expected to be a slackline guy, but along the lake in Austin there is a long boardwalk that curves along the shore. When I go running I've passed a group of people who set up a slackline across one of the the turns. It was so cool to watch them walk and fall into the water when they messed up. So I took a chance on this on Amazon Vine. It was fun and easy to set up. It's even got protectors so you don't messed up trees or poles setting up. It's a great little starter kit. Recommend!

Love this stuff. Just a tiny bit is enough. And if you run your hands through your hair during the day, they don't come back sticky or gooey. Was first exposed to this at Bird's Barbershop here in Austin but it's cheaper and easier to get from Amazon.
Works good enough and was substantially cheaper in the three back than a single can of many of the competitors. Recommend!

Solid strings, they're what I've used for years. The box is a little flimsy which can lead to the strings popping out if you're not careful. It's annoying, it can stick your hand when you reach in and worse scenario, bend them.

For the last several years, I've used the Philips SHQ1200/28 ActionFit Sports In-Ear Headphones (basically the red ones that were the previous model). I've loved them because 1) they stay in your ear 2) they are almost entirely sweat proof (unlike standard Apple headphones) 3) the headphone jack is at a right angle instead of simple being a standard straight plug.These are basically the same headphones in a different color with the little tails on them that help them stay in your ear even better. I thought it'd be annoying but it wasn't. You forget its there almost immediately.Anyway, great headphones. These are what I use on a daily basis for whatever that's worth.

Nice little product. Easy enough to apply to the doors of both cars (a truck and SUV). It looks like it will do its job and took about 10 minutes per car to do. The problem is that the instructions suggest apply every 2-3 works. I've been driving a long time and owned my share of cars. The idea that I'm going to start using some product--something I've never seen or heard of before for a problem that I've never had (bad rubber around doors)--once a month for the rest of my life is absurd. I don't know anyone else that would either. I'd much prefer some sort of one time, or multi-year solution because this is just not practical.

My iPhone cords keep breaking. I think it's because my wife uses her phone while it's plugged in and the odd bending of the cord eventually wears it down--the wires become exposed and then eventually fall apart and it stops working. I am positive this isn't going to be a problem here. It's woven instead of plastic. It's much longer. Works great. Definitely recommend.

My parents never let me have a slip and slide. But now I am adult and I can have whatever I want. Turns out they were right. These are pretty dumb. Even if you have the smoothest yard in the entire world, it's not that fun and it always hurts. What kind of person runs, hurls themselves at the ground and thinks 'Oh, it's wet plastic so it won't hurt?" It still hurts. Sure, it's nice that there is some inflatable padding at the end but that's comes into play after you've hit numerous rocks and sticks (that you swore you picked up) on the way there. Oh yeah, and you have to inflate the whole thing first yourself. No thanks.In any case, don't be an idiot. Go to a water park. Go to a pool. Stop trying to make this slide and slide thing work. It won't.

Shadow Divers is one of the best non-fiction books I've ever read. Kurson manages to so effortlessly explain a man who is probably a mystery even to himself, he's able to make relatable a drive to discover and understand a drive that goes beyond what many of us will ever experience. In Pirate Hunters, all the same mastery is at play again. Only this time, instead of exploring the depths of a sunken u-boat, John Chatterton is searching the entire Caribbean for one of the greatest pirate ships of all time. What makes Kurson's story so compelling is that this isn't some simple treasure hunt. It's not a fictional story where all the ends are tied up loosely. It's complicated. It's confusing. It's not Johnny Depp's brand of pirates. It's something different. Yet Kurson tells it all so compellingly and so clearly that you turn every page and want to know what happened next. Read this book.

I rarely play Ping Pong so a robot that lets me play by myself was not high of my list of needs. That being said this is pretty fun. I'm not saying it will turn me into Forest Gump anytime soon but it has improved my game. Yet...ping pong is really only fun with other people. By yourself is well, boring.Couple weird features on this. It says it can shoot 30 balls a minute. That's one every other second. Why you'd ever need that many is beyond me. But more importantly, it only holds 20 balls. So how does that work exactly?

These are actually different than typical ping pong balls. As a result, they dent less easy and I assume will last much longer. I would hope so considering just how much more expensive they are. Are you someone who buys expensive pens or the cheapest ones you can get? Do you buy generic or brand name? That's probably a good rule of thumb here on whether these are for you.Now, I'm off to throw these at people.

I don't like tea--at all. But my guests and friends do. This was a nice thing to throw in the fridge for any weirdo and psychopath who enjoys such a drink. Takes up much less space than a pitcher and no need for bags or leaves either. It's small, compact and seems like it's going to last a while. Let me reiterate: I do not like tea so I have no idea how this tastes. But again, I hear good things. So take that for what it's worth.

I don't want to overstate this but as a 28 year old man with no children, these placemats were everything I had hoped for and more. They're thin but durable. They're pink. And as you can see, they make the very true and very profound statement that: "Bows go with everything." They do indeed.Anyway, I'm actually using these to go under my dog's water and food bowls. She's a pretty sloppy eater and it was messing with the wood floor. No more, because Minnie has come to the rescue. Thanks!

Mr. Holzer has crafted a book that sheds light on how, in addition to waging war on the battlefield, in the courts, and in Congress, Lincoln was also required to fight and win on the hotly contested front pages of the nation’s newspapers. Never before until now, has America seen the tail wag the dog in the way that newspapers—empowered by technological advancements in the printing press and the telegraph—did in Lincoln’s time.If you were to ask the average person what they know about Lincoln and the media, they’d probably say something about him throwing journalists in jail or suspending certain Constitutional rights. That is true and it is interesting.But what the record actually shows is that Lincoln was an astute and deft manipulator of the media—a manipulator-in-chief has he had been called. He needed to be. And frankly, the media in that day deserved it.It is not for nothing that one could swap out “newspaper” for “blog” in many instances in this book and be just as accurate now as it was 150 years ago. The “racket” we see today—was in fact invented and perfected back then. It made a handful of moguls quite rich, and quite influential, as the expense of pretty much everyone else. Like today, it was disruptive technology when combined with a self-interested internal culture that made the media such a difficult beast to be reckoned with.What Lincoln ultimately got very good at was using the press against itself—the art of a well-timed letter, a key leak to the right reporter, even knowing when to let outrage outdo and undermine itself. To see and understand this is to observe a master politician and communicator at work.But…In my eyes, one can look at the 19th century media and Lincoln and only be appalled at the needless cost and real damage that was inflicted on the country by bands of partisan, attention and patronage hungry editors and reporters.What Lincoln showed then and now is a path forward—how politicians can lead and overcome a toxic media environment. As Mr. Holzer relates, as the war progressed Lincoln broke his lifelong addiction to newspapers. He realized that his duty required him to see a larger picture than biased, misguided and small-minded reporters could ever capture.As Mr. Holzer tells it, only after the Emancipation Proclamation did Lincoln begin to “look beyond ephemeral journalism to validate his place in history.” He began to delegate his media diet to subordinates and opted for real interactions with real people (soldiers, letters, office hours and ironically interviews with reporters directly back from the front) in what he terms “public opinion baths.” Lincoln’s homespun language and stories—these were not for reporters and editors, who in fact, looked upon them condescendingly but for the people who loved it—who got it.In a way, Lincoln was temporarily able to transcend the everyday squabbles of the media in light of a larger goal. He was the right man, at the right time who did the right things, the right way. How long this would have lasted, though, we have no idea. Had he not been assassinated Lincoln may have been almost immediately pulled back into the swamp (recommended read: The Impeachment of Abraham Lincoln by Stephen L. Carter is a great fictional look at this idea). How he would have responded, we cannot say, but Mr. Holzer’s book makes it safe to assume that it would have been impressive and masterful.

I used these clips to hang up some Edison style outdoor string lights. They're easy to use, cheap and simple. These bill themselves as outdoor light clips but I worry how long they will last in the elements. I doubled up by using a staple gun.

I have a lot of respect for anyone who can make philosophy accessible to people. I doubly appreciate anyone who brings it to a mass audience. Rebecca Goldstein has managed to do this (as I write this it sits at #160 on Amazon, several months after release). If I had one criticism it would be to ask: to what end does she do this? "Vain," Epicurus once said, "is the word of the philosopher that does not heal the suffering of man." This book poses all sorts of interesting questions and debates. It is definitely well written. But there is little practical advice on how to live. That being said, this book is important, readable and fun.

The topic of this book is like one of those ridiculous but awesome Wikipedia pages you stumble across--the Polish regiment with a bear for a pet. The camels in the US Civil War. Now, Stubby the WWI dog. As we sit now at the 100th anniversary of WWI--the war to end all wars--and you're looking for a nice easy book on the topic, this one might be a good place to start.

This is an exciting topic for a book. Yellow journalism may not have been the most accurate or honest of professions but it's practitioners were wildly adventurous and brave. The book somewhat awkwardly begins well into the Gilded Age (despite the subtitle saying it begins with the Civil War) but the author has a knack for story and personalities. I suggest this to anyone who is doing a deep dive into the history of journalism and journalists. If you're just looking for a good romp about journalists, I might recommend you start with Junius and Alberts Adventures in the Confederacy.

Networking: any activity that increases the value of your network and/or the value you contribute to it.That is Derek Coburn’s definition of networking. Notice he doesn’t include “attending large events” or “handing out business cards”. Derek found through his years of doing similar low-yield activities that most things people consider “networking” are really just a waste of time. Instead, Coburn decided to try new approaches, and only spend his time on what actually worked.The result of these years of testing is “Networking Is Not Working.” The book is split into two sections: the first looks at the inefficiencies in common networking strategies. The second part explores Derek’s response to those inefficiencies and how anyone can replicate his unconventional methods.The process Coburn developed and lays out is called “CONECTOR”:C: ClientsO: Open DoorsN: NucleateE: EventsC: CommunityTOR: Trigger Ongoing ReciprocityThe book emphasizes that networking is not a volume business and instead professionals should focus on creating small, motivated groups of like-minded people who appreciate staying connected and helping each other out. I recognize in my own life, similar small groups of friends and colleagues have lead to my most rewarding (and lucrative) ongoing business. Having known and worked with Derek, I've seen him live and prove the theories he talks about here.Luckily, this book can save you hours of learning by trial and error and accelerate your path to becoming, as Coburn says in the book, the “Ultimate Connector.”

Feeling stuck is a very common feeling. Stuck at a job. Stuck in a relationship. Stuck because of groupthink and nearsightedness. Headed down a path, not exactly sure how they got there, or how to change that course. As Hankel puts it in the book “Too miserable to move forward, too invested to turn around.” As someone who has been in that situation before, I know that feeling trapped in a situation or bound by circumstances is one of the worst feelings ever.Black Hole Focus argues that the solution to this problem is not just figuring out WHAT we want to be, but WHO. Defining a purpose in life and working backwards to fulfill that purpose.The book lays out a strategy to finding this purpose in 3 sections:- The first section discussed why you need to actively find a purpose for your life- The second section lays out the process of transforming your current life so it is aligned with that purpose- The final section covers Hankel’s strategies for keeping with your purpose in the face of adversity.Hankel draws heavily from his extended time in academia (which ultimately lead him to being hospitalized before the age of 30 due to kidney disease brought on by stressed-induced inflammation) as well as recent studies in psychology, physiology, and motivational theory to build upon his compelling thesis.This book is inspiring, it's honest, it's practical, it's based on real experiences and insights born from Hankel’s NEED (medical and otherwise) for purpose. I ended up with a page of notes that called into question my purpose I felt was already well established.I recommend it to everyone, stuck or not. It will undoubtedly call your attention to larger questions which need your “black hole focus."

I was excited about this but after trying it out, realized it was essentially the same as my Dropcam (and they are the same price). The only additional feature this has that a Dropcam doesn't is that you can click the base and it turns into a light. My Dropcam on the other hand, is the same price, had a mic you can speak through and its cloud recording system actually recognizes and identifies common patterns of activity and alerts you. While this product here is specifically marketed as a baby monitor, it looks like there are better products out there--intended for general use yes--that do the same thing.

I have had probably 10 different memory foam mattress toppers over the years. Some were expensive, some were not. This one from Serta was the BEST by far. I'll even say it was one of the most comfortable things I've slept on EVER. Honestly, it's like a mattress in and of itself--except in my opinion full memory foam mattresses are too soft while this is actually better and more affordable.On top of all this, it looks good. It's not some gross yellow piece of foam you throw a sheet over. It's two layers of foam, it's dyed white, and then it comes with a thick, soft topper that goes over it. And it is much thicker and higher quality than it appears in the photo.If you're looking for a topper, get this one. Trust me.

This has got to be one of the most ridiculous product extensions in the history of television--maybe even product endorsements period. Frankly, that's why I got it. It's obviously just generic coffee with the dudes from Workaholics on it. They clearly aren't into coffee. I don't think it's ever appeared on the show ever. If they were endorsing Costco jeans, or weed or beer it would make sense. But coffee? It's hilarious.Anyway, the only reason to get this would be as a joke. But it's a good joke, so enjoy. And watch the show. It's funny.
These are not 1000mah! I compared the size to my 850 mah battery and it is the same physical size. I cycled it and only got 800mah out of it.

Unfortunately my college course requires this textbook. Fortunately this Indian version is exactly the same as the US version but has a few "for sale only in India" markings. IT IS IN ENGLISH! If you want to save an order of 10 times, buy this version. Mine came brand new in plastic wrap.

I have used 900MHz for the last few years and just decided to try out 5.8GHz. Installation is pretty standard, try to use a little double sided foam tape on the back to prevent vibration from destroying the circuitry then use zip ties to keep it from falling off. The wiring is a little annoying, it has 5V out with no option of 12V, which nearly all cameras use so you need to make a bridge from the 12V input then build an LC filter. I also think these transmitters are weaker physically at the SMA socket. The 900MHz TX's have the SMA socket soldered to the metal case for example. I would recommend using a short 2-3" extension with the other end screwed on to your aircraft, this will prevent your antenna from ripping the connector off in a crash (loss will be minimum too).Performance is not bad at all, I get nice clean video pretty far out but get bad interference the second I dip behind a bush/tree. 900MHz does not have this problem and video clarity is about the same. This transmitter does get pretty warm, be sure to keep the red sticker side exposed to air to cool it. Also be sure to use the stock antenna to stir paint and buy your self some circularly polarized antennae, this will cut down on the multipath problem of this frequency. I personally use IBcrazy's bluebeam ultra with plastic dome cover.

Fatshark is known as a "standard" brand in FPV, there are really not many other companies making video glasses. I went through THREE pairs of these and every single one had multiple dead pixels. I got fed up and spoke to Fatshark and they essentially said "it cost too much to make perfect goggles and a few dead pixels is allowable".The quality of the image is ok but not super great as marketing would trick you into thinking. The edges are very blurry and everything else is fuzzy even with corrected vision. The eye cups are uncomfortable and cause the glasses to droop and the optics to fog. Wait for the technology to ripen before buying.

I am an engineering student and wanted something to replace my heavy/aging 2009 macbook pro. I needed something light to take to school and did not need a heavy duty computer. I picked the Surface Pro 3 128gb/i5 model and used it for a few days. Here is my opinion..Hardware:Pros - The hardware is great. Screen is bright and crisp, touch screen is pretty precise, kick stand is surprisingly sturdy, and the build feels solid.Cons - The haptic feedback motor is loud. Very loud. When it is on a desk, bumping that windows button will cause it to vibrate which will resonate with what ever it is touching. There is no way to disable this "feature" unless if you disable the windows button. But it seems the volume/power/windows button is all on the same I2C bus, disabling one with device manager will disable them all. You will bump this key at some point, especially if you use the pen to write with.The keyboard:I will talk about the type cover here too, since the thing is almost useless without it.Pros - The keyboard is very light and adds only a tiny bit of thickness to the SP3. I did not have much trouble adapting to it and I can type on it at a normal rate.Cons - When on a desk and the keyboard is angled, it is INCREDIBLY loud, it sounds like a 1940's type writer. If you are in a quite area, you WILL disturb people around you. Microsoft also chose to use some type of weird felt like cloth covering. It will get dirty eventually and be difficult to clean. The mouse pad is located slightly to the left, and as I result I am always hitting it with my palm. I have also noticed that laying sideways in bed will make the SP3 think it is being used like a tablet and automatically disable the keyboard.The pen:Pros - The pen and palm rejection surpassed my (high) expectations. The pen feels pretty close to using a ball point on glass except the ink is electronic. There is also a feature to convert handwriting to text that is pretty useful and accurate.Cons - The buttons are a little awkward to use, the magnetic holder at the bottom is not strong enough to hold it, and there is no symbol support for the handwriting input.The charger:Pros - Has a USB port!The software:Now, I use both windows and mac and I might be used to the extra polish of OS X. I thought I could try to adapt to windows 8 but I can't. It is just too awkward of an operating system, having to manage programs and apps, having tablet settings and then desktop settings. There are too many little things that could just be better. For example, in desktop mode I have to bring up the digital keyboard every time I want to type and X it out once I am done. Windows get resized but do not go back to normal once the digital keyboard is gone. Desktop items often end up shuffled too.The absolute worst part is that I cannot get over is the fact that the stock microsoft apps have 3rd party ads built into them! I paid $900 for this machine, I do not want to have advertisements!Overall, it is a great idea and could have completely changed the way I work. Unfortunately typical microsoft blundered it by missing out the tiny but ever so annoying details. Usable? Totally. Perfect? Not at all.

If you are looking into getting your HAM license, I think this is the only book you need. It has ALL the real exam questions and answers on marked pages. The questions are marked as you read the book so you know exactly where to find the answer. The book is straight to the point and gives an explanation of the concept then moves on.
