I thought the price was high because it would actually be something of quality.The gun part is completely flat, less than a centimeter thick, so that if you pointed it at someone, they would have no idea what you were pointing at them. It also comes wrinkled and bent, because the wire that's keeping it straight leaves a lot to be desired. The "purse" part is basically a coin purse; the only part of it that holds anything is the little round pouch which (as my best friend and husband both pointed out) looks like a man's sack. It's wrinkled, asymmetrical and bent out of shape when it arrives. After ten minutes of trying to get it to face the way it's supposed to, I finally gave up and realized that it was just going to keep turning to the side, no matter what I did.It looks like a machine gun that some kid cut out of cardboard and painted black, and the purse part doesn't actually function as a purse unless you're not carrying anything more than some cash and cards. Overall, incredibly poor quality and I will be returning it asap.****EDIT*****Even worse - their return policy stinks.  You have to pay for the postage, the original shipping is non-refundable and they charge a "minimum" 15% restocking fee.  Makes me wonder what the maximum is and how much money I'm actually going to get back from this terrible purchase.  Not only am I returning this item, I'm NEVER buying from this seller again.

I really wish I had read the other one-star reviews before buying this book.Callie had HUGE potential and I was so looking forward to reading her story about how she comes into her own and learns to stand up for herself and stand on her own two feet... yeah, that's not at all what the story was.  It was still a good read though, even if I wanted to kick her over and over again for the way she was treated Cadence.  She was a really $hitastic friend to Cadence after leaving, not returning Cadence's calls, not talking to her, and really hurting Cadence over and over again.  I was also looking forward to seeing their reconciliation.Instead, Butler has Callie turn from a sweet and compassionate person to everyone, to only being sweet and compassionate to her twins and their family members.  By the end of it, she's even forgotten to invite Cadence and her old friends / family to her wedding.  She's completely shut them out of her life, and she wouldn't have remembered at all if Cadence hadn't called to bug her about it.  She doesn't even CARE how much she's hurt Cadence.  She never apologizes, and then she's all pissed when she finds out that Cadence wanted her to be miserable so that she could come back to the pack?  Of COURSE CADENCE DID!  SHE WANTS HER BEST FRIEND BACK!  If Callie hadn't been such a terrible friend, if she had actually kept in contact with Cadence and hadn't ABANDONED her completely, Cadence would probably have never wished that.  Because she would still HAVE HER BEST FRIEND.It also bothered me that the twins were so pushy about Callie forgetting her past friendships as well.  They were even jealous over her playing with her new nephews.  WTF.  They're verging on being abusive; cutting her off from her other ties, keeping her from interacting with anyone outside of their family, stifling some of her interactions within their family, and keeping her from working so that she literally CANT have interactions with other men outside of their family.Instead of finding her strength and being a good person, Callie caves on all these points.  It wasn't romantic, it was actually pretty terrifying.  And the way she treated Cadence was unforgiveable.  By the end of the book, I asked for a refund, which I NEVER do if I actually finish a book.  I hated the characters that much.  I could barely even skim over their HEA because I didn't feel like any of them deserved it.  Callie started off the book a wimp in search of herself, and ended the book under the thumbs of her new hubbies, and during her journey, she became a terrible friend and kind of a terrible person.If you're reading this series, skip this book.

This is what I like to refer to as a "limbo" book.  Because everything is stuck in limbo.  A whole bunch of stuff happens, but at the same time... nothing happens.  Because nothing gets resolved.  It kinda sucks to write a 3 star review after I wrote a 5 star one for the last book, but the last book had a lot more going for it.Starting with the most upsetting / disappointing aspect of this book - Reece and Lexi's relationship.  They actually get it together for a bit, but who cares, because by the end of the book they've fallen apart again.  The only thing that's holding this relationship together is the "bond" between them, which is basically a false foundation for a relationship because it's something they don't have a choice about.  I really wish they'd spent the entire book being good together and didn't fall apart until the next one because it would have done a couple of things - given them a chance to build their relationship on a solid foundation so that when they did fall apart it would be more devastating but it would also be more believable when they start to work things out again (because you know they're going to... Lexi has to, she's drilled it into the reader's heads that she had no choice about that because of the bond).  It also would have made me a lot more anxious, because I was honestly expecting their relationship to fall apart sometime during the book.  Diem has already set that up during the past several books and so I waited and then it got to the critical point and I thought "I bet this is when it all falls apart" and BOOM yup.  Except that Reece didn't have to let it fall apart, but he did anyway, and that just made me even more disappointed in him as a hero.  Especially since there was basically no time to build him up as a better boyfriend before that.  There was no time for Lexi to make a real romantic connection to him and so it's hard for the reader to feel it.Lexi comes off as more immature in this book, which is understandable when I remind myself that she's 18.  Diem also has liking for major foreshadowing, I've noticed, and does a lot of it with pushing home that Lexi can never get it on with another guy because Reece bound her so tightly, but apparently she didn't bind Reece as tightly so he can totally get it on with another girl.  Gee... I wonder what's going to happen in the next book.  On Facebook Diem has said that Reece will SEEM like a cheating bastard, so my hope is that he's not ACTUALLY a cheating bastard, and that Lexi will not put up with his b.s. forever.  Which is great and everything and I'm looking forward to watching Reece suffer and, hopefully, spend a lot of time proving to Lexi that he can be a good mate and actually building a relationship with her, but after this book and the abruptness with which they fell apart, without building a foundation, it's hard to believe that Lexi would ever want to.  She's got good reason to have rejection and trust issues at this point and with Reece doing it over and over again... honestly, unless he spends MULTIPLE books trying to win her back, I'm going to be pretty disappointed.  Diem has also stated that despair is the most powerful driving force and only those we love can get us there... I'd argue that LOVE is the most powerful driving force and that Lexi - who has already lost so much of what she loves with her mother and father - would fight hardest to KEEP her loves safe whereas despair tends to make people take suicidal risks when they feel they have nothing left to live for (and Diem def has her getting to that point since she's now lost her mother, her father and Reece, not to mention any hope for her future with Reece because of the restrictions of the bond - and seriously, how does she know the differences in how they're bound nad Reece doesn't? it's never explained)... but yeah.  At this point, the only way 'despair' as a driving force makes sense to me is if she's going to sacrifice herself for them, because right now it doesn't look like she has a whole lot worth living for.  And that's before Reece becomes even more of an @$$ (which, according to Diem's fb posts, is going to happen in the next book).As to the main action... Lexi's mother isn't even an issue in this book, the rogue shifter takes center stage (despite the fact that Lexi is slowly being pulled to the dark side and will continue to be so until they kill her mother).  Focusing on the wolves mostly seemed like a plot device to make sure that Reece and Lexi fell apart again more than anything else, and it was pretty disappointing that the mother story line got shunted off to the side, despite the danger that it puts Reece and Lexi into.  While the wolves were interesting and the succubuses were interesting... it really did seem like a plot device more than needed action.  It didn't totally make sense to me either.  Hunt down murderous paranormals vs. hunt down murderous paranormal that is going to tear the team apart because two of them will die if they don't... and somehow the former won?  Sure the rogue wolf could make them look bad, but it ended up that they didn't spend most of the book hunting the rogue wolf, they spent it hunting a succubus... so why aren't they looking for her mom again?  As strategy goes, it was incredibly questionable, which is why I say plot device.So... of unresolved issues at the end of the book we have:Lexi's fatherLexi's motherWhether or not Lexi and Reece are going to be consumed by the vampirism they're infected withLexi and Reece's relationshipSounds a lot like the end of the last book.  Except add to this that now we can expect Reece to have to choose between his team and his heritage in the next book, so we got new information, but instead of any answers we just got new questions.Here's hoping that in the next book there is at least SOME resolution to SOMETHING.  I'm also personally hoping that Lexi finds out she's not as bound to Reece as she thought and he ends up with some competition.  Esp if he ends up sniffing around some other women, because I really hate the sexist cliche of the heroine having to remain faithful while the "hero" gets to dip his wick.  Reece could use some shaking up and, honestly, so could Lexi.  The 18 year old mentality of "i'll never love again" might be kind of true thanks to the bond, but hey... we know from this book that alphas can steal bonds.  So at least there's an out for her if Reece becomes any more emotionally withdrawn (*cough*abusive*cough*) and hopefully she'll get a happily ever after that is believable.All of that being said; the actual writing is still very good (Diem is one of my faves for writing style), the bad guys are interesting and different, a lot of what happens in the book (other than the strange strategic choice of which baddie to deal with) is believable (even if it does make me strongly dislike Reece), and I still have hope that the books will eventually come together in a way that will be happy for Lexi AND believable/happy for the readers.

I adored this book.  Almost.  Except that Ms. Blake is an evil writer who put something into the epilogue that makes me want the next book NOW NOW NOW NOW!  Although that's not exactly an unusual feeling for me whenever I read her writing.  But still.  I WANT IT NOOOOOW!Enough of that though - this book.  Adored.Mitch is one of those frustrating heroes that's all closed up inside emotionally and you just want to kick him, but he has such good reasons for being guarded that you also want to pet him and tell him that everything's going to be okay.  On top of that, he's a sexy and demanding Dom that makes you want to drop your panties.I loved Laurel.  She was an exceptionally strong heroine, one who had the guts to walk away when she needed to and - even more important - to stand her ground when the stakes were high.  So many books have the hero chasing after the heroine after he messes up, and it's good to see the groveling, but in a relationship not everything can be high drama and "we're over" as soon as there's a fight.  Both people have to be willing to fight FOR the relationship when the fight is over, despite their pride, despite their hurt... and Laurel is strong enough to do that and to show Mitch how a relationship SHOULD be.  All he has to do is be deserving of that.There's some danger, some twists and turns, plenty of humor, just a little bit of Ian's delightful relationship advice, and some new characters that have me super curious. Speaking of adoration, I really hope Kai gets his own book or novella eventually (although, like most of her novellas, Adored is more like a short book than a true novella) because listening to him talk about women and relationships... ha!  His theories are sound, but he's obviously lacking in some practical experience =DAnd, when you get to the epilogue, you'll probably curse Ms. Blake for not having the next book ready immediately. There's a reason she's an automatic-buy author for me, and I have not been disappointed yet.

I was actually pretty disappointed in this book.  Partly because I'm not sure I like the way the story line is heading... I'm down with shifters and 'changed' humans, but once you start throwing "gods" around into the mix... things always get too deus ex machina for me.In this particular Luna Lodge book I felt like there was a lot less romance, which really sucked because I was looking forward to two things 1. Remus being super alpha sexy (which he has been in past books) and 2. Finding out more about Remus because he's pretty swathed in mystery.The problem was, we didn't get to find out much about Remus' past still.  We still know very little about why any of the bad guys are doing what they do - which is part of my problem with gods being thrown into the mix, it adds a whole new aspect that now needs to be explained, even though not much else has yet - and we're introduced to more of the inner circle of bad guys... and still get no motivation other than they're working for these mysterious gods.  Except at least one of them thinks that the gods would disapprove of what's going on.  We didn't even get to find out why Romulus does what he does, except that he's power hunger and jealous of Remus?  maybe?  No explanation why though.  oh, and apparently he's NOT in charge of the bad guys.  At least, he's not the big in charge.  There's others that are in charge of him that he's scared of? or feels like he has to listen to?  Ugh.  Things were not entirely clear.  Even Remus was confused by what the heck was going on.Because of the bad bad things the bad guys are doing to Remus while he's with them, trying to arrange to get his people freed, he's getting weaker and weaker.  And while I love seeing Jenna step up to the plate as the bada$$ that she is... there was something very much missing in the romance of this one for me.  I read Luna Lodge because I love the hot alpha males... there wasn't a whole lot of that going on.  There were some tender alpha male times, which were pretty great, but Remus was always so much fun because he was so cocky, so mysterious... and there was none of that here.I adored Jenna, but that wasn't enough to make up for the things I felt were missing from the book.  Namely - any kind of real insight into the bad guys and Remus' alpha sexiness.

Not Jillian Eaton's best work, which is truly disappointing as this may have been one of the books that I was looking forward to the most and which had the potential to be one of the best.I liked a lot of the book, I even liked Miles... up until the last quarter of the book.  Maybe Ms. Eaton got lazy.  Maybe she's just a more forgiving person than I am.  But she let him off way too easily.  "Four times" he puts his heart out on his sleeve for Diana... soooo one time for each year?  Whoop-de-doo.  Then he runs away like a pansy because she keeps saying no to him.  Of course she keeps saying no to him, she even tells him that she can't love him because she can't trust him not to leave.  Instead of PROVING that he can stick around, PROVING that she should be able to trust him.. what does he do?  He leaves!  WITHOUT TELLING HER AGAIN!!!!Which apparently somehow makes him worthy of being chased after?  I don't think so.  She should have realized she was well shot of him and gone on to marry someone else who was actually worthy of her.  Someone who was willing to fight for her.  For all Miles' talk of how much he loves her, he chooses his horse over her at one point (it had a fever... it's called grooms.), he doesn't do anything to court her (no flowers, no determined wooing, just some attempts at seduction which is NOT the same thing) and he never REALLY grovels to her for abandoning her to her family and the censure of Society.All in all, he is still taking her for granted by the end of the book.  But she's will to accept that, so I guess she's going to get what she deserves... a husband that's undeserving and doesn't appreciate her the way he should and was never willing to really fight for her, because she never made him.Honestly, I really hope that one day Ms. Eaton rewrites this book and makes Miles into an actual hero instead of a spineless, useless, unappreciative a$$ that is so far from being worthy of Diana that it's not even funny.

Such a great follow-up to the first book!I'm a big fan of Amanda Lee's Witches and Avery Shaw series (although, admittedly, I could NOT get into her young adult series... hated the main character in that) and it looks like she's got me hooked on a new one now.Definitely read the first book before trying this one, because there's a lot of background about reapers that you need to know, as well as about Aisling's rather unique family.  If you like snarky dialogue, nosy brothers, alpha male overload, and a seriously sassy heroine, then you need to check this series out.  I've tried other reaper series and been turned off by the magic or the exposition, but Ms. Lee weaves the mythology and facts that you need in order to swallow your suspension of disbelief through snappy quips and lots of action to keep the reader interested.As a follow-up book, we get to go deeper into Aisling's family situation, AND we get to learn a lot more about Det. Griffin - even meeting a family member!  Can I just say, I freaking love Griffin????  He's got a ton of patience, and at the same time manages to hold his own with Aisling's family, occasionally giving out the affectionate verbal abuse as fast as he gets pummeled with it.  I really love that this book shows a lot of Aisling just trying to do the mundane business of her job, while being sidetracked by more wraiths, more little mysteries and more murders.I also really appreciate that a new character brings in some great insight into Aisling and the way her family works.  It's easy, at times, to dismiss Aisling's behavior as childish, and there was one point when I was shaking my head and thinking WHY IS SHE SO STUPID?! I was almost disappointed at Ms. Lee, because it seemed like she was being stupid for the sake of being stupid, but then the side character brought up some really good points as she was basically psychoanalyzing Aisling and her family, and I immediately was like "Oh... okay, good points."  I'm totally okay with behavior that verges on idiocy as long as there's a reasonable explanation behind it that makes the character's motivations plausible and not just a convenient plot point.  Ms. Lee is RIGHT on top of it with providing that explanation.More girl fights with Angelina, more delightful nights with Jerry, more family confrontations, and a rousing game of Shark Attack (which... I am dying to get my friends drunk enough to convince them to play it with me...) and there's plenty to laugh about through the book as you wait for the mystery to be solved.The best part?  No cliffhanger ending.  There IS some information that comes up at the end which is like OMG and of course I can't wait to see where that information is going to lead in the next book, but it's not a frustrating / things are unexplained kind of cliff hanger ending.  Which is one of the nice things about reading this series - I'm not MAD at the end of the book.  I'm satisfied with the way things wrapped up but looking forward to the next book (a lot).  It's the best way to feel at the end of a book - and highly unusual for a serial.

Here's the thing. I really wanted to like this book.  It sounded like it was going to be so good.  It started off so promising.  The writing style is well done.  The opening is well done.  The characters are well done... right up until Jada STOPS being a strong, sassy woman and throws herself into Brandon's arms only a page or two after she's all "he's not the golden boy to me... I'll never trust another man because of him"  etc etc.  With good reason too.  So, without even an explanation as to why he left her high and dry, which led to quite a bit of bullying and making her absolutely miserable, or even a freaking APOLOGY, he's holding her hand and then they're getting it on.  WHERE DID STRONG JADA GO?!Okay, so that means that AFTER the sexy times, they're going to talk and she's going to get an apology and an explanation, right?WRONG.They're getting it on again only minutes after she thinks she caught him getting it on with another woman.  Although, I suppose one way to find out if a guy has had his face between another woman's legs is to kiss him and see if you taste her... like... come on.  We all know that's not why she did it.  She just "couldn't resist him".Well this book would have been a lot better if she had.  This book needed tension.  Sexual and emotional.  There was absolutely none, because the second Brandon shows up, Jada forgets all of her convictions, she forgets all of her trust issues, and it's like she's a totally normal woman who's smitten with him.  What's the point of building up her character in the beginning if that's not who she really is?!  It would have been an AWESOME book if Brandon had actually had to do all the things that he thinks he's going to have to do - like groveling, winning her trust, winning her love.  Instead, she basically just throws her trust, love and body at his head within a couple of hours of him showing up in town.  No apologies, explanations or groveling necessary.As second chance books go, this one was a flop... right from the moment the couple flopped into each other's arms rather than actually building anything between them.

This was a fairly decent novella, except for the fact that with the amount of story going on, it really should have been a full length novel.  I enjoyed most of the read, but almost every aspect (except the erotic) left me wanting MORE.There's a dating service... but we barely get a glimpse of how it works, other than Mrs. Wilder making decisions based on whether or not Talia might be attracted to Connor and Theron and whether she'd be open-minded to a threesome.  I wanted to know more about this dating agency that's run out of the feisty old woman's home.There's an evil ex... but why exactly is he evil?  I'm not entirely sure.  We get a VERY short glimpse of him being a jerk to Talia, but there's never any real explanation about why they broke up, what took the "blinders off of her eyes" as to what he was really like, or how her family has shut her out since then.  She talks about it a lot, but we never really get to SEE it because even when she goes to her cousin's bridal shower and wedding, she has NO interaction with any of them whatsoever.  Not even them giving her dirty looks or speculative looks or even just straight out ignoring her...  We don't even really get to hear about Paul (the evil ex) interacting with her family.  Which is a big part of my basic problem with this novella, it was a lot of "tell" and not "show," which made it feel very rushed because there's so much telling going on.Even the closure on the ex is kind of lackluster, because Granny just gets feisty with him and kicks him out... why hasn't she done this before if she loves Talia so much?  Why is this the first time that she's stood up for her granddaughter to her family?  And we also STILL don't get to see any of the family reaction.  No one says sorry or looks upset or defends Paul or looks guilty... it's just this blank silence on the family front.Despite this being a shifter novella, that doesn't really come up until the end of the book.  We HEAR about how the women of the Pack are going to be upset, and how they're petty and mean and the guys aren't interested in any of them.... but we don't see any of them until literally the last chapter.  There's not a lot of explanation beforehand about how Talia's supposed to prove herself, or even the fact that she IS going to turn into a werewolf (which I was a bit confused about, because Connor and Theron had been so concerned that she was human).  It seems like the challenge laws are set up so that any human turned werewolf is going to fail, but Talia turns so quickly that the Pack is impressed... at least I think that's why they all ended up caving in without any real expected trouble?  It was all a bit confusing to be honest, by the time it got to that point, because there'd been no chance to see the Pack dynamics at work before this very last, very rushed chapter.Overall... I enjoyed a lot about this novella.  Except for the fact that it was a novella, had enough story and characters to be a book, and so ended up feeling both rushed and unsatisfying.  It won't stop me from reading Milly Taiden, because I love her books, but I do wish that she'd either put more time or less story into this novella, and done a lot more showing instead of telling.  This was not one of my favorites of hers.

This book COULD have been5 Stars if the author hadn't gotten lazy at the very end and decided to go with a stupid romance trope instead of actually finishing out the emotional journey that the characters were on.It takes a lot of skill to write a sympathetic cheating character, but Immad was on his way to being one.  He was typically arrogant, just like an alpha ruler would be expected to be, and it was obvious from the conversations with his family and the people around him that none of them expected him to be faithful to Mersiha, even after their marriage.  But he still wanted to be, once they were married.  In such a culture, it's fairly understandable that he kept his mistress until he was formally engaged.  Mersiha's response is just as understandable and I was cheering for her all the way... I was even starting to cheer for him a little bit too until the author decided she was done having Immad actually trying to make up for his previous transgressions.Not only does he start treating Mersiha coldly again, because for some reason in his brain that's a better plan than continuing to shower her with his love and affection and proving to her that he's not going to change his mind about wanting to be with her and only her, but then instead of even continuing the play out that tangent and seeing where it takes the characters.... oh no! there's been an accident!  His life is in danger!  And of course the requisite vows of love come out.*gag*This book was headed towards something truly unique and fantastic and then the author just RUINED all of it.  It reeks of laziness, which was especially upsetting because the emotions and characters had been so well thought out and wonderfully rounded until then.  I was really enjoying watching a male alpha actually paying for his mistakes and doing his best to make up for them.  Then I realized how little book I had to go... and I was like oh no... please don't tell me she's going to... *(&*(^3@#$%@... she did it.Laziest and most overdone romance trope of all time to the rescue.  Except that this book didn't need that rescue, Immad was doing a fine job on his own if he'd just kept it up in the face of M's punishments.  Which made it all the more disappointing and unsatisfying to reach the end and the supposed HEA.

I've always had an interest in WWII and especially the sociological and psychological implications of the horrors that were perpetrated and how it was made possible by the culture.  This book delves into the psychology of Goering, the highest ranking member of the Nazi party who was put on trial at Nuremburg, and focuses on the cross-examination.Ms. George does an excellent job of setting up a thorough background of Goering's life, the war, the prosecutors, and the events leading up to Nuremburg, without the book becoming bogged down in exposition.  It's easy to read and easy to understand, and, once the trial starts, every chapter has some explanation before the transcript of the cross-examination, which made it much easier for me to understand the context in which this cross-examination was happening.  The content is rather chilling, but it's also an important glimpse into the mind of one of Hitler's highest ranking men.  In the forward, the author says that she usually writes fiction, but she's done a fantastic job of the non-fiction genre and making it both understandable and interesting.  Transcripts by themselves can often be dry and tedious; set in this book, they're so much easier to read and comprehend.***Free copy of the book received in exchange for an honest review***

omg this book just about gave me a heart attack.First of all, if you've been reading this series, you're already invested in the two main characters.  Chelsea, who is both broken and a big b!tch, and sooooo needs the support and happiness that her sister Charlotte found with Ian.  On the other side is Simon, who has been pretty hunky and appealing since the very first time he was introduced, and has only gotten even more mouth-watering with his patient stalking of Chelsea.  Learning more about Simon was possibly my favorite part of this book, because he's always been such a closed character.  With Chelsea, there was always more information about her because Charlotte knew her so well, although I learned quite a bit about her during this book also.  Seeing her finally become the strong, giving person that was always hiding behind her walls was such a treat.Although it was also super frustrating.  Simon had his work cut out for him with those walls, and just when he thinks he's gained ground... she's running again.  She's got some good reasons, but she also deserves the reaming out that she finally gets from Charlotte and goodness was it good to watch that go down!  Even better was her reaction afterwards, and then Ian's reaction to her reaction.  Man I love that big guy.  Simon had his own issues of course, and a background story that I would have NEVER guessed at.  We get to meet some of his cousins, who are a riot, as well as (eventually) his parents and brother.But that's not all!  We've got lots of danger as Chelsea is hunted by the Collective, lots of Jesse being an adorable ball of Crazytown murder (and I don't know why I find that so cute), and we've got TWO NEW TAGGERTS that Tennessee Smith has been keeping from Ian & Sean.  That's right, Big Tag and Little Tag have two little brothers that they never knew about and they're part of Ten's Agency team... let's just say, Ian does not take the news that Ten has been hiding family members from him so well and I cannot WAIT to see him throw up his big middle finger to Ten as he pulls his brothers into his family.  Because that's what Ian does, and that's what this entire book was about - family (both biological and the family of the McKay-Taggert team, because we all know that's what they are), second and third chances, and finding out what's worth dying for - and maybe even living for.Although, I have to say...  Lexi Blake... I almost kind of hate you because I had a feeling that the epilogue was going to be exactly what it was and NOW I HAVE TO WAIT UNTIL FEBRUARY FOR RELIEF!!!!!!!!!! You evil, wonderful, sadistic author... just like all the subbies at the club, I want more!

If you've read the other Delroi Prophecy books, you were probably like me and wondering what the heck happened with Anna Leigh and Zora's brother, and you wanted more of a conclusion than what Book 3 provided.  This is where we get that.It's not as detailed a book as the first three in the Prophecy series, maybe because Ms. Hunt figured we already knew most of the details, but I do think that the book suffered a little because of that.  That's why I'm only giving four stars instead of five.  The plot felt rather rushed, as did the character development.  I still don't entirely understand what was going on with Xan's cousin and her mate.  It was confusing and it made me wonder if I needed to go back and re-read book 3 to remember what had happened there, which I didn't like.  Considering how involved Xan was with his family and that he was eventually wounded because of the situation, I felt like it should have been more fully explained in THIS book.  I also felt like more time could have been taken between Xan and Anna Leigh on the spaceship, so she could learn more about him and his family and culture... and I didn't like that the meeting between her and one of his old girlfriends was kind of made into a big deal, and then we never really got to see what her feelings about Lady R. were after the meeting.  Which... is kind of important since the three of them were all going to be in-laws.Overall, however, it did do what I wanted.  I learned more about Anna Leigh's perspective, I got to see her and Xan's relationship blossom - which was great because I really liked him in Book 3 and wanted to see how that all came about.  We get the final rescue of Zora's brother and the beginning of the next part of his story, as well as a glimpse as to what Ms. Hunt has planned for the future.  But I felt like it could have been a more fully fleshed out book, one that could stand on its own.  Instead, it feels more like a way point between the real books in the series.

The plot was interesting enough, but I couldn't finish the book because it felt like my head was going numb from all the terrible dialogue.  Seriously, NO ONE talks like that.  And the amount of exposition that was shoved into the dialogue... ugh.  So much talking, not enough action, and the talking was soooooo stilted.  I couldn't take it anymore.  I could barely get one fourth of the way through the book and I kept trying to push through, but by the time she and Matthews are telling each other more of the visions (rather than let us seeing what's going on), I was ready to bang my head against the wall.  Even when she's dreaming about things from the past, she dreams more stilted conversations filled with yet more exposition. Ugh.

While the author had a fairly decent writing style (although is also in need of an editor), I just couldn't get fully involved in this story.  Thankfully I got it for free from Kindle Unlimited, because I don't think I would have wanted to pay for it.There was really good potential for this book.  There were a couple of mysteries going on - why did the Cruentas clan want to kill Gabby?  Who was killing off cubs?  But there were also just too many things that didn't add up, and the two main characters... well their relationship just didn't make sense to me at ALL.  It was basically based on nothing more than animal attraction.  They didn't seem to particularly like each other, they didn't have anything in common, and throughout the entire book, Zane is still hung up over his ex.  I mean, yeah, she cheated on him and left him for another dude... I get that it might be hard to see her for a while, but the way he's hung up on it isn't anger or anything like that, it's like he's still in love with her.  Even after he meets Gabby.  Even after he and Gabby start making out.  Even after he realizes he doesn't want Gabby choosing anyone else for a mate.  Nope, he still can't quite get over Alicia.  It's... not attractive.  On top of that, he's the worst Casanova ever.  His idea of wooing Gabby seems to be jumping her bones.  There were a lot of times that I found her personality to be somewhat unpleasant, but honestly I can't blame her for being a big B to him.  I'm just surprised she let him succeed as much as she did.Then the main plot... even though the whole mystery around cubs being killed is talked about throughout the book, it's wrapped up in a neat little bow that's not all that neat because we don't get to see ANY of the finding out whodunnit or the resolution to that.  Then the whole thing about why Gabby is so powerful and wanted... it drove me up the WALL that she has this awesome moment when her inner alpha power pushes back some of Zane's clan, which is how they know what she is, but it NEVER happens when she's upset and yelling at her attackers to leave her alone?  Seriously?  It happens ONCE and it's not even when she's in danger.  HELLO illogical plot device.There's a lot of potential in this book, but it could have been much better done if the story had been more fleshed out and the clans more fleshed out and everything better thought out.  I would have liked to see more of the suitors actually trying to woo her.  More relationship building between her and Zane (or you know, any at all that doesn't involve sexy time), which would have also helped with her final decision on who she wants to be a mate with.  Would have been nice to see her use her awesome powers when she's being attacked, make her a harder prospect to kill.  As it is, everything just feels rushed and open ended.

This is my favorite so far in the Casebook of Barnaby Adair!!!Ms. Laurens did a fantastic job combining the old and the new with this one.  Thomas Glendower aka. Malcolm Sinclair is an old character, but with a new lease on life.  If you've read the Cynster series and the Bastion Club series, then you'll remember him... and honestly, I wasn't sure that it was going to be possible to make him a redeemable character, but by the end of it I was proud of him.This book harkens back to the Cynster series in a lot of ways - not because it includes a lot of Cynster characters (other than the Adair characters of course), but in how it's written.  Rather than jumping right into the case, we get to see Thomas Glendower making himself into a new man and then taking his first steps back out into the world where he meets Rose.  The little hints and revelations that not all is right with his new housekeeper come slowly, and (as much as I tried) I couldn't figure out what they added up to.Unlike the other Casebooks, this one focuses more on the relationship between the lovers than on the mystery.  And Thomas and Rose are wonderful.  There's a lot less focus on the Adairs and Stokes, and more on Malcolm and Rose - and with several of the sumptuous love scenes that Ms. Laurens is well known for.  While Malcolm might not be a sexy alpha tyrant on level with Devil Cynster, it's still a pleasure to read about his and Rose's burgeoning relationship.The mystery itself was incredibly well handled.  I was kept guessing all throughout the book.  It was nice to have the characters sharing my confusion.I thought this was the perfect blend of the old books that I loved from the Cynster series and the new, exciting mysteries from the Casebooks.  Definitely recommend!

Honestly this wasn't what I expected and I came away with fairly mixed feelings about it.On one hand... I really liked that it the ending wasn't at ALL what I expected (and I'm not going to give anything away about it except that).On the other hand... I felt like there was something missing between all three of the characters.  I think part of me had expected more punishment scenes between husband and wife - there were really only a couple - and the scenes between the wife and her lover weren't all that hot after the first one.  I also wish there had been more scenes of passion between the husband and wife, or at least some more scenes between them at all to help with the character / relationship development.It's not my favorite by Ms. Belford, but I did enjoy quite a bit of it... I just think it could have been a lot better.

Ugh... this book is filled with Dominants who are just terrible.  Like... seriously.Emerald's protector and mentor, Daddy Drake, who has no interest in her sexually apparently decided that she's "too much" for any of the Doms at the club to handle her, and so he won't let any of them approach her for scening.  Not that he tells her this; nope, she just thinks that no one's interested in her at all and hasn't been for FOUR YEARS.  And somehow it's a shock to him that she's suffering from low-confidence and insecurity?  Seriously?  Then, he also loses his temper with her and uses humiliation as a punishment - even knowing that it's a hard limit for her.  I don't care what she did, he even admits later that he knows it's something he should have never done to her - not that he'll apologize for that until she apologizes for running off when he does it.  She's so freaking desperate to please and he uses that and manipulates her with it.Then, when she finally meets Sir Drool (who has been featuring in her dreams for years now, along with his dead wife who encourages Emerald to find him), he inserts himself into a scene with her, is angry at himself and treats her like crap at the end of it.  Then she starts avoiding callings from Daddy Drake - who gets super pissed without even considering where she is emotionally after that.  He was there for the smackdown, he SHOULD have done his duty as a Dom and done something to reassure and take care of her THEN, instead of just calling and accepting her excuses.  Nope, he gets all pissy about her reactions, so she has to apologize for that too eventually.  Sir Drool sends one of her friends who basically drags her back to the club where she spends the night in a locked room.  She does this for two nights in a row, pissed and tired of being treated like sh!t (which is completely reasonable) and then Ghost-Wife comes to her in another dream and helps her to realize that she needs to accept what the Doms are doing and act like a submissive.This is when Mika finally apologizes to her for being a jerk.What the heck happened to the communication between ANY of these characters?  The Doms make decisions that they don't have the right to, manipulate Emerald all over the place, make her apologize for things that she really shouldn't have to, and overall just keep pushing her into the shape of a doormat.I was not a fan.  I suggest Cherise Sinclair if you want to read a good BDSM romance with Doms that actually treat their submissives with respect and love, instead of just mouthing the words constantly while not backing it up with their actions.

I LOVE Prisma colored pencils! I love colored pencils anyway, and these- with Crayola many years ago- are the only ones I've encountered that have not had SAND in them.About 15 years ago, I got a set of 120 Prisma colored pencils, and love it. But! I am currently getting into adult coloring as an alternative to meditation, and so when I saw THIRTY MORE COLORS!!!!- I was intrigued.What I like: the extra colors; the fact that the pencils are more-or-less sorted chromatically as packaged; having them come partially sharpened.What I dislike: my set of 120 had a tiered box in which all colors were visible all the time. This one with 150 colors has instead flimsy plastic trays that have an unfortunate tendency to explode one's pencils all over oneself; also, these trays are stacked on top of each other so one cannot see the full range of available colors.Still- great quality, and great colors!

This is #6 in the series, and it's going strong!Here, Phryne puts aside her many class and wealth advantages to investigate a small circus, and manages to learn trick riding while she's at it!Much less involvement of her usual gang of friends- but that makes it interesting. The characters we meet here are complex and well-drawn, and i expect at least some of them will appear in subsequent books.An excellent book in a great series! nd if you did not want to start with book #1, this one would probably make more sense as a beginning.

This is a rather odd assortment of things in a travel sewing kit, but mostly useful.I like: various colors of thread; assorted needles; a small scissors (though this might be a problem with airport security); and the needle threaders.Makes me go "huh?": TWO needle threaders; only 2 straight pins and 1 safety pin vs a whole bunch of needles; no pale/med/dark gray thread which can be used to mend most anything.Supplement with an assortment of safety pins, and maybe more straight pins, and you'll probably be OK. Even as is, though, it's potentially handy for emergency situations. I have put this in my luggage.

This was a good sequel to "Unseen", and developed both the world and Mac's character more.Unfortunately, the Big Bad seems to be Big and Bad without any specific agenda; while they are terrorists, they do not seem to have a goal besides being terrorists. Since no one is a villain in his/her own mind... they clearly ought to have some kind of goal besides "power!"- but that isn't clear, and so the terrorist acts they commit do not make any particular sense as means to a goal.I do like the way Erickson handles the mind-reading, and the world in which it exists.However, in this sequel the characters were less important and well-drawn, and combined with a fairly basic plot it was not as enticing as the first book in the series. I am not at all sure I'll continue with it.I received this book for free via the author's website.

Gorgeous, fragrant, wonderful coconut oil! And at an attractive price, because this is a HUGE jar!I've been using it for several weeks now, mainly for cooking and cosmetic purposes. It's great! As winter approaches (it's November here in MA), my skin dries out, and not only does this oil absorb quickly, it smells lovely (though it does remind me of the Pina Colada song!).It's equally good for cooking, especially curries. If the dish has coconut milk, it reinforces the flavor; if not, it';s very subtle but does enrich the taste.I have not yet used it for cosmetics or soaps, but I think it has great promise for these as well.Highly recommended, if you like coconut oil and especially when you use it for multiple purposes!I got this in exchange for writing an honest review, but once I use this jar up I'll buy it again.

Mind reading is tricky to handle in fiction- either the the mind-reader Knows All, or is a basket case because of too much input.Erickson handled this really well. She dealt with what it would actually mean to read minds, and how difficult that would be until and unless one develops ways to control it.And if there were mind readers, there would definitely be various schools of them, mostly at odds.I think this was more novella length than novel length, but it was a fast, suspenseful and engaging read, as Mac finds others who share her gifts, and learns the advantages and perils of having such a power.I received this for free from the author's website, and do recommend it to those who find this intriguing- it's well done.

Set in the 1930s, in the Twin Cities area of Minnesota, this story in Ted Korsmo's Wayzata can accurately be described as both hard-boiled and noir. Korsmo made considerable efforts to keep the locales and the language historically correct, as far as I could tell; having grown up in the area 60 years later, I enjoyed getting an idea of what various areas like North Oaks, Uptown and the titular Wayzata were like back then.Unfortunately, these were this book's strongest points.I like noir (though I prefer it with some black humor thrown in), and I enjoy following the twists and turns when everyone is gaming everyone else. For this to work, though, the plotting and characterizations both need to be very strong indeed ... and here neither were. Therefore the plot seemed utterly arbitrary, and character actions and interactions that drove the plot were baffling. It is not good when a sudden relation of, perhaps, a hitherto-unknown connection between major characters is met with "Huh???" rather than "Man! I should have guessed!" In such complex scenarios, some foreshadowing can be a big help in making a plot plausible.As can coherent, consistent characters. I expect Korsmo himself can picture them all with all their individual nuances, but he did not succeed in communicating such, even when situations were ripe to do so. Thus, everything anyone did felt arbitrary, and rather than continuing to reveal aspects of character, every surprising turn made me feel slapped by a dead fish.The language was also an issue. While I give Korsmo great credit for incorporating so much period slang and wordings into the text, he rather overdoes it, sometimes to the point of incomprehension. Call cigarettes "nails" if you will -- but please make the context clear the first couple of times you call them such, and do not substitute pretty much every other possible slang name and never, ever call them "cigarettes"! I've read books written when this was set, and they used slang more judiciously.Most of the novel is first-person by our hard-boiled detective. He is not one for introspection, though, so we see pretty much nothing of his inner life. Maybe that's the point? He does seem to have an excessively fine opinion of himself, particularly his physical handsomeness, which he himself tells us all about. Neither he nor the author seem to notice his obsessiveness, or play at all with how a job to shadow someone is similar to stalking.In short -- while I like the idea, I do not think this novel has sufficient charms to make it worth reading despite its numerous flaws.I received this book in exchange for writing an honest review.

To Lady with Love is a very personal and intimate album. Annie Ross's vocals are spoken/sung, and the guitar work from Bucky and John Pizzarelli is superb and equally personal in execution. The whole album was recorded in one 4.5-hour session, and that shows, too -- there is nothing over-produced here, just excellent music from excellent artists, with a spontaneous feel.The liner notes are interesting and informative, and there is also a DVD with interviews with all three artists that offers some additional context for the music.I strongly recommend this for jazz fans. Even if you're not, it's a solid album.I received this CD in exchange for writing an honest review.

This is an amazing novel, that combines wonderfully written personal relationships with historical fiction, a police procedural, and a serial killer...not to mention the ghosts!The plotting and the pace are perfect, and the historical aspects so evocative that I almost felt I lived in San Francisco a few  years after the earthquake...But the strongest aspect is the characters. Not only are the POV characters complex, sympathetic, and interesting, but so are all the other ones; they all come to life, even ones that are only briefly mentioned.I like that it did not have pat answers for things like- what sparked the serial killer's murderous rampages? and how, exactly, do the ghosts fit in? For both, there are suggestions made, but no definitive answers, and I think that's appropriate.While there is definitely some violence, most of it is in the background, and the overall feel is more creepy than anything else.Very much recommended!

The plot has it all: social media, WoW-style game, hacking, IPOs, murder, human trafficking... and that's perhaps rather more than the plot can handle comfortably. Any one or 2- or even 3- of these could fit together to make a very tight, exciting plot... but here, they distract from each other.I could see a solid plot involving social media, human trafficking, and an IPO. I could see one involving the online game, murder, and human trafficking. Or pretty much any combo of the above. But- when they are all thrown into the same jar, one does not get a smoothie as much as a mish-mash; as soon as the plot seems to be going in any one direction toward resolution... it changes course!The description of the antics behind an IPO were entertaining, and well-enough explained that I pretty much understood them. Some of the other technical parts, though, made utterly no sense to me, and seemed to be vital to the plotline(s).The characters were reasonably well-drawn, though the book brings in aspects of their lives that have no relevance to the plot, like the banker's daughter who is going to shoot a porn film. I was curious as to how that would tie in and it just- did not.It was an exciting and pretty engaging book; I just wish that after I finished it, it had made more sense.I received this ebook in exchange for writing an honest review.

I have been using my old plastic Amazon water bottle for years. even though I know the plastic ones are not ideal.This is a great replacement!It does not leak at all, and the water is safely in stainless steel. There's a handy button that makes it ready to drink, with a convenient spout.It also has a handy loop that one can attach to one's bike or whatever.Very nicely designed!It does make some chirping noises when one sucks water out of the spout. These intrigue our dog mightily.I received this in exchange for doing an objective review.

If you don't like farces, read no further. This is definitely a farce.While Curtright takes a light approach to everything, some scenes stand out. I utterly adored the 5th grade class who were all Objectivists (until it came time for trick-or-treating), and their Rand-worshipping teacher's description of a RATIONAL Halloween party. Also, the "play" of Pioneer Days-done instead of the possibly Satanic Halloween- was a hoot.It IS a farce, and no one really comes off well... but they are all entertaining. And meanwhile it skewers standardized testing as the ONE way to determine whether kids are learning anything; fertility clinics; Ayn Rand style Objectivism (especially as implemented by fifth-graders); and meddlesomeness in general.All the characters are more caricatures than real people- but that's part of the point, and they are amusing.If you like humorous "cozy" mysteries, you'll probably enjoy this, despite the sad lack of murders.I got this for free via Kindle First, and definitely enjoyed it.

I have tried to resist- our House Rule is no Xmas until after Thanksgiving- but could not. Yes, readers, I started coloring this, and it's merely Nov 12!The designs are very enticing and mostly complex, so it will last me for several years of seasonal enjoyment. I like that each design has both tiny intricate spaces, and larger ones in which one can do ombres and shadings.The designs are secular, not religious: feathers, pinecones, stands of birches with deer and cardinals, tree ornaments, etc. No Nativity scenes!I look forward to having a lot of fun with this book!

This may be the best thus far in Shinn's "Elemental Blessings" series! The pacing, the characters, the plots, the world- all worked together to make a seamless, compelling whole.Corene- an annoying character from the previous books- sets off for parts unknown (with her family's disapproval), and in so doing, learns a lot about herself and the world, and how she can interact with the world as it is.But that sounds all too educational! There is flirting! There are mysteries, including murder mysteries! There are even action-adventure sequences! There are satisfactory marriages arranged, based on the idiosyncratic needs and desires of various characters, and their countries!Also- great political intrigue, sometimes with unexpected results.Corene really came alive here, and the other characters as well. A lot of the plot(s) were character-driven, so that really intensified things.I love Shinn's writing. I love the characters here! and the world, and all the plotting makes sense.Very recommended, and I think one would not have to read the previous 2 books to enjoy this one.

This is a physically lovely book that features food that hobbits would love, properly divided into their 7 meals of the day! (There is also an index in the back.)Besides the recipes- all photographed, it has photographs of Shire-like places, pictures of the "source materials" and the story about how they were found, and lovely botanical illustrations.The recipes themselves are based on British home cooking and look delicious- and mostly pretty easy. An exception is the brewing recipes, which require equipment and knowledge of basic brewing of beer and/or mead... but which look very intriguing! Brewing supply vendors ought to be able to supply some of the less-common ingredients for some other recipes, too, like the dried elderflowers.All told, there are maybe 50 recipes here, and I am including the separate recipes for, say, piecrust and pie filling, dumplings to accompany the stew, etc. That's not a lot for a book that costs what this one does, but they are all enticing- and the book itself is lovely!The notes say the recipes are based on historical ones from the 1890s in rural England.Recommended for cooks who are LotR fans, or interested in fairly accessible historic recipes.

This is the seventh in the series, which I am not reading in order. This series, though- while I'm sure it's richer if read in order!- does not really require that...although for this volume, some familiarity with the basic set-up is helpful.While I loved the atmosphere, and learning more about the ongoing characters, this was not as satisfactory as a mystery as the others I have read in this series. The overall plot seemed arbitrary, and Simon was utterly revolting; I expect he will feature in subsequent novels. Most of the characters we are following just get a brief look-in; I think that's a major part of what made it less satisfying for me.Still, the medieval atmosphere is skillfully drawn, and the details of medieval church drama were fascinating.Mildly recommended.

This is the final book in the "Finishing School" series, and I recommend it highly- but only after you've read the first 3. I like this series better than Carriger's "Parasol Protectorate" series, to which this one is something of a prequel.I'm a sucker for boarding-school novels- SO different from my life! Plus, I read etiquette books for fun (though this is not required to enjoy this series!). The steampunk elements give it extra energy and fun.Ria is a solid character, that is her own person even as readers can identify with her. The other characters are also both coherent and surprising. The plot is complex, of course, albeit a bit silly... but that's in keeping with the overall light tone of the novels; it is hard to take seriously Evil Villains called the Picklemen, whose head is called "the Chutney". And here, it works!So, if you like light novels and favor boarding-school tales (like Harry Potter) with serious action-adventure, read this series!

I love this series so much, I have to be careful in doling it out to myself! I want it to last!(My edition, bought 10-2015, is complete. If you get one that is missing pages, I'd suggest either returning it to Amazon or contacting Poisoned Pen Press directly.)This is an excellent mystery, piquing my interest in both the origins of jazz, the legal riskiness of homosexuality (male), and some of the effects of the Great War on the men that fought in it.As with the previous books, while some of the content is heavy, the books themselves have a verve that honors the heaviness but still has fun- much like Phryne herself.Phryne is superb, of course! And I love seeing and learning more about her various associates, all of whom are well-drawn and interesting people in their own right.The plots are nicely elaborate and convoluted, and resolve satisfactorily in ways i could not call- much- beforehand. Kudos! (Because I have been reading mysteries for at least 45 years, since childhood, and I really love ones that still surprise me.)Very recommended for fans of the series, in either TV or book form... but I'd start at the beginning. This may be one of the better stand-alines of the ones I've read, though.

These designs are fun and very Halloween-y... but are not nearly as complex as are in many of the other adult coloring books around.This is either a plus or a minus, depending on what you like!I prefer the crazy elaborate, intricate designs, but I know that's not to everyone's taste- and this book does give one more flexibility in doing shading and ombre, if one likes that.It also has fewer designs- around 33- since it's a slender book and the pages are printed on only 1 side. The one-sided printing might be really helpful for people who want to use markers and are concerned about bleed-though- I would suggest putting a layer of paper toweling or plastic under the page one is working on if using markers.Since the designs are less crazy-elaborate than many other books, it might be a good choice for teenagers- along with some GOOD colored pencils and a good sharpener.

The story has a lot of promise, and the plotting helps.Synopsis: a rogue vampire is causing a lot of problems in Philadelphia, with both the established vamp brood, the Mob, and the law. What to do?I like the shifting alliances, and that all 3 main groups have both (semi)admirable characters and loathsome ones. The Mob contingent was especially effective this way.Unfortunately, none of the characters really came to life themselves; they had their basic character descriptions, and then reacted more according to the needs of the plot than with internal motivations. I think Alves tried to bring more life to them- certainly his Mob boss is somewhat more complex than is usual for criminal kingpins- as is his second-in-command, Sophie....And that brings me to the main women, who are 100% physically gorgeous. Some are smarter than others- a decent differentiation- but they all start out as 10+++ on the looks scale. AND, what's more- even the most capable and intelligent ones are 100% willing to throw things over for Their Man (or Vamp, as the case may be). The secondary women can be shrewish, but are generally also well-nigh-perfect physically. What- no old women? None who have put on weight from all that Italian cooking they're doing?Back to the men: I don't really see Enzo, the Mob boss, having a lot of patience with the mess his subordinates seem to make fairly regularly. He went into the Mob vs legit biz because he couldn't stand the rules... and yet, as the Mob boss, he has no choice but to put up with pretty sketchy "soldiers", which he can't even effectively fire. We see less of management challenges with the law, but similar seems to happen there.And the vamps? It simply does not make sense that Magnus, the Head Vamp, would put up with so much crap from the rogue, especially when the rogue is directly challenging his leadership. Family? OK, maybe, at first. But if Magnus was half as good a leader as he is described as being, he would not let the rogue be the reason that half or more of his brood died. Especially considering the challenging.So there's a lot of it that is not great. I'll also add the copy-editing, or the lack thereof; lines are "toed" not "towed", unless you are shipboard, for example, and that's only one of many- the funniest was when Alves clearly meant "wine and dine", but instead it was printed as "whine and dine"- rather different!The language is often raw, but I'd expect that of gangsters. There is also much gore.In short: the premise and the shifting and morphing alliances are solid and fascinating. The characterization- especially combined with meeting the needs of the plot- and the writing, could both use work. It would help if behavior did not often seem so arbitrary.I received this book in exchange for writing an honest review.

OK, one can fairly easily cut corn off the cob with a knife...But this is so much easier and more efficient! Even when one does not use a drill in the corncob to expedite the process!Tonight our corn soup required removing the kernels from 6 ears of fresh corn. It took almost no time, and with a knife, would have been 5-10 min.The slicing round is adjustable, which means that each ear benefited from 2 passes... but since they took almost no time, that was cool.Very recommended for anyone who regularly removes corn from the cob!Edited to add: I note that many people have had problems with its sturdiness. It's working well for us, but we may have just been lucky. I do like the basic design, but be aware that some seem to be made better than others.

This is an enticing cookbook, suitable for everyone, with enticing, mostly fast and easy recipes that are nonetheless frugal- mostly because they de-emphasize meat.While there are a few time-consuming recipes, most are not- and there are tons of ideas for altering and re-combining elements to make new dishes. It's really more about an approach to cooking than about recipes per se... though the recipes look delicious!The directions are also very clearly written, so this is suitable for people of all levels of skill in the kitchen, including beginners.A particular benefit of buying this book is that Brown has committed to giving away one copy to someone in need for every one sold.I am lucky that I personally do not have to adhere to a strict food budget (but I still want to cook lots of these recipes!). It's even more important for people who do have a strict and limited budget, since it's way too easy to fall into the routine and boring; I remember those times.Unfortunately, it does not address people who are stuck in a food desert, which is a huge problem.Very recommended, both as an accessible basic cookbook that will improve skills for the novice, and for enticing recipes that are very cost-effective.Edited to add: The PDF of it is available for free on the author's website!

I love Boynton's work, and somewhere have the original 1982 edition of this book of hers.But this one is better! She says the drawing have been redone, and the text is longer and modernized.It is still silly fun, all about chocolate, with some informative interludes.Recommended for Boynton fans, and for whimsical chocolate lovers.

This is a very silly story, and I mean that in the best way possible.Our main protagonist, Toby, is in the 8th or 9th grade, and acts like it- including various stupid chpoices, like stealing stuff from his parents to sell to buy a fancy gaming computer. This brings a second plot into action... but the first is the way a foreign national is subverting the Science Fair in order to bring down the United States, with the aid and assistance of ambitious and unethical parents and kids.Naturally, everyone believes the rich kids, including the Feds. So it is up to our middle-schoolers to save the day!Unlike some of Barry's adult novels, this has no inappropriate content in terms of sex or language, so is suitable for most middle-schoolers and up- though as an adult, I found it a very entertaining read.Characterization was good; ridiculousness abounds; the plot(s) is/are complex and a bit farce-like, and there's a real snarky shout-out to Home Shopping Network.Recommended if you like silly farces!

I am apparently the odd one out, since I have not yet read "Just City" (it lurks in the depths of Mount TBR at the moment).Despite clearly missing all that background, though, this is an engaging and effective tale. There are enough references to important incidents in the first book that a savvy reader can catch  up on the gist, if not on the details.I have not read much of Plato's Republic, and am not exactly enthused about many of the aspects I have read. I particularly dislike and am suspicious of the caste system, as I am of the current caste system in the USA; I think it behooves governance to include the voices of all its citizens, not just the "golds".So- there are meaty philosophical issues raised here, and not answered directly- which is as it should be! This may be one of the most thoughtful "utopias" I've read; it's certainly the least didactic.The characters are engaging and complex, and interactions can get complicated- more like real life than they are in most novels.Which is not to say it lacks in action! It's got some tense action, as well as the thinkiness! The balance, I thought, was excellent.I really enjoyed this, and recommend it to people who like clear, lovely prose, and some serious philosophy with their sf/f action.

I expect I am dating myself, but if you liked "The Serial", you will like this.The promises of a genuine life can collide with the realities of what that means.I found this both sweet and funny- one of the better rom-com movies I've seen.Recommended for light fun.

I love this, and it seems to be working well!This is the second such product I've tried, and they each have their own advantages. Both seem to be very effective in discouraging carpenter ants during warm weather, which is a huge plus!And now that it's fall, I am hoping that they will discourage the usual annual influx of mice and wolf spiders into our house.Our cats and dog do not seem to be troubled by it, but I do have it set up in a place they mostly don't go.Anyway, so far it's working like a charm, and I am looking forward to it decreasing the number of interlopers we get as the weather cools off!I received this in exchange for trying it out and writing an honest review.Edited to add: It is now early November, with some very cold nights- and usually at this time of year we have mice in our walls. This year, none! So while I am uncertain how well it discourages bugs, it seems to be very effective indeed at discouraging mice.Also, the cats and dog are oblivious to it.

I know I am late to the Phryne fanclub, but I have become an avid member!This is the first of the novels I have read, and now I am eager to read many, many more.Phryne is possibly a bit too perfectly competent as a heroine, but is written well enough that I don't care. I also love the period details, and the secondary characters- all of whom spring to life as individuals.The plots are nicely complex, and do NOT mesh into one- a touch I liked, since too often apparently disparate plots all turn into one. That's clever when the authors pull it off... but I did like thzt this one had 2 distinct and not overlapping threads.Very recommended!

I have tried various Viva Labs products over the years, and have been very happy and impressed!This is no exception.I've tried probiotics before, but they did not seem to have any effect. (I also eat naturally fermented foods for similar reasons.)These though- I really like them. They caused no digestive unpleasantness, and indeed seem to be reducing such for me. Win!This is possibly because they say their capsules delay being digested in the stomach, to more effectively deliver the fauna to the gut. Or maybe it's the 6 strains; previously, the supplements I tried had maybe 4.In any case, I love them and will buy more when I run low. Very recommended for people who feel the need or desire for probiotic supplements.I got a sample jar in exchange for doing an objective review.Edited to add: I am nearing done on my initial jar, and am ordering more.

A woman is haunted in both dreaming and waking life by someone who lived around 100 years previously. Hallucinations? Ghosts? Memories of a prior life?This is coupled with various more mundane problems, such as her miscarriages, her disinterest in her job, an annoying set of tics in her right hand that prevent her from creating art (though not, apparently, from doing other things that require facility) and feeling a rift between herself and her husband.The pacing did not work for me.We start out with Jane, a modern American woman, who is having dreams and visions of Elizabeth, a Victorian British woman, as well as her spastic hand, her sleepwalking and sleep-drawing, etc.At first, this novel focused on Jane and her problems. But the middle third or so was all about Elizabeth, which is also a reasonably interesting story, but the author abandons Jane for that time.After Elizabeth dies (not a spoiler, because no Victorian woman would have survived to now), we revert to Jane, who just so happens to meet a spiritualist hypnotherapist with whom she has amazing results immediately, including a lot of the cliched "white light" and "There are NO coincidences!" -- which, frankly, strikes me as terrifying. In short order her various problems are resolved; she understands that everything has worked out for the best; and most of her social and family circle turn out to be compadres in a spiritual group dedicated to evolving toward the Light over the centuries. The first part -- Jane haunted by visions -- made sense. As it progressed, though, the novel became less and less plausible for one who does not share the spiritualism that the author depicts.Although the narrative is grounded by a lot of physical details, they are often not explained, and the consequences are often not addressed. Anyway, miracles for me need to be plausible miracles. This narrative is too disjointed to provide that. I wish it had been better; the premise is sound and it starts out promising, but derails.I received this novel via Rambles.net in exchange for a fair and honest review.

This review starts out similar to the Seidio Dilex case review.  Nice quality case. Kickstand stays closed when you're not using it. Soft touch material feels nicer than the smooth plastic of the Nexus 6. The kickstand could be a little more centered. What I mean is the kickstand is so far down on the phone that if you try to use the phone while it is in kickstand mode you can tip it over really easily especially when touching the phone on the end furthest from the kickstand. I don't care for my use but for someone who maybe touches their phone a lot while in kickstand mode this case might annoy you due to that. Had they put the kickstand slightly more toward the center of the phone it may have improved the stability. Having said that, my absolute favorite part of this case is that where the kickstand is located there is a hump that sticks out. It is virtually impossible to see in the terrible stock photos on Amazon. This hump allows the phone to rest flat on a desk or table as if the back of the phone is flat. Now I can text or use the phone one handed with it resting flat on a table and it doesn't spin and wobble all over the place. I have a feeling that is why the kickstand is located where it is. The case cutouts are where they need to be. The headphone cutout is kind of small so that might be an issue depending on the plug of your headphones. Two different USB cables worked fine without being blocked. There is a cutout for the buttons.  They are not covered like on the Dilex case.  Protection appears to be on par with other similar slim cases. There is a lip around the front of the phone so if you lay it on its face it will rest on the case. The case is ever so slightly thicker than something like a Ringke but virtually the same.  One nice thing if the two part design makes this case very easy to remove.  Slim cases can sometimes be a nightmare to remove if they are one piece but the two part case solves that.  It stays together great and you can hardly tell it is actually two pieces when it's on the phone.  It is a two piece case with a soft touch hard shell outside and a felt like inside. Overall a very nice case. I uploaded a few better pictures so you can more clearly see the case and in particular the kickstand hump and how it affects the phone.

First time self filer.  I was going to use Turbo Tax based on past reports from people I know.  However, unlike most of my friends/family I need to fill out a schedule C.  After reading up on filing my own taxes this year I see Turbo Tax crippled their program and I would have to buy their most expensive package for my schedule C (1/3 of the price for the exact same thing... I wonder how many other youtubers will encounter this issue this year, lol).  H&R block has it covered so I decided to go with H&R.  Most likely this means H&R gets my business in the future as well since I doubt I will have a reason to switch.

As far as printing it seems to be fine.  Not as crisp or clear typed print as my laser printer but I guess that is to be expected.  It also takes a very long time (a couple minutes) to warm up if it hasn't been used in awhile.The reason I am giving it 2 stars is because I bought it specifically because it is Google Cloud enabled.  The only reason I bought this printer is to print from my phone.  However, if a few days have passed since I printed last it always is listed offline when I want to print something which means I have to go physically it up before the Google Cloud servers will communicate. This is extremely annoying if I want to print something while I am laying on my couch several rooms away or if I want to print something from my phone while I am out of the house.  There are no Firmware updates on Canon's site either and I bought the printer 5 months ago which means I doubt it will ever be fixed.Overall I am disappointed and wouldn't buy another Canon printer. My Brother laser printer has been a workhorse so I would probably try out that brand.

Nice watch once I found a good one.  I am picky about the second hand lining up with the marks.  I got mine at the big blue box store.  I went to several different stores and had to look at about 5 of this model watch to find one that had the second hand mostly lined up with the marks,  The worst watch had a second hand that was basically in between each second mark.  The manufacturing tolerances must be pretty loose so it might take a few tries to get one with a second hand that lines up properly.  It is to be excepted with a watch in this price range.  Even a $5,000 watch might have a second hand that doesn't line up.  I am just very OCD about it.I put this watch on a Maratac NATO style band and it looks great.
Worked to open a Citizen Eco-drive watch.  There was a spec of dust under the crystal and I had to open the back to be able to blow the dust out.  Seems well built.

You can tell it's an inexpensive tool made in China. The writing on it is even Chinese and the chrome finish isn't very nice looking. However, it works perfect for the small amount of use it gets. The 17mm end is the size needed for the front strut mount nut on a Mazda 3. The offset head allows the use of the Allen wrench to keep the strut from spinning while removing the nut. For $5 you can't go wrong and it makes removal so much easier than hacking together a solution.

This review is for the Spigen Slim Armor case (Since Amazon decided to combine all the Spigen cases for the Nexus 6 for some reason)The case arrived undamaged.  It fits my Nexus 6 perfectly.  There is no wiggle room or squish at all with the case.  It is easy to put on and take off if you tend to go without a case often or want to remove it to clean any dust off. The cutouts are all in the proper location and appear to be precisely cut.  The lip comes up around the edge of the phone enough that you could lay the phone down flat on its face and only the case will touch the surface you place it on.The hard plastic material is about as smooth/slippery as the back cover of the phone.  The thickness makes the phone much easier to hold so I don't feel like I am about to drop it like when the phone is not in a case.
