It turns out that it is at least true that the Chinese seafaring mariners had mapped the North America coast long before Columbus or the Vikings had touched the continent.But more to the earlier point, it was the French, not the English colonists, who were intrepid enough to use the Indians to help them explore the interior of North America, giving the French an enormous comparative advantage in the fur trade that lasted for a century. In fact, it was largely French maps that guided the Lewis and Clark expedition, not English maps.  The English Settlers were as scared and superstitious about venturing into the interior of the continent as were the men in this story were fearful of sailing the seven seas. Five Stars

Great addition to the travel pack for those frequent travelers who thought they had everything? Never have to worry about leaving an item on TSA security conveyer belt. Because with this bag, you can get all valuables in one easy to carry (and keep your eyes on) container --iPhones, iPads, passports, money clip, tickets, and everything in between.This bag is a fierce travel companion. I wouldn't leave the country without it. Five Stars
A fabulous product. Very high quality, durable, beautifully packaged and excellent operating instructions. Works well with iPhone-6 with bluetooth.I ordered two as Xmas presents.

Since reading Gerald Horne's earth-shattering book, "The Counter-Revolution of 1776," I have been on a vain search to find respectable (i.e., non-pandering) historical treatises that would overthrow his thesis: that the so-called "American Revolution" was in fact little more than a slyly-staged counter-revolution against the threat that the "patriots" might be forced to end slavery.So far, I have come up empty: Every respectable piece on the history of the period, including this book, simply further confirms Horne's mind-bending thesis. Here Alan Taylor, another award-winning American historian, in this book, "The Internal Enemy: Slavery and War in Virginia 1772-1832," confirms virtually everything Horne sets forth in his thesis -- and then raises him a chip or two by giving us the context with all of the missing moral nuances.There are two parts to the book: The story in the foreground about how the slaves in Virginia reacted to the shameful contradictions of the impending calls for "freedom and liberty" by the white slaveholding founding fathers (the Virginia quartet in particular of Washington, Jefferson, Madison and Mason), as the American Revolution approached.The slaves simply gathered as many of their family members as they could in canoes and rowed, in the middle of the night, out to the British ships anchored in Norfolk harbor and joined the Revolution and fought for the other side. Prominent among them were some 800 or so slaves from Jefferson, Paine, Madison and Washington's own plantations. Others grabbed their children and as a family jumped into the sea, committing mutual suicide rather than enduring the horrors of slavery for the rest of their lives.And then there is a second story, the one in the background, the subtext of events: the psychological state of mind -- the thinking, planning and plotting of Jefferson, Madison, Randolph, Paine, Washington, and others -- as they went about the business of building a libertarian case for a revolution against the British, while at the same time very self-consciously and violently repressing every instinct of liberty and freedom in their own black slaves.On page 83, for instance, Randolph summarizes the situation about as aptly as it can be done, when he says that "slavery is a social system that distorts the morality and justice of otherwise decent men ... It could not have endured without the support of attentive husbands, good fathers, pious churchgoers, and conscientious citizens ... It holds good men as well as slaves as its captives."It is thus inescapable that the Virginia patriots proceeded along this morally bankrupt path willingly and with a mixture of greed, hubris, deep fear both of their slaves and their God, yet with self-serving moral blindness and laxity towards a goal they claimed was about freedom and liberty.These men knew from the start that there simply was no way of squaring the circle between the barbaric practice of profiting by treating human beings as property, and also maintaining a self-respecting humanity for themselves. Yet they proceeded to prove themselves world-class hypocrites, while discrediting their humanity for all times.From these two stories, juxtaposed against the wider geopolitical and moral context of the revolution, the reader gets two stark pictures, the moral implications of which can no longer either be denied or defended, for it is not just unmistakable but also impossible to misread: In order to maintain slavery in a steady state, living morally blind and contradictory lives, there is no other way to put it except to say that our founding fathers had to be "much diminished moral human beings." And thus in the end, history too must ultimately judge them, as men of their own times judged them, as moral ingrates: moral villains instead of heroes -- men corrupted by greed for profits, hubris, racial prejudice and a lack of any sense of moral decency or accountability.In short, this book clears out all of the moral underbrush and leaves our founding fathers exposed, naked, out in a fully contextualized moral clearing. Unlike many other historians, who rationalize and make excuses for them (as Professor Roger Wilkins did below for instance), in both parts of this book, the author leaves the primary architects of the American Revolution, hanging in the wind, to sink or swim based only on the degree of their own moral culpability.He allows them no escape routes as he nails all of the facts down securely, giving us not just the facts -- as cold-blooded as they often are -- but also leaves nothing to chance by giving us their context with associated nuances too. In doing so, he lays the facts out end-to-end, without commentary or sentimental editorializing, allowing them to fall where they may, so that the reader can connect the dots and determine for himself, once and for all, whether the Virginia quartet were indeed heroes or villains.In this regard, I am repeatedly reminded of a similar book called "Jefferson's Pillow," by the nephew of Civil Rights leader Roy Wilkins. In it, Professor Roger Wilkins tried vainly to square the same moral circle of contradictions between the immorality of slavery and the false claims the American patriots made -- that they were fighting for freedom and liberty against a colonial tyranny.The best argument Professor Wilkins could proffer in the end to support his case was the old familiar cliched trope that "they were simply men of their times?" The irony that at the time he wrote the book, Dr. Wilkins was himself a Professor of Political science at "George Mason" University, did not escape me.But to this author's credit, that old dog "they were men of their times," will no longer hunt. Alan Taylor made the buck stop with this book: He never used that excuse here. For here the moral context of the times is laid bare for all to see. And the American patriots are condemned, not only by their own acts, but also by the commentary of very men of their times, men like them, who also had once been engaged in the degenerate business of buying and selling humans and then sitting back and living off the profits of their slaves' free labor.Moreover, all three of the major contending powers, France, England and Spain had freed their slaves and had agitated for ending the transatlantic slave trade. And while it is true that they were greatly urged along in these pursuits by the slave revolts that lit up the Caribbean, their hearts as well as their policies consistently leaned in the direction of freedom for everybody: If freedom was good for the white man, they all argued, then it was also good for their slaves too.Not so for the American Revolutionaries, as they consistently argued that even freed black men in America -- including those who had fought for the revolution on the side of the patriots, no less -- had no secure place of freedom in revolutionary America.In fact it was the French revolution that sparked the revolt in Haiti that would bring both France and Britain to their knees. And while Jefferson was busy fighting a coalition of French, Spanish and Indians on his western and southern borders, he nevertheless saw the slaves' revolution for freedom in Haiti as the much greater threat. So much so that he viewed his own slaves as "internal enemies," possessing the potential of exploding into revolt against the planters at any minute.As a result, Jefferson, among many other things he did to advance the causes of maintaining the slave system in place, also reversed the policy towards freedom in Haiti of the previous administration. Whereas John Adams had assisted the Haitian slaves' fight for freedom (as much as a way of undermining French efforts in the hemisphere, as to support the causes of freedom there), Jefferson, on the other hand, reversed Adam's course and did just the opposite, lending support to the very enemy he was busy fighting on his southern and western borders?Equally unconscionable, even while the British were giving citizenship, full pay and freedom to all slaves who would come over to their side and fight against the American Revolution, (as later was to happen in the Civil War), only when they were losing badly did the Americans allow freedmen and slaves to be armed to fight.And while some 500 slaves would be granted their freedom as a result of fighting for the American side, about 8000 who fought for Britain, began new lives as respected citizens in both Canada and Britain after the war. Some even wrote letters back to their old masters, telling them that they were doing much better in Canada than even their masters were doing back on the plantations in Virginia.But for the blacks who had won their freedom by having fought for the patriot cause and were on the winning side, a free black man living in Virginia was almost as bad off as were Virginia slaves. The Virginia quartet made it clear that freed black men were a greater threat to the peace than the slaves were themselves. In fact, Jefferson argued at the time, (as Lincoln would do too during the Civil War), that all blacks, both slave and free, should be shipped off to another country.However, this did not prevent Jefferson or other slaveholders from producing an annual crop of mulatto babies by raping their female slaves. Six such mulattoes acted as house servants in Jefferson's mansion. They were often mistaken by visitors as family members. And if recent DNA tests can be trusted, the chances are good that they were.To his credit, this author does not lean in either direction -- towards our founding fathers being either heroes or villains -- but allows the facts to speak for themselves. And when they speak, they roar like a 400-year old cold wind, howling against the deaf conscience of men claiming to be seeking freedom from British tyranny, but who in fact, only sought to continue the comforts that the barbarous and brutal system of slavery had provided for them.If the American patriots were indeed "men of their times" as Professor Wilkins claimed they were, then the "contradictions of those times," hit our founding fathers right between the eyes like a moral lightening bolt, leaving them scorched and nowhere to hide. There was no moral cover or shelter to be found between their professed rhetoric about liberty and freedom, and their everyday barbarous practices of slavery.The case against the American patriot has never been better put than the eloquent speech made by Frederick Douglass on July 4, 1852 in Rochester New York, where he ends his speech with the following flourish: "Your prayers and hymns, your sermons and thanksgivings — with all your religious parade and solemnity— are, to him (the slave), mere bombast, fraud, deception, impiety and hypocrisy, a thin veil to cover up crimes which would disgrace a nation of savages. There is not a nation on the Earth guilty of practices more shocking and bloody than are the people of the United States, at this very hour."I would say to Professor Wilkins, that Douglass himself too was a man of those times, was he not?Neither the comfortable shelter of historical lies about American exclusivity; nor the shelter of high and mighty but empty rhetoric about cherished principles of liberty and democracy, can continue to plug the holes in the moral dike. Our founding fathers are not heroes at all, but just as Lord Dunmore, another man of those times, put it on page 21: The American patriots were just "shameless, canting hypocrites who preached liberty while practicing slavery."This book proves that they were barbaric corrupt racist villains, and little more, period. Five stars

I received this book free in exchange for an honest review.My honest review is that this is a sophomoric attempt to push the Libertarian point of view without actually acknowledging it – that is, by not putting both feet in the Libertarian camp.The author falls just short of not believing in government at all, and refers to himself as an anarchist.He sees “free trade” as the answer to all of our ills. And although he does not fall on his sword for Trump, he could find only two negatives, versus finding 10 positives for him. Most of the positives fall in the emotional right-leaning ideological political lane.His faith in Trump is based on wholly on Trump's success in business.  Trump, like Sarah Palin, gets a “pass” on being intellectually prepared to serve as the leader of the Western world?That Trump is a mildly unbalanced megalomaniac also does not seem to bother the author at all. His case for Trump, mirror’s Trump’s own case for Trump.The author’s analysis of the problems that beset the U.S. are nave, shallow and rightward leaning ideologically.I failed to see a purpose for the book, except to subtly push both the Libertarian point of view, and to push Trump as a fresh face. I frankly learned little from the book. One Star.

This book, "The Course of Empire," winner of the national book award, is a novel -- a "factional" account as it were of the struggles for empire during seventeenth and eighteenth century North America. The narrative focuses sharply on the two hundred and eighty four "missing years" between "first landing" in 1492, and the American revolution in 1776, a period that, except for the French-Indian War, and the revolution itself, gets scant attention in American History books.The author's purpose here thus has been to use the geography of the land as his canvass for painting a picture that explains what actually happened on the continent during those three missing centuries. How, for instance it had occurred that by utilizing different approaches, each of the competing powers -- Spain, France, England, and to a lesser extent, the Netherlands -- came dangerously close to succeeding at achieving empire and becoming the dominant power over the North American continent. It is a richly textured, sometimes very ugly story that must be told.What we now know for sure is that in the 284 years between Columbus' voyages and the American Revolution, bands of illiterate white men, fresh out of the Dark Ages, were sent to the "New World," most as loosely defined contract employees of European kingdoms, or as indentured servants, which at the time was a euphemism for "slave." They came, following the model of conquest set by Spain, in search of gold and other booty, and to eventually establish a North American Empire for the Kingdoms of Europe.These bands of men, mostly seafaring pirates, privateers and buccaneers, and in the case of England, men and women indentured servants, did indeed converge on the continent from different directions: The Spanish came from the south and were bent on repeating the successes of Mexico and Peru in North America. The English, Swedes and Dutch followed Columbus' route across the Atlantic and landed on the Eastern seaboard.The Dutch, a tiny country, punching well above its weight, came only to get rich by selling beaver furs and then taking the money back to Amsterdam, which at the time was the most prosperous city in the world. And except for a challenge from the English that would eventually ejected them from the continent in 1684, the Dutch came very near becoming the only empire in North America.The Swedes on the other hand, came to settle on the land, live peaceably with the Indians, and farm. However, they too were ejected from New Jersey first by the Dutch and then later by England.And then finally we get to the French, which, for reasons that became obvious as the narrative progressed, was covered in much greater detail.France and England were the main protagonists of this narrative. They both came exclusively to establish an Empire on the North American continent for their respective Kings. But as will be discussed in more details later, the two countries went about the process of empire-building in entirely different ways.It is how these differences got played out that make up the main story of the book. It is a story about how in the end none of these competitors were able to achieve their aims. Somehow each of them found ways to snatch defeat from the jaws of certain victory, squandering away their opportunity.The climax of the book is the surprise that history has presented to us about what the mutual failures of the competing powers meant: History records that instead of achieving empire for one of the competing powers, their defeats merely left the spoils to be picked up by a loose collection of thirteen "English colonial city-states," made up of a ragtag bunch of English settlers -- privateers, seafaring buccaneers, religious fanatics, and indentured servants, all fleeing the hardships and oppression of the European Feudal Dark Ages. These British subjects would inherit the wind, the waters, the land, and in the end, the spoils of the competition taking place above their heads, a competition that would allow them to go on to become an empire themselves -- even before they had become a nation!As the author's story unfolds, we learn that what separated the European competitors from each other was not heroics on the many battle fields taking place during the period (they were uniformly horrible soldiers), or advantages in technological prowess (iron muskets were no match for the long bow until deep into the 19th century), or even superior European civilization (they were just beginning to wake up from the horrors of feudal Europe). But somewhat surprisingly, we learn that it was colossal ignorance of geography, bad judgment, bad timing, bad decision-making, badly composed and badly played-out geopolitical strategies, internal bickering, geopolitical posturing, hubris and colonial overreach, calculated duplicity in negotiations and in business practices, and racism against the Indians (even when their lives depended on tribal assistance for  survival) -- that separated them and got in the way of achieving empire.But equally, the main focus of this book, is also about the astonishing degree of ignorance of the land generally, and the interior of the North American continent in particular. It thus is not an exaggeration to say that, to an embarrassing extent, this book highlights the role ignorance of the geography of the interior of the North American continent played for 250 years in framing the continent for empire-building.In the end, this is a dense, rich, often ugly, but always honest and entertaining narrative picture of how blind greed and royal hubris intersected with duplicity and colossal ignorance about the land, to undermine the attempts by competing European powers to forge a North American empire.The crescendo of the book occurs in the aftermath of the French-Indian War, with the Louisiana Purchase, where the century of mutual geographic ignorance and duplicity reached a climax that conspired to checkmate the two rival powers, France and England, leaving the backdoor open for the thirteen colonial city states to pick up the pieces and "back into" empire by fiat.Other things being equal, the author makes clear that what served as a dense counterpoint to the infinite beauty and grandeur of the land, was this almost indescribably complex matrix of hubris and instability of European leaders, their inability to plan and execute sound geopolitical strategies an ocean away, their relationships with Indian nations, lack of support from the home office, the French-Indian War (and the role Indians and African slaves played as proxies in it), as well as their skill in competing in the fur trade. It was these and much more that served as the backdrop that set the parameters for empire in North America.In passing, it must also be said that serendipity played its role too. As but one example, a reader will be hard-pressed to find anywhere in American history books, the fact that a mini Ice Age was in progress during the last half of the seventeenth century, and that it was this climate change more than anything else that made trade in furs and other materials for European clothing so much more valuable than gold. During this cold and dark period of nearly 300 years, the world economy (like would later be true of tobacco, sugar cane and then slavery and cotton), turned on the axis of the North American fur trade, that is to say it turned on beaver and otter pelts.Likewise, the wars in Europe coupled with the slave revolts raging across the Caribbean, especially the war in Haiti, played a decisive role by sapping the energy and strength of both Britain and France, permanently weakening them in their quest for empire.The slave revolts in particular, were responsible for the embarrassing collapse of Napoleon's army (as well as the 50,000 British troops that came to rescue it). By its end, both the British and the French economies were on the brink of collapse. But no doubt the greater damage was done to France, which had its own revolution going on back home.One thing the reader will discover with France's lost of place and geopolitical status after the defeat in Haiti, is that American history has minimized the role France played in establishing a North American empire. Perhaps one reason that this is so is because of the complex maneuvers taken by the French King to reassert French dominance in the aftermath of France's fall from grace, which only opened the gates for colonial America to become an empire itself.What at the time must have seemed like either a supremely clever or a colossally stupid way out his difficulties, was Louis XIV's strategy of first "quick deeding" his North American possessions to Spain for temporary safekeeping. And then, within twenty days, selling them all to colonial America for 23 million dollars?!Among other things, the crafty French King knew his sale of the Louisiana territories would not only temporarily thrust the little weak set of colonial city states onto the geopolitical stage as a sworn rival of England, but as a bonus, it would also make them a permanent geopolitical thorn in England's side, hopefully paying dividends to France well into the future. If the strategy had succeeded, the French King believed it would serve to slow down England's designs for Empire, allowing France the time and space to fully recovered from its debacle in Haiti. After which, dispatching of both Spain and England's colonial irritant, would have been a routine matter for restored French power.But as reality would have its say in the matter, things got played out quite differently, and the wish that had propelled the French King to sell Louisiana turned out to be little more than a royal "wet dream." For the Americans and the British did indeed become enemies as he had predicted. But despite this, it did not prevent them from forming ad hoc military and trade alliances against France.It was these temporary alliances designed specifically to stop France's attempt to reassert its power on the North American continent that proved to be France's Achille's heel. One worked especially well against France's century long monopoly of the Western fur trade, as the Hudson Bay Company was brought in to stalk the French fur trade all across Canada as well as across the western colonial territories, greatly interrupting the hard currency being sent back to Paris, and stalling French attempts to reassert its dreams of achieving a North America empire.But there is another more important historical twist to this saga. When France sold Louisiana to America, no one knew exactly where the northern and western boundaries of the "Louisiana Territories" actually were? Unbelievably, for fully 250 years -- until after the American Revolution -- when, Jefferson secretly (and deviously) sent his two military spies Lewis and Clark to investigate and find ways to finesse the border issue, the American colonial settlers, despite lush tales of the heroics of a handful of intrepid frontiersmen, like Daniel Boone and Davy Crockett, were in fact deathly fearful of exploring the western territories. They were deterred as much by myths as by hostile Indians, who not only were seeking to protect their hunting grounds, but also had become aware that being close to white men meant a mysterious certain death to Indians.But providence would come to the rescue of the weak wayward but crafty little set of colonies. In perhaps the most stunningly brilliant stroke of political genius ever executed -- certainly the most astute move during the entire colonial era -- Jefferson took full advantage of the general ignorance of the geography of the North American continent, by sending two military spies, Lewis and Clark, to "map-out" the Louisiana territory so that the boundaries Jefferson would later use at the negotiating table, would present the two main protagonists, Britain and France, with little more than a carefully "pre-cooked" geographic and a geopolitical fait accompli.Since neither power was in a position to challenge Jefferson's unilaterally determined border designations; and since both, for their own reasons, were content with America being at the center of the North American empire, rather than their rival, the negotiations to settle disputes over the borders that would double the size of America, was a "no lose situation" for the colonies, one that at the same time checkmated the main competitors for empire on the continent.Thus, Jefferson's unilateral boundary designations for the Louisiana territory, sealed the deal for America as the unchallenged inheritor of North American empire.The French King's strategy had not only failed but had back-fired and rebounded to the benefit of a single geopolitical player: the colonial settlers.In one stroke of the pen, the King of France had catapulted a disorganized bunch of colonial city-states to the very top of the North American empire-building pyramid, thus creating by fiat, a North American empire that no one had expected, and that the colonies, not yet even a nation, could not have acquired in any other way.As a footnote, to the French King's maneuvering, there is a back story to the successful American coup that is worth telling. It is told as chapter III in the book, and is a mini geopolitical saga of how the French, after having a tremendous head start in the race for empire in North America, somehow managed in the end to lose it. It goes somewhat as follows:In the late 17th Century, the French settlers, not having a racist instinct in their bodies, came to North America under tight instructions from Louis XIV to bond by any means necessary with Western Indian nations. Unlike English settlers, they intermarried with them, establish religious missions in their towns and camps, preached the gospel of equality, brotherhood and racial intermarriage, and made enduring alliances with Indian nations -- all in an effort to harness and cultivate the invaluable knowledge the tribes had of the geography of the interior of the continent.Until then, the Holy Grail of all explorers was finding "the water route" connecting the Atlantic to the Pacific Ocean? For a century, the French were the only ones who knew that no such route existed. And as a result, a full century before other European nations understood the "Northwest mystery," France had, with considerable Indian help, "mapped-out" the area well enough to parlay its relationship with western Indian nations into almost complete control of the lucrative fur trade.From Quebec to New Orleans, Frenchmen became the key agents and continental intermediaries for the fur trade. Their alliances with Western Indians gave France control of the indispensable interior waterways, a system that ran from the Great Lakes, to the Mississippi, from the Ohio territory, to Louisiana and the Gulf of Mexico, and even as far west as the Missouri and Columbia rivers. This monopoly over the knowledge of the Western territories, alliances with Western tribes, and control over the interior waterways, constituted a formidable comparative advantage in the fur trade for France in its quest for Empire.However, this advantage would be quickly squandered through royal hubris and corruption back in Paris as well as in graft and corruption in the fur trade in North America itself. Plus, it did not help that unlike Britain, France had a difficult time recruiting Frenchmen to settle in the New World. The result was that throughout the period, when France was poised for empire, it suffered a population deficit, which made it increasingly dependent on their Indian friends for the fur trade, and eventually on Indians and slaves, to fight their wars on the continent as French proxies.The British, on the other hand, were profoundly racist and followed the Spanish model of pursuing a random search for gold. They chose to see Indian nations as little more than savages, and kept them at arms length -- except, that is, when they needed them to kill the animals that fueled the fur trade, farm their lands, to help fight wars against France or Spain, or to use Indian women as sex slaves to satisfy their sexual needs.This tableau happened so often during the "missing years" of exploration that to have included it as part of canonical American history would have been an embarrassment to the racially inspired narrative of white superiority, which included moral superiority as one of its chief components.But beyond this, history has recorded that the English strategy failed utterly as is evidenced by half a dozen or so failed attempts at settlement, where in each case, Indian tribes were repeatedly called upon to bail the the English settlers out. Eventually they did begin to learn how to take advantage of what the Indians taught them -- such as how to grow and cultivate a plant Indians had discovered, tobacco. Tobacco would become the crop that would eventually make English settlement in the New World a sustainable enterprise.But the English settlers were lazy and morally incorrigible: They learned the art of how to "trick," "game" and "exploit misunderstandings" with the Indians, and did it to a fault. One such misunderstanding is emblematic of the period and proved decisive for the English aim of acquiring Indian lands.Indians, having evolved their economies along what today would be called a socialist model, generally had only one understanding of land ownership: as a shared tribal enterprise and as a way of binding allies together as extended tribal members.In the face of tribes being decimated by European diseases against which they had no immunity, finding new tribal members to "fill-in" for losses due to deaths, was an urgent existential matter for competing Indian nations. Most tribes were anxious to increase their tribal numbers by any means necessary, including by signing contracts with white settlers, who would then not only become extended tribal members, but could also help them get tradable goods, fight off enemy tribes and share the burden of otherwise sustaining tribal interests and survival.Thus, according to Indian tradition and understanding, signing a land deed was simply a way of forming an alliance, an alliance in which the signatories effectively became extended tribal members. Indians understood a land deal to mean that its signatories had entered into a tribal bond of mutual and shared defense, into an arrangement in which everything was shared among allies -- such things as hunting grounds, the fruits of the hunts, the giving of and sharing of presents, living together, going on the war path together, and even intermarrying.But since the English were much more racist than the French, they were having none of this extended tribalism nonsense. Instead, they purposefully misinterpreted Indian understandings to suit their own needs to acquire their version of gold: more and more Indian lands. Thus, whenever it suited them, the English "gamed" the Indian version of contractual understandings, and for years tricked and swindled land from them in unsavory and unconscionable schemes.Bogus contracts were sold back in London, causing an avalanche of Englishmen, Irish, and Scots fleeing the hardships and harsh conditions of England to take a chance on buying land and establishing a homestead in the New World. As the Indians died in huge numbers from the diseases acquired from Europeans, the rush of English settlers to fill the vacuum, gave England a comparative advantage in population, in settling new arrivals, who upon arrival often took over whole Indian camps and farms.Population increase would soon become colonial America's most potent secret weapon. Add to this the fact that Indians were uniformly reviled by the English, and that, as early as 1712, they were being referred to collectively as savages and as "red n*ggers," and one can see why the English Settlers had a difficult time with Indians.And although it is true that the English settlers did occasionally engage in alliances with Indians, with the powerful Iroquois in the New England area in particular, it was almost always on English, rather than on Indian terms. As a result, English-Indian alliances tended to be extremely fragile and almost always temporary, based on expediency, and invariably crowned with mutual suspicions.Yet, despite these handicaps, the English proved to be better businessmen than their most fierce competitor, France. And thus what they lacked in racial tolerance and social graces, they made up for in business savvy and in competitive business practices. From the very beginning and throughout the two hundred years of competition with the French, England consistently produced and sold better quality goods more cheaply, on a more timely basis, and often used these advantages to strip away tribes from their alliance with France.But the English had some of the same deficiencies that other competing European powers had: The British treasury was in free-fall. They thus got minimum help from London; they too were heavily engaged in European Wars, and the slaves in their colonies were rebelling all across the Caribbean. In addition, they were locked into the narrow strip of land on the Atlantic sea coast. With the colonies serving as proxies for exploration of the interior, English exploration was literally limited to the fears held by the colonists, who despite the exploits of a handful like Jim Bowie, David Crockett and Lewis and Clark, were scared to death to venture out onto the Western frontier and into the interior of the continent. Five Stars

This is the story told by the author, Kenneth C. Bucchi, a "supposed" veteran of the CIA Drug Wars.As he tells it, during the time he was being recruited out of college to serve in the CIA, Bucchi apparently made an "off-the-cuff" remark about a "pseudo Miranda plan" that got CIA Director Bill Casey's attention. Casey later asked Bucchi to brief him on his idea.As the the idea was explained to Casey, all the stakeholders to the international cocaine trade were to be assembled in Switzerland and presented with what essentially amounted to a CIA fait accompli, in which they would be forced to agree to a new mode of operating the drug trade, one intended to stabilize and regularize it. Indirectly, the CIA would maintain exclusive control and oversight over the trade by allowing the two major drug cartels to operate as an international monopoly. In exchange for relinquishing control, they would enjoy a suite of CIA designated privileges.As it is explained on page 27, the agreement that was finally struck between the CIA and the two dominant drug cartels -- the Cali and the Medellin cartels -- empowered the CIA to destroy half of their cocaine stocks, while at the same time completely destroying all of the stocks, the processing plants and distribution networks of the smaller competing cartels. This would thus leave a clear open field monopoly to Cali and Medellin -- that is, to Pablo Escobar and Fabio Ochoa.Escobar and Ochoa acquiesced to this arrangement in exchange for never being threatened with arrest, prosecution or extradition, and in exchange for the CIA purchasing the remaining 50% of their existing cocaine stocks. Additionally, the CIA would also guarantee them unrestricted access to the lucrative U.S. inner city cocaine market, including escorting the cartel's narcotic-carrying aircraft over protected U.S. air routes and territory allowing them to land onto protected airstrips in Arkansas, Texas and other southern and Western states unmolested.The bulk of the story is what I have termed a "pseudo novella of CIA disinformation" -- mostly a tale about the romantic "derring-dos" of a half dozen carefully-selected multi-racial and multi-gendered CIA recruits, who, like Bucchi himself, were earmarked to make the "pseudo Miranda plan" happen.Their story follows the well-worn (and tiring) story of CIA agent exploits -- of plane crashes, shootouts, bombs breaking up jungle drug labs, expelling tons of pure cocaine from the cargo bay of airplanes, and otherwise getting caught in cliff-hanging situations that all but a couple of "reality-style CIA heroes" would escape.Does the story make any sense?Given what I know about the potential for the international economy to be destabilized by the global drug trade, it does not surprise me at all that the USG, through its intelligence agencies, would get involved in trying to manage and better regulate the drug trade. The need to do so is rather transparent: to ensure that the world economy will not de-stabilized by a handful of resourceful Third World criminals. However, knowing that this could happen, certainly does not justify a CIA take-over of the drug trade? Nor, would it necessarily be any better for the world economy if First World criminals instead of the Third World criminals were to take over the trade.And anyone who fails to see the logic of the necessity to regulate the global drug trade -- due primarily to the insane sums of money that flood the global economy -- need to first remember Miami during the 1980s, and then read "The Underground Empire." There, the reader will see how, just from the enormous sums of cash resulting from the sell of marijuana, a handful of criminals came very close to destabilizing the world economy in the 1970s. It is frightening to try to imagine how much larger that potential would be today in the marijuana, cocaine, heroine and amphetamines drug environment?That said however, I have serious doubts believing that this "fictionalized" account of a CIA takeover of the international drug trade happened in exactly the romantically scripted way that this author's formulaic narrative has described it here -- indeed if it happened at all? One reason for doubt is that it follows to the letter the well-worn script of CIA disinformation: It is a romantic heroe's tale of derring-do, in which the inessential facts could easily be true. However, in all such scripts, there is never a way to verify or validate any of the "essential facts" or to connect the dots between them, because invariably they are classified top secret, and thus remain shielded behind the U.S. national security screen.Another important reason I doubt this narrative is true is because the truth in the drug world is stranger than fiction: there are enough true "non-fictionalized" exceptions to this disinformation narrative that have leaked out and embarrassed U.S. administrations, that perhaps this "soapy" variation is needed to "cover" and discredit these certifiably true versions of CIA and USG involvement in the drug trade? And here I mean in particular the exposes revealed by Barry Seal, Dr. JD Brown, Eugene Hasenfus, Terry Reed, Gary Webb ... and the list goes on.U.S. government involvement in the global drug trade is much too serious an issue to be turned into a cheap CIA Disinformation movie script. Clearly this manuscript was "cleared" if not written entirely by Langley's disinformation writer's staff.Altogether this book is a sophomoric attempt to tell us a sanitized story that implies that although the USG is indeed interested in controlling the global drug trade, it has absolutely no interest in making use of the power and money that controling the drug trade implies? This story thus suggests that U.S. politicians are more chaste than Caesar's wife -- that they can get in bed with the Cali and Medellin godfathers, the rabid dogs of the drug universe, and not become rabid dogs themselves?But the truth that has seeped out from behind the national security screen -- in the list mentioned above -- tells quite another story. The stories these exposes tell is about how the power and money of the drug trade have infected, penetrated, and deeply corrupted the American political class as well as the American body politic. What we see in Mena, Arkansas, Iran-Contra and Miami, are no different than what we would expect to find in any Banana Republic.Thus, this sophomoric attempt to deflect us from the underlying truth revealed in those exposes, in my view has failed. Because, anyone who remembers Miami during the 1980s -- when every dollar that passed through a bank teller's window had traces of cocaine on it; or that illicit but legal banks laundering drug money sprung up like mushrooms -- cannot deny that America is as corruption-prone as any other nation.This book thus does us a disservice by not allowing us to confront the truth about the deep corruption of our own politicians. And in doing so, it ensures that we too will just remain an out-sized Banana Republic, pretending to be a respectable democracy. When the unalloyed truth is, that since 22 November 1963, we have been run by a "shadow government" hidden behind the screen -- of the very national security apparatus responsible for this disinformation tract that is posing here as a true history of America's participation in the drug trade. What a pity.  Two stars

While this edited volume of a select collection of articles does not take sides on the controversy about Freud's sexual theories on women, it does add up to a rich and robust historical trail of his intellectual development on the issue. In particular it shows more or less step-by-step how he boot-strapped his way from one proto-theory to another, final ending up with a two-sided theory of the Oedipal complex, with transference.  This narrative is the reviewer's compiled summary of the articles in the book. To him they reveal this development as having emerged somewhat in the follows way:Freud's work in psychoanalysis of course began with his work on hysteria in women, which at the time was thought to be an ailment that was peculiar only to women. His theorizing began by noticing the very real differences in sexual attitudes between men and women: Women invariably adopted a defensive or a passive stance, while men did the opposite: They were aggressive and more open about sex.This coupled with the fact that the problems of hysteria within many of his patients began in the marriage bedroom, where it took on the character of being more a violation than an erotic seduction, led Freud to suspect that these attitudes probably had a pre-sexual root that began in childhood. From there he slowly discovered from his patients, that, more often than not, hysterical symptoms had been triggered as a result of some form of sexual abuse (real or imagined) by a father, or father figure.He thus became more and more convinced that memories from childhood sexual traumas lay in the background of adult hysterias. Locating the precise timing of the triggering event seemed to be of paramount importance. So he drew up a table of childhood stages that would suggest "what primal experiences" could lead to "what hysteria symptoms." He and his colleagues concluded that such symptoms could have begun as early as the age of four.This prompted him to posit a theory of erogenous zones -- of the mouth, the anus, and the genitals -- areas that were exciting to children at various ages and thus at different stages of their sexual development. Satisfaction and dissatisfaction with these experiences, which incidentally could also have involved auto-erotic pleasures even before they involved passive or seductive experience with adults, undoubtedly made up an important part of the psychic history of his hysteria patients.First he tried to associate particular sexual experiences with particular neuroses. Being especially aware of the role childhood fantasies play in generating hysterical symptoms, Freud no longer assumed that the father -- either through actual or imagined abuse -- was necessarily always the only source of the neurosis. Later this "train of thought" would be referred to as his "seduction hypothesis." Summarized succinctly, it hypothesized that "sexualized fantasies" had been repressed in females -- especially in those representations where the female felt more masculine.Freud would find this hypothesis to be unproductive and he eventually gave it up in favor of the richer framework called the Oedipal complex. The Oedipal complex posited a framework that assumed opposite-sex love and same-sex rivalry in both girls and boys. Its foundation assumption was that both genders have a death-wish for the parent of the same sex, and a corresponding fantasized sexual involvement with the parent of the opposite sex.Since a single source for hysteria could not be found, Freud then focused on correlating "wish fulfillment" of repressed thoughts in dreams and fantasies with hysterical symptoms -- always being alert to the possibility that the symptoms might have deeper bisexual meanings, especially in women who tended to strongly repress masculine meanings within their sexual representations.In the case of Dora, the only case publish among his his written research, the puzzle of her hysteria kept getting more complex the deeper it went. The Oedipal elements remained prominent, but they took on ever more complex forms: Her repressed sexual representations now had two objects, both her father and his mistress (recomposed and refocused as a second-order repressed representation of her mother).As Dora fled from analysis, Freud understood why she had to do so: A treatment can relive existing symptoms and stop formation of new ones without actually halting the "productive powers" of the neurosis, which in Dora continued through an ever deeper and more subterranean mechanism called transference: Freud, the therapist himself, had become Dora's replaced sexual object -- a recomposed and refocused "stand-in" for one of her repressed parental sexual objects. Freud understood that Dora's love had been played out in a transference to him.Since he was not sure of these materials, he did not stop until he had worked them through and tested them in a non-pathological domain. This resulted in a monograph called "The psychological Pathology of Everyday Life."Even if in the final analysis a reader is not convinced of Freud's theories about sexuality in women, no one will be able to deny that he and his team engaged in research of the highest order. This sample of articles convinces me that this is indeed the case. Five Stars

A comprehensive overview guide that highlights "the highlights." Very well organized and covers Scotland Wales, the Isle of Jersey and Scilly, as well as the Channel Islands.Although we had a very good guidebook (DK) when we last visited Britain, it was a bit too cluttered to give us the big picture of the British Isles. This one fixes that problem. So, next time we will not go without two guidebooks: this one for the big picture and the DK guide for the detailed picture. Four Stars

Although the author marshals some heavy historical artillery to make his case, I believe he nevertheless builds a rather thin case for a revolution occurring in the U.S. -- at least not in the classical way revolutions have occurred in his historical examples.In fact I would argue that if we "factor-in" what we know about the uniqueness of the American character and how that character has affected the stability of American society, and the unique course the history of the American nation has taken as a result of it -- especially in the face of severe hardship -- I think one may come to an entirely different set of conclusions about just how imminent another American revolution may really be?While what the author says about the present economic and political conditions, and the instability of U.S. society that they portent, is all devastatingly true. (Which, greatly summarized, is essentially that there is a crisis of disappointing expectations within the American middle class.) It is also true that the difference between the way stability is created and maintained in the U.S. and the way it was created and maintained in societies that led to revolutions in the past, while subtle, is still vast. And this subtlety is way more than just a difference in the political and economic nuances suggested in this book.Thus, I would argue that when the uniqueness of the effects of the American character on the stability of American society is fully taken into account, a revolution of the historical type is much less imminent than the author makes it seem. However, that said, this of course does not preclude the possibility of a revolution "American style" being just as imminent as the author's suggestions. But in that case, the constellation of reasons would be vastly different than those given in this book.Thus, to know just how imminent a revolution may be in America, of course revolves around knowing precisely how stability is forged and maintained in U.S.society rather than on textbook historical examples. I believe the author's narrative and the examples he used to support his case, actually subtly skirted this very important issue. And therefore the book, perhaps unwittingly, but subtly, only begs the question of just how societal stability is actually created and maintained within the U.S.Getting right to the crux of this matter, I wished that Mr. Hedges, one of my intellectual heroes, would have argued that stability in U.S. society, unlike in most other Western societies, does not rest on the normal political and economic factors, but instead rests heavily on a peculiar hierarchy of emotional issues that point to an embarrassing hierarchy of U.S. values, values that are as often as not acted out subconsciously, and reflect the peculiarities of the American character that go all the way back to the way the American nation was founded and has evolved ever since.It is no accident that much more of American politics today revolve around emotional issues than around normal political and economic issues. That they do so, more than any other reason, is why the author's formulas derived from historical examples of how revolutions evolve, do not always apply to the U.S.?The American character still rests heavily on the fetish of having been established as an exclusively "white run nation," one that conquered the colored peoples that once owned the land --as well as those that were brought here to  "service" it.  And whether or not white America admits and acknowledges it, it is this fetish about race and the collection of related issues, that serve as the cornerstone to the stability of the American nation.As long as the fetish of race remains a wedge issue, you will never get a soldier or policeman to side with revolutionaries against a white run government, no matter how corrupt that government might be, or how economically devastated those soldiers may be. It simply will not happen, period. End of the Hedges paradigm for an American revolution that overthrows a bankrupt immoral, mean-spirited capitalist system.The fetish of race is still a value that dwarfs and trumps all others. It is such a juvenile value, that rightly so, most Americans are embarrassed by it and by the fact that it still remains at the top of the American tribal totem pole. Yet, it is what it is. And for anyone who would like to dismiss this as being an exaggeration of the post-modern American character, with its mulatto president, I challenge you to show me a single decade since 1619, when race was not one of the most, if not the most important issue on the American agenda?All other values are subordinate to this one. Thus, so long as the racist status quo remains essentially undisturbed: all is seen as being right with the American way of life -- no matter what else happens on the political or economic fronts. Another way of saying this is that there is a lot of "play" left in the way the other variables that affect the stability of American culture can be arranged and can get played out when the racist status quo remains undisturbed. In fact I would argue that the amount of play is darn near infinite!For instance, so long as race remains in a steady state, whites on all sides of the political spectrum have virtually infinite faith and confidence in the magic of the capitalist free enterprise system. This is so in part because built into the Protestant Ethic of Capitalism, the catechism of American capitalists, is the hint of white supremacy, just enough to send a "dog whistle" to anyone of the least bit of the Ayn Rand Libertarian persuasion to know what side of the bread is buttered white. That is why "the government" (as if the government is not just We the people") and not the evils of capitalism is always the target of white America's angst.Here is a guaranteed formula for the next American revolution: Allow equality between the races to break out in such a way that blacks actually can, through their own efforts, pull even with whites. Now that is a guaranteed formula for the next American Revolution. All hell will break loose if that ever happens.All we have today is a situation where the political elite and the ruling classes have discovered that it is equally profitable to them to continue the racist wedge by spreading the "benign-neglect" once only reserved for blacks, upwards to the rest of the population all the way up through the middle class. That way they no longer have to help pay for any social services, no schools, no infrastructure, no healthcare, no nothing.They can quietly dismantle the country as they have been doing without fear of a collective negative reaction because there is no such thing in a racially divided America as a "collective reaction:" We are a nation split right down the middle into three parts by race: On one side there are the whites. On another side there are those who are "trying not to be black;" and then there are the blacks.There is no way this triangle of racism, America's highest value since its inception, will ever become a collective. So the ruling class can relax: The revolution after all, will be televised. It will be a "reality show" disseminated via "social media," and Donald Trump with be our next white President, and America will be great again. Amen

Here, Charles Murray makes a very weak and I think a very tortured "pseudo-Madisonian" case, for the need of a Libertarian revolution? Early on he quotes his version of the Jeffersonian mantra: “It is part of our national catechism that government is instituted to protect our unalienable rights, and that when it becomes destructive of those rights, the reason for our allegiance is gone. At that point, revolution is not treason, but the people’s right."I say he makes a weak pseudo-Madisonian case because in my reading of the Federalist Papers, it was Madison himself, who launched a cleverly engineered coup against states rights that resulted in the establishment of the federal government in the first place? And if that is so, how is it that despite this, Libertarians like Murray, still see Madison as the champion of both states rights and small government? Their position defies common sense? It thus seems to me this is a clear purposeful mis-reading of American history.I doubt very seriously that, to Madison, "Big Government" would be the same root of all the nation's evils as it is made out to be here by Murray and his likeminded ideological cohorts? Nor, do I believe that Madison would see FDR's "New Deal Programs" as being the generator of all the evils of Big Government, as Murray's Libertarians do? It seems rather self-evident that "Big Government" for these guys is just a convenient ideological canard: bad only when it does not serve the conservative and Libertarian causes, and good otherwise?Somehow through the twisted contradictory logic of Murray and his likeminded ideological cohorts (of Denesh D'Sousa, and Thomas Sowell, in particular), FDR's New Deal programs are seen as being responsible for all of America's problems. I think this is true in the eyes of the Libertarians/conservatives only because they see those programs as drawing a bright line between what they see as the "common good," and what they see as the "so-called job creators;" between what they imagine to be the "productive citizens" and those they see as "waiting for a handout;" between the "smart and creative people," and what they see as the "dumb dull and the uncreative perpetual down-and-outs."Libertarians, who love Ayn Rand and have no moral problems with Gordon Gecko style greed, believe that no such line is needed because the notion of a "common good" is no longer via or needed, and thus should be abandoned altogether despite its clear inclusion in the U.S. Constitution on par with "providing for the common defense?"The U.S. Constitution and "authentic" American History aside, the only meaningful division to Libertarians like Murray is between the "so-called" "job creators" and those who "wait for the job creators to feed them;" or failing that, those who wait for the government to provide them "meals on wheels?"Do we really need a revolution to reduce the oppression from too many regulations on corporations and too many pages in the tax code? How about a revolution for evading taxes by sheltering them in illegal off shore accounts? How about a revolution against dismantling American factories and jobs, and then shipping them off to Mexico and China? Wouldn't these be better ways to spend our national treasure on a revolution? And if this is a serious revolution, why make it non-violent?Did Mr. Murray miss the fact that the Libertarian revolution has already occurred, and has been won? So, why do the Libertarians like Ron Paul and that ilk keep crying foul? Bush privatized prescription drugs, and now the same drugs cost the American public six to ten times what they cost in Canada? The prisons have been privatized; and now inner city communities have been further decimated by drug infestation and dumbed-down education, in order to keep the pipeline of criminals open thereby ensuring that the beds in the pre-planned prisons of the prison-industrial complex, will be filled thus allowing them to remain a "going concern." We now also have "for profit Colleges." And in less than a decade, they alone have succeeded in making student loan debt second only to home mortgage debit? When the firewall between regular and international banks went unregulated, by tearing down Glass-stegall, we got the sub-prime loan crisis, and the world lost 60 trillion dollars in wealth?Every time an American institution is privatized, or deregulated, or what is the same, handed over to the "so-called job creators, a handful of greedy amoral people get rich, and America's problems and those of the rest of the world multiply and continue to expand to the point of festering?I say to Mr. Murray, who has correctly abandoned some of his previous "hard-hearted" conclusions promoted and then defended in his previous books (i.e., in “Losing Ground”, “The Bell Curve” and "Coming Apart.”): We don't need another Libertarian Revolution, what we need is a Libertarian Counter-Revolution. Indeed, what we need, more than anything else, is a war on Libertarian greed and mindless profiteering. Two stars

Bliss Broyard, woke up after it was revealed at her father's death, by the infamous "One Drop Rule," that she and her brother Todd, shared with our 45th President, Mr. Barack Obama, the fact that even though they all are of mixed racial lineage, they all still are definitely considered black.Her way of getting over the shock of it all, even though there had been a string of clues trailing her throughout her "tony" life in ritzy upscale Connecticut, was to strike out to New Orleans to find out more about why her, writer father, had chosen to remain in the "racial closet" throughout his life, "passing" for white.What she found along her journey to New Orleans to find her roots makes for interesting reading as well as for a robust experiment in racial self-discovery. In fact, what she discovered (only after she had determined that by the default rule of "one drop of blood," that she was now black), is something any keen observer of American culture will discover at first sight: That American cultural waters are little more than a sea of raging mean-spirited, passive-aggressive white racism; that one cannot live in America without first being a racist -- for racism is not only the air we breathe, but is also the air that defines the norm -- the white people's humanity. It is the swift moving cultural waters that we swim in; and it is the set of cultural rules that all Americans inhale from birth onwards.The first thing that Bliss discovered along her journey is that American culture had "programmed" her unconsciously to invest in, defend, and then assist in maintaining a culture of  white supremacy. Without any conscious intervention on the part of her mind, and without ever having had any contact with blacks, she had learned how to judge blacks by the behavior of the worse of "them." She had learned to be disgusted with behavior committed by blacks, that when whites routinely engaged in the same behavior, it did not even bother her.Now that she had no choice but to accept that she was no longer white, only then did she become both appalled with, and alarmed by, her own racist behavior. That is to say, that only in a "new found blackness" did she begin to recognize that she had been "programmed" into being a regular "dyed-in-the-wool," "garden variety," white racist. The only way Bliss saw to undo the damage living as a WASP had done to her, was to "deprogram" herself. On pages 99-100 she describes how this process worked:"I developed a method by which I hoped to deprogram myself. First, I would forgive myself, because the only other choice, self-censure, didn't leave any room to correct the problem. I reasoned that given the pervasiveness of racism in America, it's impossible for a person to escape its effect. Of course I was a racist, meaning I made judgments,  valuations, and assumptions about people based on what I perceived their ethnicity to be. After all fitting information into categories is how we make sense of the world. Perhaps if people were less apprehensive about acknowledging their racists thoughts, then they could move on to addressing them.Next I would try to identify which particular stereotype of African Americans had fueled the belief in question: that black men are dangerous, or black students aren't as smart as white ones, or black girls have no ambition. And then in a logical fashion, I would attempt to debunk it: What proof did I have that black men were more dangerous? Well, they are  incarcerated at a higher rate than white men -- but isn't that also due in part to the bias of the justice system, issues of class, and a historical deprivation of opportunity? If all other things were equal, was there evidence that black men would be continuously more prone to reckless behavior than white men?  Hadn't I in fact known white men who were  reckless and black men who were not? And why should the (school bus driver who molested white girls) be made to stand in for all other black men and not, say, for all other people  who drive old sedans? Couldn't I just as easily judged him as yet another inconsiderate old-sedan driver? Once I was satisfied that my belief was unfounded, I would made a  pledge to myself to try to do better the next time."It was strange to take such a systematic approach to changing the way I thought and  behaved, as if I were making myself the subject of a psychological experiment. And it was hard work. Trying to be constantly vigilant wasn't fun or easy. Sometimes it was difficult to resist the desire to feel superior over another person. Sometimes I got a thrill from thinking something that was ugly and extreme, the way that smelling a terrible smell can be perversely exhilarating. But mostly I didn't feel I had much choice in challenging these thoughts. Along the way my loyalties had shifted without my even realizing it."It is not only strange, but also sad to have to admit that only as a "newly minted" black person, did Bliss become conscious enough of her racist ways, to then her own 12-step program to correct them? I did the same thing to overcome my own sexist ways. Presumably, had Bliss remained "captured" in the white racist orbit, it would have been nearly impossible for her to have mustered the "escape velocity" needed for the self-introspection required to overcome her racism.Sadly too, this also means that unless whites' cozy arrangement at the top of the racist totem pole is threatened, they are simply too invested in maintaining white racism and white supremacy in a steady state to do anything about it, or about themselves.However, the most interesting part of the book is the history of New Orleans from 1850 onwards. Included in that history is the explanation as to how the Broyards became a mixed-race clan: In a twist of racial irony for the ages, her great grandfather, Henry Broyard, actually married a free woman of color, Pauline Bonee, solely because he loved her. He went on to have four children with her and as a result became the grand patron of the Broyard clan. And here is the irony: Since it was illegal for blacks and whites to marry in New Orleans in 1850, Henry legally changed his race from "white" to "black" solely because he was in love with a black woman. QED Five Stars

This wallet was just what my doctor ordered. With a recent disk operation in my back, I was told not to keep a large wallet in my back pocket, so I got this one as a promotion, and it is neat, durable and most of all very thin. I hardly know its back there. The only drawback is if you have more than a half dozen credit cards. I do, but some I never use, so I just jettisoned them. Five Stars

This visual compendium has the virtue of being broad but the disadvantage of not being very deep. Plus, the text is mostly what is accepted as "settled history," never the least bit "contested history." So readers must be aware that unlike science, where "bad science" is inevitably weeded out and replaced by "tested or falsified science," the same is not true of history."Bad history" lives on until another, mostly political consensus, forms that reaches a "critical mass" around updated information that is sufficient to overthrow the previous "bad History." However, since its criteria are always subjective, and thus equally contested, the diffent between "good" and "bad" history is always a problematic concern.My concern here was with the fact that so much of "Western History" is being contested that thee is a need to speed up the process of updating it. Sadly, even when there is a critical mass among professionals has been reached, historians still drag their feet in updating outdate historical facts.When will mainstream general compendia such as this one make the decision to update its materials, so that at the very least, they keep up with the better AP High School History textbooks?My compliant is not that I did not enjoy this book, or value having highly it as a handy reference guide, just that so much of it needs serious updating. Also, while it is good to have many glossy pictures associated with the periods in question within the text, it would be more useful if they were chosen and inserted only on the basis of relevance -- not just for the sake of filling-in a blank spot? Otherwise, this is a useful volume that is very heavy.

Despite what can only be described as sophomoric academic research. The results reported on here had only a single objective in mind: to embarrass, bully and intimidate "professional black men" in such a way as to forever corral and keep them on the segregated sexual plantation where they are only available to black women. However, that strategy does not seem to have worked. In fact, arguably, it has had the opposite effect. The best evidence that it is not working is that professional black women as a group have become more and more agitated as they watch the procession of the old segregated sexual preserve -- one that they once commandeered by the default of a racist social order -- give way to a new multi-racial and interracial sexual social order that leaves them out.As one who has done extensive research in this area, and who has had a keen interest in these issues as well as one who has kept up with recent developments on this front, I believe the author's research design suffers several defects.For one, her research design needs interviews of at least three additional groups: (1) non-black women (whites, Latina, and Asians primarily) who are now using their new found more tolerant racial attitudes and feminist "agency" to overcome the racist inhibitions in American society against marrying black men; and (2) non-black men who, in statistically significant ways are electing to marry women other than professional black women? And finally, the author needed to administer a third questionnaire to professional black women in order to discover why they are marrying fewer black men, at the same time that they are also "out marrying" less than professional black men.On the second of these missing questionnaires, the Pew Research Study on Interracial Marriage and Dating, provides partial answers. And although it was not available at the time this manuscript went to print, it nevertheless reveals that non-black men as a group (not just black men), have the same reticence to not marrying black women: because both groups share a perceived beauty, trustworthiness, and combativeness deficit in black women when compared with "comparable marriage eligible" non-black women.Likewise, to get at the second missing questionnaire, in an unpublished 1991 MIT Master's thesis -- simulation research study, I used the results of an Ebony Magazine designed and administered a questionnaire on the respective marriage qualifying criteria black men and women used for marriage selection. These results "drove" a computer simulation model designed to reproduce the illegitimacy spike that occurred among black women that first appeared with alarm in the 1985 census data.What the simulation reported is that "marriage formation" among blacks was down by nearly 80 percent from just a generation prior. This shocking reduction in black family formation, few seem to have noticed, is not due to "so many black men being in prison as black women tell us, but was due in large part to the large pool of ineligibles, the residuals left over after both groups apply their marriage rules to the opposite sex within the black race. When black women apply their qualifying rules to black men, fully 51% of all black males are eliminated. But the real shock came when the simulation reported that when black men apply their marriage qualifying rules to black women, a hefty 67% of all black women were disqualified and were found to be ineligible for marriage within the black race too.After running my simulation repeatedly, it was clear that practically no one was left among blacks to "in marry?"The minimum qualifying criteria were used on both sides: For black women, any black man who had a job, did not use alcohol or drugs, was not in jail, and was religious, qualified. For black men, any black woman who was not obese, did not already have children out of wedlock, and was not be on welfare, also qualified.When these two sets of minimum marriage qualifying rules, were deployed in the computer simulation, its results reported that the pools of ineligibles on both sides, dwarfed the numbers of blacks that qualified for marriage. Put another way, the pool of "marriage eligibles" men and women within the black race shrank to such a vanishingly small rate that, as noted above,  black-on-black marriages dropped by nearly 80 percent from the previous generation?And thus, since marriage was virtually "off the table" for so many blacks of marriage age, no Sociologist, or Social-Psychologist like the author, could have predicted as my simulation did that the resulting "reject pools of ineligibles," were nevertheless engaging in high risk sex at rates several times higher than that of even black married couples!  Anyone who reviews the statistics of sex in the 1985 census data as I did, will not need a computer simulation to come to the exact same conclusions.The alarming sexual activity of the two pools of "ineligibles" is carefully buried in the census statistics.Thus as a result, the simulation reproduced the alarming illegitimacy rate that raised so much concerned during the 1985 census report. It took a computer simulation to put all of the factors together into a mate selection and sex activity matrix that revealed the true source of the problem. The spike in illegitimacy was literally a mere accidental byproduct of unprotected high risk sex between two very large pools of "marriage ineligibles."As for the third missing questionnaire, the unintended answer given by the famous actor Yaphet Kotto, on page 89 of this book, probably gets as close to an answer as we are likely to get from this author. When the author asked Mr. Kotto why he married a white woman instead of a black one, he answered that it was because since he was "a very large man with very dark skin." As a result, black women would not give him the time of day. He said that he was so often rejected by black women because of his size and his dark skin that he had no choice but to date women who did not see it as a problem. (In this regard, I can personally attest to at least one anecdote, in which one my black female friends asked me if Mr. Kotto was from Nigeria? However, before I could answer, she had already said: "He looks just like a big old gorilla -- and snickered. I did not see anything funny?).And in this same regard, it was not too many years ago when Howard University, where the author teaches, had its own "Brown Bag test" for skin color. Those who failed, severely reduced their chances of being admitted to Howard, and forfeited all possibility of pledging a fraternity or a sorority.The more important point here though is this: In this new race-free sexual social order, it is not so much black professional men who are taking the lead, as it is Latina, Asian and white women, who are using their new changed attitudes towards black men, and their new found feminist "agency," to overcome the racist and sexist rules of American society. It is they who are using both their new attitudes and their new found feminist agency, to embrace black men as sexually attractive marriage partners -- the same as one embraced Mr. Kotto, who, not coincidentally, is now happily married to a white woman, and has two children.One would think that such changes in non-black female racial attitudes and empowerment, would be seen for what they really are: welcomed indicators of racial progress on the sexual and marriage front. However, that is not how this author sees it.Since non-black men have not been returning the favor of using their own changed attitudes and their own "agency" to similarly embrace black women as potential marriage partners -- at least not in numbers equal to that of non-black women towards professional black men -- this author has mis-framed the issue of what is really a "lagging interest in black women by non-black men" as a problem of too many black men bolting the old race/sex-based plantation and ending up in the beds of too many non-black (i.e. white) women?Clearly my computer simulation, among other things, proved that this is not what is going on here at all.Although the most recent Pew Research Study on Interracial Marriages, does confirm that "out-marriages" by professional black men are indeed a full eight times more likely than that of professional black women (not just four times as this book claims). This could not have happened unless women of other races were not becoming both more tolerant of black men, and felt freer in exercising their agency to overcome society's racist resistance to non-black women marrying black men.And, despite the author's attempt to paint a distorted picture otherwise, these women continue to marry professional black men in increasing numbers. The other important point here is just as it is not wholly a decision of black men when they marry black women, the same is true when they marry non-black women. More often than not, it is women, and not men, who are the choosers in both cases.Rather surprisingly, and incongruously, instead of praising America's non-black women for their new racial open-mindedness, the author has instead misdirected the reader's attention from this new important indicator of dramatic racial progress, to one of trying to denigrate and bully black men back into remaining on the old segregated sexual plantation, where their choices are limited only to black women?In other words, this author has turned an asymmetric in "out-marriage by black men," which should be a deep indicator of racial progress, into a negative, by energetically and openly trying to undermine and oppose this "out-marriage." And having done so, the author has aligned black women with the most regressive and racially intolerant groups in America. Those groups too argue as this author's carefully "rigged taxonomy" on page 88 has depicted black men: as just cardboard cutouts of society's mindless sexual predators? Why would any men want to marry women who would characterize them in such demeaning terms?However, that is not all. Rather incredibly, this author goes these anti-black groups one better.
