To her not so clever arguments, the author throws in an important additional "kicker:" She argues that by marrying outside the race, these black professional men, are also hurting the black family?"In past generations, racist whites used a similar rhetorical canard with a similar stinging lament: What will happen to the children of these interracial marriages, they asked with feigned fake concern?To both fake concerns, I cannot resist ending this review by answering both queries in the following way: There once was a black Harvard Phd, from Kenya, named Barack Obama, who married a white Kansas Phd, named Dr. Stanley Ann Dunham. Together they produced a son, who in 2008 became not only the first and only black president of the USA, but also the first and only US president both of whose parents were doctors.So I say, so much for the argument that interracial marriages hurt the black family, or their children. Indeed, how many black-on-black marriages have produced a U.S. president? Or more to this point, how many black mothers do as Dr. Stanley Ann Dunham did with Barack: get their ten year old sons up at 4am daily to study?And make no mistake about it, there is no doubt in my mind whatsoever, that it was this one white woman, Dr. Stanley Ann Dunham's, parental study regiment, of getting little Barry up at 4am, that had a lot to do with him eventually becoming president of the US. One star.

Received these as a promotion. They come in a very attractive case, but the zipper broke as I was opening it. This did not leave me with a warm feeling about the product, nor did the very limp and cheesy strap holding it together.As a test, I wore the Goggles on my bike ride at about noon today. The sun was blistering hot (102) and  a straight up August sun.I must say I was quite surprised with how well the goggles blocked out the sun. In fact I could look directly at it without any ill effects. The UV blocking value must be very high indeed.Thus, on the strength of the lens alone, I am going to give these goggles four stars, with the hope the manufacturers will fix the case and replace the cheesy strap. They obviously do not do a good product justice.
A first rate product. I like corkscrews that are uncomplicated and work correctly every time. This product passes that test. Plus it is substantial, slickly designed, and my wife loves it!
Runs fine so far, after quite limited use: quiet and powerful. I am delighted so far. If it continues to provide good service, I will upgrade this rating later t a later date.

This, very much "after-the-fact book," reporting on the criminal tornado called the Bulger brothers crime wave, most reminds me of GW's excursion in a "standoff presidential helicopter" surveying the damage of Katrina. Like Bush Jr, these two "not so intrepid" reporters did all they could to keep their heads down, and their hands clean in the wake of the murderous knee-deep mire that Jimmy and Billy Bulger's crime waves left across the Boston moral landscape.So they turned this book into a "stand-off reporter's legal brief," a palatable, but clinical back-handed de facto hero story "in waiting." It is seemingly a story specifically designed not to make waves or jar the Boston sensibility too much, but one that would curiously preserve the right to make "Whitey" a bona fide hero later -- if, that is, it turns out that after his capture, he should ever be set free again. Certainly these authors were hedging their bets that he might indeed be set free again someday?As a result, no one should be surprised that Whitey has endorsed this book; or upset with the fact that these authors interviewed Steve Flemmi's lawyers, the judges, and the spectators on the margins of the courtroom ad nausea, and yet say nothing at all about the dead bodies that are left in Flemmi's and Whitey's wake lining the swamps on the margins of the Boston freeway. These authors thus have proven to be consummate professionals at creating a manuscript that nibbles around the edges but never quite gets to the heart of the Bulger carnage.Thus, perhaps unwittingly, they have succeed in reducing crime reporting to the fine art of knowing when and where to "pull their punches," when and where to interview already tainted ex-FBI agents; when and where to minimize the vast corrupt system in place from which the Bulger brothers simply picked the already ripen low-hanging fruit. Instead of plumbing the depths of Boston's reservoir of corruption, here they are content with "dotting all of the legal "eyes" and "crossing all of the legal "tees?" That way they can then take a more relaxed clinical approach to interrogating and investigating the court records and interviewing the prisoners locked in cages behind bars, instead of digging into how Boston's own corruption led to the corpses strewn along the marshes lining the Boston freeway. Or, indeed how that fine and cultured city created the likes of Whitey and Billy Bulger in the first place?Sadly, it is left as an exercise for the reader to conclude that those bodies are in fact not all just souvenirs from the Whitey Bulger category-five crime wave, but are also grim monuments to Boston's culture of crime and corruption. So, I say that these authors have made a fundamental mistake in producing a clinically clean book that ignores how all those dead bodies got there, yet leaves the backdoor open for the Bulger brothers to one day become de facto heroes. No wonder Whitey wanted this version of his story to become the movie script about  his life.But I believe that these authors have assumed erroneously that the dead cannot speak? This is where they have gone wrong. The dead that now line the marshes along the freeways entering Boston, do indeed speak: I can hear them now. (Listen closely and carefully), they say: "In Boston, crime pays, so long as it is tribal and so long as it has the prefix "Whitey" in its name!" And anyone who doubts this can just ask our families. Or, better yet, look at the way the whole Boston moral ecosystem is today? Does anyone remember Charles Stuart?But in addition to forgetting the families, and forgetting to look objectively at the way Boston morality really is, these authors also forgot one other thing: The crime scene is not just restricted to the marshes bordering the Boston Harbor freeway. The Bulger brothers crime wave IS the new Boston moral ecosystem. The crime scene is all of Boston. It has affected not just the City Government, the FBI, the city police and highway patrolmen, it has also affected everyone and everything else in Boston too, including these authors. Whether they recognize it or not, their own timidity as reporters is an integral reaction to, and thus an integral part of the Bulger crime wave.This book, soon to be a movie, whose script has already been endorsed by Whitey, is nothing if not a carefully orchestrated social production under the direction of the ethics conducted by Billy and Whitey Bulger. If it were not so, why else would they so carefully tiptoe around every sensitive issue? If it were not so, why else would they not talk about those dead bodies Whitey and Flimmi left lining swamps near the Boston freeways? If it were not so, why would Whitey endorse it? If it were not so, why else would these authors fail to indict the criminal ethos of Boston that both created and allowed the Bulger brothers to thrive, and then run amok?I lived in Brookline, Ma., on Upton Street while doing a post-doc at MIT, during the academic year of 1991. One day, as I exited the subway station going home for lunch, there was a big commotion in the Strip Mall yards away from the subway stop. When I asked what had happened, I was told that a man had been shot dead trying to rob a bank. Then, as I approached my basement apartment two blocks away, I saw yet another set of police lights flashing with the tale-tell yellow ribbons around one of my neighbors' house. Again, I asked what had happened, but this time no one would answer. However, once inside my apartment, I flipped on the TV and the news was reporting that a Harvard Law Professor had been raped and knifed to death two doors from my apartment? And although I know that these were just two random events, things like that do have a way of leaving a permanent and jaundiced imprint on the mind.But even before this eventful day of two violent but random crimes, the only two I have witnessed in my life, so near my upper middle-class neighborhood, I had sensed and had already concluded that something was wrong with the Boston DNA. Everyone had a scowl on their faces. Everyone was mad about something, and whatever it was, I was not in on it? There appeared to be an evil vapor in the air. It undoubtedly must have been a part of the mystique of the Bulger ghost that still haunts the ethos of Boston today. And as beautiful and as cultured as Boston is, there is no city in America that scares me more. It is more tense, more racist, more unscaled, and yet, on a per capita basis, as violently criminal as any city in the US. I think twice every time I have to go there.It thus struck me as odd that even before they were implicitly threatened by those acting on Whitey Bulger's behalf, these authors had already adopted a "prevent defense" for writing this book, one designed more to respect the "criminal ways of Boston" than to get at the unalloyed underlying truth about the nature of crime in that very much troubled city. And who, in the last three decades have been most responsible for shaping those criminal ways? None more so than the infamous Bulger brothers.There is an evil spell hanging in the air in Boston, and here these authors, wittingly or not, rather than exposing it, have deferred to it. By deferring to the "ways of Boston immorality and crime," and giving the Bulger brothers too much undeserved respect, and too much moral running room -- by giving us here a sanitized version of the Bulger crimes -- they have tipped the scales and their hats in the direction of the existing Boston criminal ecosystem. They too have proven through and through that they are true Bostonians; that they too have been affected by, if not totally socially-adjusted by, Whitey and Billy Bulger's criminal ways of life; they too have drank the macho Southie tribalistic Kool Aid that says that Irish tribalism is more important than morality.Had I not read and reviewed several other books about both the "high" and "low" criminal careers of the Bulger brothers, books that now allow me to properly assess the devastation of their respective crime waves, I too might have been inclined to give this book a pass and say of it, and of these authors, the same as what other reviewers have said: "a job well done."However, after having read and reviewed several other books about this Boston criminal tornado, and after my own negative experiences in Boston, it is easy to see that these authors ducked, and took the easy way out. They merely tasted the slurry with the cream on top, not the bitterness beneath, wrought by the Bulger criminal tornado. They are thus wrong in their conclusions: The Bulgier brothers did not just change the FBI and Boston law enforcement departments forever, they also changed the moral ecosystem of Boston forever too.The movie based on this book will make a lot of money, because I am going to go see it myself. But if it too genuflects and bends in the direction of the two "maestros of Boston crime," as this book does, the moral ethics of James "Whitey" and William Bolger will be the winner of the Academy Awards. This book and that movie, will just help establish Whitey as another morally-damaged, undeserving criminal white folk hero, like Jessie James or Bonnie and Clyde, or General Custer. Let us be clear about one thing: Whitey Bulger is, and always will be, just another two-bit serial killing rat, a Southie thug and nothing more. Two stars

This is a well-argued but rather pessimistic essay written almost two decades ago by one of the heavyweights in the field of particle physics. It is based on the author's belief that the present search for  a unified theory of everything (TOE) -- based mostly on the developments in string theory -- is a misguided effort.At the time this book went to print in 1992, he believed that string theory and its related mathematical techniques, were all of low predictive power since they relied much too heavily on a suite of untested often ad hoc and speculative semi-deductive techniques of theorizing. These "partial theoretical techniques" seem to bootstrap their way up a never-ending deductive chain completely suspended in the intellectual ether, where he believed that they could never properly under go systematic scientific testing. The most important of these techniques being those that relied heavily on mathematical techniques that predicted symmetry-breaking.The author argued two decades ago that these techniques were based mostly on mathematical speculation, and thus were of low predictive power. Despite this, they just kept on expanding into an entire family of related symmetries-breaking ideas such as supersymmetry, supergravity, super-force, and superstrings themselves. It was the author's view that they all existed as a result of undue reliance on extra-scientific theorizing, theorizing that in the end he believed would be worthless since they could never be tested with real data?Yet, since this book went to print, in 1992, the LHC at CERN, using the theories that this author was so pessimistic about, has been able to produce hard and testable evidence of the existence of the Higgs boson particle, a finding that at least goes a long way towards confirming the standard model. It goes without saying that it was based primarily on the techniques the author gauged to be of low predictive power.Although, in the author' favor, the CERN predictions did not go beyond the standard model to, for instance, predict the W' or Z' gauge bosons. So, at least technically, the author remains right about the lack of scientific verification of models that go beyond the standard model of particle physics. However, given what has been discovered so far, I would not be too sanguine if I were in his position. Three stars

Immediately, the reader will get the impression that this book has been mislabelled. The subtitle is "A biblical, Philosophical and Scientific Exploration" of the theories on the creation out of nothing (creatio ex Nihilo). However, Philosophical and Scientific theories do not enter the discussion until the last three chapters, the last 100 pages of the book. The bulk of the book, five of its eight chapters, 2/3 of its 266 pages -- very much after the fact -- are devoted exclusively to trying to establish a religious argument that justifies and supports a biblical interpretation of the Big Bang Theory.After reading the book, it would be an understatement to say that the religious energy devoted to this effort has been energy poorly spent, as they all have been maximally confusing and mutually inconsistent -- but curiously always toeing the orthodox religious line.In fact, after trying vainly to make sense out of all of this religious ambiguity, the reader will surely discover as I did, that there is at least one heavy-hitting high level religious advocate on every side of these discussions, including on the side that warns against trying to coordinate biblical interpretation with scientifically derived facts. Of all the topics that one would think are most critical to religious beliefs -- creation out of nothing -- the reader will also discover that there is no consensus, nor even a minimally consistent biblical view?In other words, sadly, and after 166 pages, these religious scholars' arguments curiously all remained at right angles to each other?  In the end, exactly nothing was resolved!My own conclusion is that the "religionists way of proof," that is, proof "by the fiat of divine authority," may have inadvertently hoisted them by their own petard, and thus, may have left them hanging in the wind, way out on a slippery slope, one that like one of the roads leading away from Nob Hill in San Francisco, leans steeply and precipitously downwards.It seems to me that the best of the many religious arguments put forth here, do little more than set up a spurious dichotomy between the cosmological facts of science (i.e., the Big Bang Theory), and the theological affirmation (or is it confirmation?) of it by God through jerry-rigged, and shaky after the fact established scripture-based truths (i.e. by the fiat of divine authority as read in the scripture).However, having set up this spurious dichotomy, I believe Kwasi Wiredu's and Hans Swartz's warnings about "not too quickly identifying religious interpretations with the temporal scientific beginnings of the universe," is well advised and correlate well with my own views. For doing so, begs the very important question of what happens when the scientific facts and theories change, as invariably they will?  Does God's authority then also change? Are scriptual references then to also be updated as was the case with most of this book? If they do, then does this not simply mean that God's authority will always be "playing catch-up" to the latest scientific theories?Since the idea of scientific proof is just the opposite of religious proof -- that is to say, it does NOT just sit back and defend forever singularly established scientific facts, truths, or theories, but instead, it puts them all through the most rigorous of scientific tests: the test of falsification.Like religionists, scientists too do start out with but one goal -- but it is the opposite of what religionists start out to do: Scientists try as much as they possibly can, to overthrow and thereby try to falsify their own theories. Only those that survive this most brutal and rigorous process of falsification, will survive as true well-tested theories.What this means of course is that the Big Bang Theory is itself forever "an open-ended hypothesis" about the nature of creation -- not a once for all times scientific truth. The Big Bang theory therefore must forever be opened to future falsification. So far it survives because it has not yet failed a singular attempt to falsify it. And if in the future it should fail even one attempt at falsification, it will then be declared forever, an invalid theory. And the process simply begins all over again with a new trial hypothesis about the nature of creation.Therefore, the regionalists must be careful. If they hook their "creationist's wagons" up to the Big Bang Theory, inadvertently they are also hooking it up to the scientific method's mode of falsification. Now, do religionists really want to do that? I don't think so? Three stars

The topic of this book is the science of the Ishango Bones. With dedication and patience, and wherever it was possible to do so, use of the highest research standards, Mr. Marshack has shown beyond a reasonable scientific doubt that the groupings of markings on the bones of tribesmen of the Central African Congo of 35,000 years ago, is probably the first instance of man engaging in science -- mathematics in particular. Beyond a reasonable doubt, he has shown that these engraved scripted bones, at the very least were the first recorded lunar calculators, used to chart and predict the lunar cycles and all survival activities associated with such cycles.Many who read and engage in research on the early history of mankind, feel that something is very much amiss in Archaeological theorizing? Even if it is only a deep feeling within their bones, many feel as I do that since the Archaeologists often get the time-scale of fossils wrong by orders of magnitude, and are constantly revising their theories of intellectual and cognitive development in early humans, being caught on their back foot seems more the rule than the exception, more like an occupational hazard of the field? And although errors in time-scale estimates may be due in large part to the porousness and scarcity of fossil finds, errors in theorizing, it seems to me, is wholly a product of lack of imagination. And, as this author argues, an unwillingness to venture too far from the orthodox line.Perhaps it was my own naveté that led me to believe that Cognitive Archaeology thus would welcome and embrace the radical new platform for theorizing offered up here by Professor Alexander Marshack. However, the more one examines Marshack's thesis, the more revolutionary and formidable, and thus threatening, it can be seen to be to the established orthodoxy. It would not be an exaggeration to compare its impact on Archaeology to the impact Darwin's theory of Evolution has had on religion. Protectors of the state-sanctioned orthodoxy have circled their wagons to resist any new theoretical encroachments.Stated as simply as it can be stated, Mr. Marshack has hypothesized that any Archaeological theories of human intellect based on "supposed" changes in brain architecture, unless such changes can be accounted for experimentally, are likely to be wrong. This is true, as he sees it, because the brain architecture of pre-humans and modern man, at least for the last 100,000 years, as far as we can tell, has been essentially the same. So the science being performed by the Ishango tribesmen, and the PhD scientists at the Jet propulsion Laboratory, are different only in degree, not in kind, different only in the content of the data used and problems being solved. The processes used, however more complex for "modern man" than for "primitive man," are still the same as that used by the Ishango Congo African tribesman.This is certainly true as far as it can be determined through their respective cognitive functioning brain architecture. The author thus argues here, rather convincingly in my view, that since the beginning of time, man's creative thinking has always been both purposeful and time-bound -- directed almost exclusively at the problem of survival for the moment. As a result, while the content of thinking may have changed over various epochs, ecologies and cultures, the process of thinking itself has not.His crowning point is that, as much as Western man would like for it to be so, "mind development" is not quite the same thing as "brain or architecture development." Like cultural development, mind and intellectual development are almost never "a bolt-out-of-the-blue" - the de fault category when no reasonable explanation is forthcoming -- but like culture, man's intellectual development, such as science, is a continuous, connected, layered accreted process that takes place over long periods of time. It seems that for reasons having to do with modern chauvinism alone, incredibly, no one in Archaeology has ever begun with such an assumption about brain architecture versus the process of human cognitive development, before. I do not believe it would be an exaggeration of the author's point to suggest that almost all of man's development -- in agriculture, in art, in economics, politics, etc. -- is also of the process sort. Ten Stars!

This book is one of a trilogy of books penned by Charles Mann. They bracket 1492, the fateful year of "discovery."  It tells the story of what happened the last year before the European invasion of the Americas. It is a revealing historical research/travel-guide -- overlain with, and guided by, a forensic-like Anthropological debate between two heavyweights in the field, both of whom were in search of the truth of what actually happened before, during and after the conquest of the Americas.It is a spirited search that literally leaves no stones unturned. It is thus a tribute to the author that the book is an even-handed and balanced report on, about all there is available to report on in the field of research on this issue. It is a report best characterized by the author's flair for getting out of the way of his own story, allowing the narrative to breath, and the data to speak for themselves: And boy what an interesting story they have to tell.A quick and dirty summary of the book is that the most recently uncovered data, thoroughly massaged with an amazing compliment of modern research tools, concludes that the history we have been "force-fed" since Grade School, and is best represented in Allan Holmburg's Cornell PhD thesis as "Holmburg's Mistake," is simply wrong.For instance, the Americas were NOT unoccupied virgin lands, but were quite the opposite: well-managed lands cleared of forests and underbrush, populated by estimates of up to 100 million people. The data reviewed here proves that distinct cultures of Indians went back for at least four millennia, and slivers of evidence exists that they may even have gone as far back as 30,000 years ago!What the European invaders mistook for virgin lands was in fact the mere remnants, the remaining stragglers and the last flickers of a dying people, people who as a result of the mega-deaths caused by exposure to European transported diseases, had simply abandoned the lands and were wandering about trying find their bearings as the forests began to reclaim the land. It was these reclaimed forests and these scattered groups of wandering survivors that the invaders actually saw. In point of fact, before the invasion, the Americas had been well-managed for millennia, by, among other techniques, the continuous use of controlled "slash-and-burn" fires. And although this technique did put more stress on the environment by emitting more carbon into the air, it also renewed the soil.The Indians were not, as Allan Holmburg's mistaken Cornell Phd thesis implied: "among the most uncultured and most backward peoples to ever walk the face of the earth." In fact, once researchers were able to move beyond the wandering stragglers that the early settlers had confronted, they found that the Indians were a varied group of people who lived and survived in cultures that respected nature as best they could, for at least four millennia. Some succeeded brilliantly at it -- even beyond anything to be seen elsewhere in the rest of the world until at least a millennium or so later. Others failed at it, some damaged the environment, and some didn't survive at all.As for Holmburg's notion that all Indians were cultural backward, except for a pocket of culture in Renaissance Italy, Europe was still digging its way out of the feudal Dark Ages. England, for instance, even within the monarchy, had not yet invented the bath and personal hygiene, On the other hand, Indians bathed daily and could not stand the stench of the body odor of the invaders. In one of the most colorful examples in the book, a Connecticut tribe so detested engaging up close and personal with the unhygienic invaders, that they traded with them by conveying goods back and forth across the Connecticut River by rope and pulley. To further show their disgust, the Indians across the river laughed and "mooned" the Settlers as a final mocking and derisive insult to end their transactions. Indians were taking daily bathes when Londoners were still throwing garbage into the streets from their windows, creating a cesspool for the breeding and proliferation of rats as well as an incubator for spreading diseases like small pox and the plague. It was England's own lax hygiene habits coupled with its extreme poverty, that were in large part responsible for both the later "white flight" to the "New World" and for the diseases, poverty and rats, they brought along with them.But beyond hygiene, at least two millennia before Europe was even thought of as being a viable continent, Indians had experimented with, and succeeded at inventing modern forms of civic interactions, such as municipal governments and administrations, including their own forms of representative democracy and socialism. They polities had no poverty or taxes. They lived in literally hundreds of well-run city states, flung across two continents from Canada to Chile.Under government administration, they built large-scale monolithic monuments and infrastructure projects like dams, viaducts, irrigations waterways, roads and highways, engaged in collective farming, raised animals and plants, successfully bred a wide variety of plants; were the first to produce potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers, melons, cassava, bananas, peach trees, maize, tobacco and engaged in both domestic and international trade. The Indians of Peru/Brazil, invented a soil compose that was 880 times as fertile as anything we have yet seen in modern agriculture. This potent form of dirt is a mystery still being studied in universities across the globe. And even though it took them two millennia to understand the full uses of metal, which they smelted but used only for ceremonial purposes; and the wheel, which they used only to make children's toys; and also failed to invent money because they had no need for it, Indian cultures nevertheless did engage in Astronomy, using megaliths like Stonehenge to reckon the stars and the moon; mathematics by inventing the first calendars, and accounting practices. As well, they were the first to invent the zero, and bootstrapped the accounting and the zero into the invention of writing.At "first contact," new uses of both metal and the wheel were re-introduced to the Americas, and this reintroduction proved to be a game changer. For Indian culture, these new uses were transformative, as it allowed them finally to see the importance of guns, and of even more importance, they could finally replace stone axes for iron ones. Trading with Settlers for metal goods like pots and pans and iron axes was so important that whole Indian communities moved closer to settler communities in order to be first in line to buy the Settlers' metal products. Wars were even instigated among Indians in order to control access to trade with Settlers for metal products with their newer uses.As for conquest itself, this book clears up many matters previously shrouded in obscurity, or left as a mystery to history. First, while the European gun was frightful, it was not into the late 18th Century before it was as accurate or as lethal as the Indian longbow. Moreover, the two most important allies of European conquest were not the superiority of European soldiers or their guns as we have been repeatedly told, but the much more subtle and silent allies that remained unknown and unknowable to the Europeans at the time: diseases and demography.The research here shows that European diseases killed and removed Indians from the land so rapidly and in such large numbers that Settlers would take over their camps and villages lock-stock-and-barrel just as quickly as they died. Where upon, unsavory entrepreneurs, sponsoring "pie-in-the-sky come-ons for voyages across the Atlantic to promote imperial expansion, radically increased their promotion ads in order to "con" more and more poor and disgruntled Europeans to move to the Americas. This increase in numbers would eventually possess a quality of its own. For within decades, the increased population helped those with the larger numbers, to commandeer larger and larger swarths of land. Larger numbers alone, invariably translated into both more wealth and more power for those who took over large tracts of land. Unfortunately, those that did so, were almost exclusively the landed gentry, among them being pirates and smugglers, as well as ship-owning and ship-building corporate enterprises. Only rarely did an ordinary immigrant, seeking their "proverbial pot of gold at the end of the rainbow," promoted by unsavory ads, end up with large parcels of land. Most ended up as indentured servants.As but one example of how the phenomenon of catastrophic losses due to diseases worked in wars of conquest, the research here proves that, at a very minimum, it drastically changed the calculus of divide and conquer, and did so decisively in favor of the Settlers, as it made it infinitely easier for decimated tribes, acting out of pure survival desperation, to be willing to side with the Settlers in an effort to outmaneuver and thereby out-survive their tribal enemies.There also was yet another not quite so silent ally to European conquest. It too was one that saved the North American Settlers from themselves -- i.e., from their own incompetence in survival skills, and their poor ability to wage war, as well from their own well-known laziness and infighting. This ally was a plant, one of the many that Indians had learned to harvest and that quickly became a profitable item of trade between American Settlers and European markets.That plant was called tobacco. And according to the research reviewed here, at the time that tobacco was being introduced as the saving grace of North America's transatlantic trade (a trade that would eventually become second only to slavery), it was probably more a potent hallucinogen than the equivalent of one of today's more innocent habit-forming "nicotine vehicles" called cigarettes. The point being that only after Catholic Maryland and Protestant Virginia began to export the drug tobacco in large amounts, was the survival of the colonies ensured.In summary, the author's storyline centers on the academic debate that among many other things, demolished "Holmburg's Mistake." That debate, as it turns out is an academic "battle royal," that will simply titillate the reader to no end. But I would point out that it is a deadly serious debate, the likes of which, we have not seen since Newton and Einstein ideas squared-off in debates over the true nature gravity. And like in that battle, the differences between the sides in this one too lies in academic nuances, not in the main revised storylines. Here, importantly, and to their credit, both sides agree that "Holmburg's Mistake" can no longer stand as acceptable and respectable American History.Representing one side of this debate is Dr. Betty Meggers of the Smithsonian Institute, who advances the rather contentious notion (that later research simply does not back up): that the Olmecs of Mexica, were the end point of the Native American cultural line, putting the oldest Indian culture back to being no older than about fifteen centuries old.On the other side of this debate is Dr. Anna Roosevelt, of Yale University, who retraced, and in part, replicated and then went well beyond the research of Dr. Meggers, concluded that the true cultural history of Indians goes back much further, as far back as four millennia, and perhaps as far back as even beyond the era of the oldest city known to man, Sumer.As a result of Roosevelt's findings, she now believes that if we accept Meggers' rendition of Indian pre-history -- that is, that it began with the Olmecs -- then we will have simply replaced Holmberg's Mistake with a more sophisticated but slightly updated version of it. One that instead of cutting Indian cultural history off at the neck, cuts it off at the knees instead. But perhaps more importantly, she claims that Meggers theories obscure more than they reveal. The very fact that their true cultural history and contribution goes back at least four millennia and possibly as far back as 30,000 years, makes it a second order crime to stop cultural exploration at the Olmecs. In any case, this debate is the headiest one raging across the generations that now exists in academia. Five Stars

If one has a predilection to first take a "mind trip" before actually visiting a historical city, as I do, he can do no better than read this beautifully rendered book about the history of Rome. I have not been to Rome since my diplomatic days, but what I remember are exquisitely rendered in the glossies of this book (minus all the pigeon droppings and the associated smells). Yet, on a sunny day, Rome is difficult to beat anywhere in the world.The brief chronology of Roman history from its origin to the year 2000 gives the kind of perspective that old brains that have forgotten most of Roman history, sorely need. It is also helpful that the structures are numbered in the pictures making it easier to identify the unfamiliar ones.I am unfamiliar with this publisher, but his work should be commended. I highly recommend this book for future travelers to Rome. Four stars.

This book outlines a scary new paradigm, which effectively upgrades and revises the old imperialist phenomenon once referred to only as "Western Economic Imperialism." This new version 2.0 of the phenomenon of "Western Economic Imperialism," is presented here as a heady, smart, "Marxist tainted," skillfully deployed, clandestine, information run, theoretical paradigm of a new global order. One that hypothesizes that the old familiar notion of imperialism is not so much dead and gone as rendered obsolete and no longer applicable to the capitalists' exigencies and necessities of our post-modern times.The newer model 2.0 has adapted, evolved, and inexorably morphed from the old limited state-centered modern economic-based capitalist model of production, that once loyally served and was well-integrated into the community within a nation state which it exploited, to today's much broader, much more amorphous, globally de-centered, almost detached, as well as de-cultured but information-based, stand alone post-modern economic, organism. This new organism has no discernible human attachments, and most of all, no return address. Its only known identity is its offshore secret bank account numbers in the Cayman Islands or Switzerland.This newer, epistemologically more slippery organism leaves the mistaken impression that state-based and citizen-based sovereignty somehow has declined and is withering away? But in fact, as these authors so carefully point out, sovereignty itself has not declined so much as has simply been moved on up to a higher plane into the ether of cyberspace by a new global cabal. And there it has "parked" and then been taken over by a "new much more organized and much more sinister form of management," a form of management that is defined by, and operates under, the new rules of global empire.In short, the political controls, state functions, regulatory mechanisms and means of capitalist production that used to operate within carefully proscribed and limited territorial and state-centered grids, and more or less under citizen sovereignty, have now moved on to the higher plane where the new corporate rules of supra nationalism and global economic manipulation are invoked, with a vengeance.These are corporate rules devised by ad hoc coalitions of like-minded capitalist robber barons, having allegiances to no one but themselves and their global enterprises -- such as the race to the bottom of the global labor pool, buying and controlling politicians the world over, despoiling the environment, and maintaining control over the very lucrative international drug trade. In these endeavors, these new managers, unlike their forerunner and model, the managers at the CIA, now have no need to be associated with any known or recognizable state structures. This new amorphous cabal, and their self-defined rules, now constitute a new capitalist entity unto themselves, in the new corporate-run capitalist global world order.Remember the good old days when the reactionary right had an existential fear of "one world government under UN auspices?" No one could have ever imagined that the flip side of that fear, of that one world coin, would be much worst: that it would involve these same reactionaries colluding with like-minded capitalist industrialists the world over, to produce the much scarier scenario of another one world government: only this time it is a new global world order under a vicious "dog-eat-dog" global capitalist corporate cabal?  Five stars

This powerful poetic ati-war essay offered in the form of a novel about the universal meanings of war, and the significance those meanings attach to manhood, fear, bravery, cowardice and male character, is perhaps Steven Crane's best work. It is set in a war of "blues" against "grays," and traces the "manhood construction project" of one generic soldier, called Henry "the youth."Henry had dreamed of the valor and glory of joining the military to fight and become a war hero. He luxuriated in his imaginary glory, until, once he was on the battlefield, the stark reality of the brutality of war, hit him. The shock of this reality caused him to question everything: the purpose of war, morality, his own bravery, as well as his own character.The story is brilliantly told along two parallel tracks: the raw brutality of the reality of war and its utter indifference to man on the one hand -- as well as through the inner voice and conscience of one scared and confused young soldier, Henry -- on the other.Until the fighting actually began, Henry had smugly decided that war was quite boring, rather senseless and that all of his commanding officers were incompetents. But then, once the shooting started -- in the heat and fury of battle -- Henry's self-confidence and superior attitude gave way to instincts of self-preservation, which came into play in a big way. Henry's "fight or flight" instincts were severely tested during his second battle, and the flight instinct apparently won out, as he failed the only manhood test war had offered him: He had fled from the battlefield.While going AWOL, Henry hovered along the periphery of the battlefield spying on what was taking place. He did this long enough to see his unit routed, his best friend killed and many of his comrades wounded. The guilt of seeing his best friend killed, his comrades in arms injured, and himself on the sidelines as a bona fide deserter and coward, overwhelmed Henry and he slowly and slyly tried to find a way back into his unit without his desertion being discovered. While falling in the line with a group of retreating soldiers, he asked an annoying question of one of them. In anger, the soldier smashed Henry up side the head with the butt of his rifle.He rejoined his unit still bleeding from the head wound, and naturally his comrades thought he had been injured in battle like the others. And with the injury serving as his new "red badge of courage," Henry was accorded the full attention deserving of a soldier "actually" wounded in battle.For the rest of his military career, Henry not only found it convenient to hide behind the lies of his desertion and his fake wound. His life was re-centered around a delusional version of himself --  as a wounded war hero who had never fled from the battlefield. He learned to live hiding behind his lies, fashioning a new "life script" of courage and heroism built on this delusional foundation.Having had his life redeemed through fiat, with no one the wiser, allowed Henry to faced down his fears as well as the horrors of war, the same as any other brave warrior would have done. He thus surprised himself by then going forth conquering his fear and acquitting himself well in subsequent battles, in the end becoming a decorated war hero who had achieved the glory he sought. However, he did not acquire it without having been given a second chance, nor without the benefit of the kind of self-awareness that comes with maturity.His redemption, although it came as a second chance masked under the guile of self-deception, nevertheless allowed Henry to find the space to better contemplate the meaning of his life --  as well as to better understand the morality of war.Among other things, his introspection taught him that morality was man-made rather than inherent in nature. Under such conditions it was thus indeed possible to be a coward and still overcome one's fears and become a hero based on actual deeds achieved on the battlefield.There are many morals to Crane's story beyond those acquired by Henry, foremost among them being that war is senseless. But a related one is that the pursuit of glory through the senselessness of war is even more senseless. Also, Crane's novel is a redemption story that parallels the Christian story of redemption. Only here the redemption is achieved through "actual" exploits on the battlefield, rather than through the single symbolic act of Baptism, which, to the extent it is a deed at all, is one centered on ritual. Five stars

As usual, DK publications are the best: succinct, to the point, but with all the substance a traveler will need, all provided in a neat -- even slick -- "near hardback" package. With the 3-D color overhead aerial photos of key tourist sections of the city of Honolulu as the hub of key pages, the reader feels like he knows his destination even before he arrives? Well organized and well laid out. Difficult to beat. Five stars

Given that it was a Clint Eastwood directed movie, who as a Republican, had no choice but to "crop" the political context -- finessing the fact that the Seals ended up in Fallujah under the misimpression sold to us by the Cheney-Bush administration that Saddam Hussein had WMD -- it was a decent well done movie.For an American war movie, the acting by the lead, was strong, understated and superbly played. It will surely garner a Best Actor's award. Although, the dialog was contemporary "Texas-American," it was surprisingly realistic and devoid of overly syrupy patriotic mush. I enjoyed the movie despite its formulaic nature and the fact that the 911 dialogue in the set up piece was intended to mislead the viewer politically.The script was not deep, but what there was, was economic and tightly written. The only negative was that it left the unstated impression that all American soldiers, and especially the Navy Seals, are all politically tone-deaf patriotic drones: that they click their heels and die for any American cause, without asking any questions, the "my country, right or wrong" syndrome. Those who questioned the war were either seen as cowards (like Chris' brother, who cashed-in early), or made their views known posthumously (as in a letter read at the funereal of his fallen best friend).I give the movie four stars, reserving five stars for my pick as this year's Best Picture: "The Imitation Game," which is actually much too smart; too well done, and too British to be selected as Best picture. So, by default, "American Sniper" may indeed win. If it does, I will not be disappointed.

This well written, carefully researched biography reminds us of what Richard Pryor, the man and his life has taught us: How to navigate and survive the complex existential set of fears called "American Society."Richard too came into this world "an innocent." He learned indirectly and brutally from his own immediate family that in this world he was alone and had to navigate it all by himself. The only real friends Richard had were his ever-present inner demons. Those demons can be seen etched in his eyes on the cover of this book: Richard Pryor, the black comedian extraordinaire, until his premature demise, had good reasons to be scared to death of this world and of where his own life might take him in it.He feared his parents, especially his violent father Buck, who his own sister had said about him at his funereal that he had screwed everybody, and that Richard should be happy that he had escaped being screwed by him too. But also there was his Grandmother Marie Carter Bryant, the "madam," no less brutal than her sons, who ruled over her family and her black female sex slaves and prostitutes, in the same way that John Gotti ruled over the mob: brutally tyrannically and with purposefully cultivated fear. This of course did not deter her from manning the front pew of her Baptist Church every Sunday morning -- apparently she had existential fears of her own?Richard was scared of the rest of his family too, as they were a clan of societal misfits who made their living on the backstreets of American ghetto life, in the underground economy of Peoria, Illinois. Which is another way of saying that they were a tribe of low-lifes: criminals, who lived on the edge and died by the codes of the streets. From day-to-day, their lives, as was Richard's, was always up for grab, an existential "crap shoot:" You were as likely to get shot or hauled off to jail as you were to eat a ham sandwich.Richard's innocence was stolen from him, as is too often the case in the US, through societal osmosis. He was fearful of the carnal knowledge that he had picked up peeping over the transoms of his Christian grandmother's whorehouses, a knowledge he had acquired while he was still too young to understand, but which nevertheless had a lasting effect on his always fragile psyche. It taught him how to be numb to sex, numb to love and to all tender feelings, as well as to most other emotions -- even before he possessed the maturity to understood their meanings. It also taught him how not to trust anyone, including and especially his grandmother, even though throughout his life he pretended that she was the only one in the family that he did love? That he loved Marie, is itself much too twisted for even the best Psychologist to make any sense of?He was fearful of American white society too. But despite his fear, he was nevertheless dumped into it against his will via the racist white schools he was forced to attend. They too robbed him of his innocence by telling him early and often that "black boys" (they used the N-word) were not wanted, and that there was no place in American society for him. He got the same message (and the same N-word) from his commanding officers while serving a stint in the US Army in Germany, defending democracy overseas but not here at home.He also got it in Hollywood when he refused to continue "playing-the-fool," the only role carved out and reserved for black Comedians. That is one of the reasons he chose to follow in the footsteps of Dr. William Cosby.On his way to the kind of freedom and success that America reserves exclusively for the handful of black comics that toe the racist social and political line, Dr. Cosby had cornered the market for the role of America's first "neutered race free black comic." Richard decided he would be the second. Until recently, Cosby never looked back, gained unheard of wealth and fame -- that is until all of the recent revelations about him drugging and raping a whole parcel of young ingenues and star-seeking females, hit the tabloids.And in perhaps the oddest paradox of his life, the sliver of humanity reflected back to him as the class clown, as Cosby's doppelgänger, another black comic in "blackface," something he had learned out of necessity to gain attention within the family, to avoid the daily beat-downs at school, and in order to get a job in entertainment field, set the parameters for the rest of his life. It wasn't much to hold onto, but throughout his life, this was the thin reed that "America's master comic" held onto.Most of all, Richard Pryor was scared of himself. He desperately wanted (indeed needed) to first know who he was; and then he wanted to be loved. Both needs made him vulnerable. His deepest fear however, was that with or without love, he would not survive -- and that even if he did manage to survive, he would end up like the rest of the family tribe, a backstreet low-life; a hypocritical Christian -- forever gaming on other blacks just to survive a miserable second-class life.Thus, Richard Pryor's life, paradoxically was an "object lesson" in how, in America, to successfully wrestle one's demons to the ground, and still not win the battle, and still not pin them to the mat; that is, and still come out on the other side, a loser.The idea that "ignorance is bliss" has been a flawed ground rule of common sense since time immemorial. However, I believe that Richard's life finally and conclusively proves this simple-minded ground rule of life is nonsense. While it is true that the less we know about the world, and about ourselves, the less chance we have that our demons and fears will ever trip us up, over take us, or turn us into catatonic zombies, but it is equally true that remaining ignorant of self and the world around us is one of the worse strategies for survival and for finding enlightenment, enjoyment, meaning, love and richness in life, known to man.However, you couldn't tell that to a "Christian madam" like Marie Carter Bryant, Rich's grandmother? She had her own brand of bliss, all of the answers to life were in her book, where bliss was born, raised and lived on the bed side tables in the rooms where her whores were "being serviced." The "holy water" from being a Baptist, obviously inoculated and protected Marie from all of life's foibles, including especially self-knowledge.Lets be clear about this, Richard Pryor was nobody's saint or hero. He was a talented comic but a severely flawed piece of humanity. All one has to do to confirm this is to just look at his eyes on the front cover of this book. His eyes say it all: that, I don't belong here? --wherever here might be.But Richard was brave in this one sense. He did not always react to fear in the expected way. As for the fear of his family, for instance, he ran -- as far away from Peoria as he could get and never looked back. As far as his fear of race and sex, like most Americans, he tried all combinations and seemed to have never mastered either.But on the more important plane of conquering the fear of being and becoming Richard Pryor, he used comedy as his creative cudgel, his personal club to hit others over the head with to see what their reactions said about him. He was the reflection in his audiences eyes, and nothing more. It was a colossally ineffective way to learn about ones self, but again, it was all that Richard Franklin Lennox Thomas Pryor really had. Pryor's life was little more than a painful, long-running experiment in acquiring self-knowledge the hard way.His journey began as a class clown in an integrated school in Peoria, Ill., and ended as a beloved "truth-teller" who had gained fame and "reflected love" throughout the world, but little real love and even less personal peace. Clowning got him a seat at the white table, both as a kid and as an adult. When he confiscated Cosby's persona, he was another "neutered black clown" without portfolio. But who was this black man in "blackface" standing on the stage in Las Vegas, and staring back at Richard in the mirror? Even he did not know?Despite what Oprah and Dr. Phil tell us, there is no roadmap to either success or self-knowledge. One must find his own route, and then keep knocking at the door until it cracks open and then be prepared to jump in. The door opened for Richard Pryor several times, but as intelligent as he was, as talented as he was, and as good as he was at conning others (as well as himself), he never acquired the emotional stability or armor and equipment needed to feel himself worthy to walk in that door on his own and in his own shoes. Someone should have pulled his coattails and told him that what he was looking for in life rarely exists: A world of honest people, deserving of a self-aware Richard who will tell him the truth and then accept him as he is?His melt-down at the Aladdin in 1967 was his moment of truth, his "come to Jesus" moment. It was the point at which he had become tone-deaf to his own jokes. When he heard them coming out of his own mouth, he did not laugh; and when he looked into the mirror, he did not recognize the person staring back at him?  That was when he walked off the stage at the Aladdin ...When Richard finally reached the top of Mount Self-knowledge, having conquered most but not all of his fears, all he saw on the other side staring back at him, were pygmies just like the old Richard -- other people with the same demons: the same America that he had run away from: in Peoria, in New York, in Las Vegas?Rather than go around that wheel again, one has to presume that Richard decided to take the shortcut home. This time Richard decided he needed just one friend and it was not Paul Mooney: It was the one that would soothe all of his fears, always be at his bedside; the one that would accept him unconditionally; the one that would never judge him; never betray him; the one that would always laugh at all his jokes, the one that was always on his side through thick or thin; the ultimate white girlfriend: cocaine. End of the story of how to become Richard Pryor. Five stars

As much as I detest the Kim Jung Un's of the world, this movie does not speak for me. It is so bad that it should not be allowed to make a political statement on behalf of the American people.This movie is so bad that political considerations should be set aside, cinematographic art must have some minimum standards and must trump bottom feeding attempts at making a political statement such as this.I only went to see it because I refused to allow the likes of Kim Jung Un restrict my free speech via terrorist threats. However, it would have been better if I had just mailed my money into the cable company and avoided watching this cinematographic train wreck. Ugh! minus one star.

Since I knew Oprah was affiliated with this project, I figured somehow it would be twisted into another half-baked "Uncle Tom/Aunt Jemima" trope, the same way that everything else she and Tyler Perry get involved in. As a result, I told myself I would pass it up. But my curiosity got the best of me. And I am happy to report that it was a well done movie. A tightly crafted screen play, after obviously having been pieced together from what undoubtedly had to be sporadic and fragmented materials.Both LBJ and King came off as believable human characters although Coretta leaned too much in the "expected cardboard Aunt Jemima cutout" direction to be believable. Also, I was very disappointed that Malcolm X's speech at the Church in Selma was mentioned but purposely nixed. The times (and this movie) cried out for the new "Malcolm unity move" that he single-handedly was trying to integrate into the King-led movement. However, it is a measure of the kind of conservative forces controlling the script that it was omitted: Shame!Also, the role that Harry Belafonte played in getting a bunch of Hollywood heavy hitters down to Alabama for the march (he spent well over $200K) was very much minimized. Those writing the script should have read what William Cohen's wife had to say about Harry's role, or what reverend King, or Marlon Brando said about him in his autobiography, or indeed Harry's own honest description of those events provided in his own very fine autobiography.Oprah, as usual hogged center stage -- front and center -- in her usual uncompromising Aunt Jemima role. [C'mon Oprah, have you no shame? Grow up: when are your going to give that Aunt Jemima trope up? Jeez, you are a billionaire? Relax, your slip is showing?]This is an okay movie, with honest intentions, but not Academy Award material in my view. Three stars

The Imitation Game is far and away the best picture of 2014, and 2015 so far. A beautiful, mature tightly written screen play, about the life of codebreaking math phenom and homosexual, Alan Turin.It is based on the book about his life and is written with believable dialogue and a minimum of frills, props and pyrotechnics -- and thus in this sense is very un-American.Superbly cast and a lot of straight ahead superb but very challenging acting. Treats mature themes sensitively and believably. It did not hurt that it was also situated in an upper class English setting.Were it not so intelligently done, it would be odds on to win the 2014 Academy Awards. However, being both intelligent and the complete cinematic package -- screen-play, casting, acting and mature no frills themes -- these will surely disqualify it from serious consideration for the Academy Awards. Despite being overlooked by the Academy, I will be seeing it again. This movie is worth at least five stars.

Into the Woods should win the academy award for "Best Kids Movie of the Year," for having cleverly and seamlessly patched together several famous Western Fairy Tales.However, it cannot win the "best adult movie of the year" award because, for the first time, the adult movie goer will get to see what happens when the quality of the roles do not quite measure up to the quality of the actors performing them?It simply means that the actors "get a free ride:" They get away with murder by being allowed to "underperform" their way to a big payday: The "over-qualified actors" are let off the hook and left to their own devices to find clever ways to "dumb-down their acting" in order to meet the diminished demands of their respective roles. Here they did so by either "coasting" or "putting-on" in rather hammish ways. Delp is already a past expert at it, but the others like Streep?The teenagers in the theater I attended (tyson's 16) did a lot of snickering. What these actors did, did not strike me as funny, at all.It is a movie that will make a lot of prepubescent kids happy and will make a lot of money. And thus for that reason alone, must be considered an odds on favorite to win the Oscar. But will it be deserving of it? Not based on my aesthetic sensibilities. Two-and-a-half stars.

The claim made in this book, Dope, Inc. is a provocative, almost outlandish one: It is that the British Crown has been at the top of the pyramid of the international drug trade since the days of the East India company. It is well known that Britain ruled both the slave trade and the Chinese opium trade through the East India Company for well over a century. But since then, London's control over the international drug trade has been more clandestine and certainly less well known.One reason it has flown under the radar is that control over the trade was not consolidated until the end of prohibition. It was only then that the syndicated infrastructure used during prohibition -- to distill, transport and distribute alcohol -- was then converted over to an operation sophisticated enough to control the world wide drug trade. This top secret, top-down "British run syndicate," involved three hierarchically-ordered rings of power, all radiating downward from London.The first ring is made up of trusted aides, including court Jews (known as Hofjudens, or house Jews), who, since the days of Feudalism have served the British Crown loyally as its preferred courtiers. In the drug trade, Hofjudens were among a group that also included high level military and intelligence operatives, who served as "cutouts" for sensitive operations. Their job was to establish the arrangements for the international drug trade, and to manage laundering drug monies, and then investing profits through European and American banks -- all to be done under the watchful eye of UK national security.Among the Hofjudens discussed here are the Rothchilds, of England and France, the Brofmans of Canada, and Arnold Rothstein of the US. The Rothchild family had been engaged with the Crown in international finance, war industries and banking during both world wars, while the Brofman family and Rothstein, had run liquor for the Crown during prohibition.The second ring of power included the use of Sicilian as well as Jewish mobsters to distribute drugs to street vendors and users. Foremost among members of this ring was Meyer Lansky and Lucky Luciano. The mob group jointly led by them, also had deep illicit ties with both the Crown and the USG -- first through liquor running that went as far back as prohibition, and later through the Navy during WW-II, up through gun-running both for Israel and for and against Castro's revolution -- after which, Lansky was summarily kicked out of Havana.Right after the war, at the time Israel was being established, Lansky's drug trafficking routes doubled-down as gun-running routes, where both became indispensable in providing needed military and financial assistance in establishing Israel. Along with Lansky, the Hafjudens, that had been loyally to the Crown, were now deeply involved in running surplus weapons from European armories and American ships into Israel, as well as using drug profits to provide the much needed hard currency to finance the development of the new state of Israel. Ship loads of stockpiled Allied WW-II weapons, somehow, just managed to get diverted to Israel.The third and final ring of power emanating out from the Crown, was the circle of power that involved aspiring politicians, those in a position to facilitate bringing drugs in through the front door of the countries where it was needed to be done.This multi-layered structure was overseen and tightly insulated from public exposure by an intelligence blanket called the SOE. Through high level infiltration by British intelligence into both friendly and competing agencies, the UK was able to gain a foothold inside the KGB, the CIA, Division Five of the FBI, and similar organizations in the Caribbean, Mexico, Canada and Australia -- as well as in Israel -- where it helped set-up the Israeli intelligence service, the Mossad.A final most important aspect of this secret drug infrastructure, was a string of shell "business fronts" and safe houses, "cutouts," as it were, strategically placed to serve various needs, as necessary. One such business entity that first hit American newspapers during Jim Garrison's investigation into the JFK assassination, was the nefarious entity called Permindex.Ostensibly, Permindex was to be the headquarters of world exhibition centers, but in fact, as this book claims, Permindex was little more than a "clearing house" for a group of about a dozen well-trained and well-paid assassins that made up the Crown's version of Murder, Inc. And while these authors claim that Permindex was used to carry out important hits at the behest of the crown, Michael Collins Piper's  book, "Final Judgment," insinuates that Permindex was an Israeli, rather than a British creation? And further Piper, claims it was David Ben Gurion, who first resigned as Prime Minister, and then ordered JFK's murder in order to avoid having to allow the IAEA to inspect the Israeli nuclear facilities at Dimona?I have read Piper's book carefully, checked his references, and am willing to admit that he is an honest scholar and has marshaled impressive documentation to back up his claims. However, in retrospect, it now seems quite clear too that he also used a bit of creative license: as he first "cribbed," and then "improvised," a wiggly path away from pinning the tail of the assassination donkey on Great Britain, where it belonged, and instead, pinned it on Israel?The real story of this book thus is not just in providing the reader with the full history and associated details of this enormously powerful secret apparatus (often referred to elsewhere as "The Trust," or "The Octopus"), but it is also to give the reader a sense of just how powerful and all-encompassing this top-down drug syndicate really has been. The best examples of the use of its powers are presented as two "asides" to the main narrative of the book.The first example is a novel explanation of why Nixon's "opening to China" was so successful: According to theses authors, it was because the skids were greased by (Hofjuden) Henry Kissinger's shuttle diplomacy (on behalf of the Crown rather than on behalf of USG in his role as Secretary of State), where it was agreed that the West would cover-up rather than expose the Communist Chinese leadership's long-term involvement in, and profits from, the British opium and heroin trade.To say the least, and for all the obvious reasons, Kissinger went ballistics over the book's allegations generally, but particularly over its characterization of him as being an "in-house Royal Jew" and a "double agent" at the same time.The second example is the assassination of JFK, which the book claims was simply an unfortunate instance in which the Kennedy family had used up its "get-out-of-trouble-free-cards," having once again run afoul of the rules of the game and the interests of the Crown, and thus suffered the expected consequences. The Kennedy's were heavily in debt to the crown as far back as when Joe Kennedy was running liquor for them during prohibition, before he was appointed Ambassador to England with the Crown's intervention, or was finally appointed to the job he would have died for, and the one that made him filthy rich: the first SEC Chairmanship.The reader may recall that Joe was later recalled to Washington for running afoul of the Crown by gushing over Hitler and indiscrete public comments about the UK's chances of losing the war. Then, to add insult to injury, a generation later, the Kennedy sons screwed-up the Bay of Pigs invasion by not providing Air cover, threatened to abolish the Federal Reserve, went after the mob with a vengeance, and then JFK decided to secretly "kiss and make up" with both Khrushchev and Castro after the Cuban Missile Crisis, but behind Britain's back. The last of these, apparently was the final straw that broke the camel's back. So JFK had to go. End of the JFK assassination story.But what is most fascinating about this rendition is that within the context of the syndicate apparatus, the JFK assassination was nothing special? It was a routine off-the shelf operation: Colonel Clay Shaw, a functionary of the Crown, in addition to being both a CIA and a Mossad asset, was placed in charge of the operation. Guy Bannister, a veteran of the FBI's Division five, also a crown mole, along with David Ferry, were in charge of manipulating the pasty, Lee Harvey Oswald. Major Bloomfield, a functionary of the  Brofman gang out of Toronto, was responsible for the logistics of getting the funds into Permindex to pay the hit men and ferrying them in and out of the U.S. William Harvey, of the CIA hired two or three Corsicans and had them flown in via Mexico for the hit and the evil deed was done. End of story.What is so remarkable about these two examples is that both are minor details: utterly unremarkable asides to the main narrative of the book, a narrative that is neither about the JFK assassination nor about Nixon's China policy, per se, but about how they both got caught up in the larger much more powerful machinery of the Crown's drug trafficking apparatus.Oddly, and somewhat paradoxically, the very fact that the JFK assassination was a mere aside to a larger story, that Garrison's investigations fits into perfectly, lends independent credibility to Jim Garrison's findings. Indeed, is it not reasonable to ask: how is it that the Garrison details just happen to fit so perfectly into a seemingly independent and unrelated story about the history of the drug trade? ... Unless, perhaps that is, those details, somehow, just happen to be very close to the truth?Add to this the fact that the people who succeeded in scuttling Garrison's investigation (in favor of the very flawed fairy tale called the Warren Commission Report), are also the same ones who prevented this book from being circulated for more than a decade, and it is easy to conclude that maybe some very powerful people feared this book was on the trail of the truth?But a word of warning is in order for potential readers: Just like all of the JFK assassination stories and theories, this one too is heavy on self-confirming conspiratorial details, and at critical junctures, also, is very short on independently verifiable facts. However, it must also be said that this manuscript is still light years ahead of any others out in the JFK conspiratorial ether.This is true in part because it is cogent, has a context, can be confirmed or denied after the fact, and most important of all in my view: for no reason at all beyond its apparent validity, it just happened to confirm every detail of Jim Garrison's carefully scuttled investigation, and yet, somehow, it falls perfectly into place in the history of the international drug trade. Now what are the chances this would happen if the theory Garrison put forth were not mostly true? Five Stars

These two intellectual heavy-weights have combined their efforts to good effect in studying the universe and its history. With the idea of making mid-course corrections to the more obvious flaws in the way our fragmented studies and thinking about cosmology have failed to adequately convey the full significance of what cosmologists have learned about the implications of the wholeness of the world, these authors offer several brave alternatives that attempt to address these flaws.And while you may not always agree with them -- as they do not even always agree on the details themselves -- they do agree that the intellectual tools are available to develop another better way of thinking about these issues. These tools are deployed and are on vivid display in this fine two-sided exposition.Having read and reviewed two of Professor Smolin's books and five of Professor Unger's books, I know that both prefer to always first begin by grounding their theories in at least kernels of empirical truths, truths that lie close to the ground, near the root nodes of our empirical and philosophical understandings. In the present case those kernels of truths are: the fact that the universe is (1) whole (i.e., a complete unit not to be confused with one of its sub-parts); (2) relational (i.e., its order and its orderings are relational); and (3) that the universe has a history (i.e., time is inclusively real).That the fundamental order of the universe, as well as the fundamental ordering of things within it, is relational, is taken as a demonstrable given, an axiom needing no further justification. As well, seeing the universe as a singular whole that has evolved over time is also taken as axiomatic, but is one that also inevitably leads to the importance of understanding why "becoming" must take priority and primacy over "being;" why process must take precedence over function and structure; and indeed, I would argue, it also suggests why change is the only constant process in the universe.That change is the only constant process in a universe with a history, also implies that even the laws of nature themselves are mutable since they too inevitably must have evolved out of the big bang, taking on very different forms as the univers cooled, and thus must still be evolving along with all other evolving processes, functions and structures within the universe. In a similar way, having a history, necessarily implies that time itself -- the tool used to reckon history -- is inclusively real rather than a mere external artifact of our system of measurement and mathematics.These are all new ideas that have not heretofore been examined and explored carefully in the field of Cosmology.Under Unger's updated re-formulation of the Philosophy of Naturalism, which he calls "temporal naturalism," "newness" becomes a natural emergent property of change: it is merely nature at work, and thus is simply a property that inheres in all change or evolutionary processes.It reminds me of David Bohm's example of whirling eddies in a liquid, where new forms, structures and processes are constantly "coming into" and "going out of being" as they morph in and out of different structures, functions and forms continuously. Thus, in a universe where change is the only constant, the emergence of new forms is the rule rather than the exception.These authors argue rather persuasively, that the science of cosmology cannot just be a reductionist Newtonian accordion, a machine scaled-up to relativistic speeds and sizes when needed, on the one hand, and then scaled-down and squeezed to quantum level details when needed, on the other. They both make the point that Physics is not just about the study of local particles, and their properties, or just about the subsystems and sub-functions of the universe. Were this the only view of cosmology, then there would be no way of accounting for the laws of nature or of the initial conditions that set the universe into motion, or indeed for the mathematics used to describe them. While all these may be seen as external to a family of hypothetical universes, they cannot be seen as external to our singular world, one that just happens to have a history, and of which these three are mere attributes, or sub-parts.If we are to ever answer questions about the inclusivity -- of the laws of nature, the nature of mathematics, or the initial conditions of our unitary singular universe (with a history) -- we are going to need "a bigger philosophical boat," one that takes into account the wholeness of the universe, and one that is at the same time open to empirical confirmation and falsification.Here in 500 pages, presented in two separate but mirror image parts, one dealing with new approaches to the philosophy of cosmology, and the other dealing more with the physics of cosmology, we have a double-barreled shot at the rudiments of a new bigger, wider, deeper philosophical boat. And while it does not always make for easy reading, it nonetheless makes an impressive if only a modest dent in forging a new way forward, a new way of seeing and understanding what we already know about how the universe works.The bravery of having embarked on such a joint enterprise itself is surely worthy of five stars. But the fact that it also involves too mavericks going about their day-to-day work in their respective research fields, makes their discoveries like a chess move that requires both a question mark and an explanation point: Only further developments will "tell" whether their respective suggestions have been good or a bad moves. Only time will tell how important a contribution this new foray into philosophy and physics has really been. Undoubtedly it will excite and shake up the kibitzers!As but one note, since I have already used up my space, I was unconvinced by the heuristic Professor Unger's used as a guiding light to solve the "multiple universe" problem. I failed to see any value-added in crossing the threshold from finite to infinite simply by changing the direction of the history in which the train of multiple universes entered the picture?Surely at some level it is no different than approaching the limits of a convergent or a divergent mathematical series in calculus, or indeed rehearsing the Tortoise and the hare race of Zeno's famous paradox, or more to the point of the rest of the book, approaching (or leaving) the event horizon of a black hole. Steven Hawking has examined these issues ad nauseam and has, far as I can tell, continued to finesse theses issues in the accepted (but flawed) way.It seems to me that no matter from what side the infinite universes problem is approached, you cannot sneak up on the point at which the finite finally goes over to becoming infinite or vice versa -- whether or not the history of the universe you are in is finite and is involved. I get the point that these things cannot, in the end, just continue to be finessed and left undiscussed, but I think the kind of brain power needed is that on the order of Gregor Cantor, who spent the latter half of his mathematical life dealing with these issues. And what he taught us is that you cannot sneak up on that particular problem: Going from the finite to the infinite, at least in Cantor's case, always involved a quantum leap, a paradigm shift into a new mindset, as it were, not a more careful peek at the last few numbers before (or after) the shift. We finessed that in mathematical induction too, but there it worked only because when a series converges, it is like cheating: we knew that the process was so orderly that nothing untoward could happen in the gap between the finite and the infinite. Five Stars

This band is different, a mix of foot stomping electric blues and dirty guitar melodies.
