Some call it swamp boogie, some call it nasty blues, I call it Delta Soul/Chicago Blues a la Bayou.Down and dirty, gravel road, dust in your eyeballs, nastiness. Sounds like a mixture of Omar Dykes and Black Oak Arkansas all rolled into one. Protest "Honeywell", despair and anger, "In A Bowl",questioning love "3 O'Clock" the songs are as unique and soulful as it can get.The Band is...Nathan 'Big Daddy' Brown ...GuitarsWillie Shane Johnston ...Vocals & HarpClay Ford ...BassJason Gardner ...Drums15 massive tunes, " You're sitting at the murky water's edge in a hot, humid bog. Sounds of frogs, insects, a faint breeze. Then, rising rapidly from the distance...? Music. A Mississippi saxophone. Complete with guitar, bass, and drums. Like a locomotive, WSNB is coming right at you. Jomo Swamp Root Boogie...sounds like its name. It has blues dripping from all 15 tracks."WSNB was one of North Carolinas hottest acts." Damn shame they're gone, they had a rare talent for Blues, and a sound that no one else had.

Celebrating 25 years since their first release, "Another Mayberry", the band returns with another killer offering. 11 great new tracks produced by Grammy Award-winning multi-instrumentalist Steve Jordan  “Black Beehive” sees the band strengthening their roots while moving forward at the same time.Classic blues based instrumentation and Todd Mohr’s stylistic vocals, a fusion of several other genres such as country, rock and folk music “Black Beehive” is a melting pot of styles and sounds which will appeal to a variety of listeners both young and old.The album features several guest performers including guitarist Ronnie Baker Brooks and long time Howlin’ Wolf band member Eddie Shaw on Saxophone and harmonica.There are funky slide guitar workouts like "Seven State Lines," along with a salute to the great Howlin' Wolf guitarist Hubert Sumlin on “Hubert’s Dream”, they have also returned to some of the easy, breezy melodic songwriting of their past which suits me fine.Mohr, Brian Nevin, Rob Squires and Jeremy Lawton return to the group’s laidback, jazz-inflected persona without losing their heightened awareness of the blues.This one has it all.I read..."There’s a topical feel to Black Beehive, as Mohr delves into issues both large (the Arab Spring uprisings, in “We Won’t Go Back”; the recent economic meltdown, in “Fear, Greed and Ignorance”) and small (Amy Winehouse’s sudden death, in the title track), but also a personal one, as Mohr explores the wonders outside our world “Everything About You”, and life’s strange coincidences “Forgive Me Bonnie”."Almost a 3 year gap between this album and the bands previous release “100 Years of Robert Johnson” definitely worth the wait as both acoustic and electric instrumentation coupled with Todd Mohr’s stylistic vocals make this a must have for any BHT fan.There's storytelling and intimate admissions, serenading, splitting guitar solos,infectious melodic material, yes, this is musical love at its best,soulful and intense !

“The Royal Sessions,” finds Paul Rodgers paying tribute to the sounds of Memphis with a set of classic covers recorded in one of the city’s best-loved studios “Royal Studios”, the historic home of Willie Mitchell and “Hi Records” and surrounded by some of the greatest Memphis sidemen musicians in the history of Memphis soul. Covers of great classics by the likes of Issac Hayes, David Porter, Albert King, Otis Redding, Smokey Robinson and Warren Moore and Ann Peebles to name a few.Many of the musicians who played on the original hit songs appear on the tracks of "The Royal Sessions”. His band including organist Reverend Charles Hodges, guitarist Michael Tolls, bassist LeRoy Hodges Jr., keyboardist “Hubby” Archie Turner, the Royal Horns and the Royal Singers and drummers Steve Potts and James Robertson Sr. deliver the spirit that is Memphis.The studio became available for Rodgers and producer Perry Margouleff to set up shop in the building and record with such a talented band, this was an opportunity too sweet to resist for Rogers. The opportunity to record in such a hallowed place with musicians he considered personal heroes was a dream come true.“The Memphis players forged an immediate bond when presented with Roger’s formidable talent and sincere love of the songs. Deeply felt, powerfully sung and expertly played, it features a cross-section of material hand-picked by Rodgers, songs of great historical significance and personal meaning. “My favorite, Otis Redding’s “I’ve Been Loving You Too Long”, Rogers simply put, steps right into Redding’s injury, into his heartbroken spirit, and he makes those feelings his very own. What a performance.Every one of these songs has an intensity of character, and Rodgers interprets so much from each and every one.  Isaac Hayes , a scorchingly sensual “I Thank You”; “Walk on By,” dissolves into a bubbling cauldron of hurt, Ann Peebles “I Can’t Stand the Rain,” is given a hearty howl, there’s also a romp and strut through “Born Under a Bad Sign”. But this is not just a Memphis music tribute it is also an Otis Redding tribute and a very special one.I enjoyed ZZtop’s version of Issac Hayes, “I Thank You” and this take by Rogers ranks right up there along with it."The Royal Sessions" is a remarkable project and a must have to add to your Paul Roger’s library of classics. “The Voice” has done it again. This one is special.

Songs of turmoil and pain, clever storytelling by Robin. The vocals are soulful and gritty, sultry and sensual. It's blues, R&B and soul interlaced with some fine jazz sensibilities. This woman has plenty of "SASS" and it shows in every song.The 11 tracks on this CD are all solid blues numbers with Robin belting, cooing, and seductively serenading the listener with her time-tested vocals. "She appropriately wraps herself vocally and emotionally around each and every track.""Drunkard’s Alley" this is an up-tempo piano-based blues number, "Color-Blind Angel" is a deep, mournful, slow blues written in tribute to the life of Viola Luizzo,  and the title track "Treat Me Right" is a swinging take on an old B.B. King tune.“Can You Hear Me Now” is a mid-tempo blues rocker,  “Nobody Stays” has a lilting raspy tone that matches her resignation to her series of failed relationships. Songs from the heart, sadness and emotion laced through the lyrics, this one brings it home in many ways.The sounds are easy and real, precise melodies to compliment the singer's personality. Rogers has plenty to offer in this outing, plenty of attitude and a gutsy performance to boot.Quite a talent !

Tim "Too Slim" Langford, it's been a while since his last solo effort. Just Tim, himself with various acoustic and electric instruments, and he's made sure the wait was worthwhile. He performs admirably on all instruments from acoustic guitar, Dobro and bass to harmonica, ukulele and programmed drums.This one is a soothing Slim experience, cool ambiance, soothing vocals and the usual unexpected twists and turns that are signature Tim Langford, I love it.Slim has been around quite some time, one of the most popular bands in the US Pacific Northwest over the last twenty years. His blues and rockabilly outfit Too Slim & The Taildraggers have amassed an extensive catalog of recorded material during that time.This one offers 11 original songs, "it's a semi-acoustic project fusing blues and folk-oriented styles with rootsy Americana music similar to that of Ry Cooder and Tony Joe White."The music has a deep south feel to it, a kick back and slip off your shoes kinda feel. The storytelling pace is reminiscent of Lou Reed to me, but that is as far as it goes of course, two distinct genres and artists.I read..."Three Chords," Langford plays the acoustic guitar like it was an extension of his hands. He produces a deep beat that resonates throughout the song. This song sounds melancholy, but a little upbeat sound within it makes listeners feel better." I agree, I felt it, I heard the message.An upbeat and happy song is "Princeville Serenade", with its cheerily strummed ukulele, the title tune "Broken Halo" rolls out a slinky blues-rock groove, almost Dylan-ish."If you want music that you can listen to, while driving somewhere far, or when its raining outside, you should listen to Broken Halo, by Tim "Too Slim" Langford. His new solo album should not be missed. It is a treat to the listener's soul."Slim is a craftsman, a true ambassador of the blues in his own way. The subject matter is raw, the images he presents are all too real and personal to the listener.This one is a keeper.

Another great read by Jason Tesar and yes I have just downloaded book four in the series. Book four takes you on a completely different ride. I'm just into it about 10% and again I'm hooked. Say goodbye to my social life....another night at home immersed in great reading. Book three had the same effect lol
Excellent Series...Great Characters. I am on book three and can't wait to see what is going to happen around the next corner.

I love this CD. Pure rock fury at its best.I read..."Pete Brasino has been playing his rock & roll-flavored brand of blues ever since he was in high school. He began to teach himself to play guitar as a 16-year-old and within six months he had become so proficient with the instrument that his classmates dubbed him Guitar Pete — the nickname that would become his performing name."If you love ZZtop you will love Guitar Pete's "Bad Intentions". The style and vocals  remind me of a cross between Frank Zappa, Leslie West and Billy Gibbons, doused in Leslie West/Gibbons guitar licks. Cool tunes.The ramblin' guitar intro  of "Snake Pit" brings to mind ZZtop's "Jesus Just Left Chicago", with a slight Guitar Pete twist which is always over the top. The man is a fearless guitar warrior with a dominating style which will leave your eardrums humming long after the first intro. The tunes just keep rollin', pure perfection.This CD is a true rear and frontal assault of your senses so get prepared to rock ! Pete has "Bad Intentions" right from the opening note, bad real bad. What can I say, to sum it up every song is a winner.Known for his heavy metal style and "axe attack", Pete has a few albums/Cds behind him. This latest in my opinion ranks up top, breaking from his usual sonic, show no mercy style. A smoother more confident approach, clean and impressive, but still 100% bad ass!Wow, cmon Pete, release more of this, I'm a fan !

"A Hiding Place" is the second album from German retro rockers Zodiac, following 2012's well-received "A Bit of Devil".Full of catchy '70s sounds with the coolest of vocals & ripping guitar playing.A Hiding Place kicks off rather safely with the upbeat rocker "Downtown", a solid  blues rock/classic rock track, a bit laid back to me as compared to the first album's material, but then the band delivers the impeccably crafted seven-minute "Free," with '70s styled blues rock guitars, powerful vocals, & Deep Purplesque influenced Hammond organ swirling about the mix, sure enough to have `future live classic' written all over it.Van Delft's guitar sets the pace through much of the album driving it forward as he plays a tight balancing act between melodic simplicity and frantic technicality, allowing the songs to evolve naturally."Believer" has a bluesy, swirling, psychedelic feel and some emotional guitar licks. Speaking of great guitar work, there is plenty to be found on the rumbling two part rocker "I Wanna Know", as well as the distortion laced cover of Neil Young's classic "Cortez the Killer".Staying away from "sonic overkill ", leaning more towards warm and inviting, the songs classically unfold. It's a rock album, and a damn good one at that.Hey, it's not hard to really like this band & album if you dig vintage sounds. It is no surprise to say that Zodiac are hardly original, but what they are is tight and armed with an arsenal of great tunes that you'll remember once the album finishes. The band was able to capture a warm and clear sound, which I feel will grow on the listener with each playing.What's next ? Let's wait and see. "A Hiding Place" is not only as good as their first album, it is an even greater blend of blues and rock which I can appreciate.Great Band....Vintage sounds.

I just recently came across this performer in my perusing of my internet trail of new and old artists. I can be like a bloodhound when I get on the scent of something good and this album is just that...sooo good!This Detroit-area guitarist deftly weaves the blues, his guitar soloing carries subtle jazz undertones, restrained without overpowering the vocals which are top notch. He has a John Scofield playing style but likes to mix it up a bit by exploring and interpreting funk, jazz and rock guitar styles. The record is an eclectic collection of all original music that explores many facets of Al-Saadi's influences.In Guitar World magazine (November 2006) Al-Saadi was heralded as sounding like "Danny Gatton and Buddy Guy at their best." With comparisons like that I definitely had to give him a listen.This was his first release and the Ann Arbor, Michigan performer, a talented instrumentalist and singer-songwriter puts it out there for all to enjoy. This is soulful Rockin' Blues at its best.The album features a dream-band of musicians such as Jim Keltner (Drums), Leland Sklar (Bass), Larry Goldings (Hammond B-3), Jimmy Vivino (Rhythm Gtr/ Backing Vox), Tom Scott (Sax), Lee Thornburg (Tpt), Brandon Fields (Bari Sax), Nick Lane (Trombone / Horn Arranger) to name a few.This CD has a great variety of sounds and songs with such a good flow to them. Laith has the technical prowess of a Jazz musician without compromising the feel for the Blues. His vocals are pure, a veritable treat for your ears. His "Who Turned Out The Lights" puts me in mind of Robert Cray, just a little bit lower than Robert's vocal range. "Circle" is one of my favorites, I love the guitar break in this one, having a Hendrix kind of echo to it without the effects and an Adrian Gurvitz style, clean and crisp...nice.I read..."His love of soul shines on the silky "If," and his guitar soloing carries subtle jazz undertones on "Who Turned Out the Lights?" But the velvety flow of album opener "Breathe" and the grave strut of "Mystified" show that blues is what makes Al-Saadi's soul sing." I totally agree. This album is sure to please Audiophiles, Telecaster fanatics and music lovers of all kinds! Check it out. You will NOT be disappointed! 5 stars easily.

Update: 5 stars as of today.  this is a really good book!I like this well laid out and designed book, Building a Shed  (Build Like a Pro Series) by Joseph Truini.  I feel good enough about it to give it Four Stars, after going through the book last night.  I will keep it in my bookshelf for those resources I want to have close at hand to reach for when I just want to look through and enjoy the pictures of the many out buildings that are given here as examples.  It always gives me some good ideas for a building project, other than a shed, as the drawings and pictures put forward many other beginnings of other projects one would see on these pages, laid out for one to pick up and go with. Now I have found at least two outdoor projects I would like to build in the back yard.  Several of the illustrations Mr. Truini gives, are right for what I will need and his pictorials of building actual projects are helpful. This is a good buy if you are interested in building or even if you only want to see what has been built before.  With a little effort and good use of the tools you will want to own, you can come up with what you are looking for in a shed or out building. I am familiar with this publisher and feel like the Taunton series of building books offered are the best of the many on the subjects offered, of which the Fine Woodworking books and offerings are in my opinion, the best.  Mr. Truini offers many of his talents and knowledge up for just a little bit of money spent so the buyer can build like a pro.

I purchased this paperback "idea" book to try and come up with an outdoor shop and to do some woodworking I no longer have space to do in my Garage, where over time I have accumulated way too much stuff.  Also I could store some wood and get out of the house a little more.  This book, Sheds & Garages, is a good source for the ideas I am looking for and with the other three, I have determined a shed with some additions that will let in more light, as it will be under some trees in the yard. Most of the project ideas in this book include mini plans, which are enough for me to build with and at the back of this book are many plans you can purchase for the larger buildings.  Plan prices start at $20 and go up to $300+.  I like it.

This Drama and played out mystery is well written and acted.  The plot is both strong and draining with the sadness of the story played out until the very end where the plot almost overwhelms.  Enough Said on this story.  I like the movie and would recommend it to those who are capable of enduring this trying layout of the theme and suspense.

I live in the area where this movie is being played out in the plot.  The use of Tig Notaro in this plot is both funny and tragic.  Any story where one looses a mother or father is tragic enough without having the main character dealing with the loss also suffering from just having a double mastectomy and being both physically weak and emotionally wounded.  Funny and Sad at the same time.  I can see where the topic and characters portrayed isn't for everyone, but I like it and will continue to follow the story and watch this series.

This series is a realistic story.  If you see this plot playing out, you get the feel that this is happening somewhere in the cities of the US.  Maybe everywhere else also.  The characters are believable and the plot dances around the issue of Italians being tied to the mafia.  A good watch.

I ordered this,  Knit Beanie Octopus Gre Unisex Barbariany stocking mask by Amurleopard, for Halloween, to hand out treats in. I've been following this product for a while now.  Did you notice I am the only one who has reviewed the XSES-500 watt Solar Generator?  Well, there are a couple ways you can check up on a product and one is Amazon.  I f there is a listing and it has no reviews, it is a good sign that the product is over priced for what you get.  There are quite a few really well designed solar battery storage generators and have been for years.  Now with the better electronics and solar panels like the monocrystalline devised panels the generators can constantly charge lithium ironsulphate batteries of various Amp hours of storage.  The really professional units like, Movie studios utilize and most solar companies produce, using their own solar panels and Solar generators that are basically a combined collection of several parts normally found in home solar setups.  These self contained, portable units are usually comprised of Sealed Lead Acid Batteries in the past and now mostly Lithium based superior battery systems,  Power Inverters which changes DC Electricity to AC for use with cameras and lighting, charge controllers and protection circuitry, digital displays of Voltage & Charge Status, combinations of USB, DC and AC outlets and switches to control on and off, monitoring of storage capacity and charge indication.  Usually a cart or a dolly with wheels for portability allows the units to be moved from transportation to utilization on the job.  Much has changed with the improvements of the lithium charging and protection circuitry that is easily available.  One can design their own generator for much less than the expensive units sold to the pros who require a guarantee of reliability.  This unit is not represented by the reviews commonly associated with a widely successful product, thus the three star rating it deserves.

I purchased these, Luna Bazaar Small Rice Paper Lanterns, Chinese Lamp Shades (8-Inch, White, Set of 8) to use with a string of Led lights on the patio. Since receiving this book, Handbook of Operational Amplifier Circuit Design by David F Stout, I have been reviewing it as a source of electronics  knowledge, to relearn and refresh my fading scope of electronics.  I am just now gaining some information I should have learned years ago and trying to become more competent in my use of electronics in design.  The contents are well presented and is a source of information I will use from now on.  The author presents this information to the reader in a basics first presentation and then gives ever more information as the subject are approached.  The op amp is one of the most versatile of devices and many of it's uses are discussed in design detail in these pages.  I do recommend it as a learning tool and as a reference to anyone who would like to become a better electronics designer.

I am still amused and the light is warm white for use permanently in the house.  When I got the lights they worked, right out of the boxes, but I installed them in sockets to charge the batteries to the fullest level of charge.  I then turned them on to see how ling they would stay lighted, I gave up after an hour, as I became convinced this light would serve as a emergency light as needed.  I really like this product.  I is not armoured enough to use as a real flashlight, as it is plastic, but I have flashlights I like less than this light for the purpose!

Principles of Mechanism by Alex Vallance is a study resource for mechanics.  I give many old methods of mechanical design and equipment used in the past to perform work and transfer energy into work.  This will be obviously a trip into the past for anyone reading this material, but one can see where the designers of past equipment were coming from in design to get a piece of equipment built utilizing the engineering of the time and each of these designs were used effectively to provide the mechanical movement to accomplish a task.  Worth looking through, or even studying the concepts to learn something.  Worth the price I paid.

This book, Handbook of Microcircuit Design and Application, by David F. Stout is dated from the early eighties and is still relevant, if you are learning or relearning electronics of microprocessor design.  Since this book has been written, Surface Mounted Devices has brought the design of electronics further along and much of this text has had many examples of more modern use of electronics advancement supersede it.  It can still be a source of learning, as the basics are here and can be applied successfully in a learning process, just not taken as how things are now designed.  The basics are still there to learn from.

1:08 MinsThe Laser Christmas Lights is awesome and I fell in love with it as soon as I projected the light and saw my entire house light up. The laser Christmas lights is so simple to install and use, just plug in the plug point and project it on a house, building, large structures, garden, trees, etc. without having to put holes in the walls. I no longer have to take all the time and effort to light up the house, I can just be done in under 5 minutes now. I projected the laser light outside on my apartment and it instantly lighted my entire patio and looked so beautiful. It gave a look of hundreds of light strings hanged and illuminated my patio giving the perfect holiday look I wanted and without all the efforts.The laser light is waterproof and is perfect for the outdoors and can be used indoors too.
