I love the Dare family series and have been eagerly waiting for a Max and Lucy's story. This is a bit of a friends to lovers story since Max and Lucy have know each other since their youth. They have also secretly (for Max) and not so secretly (for Lucy) been in love with each other for almost as long. Sadly, tragedy in their respective lives pulled them apart and Lucy's desire to distance herself from love, even the love of her siblings, drives her from NY to CA. But a wedding and a new restaurant brings Lucy back to New York and back into Max's life. And Max is ready to fight for the heart of the woman he has always loved and will blow through every single one of her defenses in the process.Dare to Seduce definitely contained Phillips' usual hotness quotient for this series, and I enjoyed seeing the couple heal each other through their love for one another. I especially enjoyed how Lucy encouraged Max to repair the rift between his parents and himself. She was there for him even when "there" put her in close proximity to the life she had with her parents before their deaths.Although I enjoyed the story, it is not among my top favorites of the series. Even though Lucy embraced and acknowledged her love for Max when he was injured I didn't feel a deep emotional connection between the couple as I felt for the other Dare couples. Lucy and Max's story missed that spark for me. I liked their love story but I didn't love it and was hoping for a bit ... more.That said, the Dare series is still one of my favorite family saga series and I cannot wait to see who's up next for this very eclectic family.

As a debut novel for West, I believe that Wolf Bait was a well done story. Those who have read romances like FSoG and the Crossfire series will find the similar trope of an older more experienced man who is paired with a younger and far less experienced (read: virginal) woman. Although the theme is familiar, I think West did a good job creating a distinguishable story.Abbi Mitchell is a young and impressionable woman or high morals. She is in college and engaged to her childhood sweetheart, a preacher's son, when she discovers that he committed the ultimate betrayal. Using the excuse of "sowing wild oats" before he marries Abbi, he puts a pause to their relationship so he can see (and have copious amounts of sex with) other women. Abbi is devastated and heartbroken. Needed to get away from anywhere near a life that reminds her of him, she applies for a job at a high end resort in Alaska. Never imagining that she would get the job because of her lack of experience in the hospitality industry, Abbi is pleasantly surprised when she is offered the job. Escape. Freedom. Abbi is on her way to Alaska and straight into the wolf's den.Well, that is Henry Wolf's den...errr...hotel.Henry Wolf is rich, successful, and GORGEOUS and Abbi cannot help her instant attraction to him when she just thinks he's a sexy lumberjack. Yet, her attractions ramps up more when the lumberjack turns in the suave businessman that he is. Sparks begin to fly immediately between the pair, but Abbi is certain that her feelings of attraction are one-sided. Wolf often runs hot and cold with her. Awakening her desires with his burning gaze one moment, and then freezing her out with his cool disposition the next. But Wolf is fighting his desire for Abbi because of something that isn't revealed to the reader until the end of the story. Yes, it ends on the cliffy. And yes, Abbi is once again devastated. But, I cannot wait to see what West does to redeem Wolf and restore Abbi's confidence in men.Wolf Bait was an easy read with lots of sexy bits included in it. If you're looking for a new-to-you author, definitely check this one out.

Unfortunately after reading four of these stories I had to stop because although the creatures were different the stories all felt reminiscent of one another. I will not be continuing on with the series.

I feel supremely deficient giving this book. As with other reviews I might have provided my personal brand of recap for the story but I cannot and will not do that with Christian. There was soooooo (yes, the "Os" are important) embedded in this story that I would be provide a woefully inadequate recap of all the goings on.What I will say is that this series has not lost its potency. In fact, I would assert that it's only gotten more so as the battle with the Europeans ramps up. Reynolds dialed it way up with Christian's story. Book 10 in the Vampires in America series is rife with deception, subterfuge, alliances, and Reynold's trademark alpha male lord and a smart and sassy woman who manages to "tame" him. I loved the dynamic between Christian and Natalie. Sparks flew between them from the very beginning of the story. And although Natalie at first seems like an atypical heroine for Reynolds, her brand of strong heroine quickly shines through as she races toward helping Christian find out what's really happening with Anthony, the lord of the South. I really enjoyed how the story was crafted around Anthony and his ascension to being the Southern Lord after Jabril's "retirement." You didn't much about the southern territory after Jabril, which was book 2 of the series, and I kind of put it out of my mind as "story over" after that. I was supremely impressed by how the territory was reintegrated into my mind. Christian is an unlikely contender for the southern territory since he was one of the Europeans who was sired by Raphael's enemy Mathilde (that story occurs in Deception). Needless to say, not one of Raphael's allies trusted Christian's emergence onto the America vampire scene, but Raphael, ever the strategist, saw how much of an ally that Christian could and would be to him.This story was expertly written, and the twists and turns and bad guys popping up left and right, left me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire story. And can I just add that the little the teaser at the end about Sophia will you desperate to know "what's next".I am loving the direction that Reynolds is taking with the series and it's absolutely one of my favorites and one that I highly recommend to vampire romance lovers.
Unfortunately after reading four of these stories I had to stop because although the creatures were different the stories all felt reminiscent of one another.

I love shifter romances, and Sage is a new to me author that I was excited to explore. Although this serial collection had the bones of a great read it felt disjointed and spastic in many spots so my enjoyment diminished a bit. And I all for the underdog but Aiden, a mere human with a few weeks of fight training, beating Sabra, a natural born shifter, who trained with alphas, was not believable. I know it's fiction so saying that feels wrong somehow...BUT I would believed it more had Aiden gained shifter powers. But beating her as a human? No. Order of Alphas was not an unenjoyable read, I was just hoping for something a bit more....

I love Rosanna Leo's paranormal romances. She has a very imaginative and innovative spin on commonly written about paranormals. Her newest release, "Night Lover" is no different in that regard. Leo takes the theme of an incubus, a male sex demon, and kicks it up to the next level mixing in jumps to the past so you can see how his story all began. The incubus in this story, Hugh Dawlish, is rakishly sexy and mercilessly tantalizes the heroine of the story, Renata Bruno. Dawlish visits Renata in her dreams and masters her body but also manages to capture a piece of her heart as well. There are just two problems with that: Hugh is a 200 year old ghost and Renata's ex Finn Mackenzie comes blazing back into her life and he wants her for himself. As Renata battles her sanity, and her heart, she definitely learns that things are not as they seem, and there is a malignant darkness hunting for not her body or her heart, but for her very soul.Night Lover was very sexy and the story was unique. The characters were so well done that I was conflicted at one point. I didn't know whether I wanted Hugh or Finn to win Renata's heart. I loved the climax of the story because the character redemption was sweet. I was hoping for a but more WOW when it came to vanquishing the evil, but it worked solidly with the story. The only thing I had a mild issue with was the jumps back and forth in time. They didn't feel as smooth as they could have been. Once I discovered their rhythm the story was a much easier read.Overall, I enjoyed the story very much. Leo's interpretation of an incubus was one that I enjoyed.

Elizabeth Hunterhas an amazing gift to weave an interesting story that is intricate and highly multifaceted. For me, Desert Bound was no different in that regard. Desert Bound focuses centrally on Alex McCann and Teodora ‘Ted’ Vasquez (who you can find out more about in their introduction in Five Mornings: A Cambio Springs Short Story. Alex and Ted had more than a contentious relationship. They went from a young love that grew to much more to near enemies after Ted feels betrayed and abandoned by Alex for pursuing his career over her. Ted returns to their home to begin her medical practice while Alex is living the life of a business mogul in Los Angeles. But things aren't always as they appear on the surface. Alex has never stopped loving Ted and his return to Cambio Springs is more than just a business venture. He wants to win back his girl. But Ted isn't making things easy for Alex; however fate sends a little nudge in the couple's favor but causing situations that throw them together. A lot of siuatioms, too.Desert Bound is definitely rife with mystery and suspense and there is a lot going on with secondary and tertiary characters that you don't want to miss. I love how Hunter connected the threads of this story into a vividly intriguing tapestry that kept the reader fully engaged in wanting to know what would happen next. The epilogue beautifully sets the stage for Waking Hearts, Ollie and Allie's journey to a happily ever after.

*Sigh*...I absolutely A-D-O-R-E-D Walk Through Fire. This is probably one of the best second chance romances I've ever read. Ashley does another amazing job with High and Millie's story of love, redemption, and forever, and proves once again why she is one of my favorite authors. Walk Through Fire was a full contact read, and will draw you into it fast and furiously from the very first page! I couldn't flip the pages fast enough to get to the heart of the story, and when I did, I truly was not disappointed. A resounding 5☆'s for this spectacular story.

Tammy Falkner fans will this newest release in her Reed Brothers series. We meet Ryan toward the end of [book:While We Waited|24951809]. He is a new artist at the Reed's shop and also gains the immediate attention of Lark, one of the Zeroes. Ryan is hearing impaired and holds firm to his rule of not dating only hearing impaired women -- that is until he meets Lark. Although the story was not overly hawt, like some of the other books in the series, it was seductively sweet. I adored the story and Ryan and Lark's journey to love.Falkner definitely has a gift for pulling together unique characters from diverse situations and background to make the reader fall in love.  It's amazing to see how she has expanded the series that started out with a family of loyal brothers into a hoard of people who come from various backgrounds, experience real life challenges, but triumph because of their love and the community of people they have rallying behind them.This series is definitely a favorite and I highly recommend the Reed Brothers if you're looking for your next best read (and several amazing book boyfriends to choose from, too).

All the stories felt a bit too similar with me as far as the character types. Sure, the stories were all different in fashion but after reading three stories, it felt a bit formulaic for me. It wasn't a bad read. But I wish I had read each story at different intervals so they didn't feel all alike.

I have been a huge fan of Rosanna Leo's Gemini Island series since the first book. Each book drew you in with a storyline that was both sexy and interesting and characters that made you experience a whole range of emotions. But I have to say, the first few books in the series were light and fun. Soren's antics with Ryland were just hilarious. However, with the introduction of August Crane and the "Alpha Brethren" in Predator's Fire, the arc of the series began to grow more intense...darker even. I thought the intensity in Predator's Fire was as high as it would go for the series. There were some hair-raising moments but it was all smiles and happily-ever-afters at the end. Like I said, I'm a Rosanna Leo fan and her writing tends to lend itself to the lighter but sexy side of the spectrum, so I had a preconceived ending in mind when I started Predator's Trinity.I was WRONG. So VERY WRONG. This BOOK!!! I was absolutely blown away with Leo's writing in this one. Predator's Trinity still had one of Leo's essential style tenets: It was sexy! *Face fanning sexy*. Leo confesses that this is her first ever menage story and she did an exceptional job creating the triad relationship between brothers Percy and Byron Moon and Suzan March. The intimate times between them helped to bridge the more intense moments of the story with lighter and sexier interludes.I won't recant the story for you because I won't do it justice and this is one that you DEFINITELY need to read for yourself. There was so much crammed into those 140ish pages. Predator's Trinity was full of twists and turns that I was not expecting. In my head, I just "knew" how things were going to play out and I was completely wrong. Pleasantly surprised in one regard but so terribly devastated in another. The Gemini Island that we see in Predator's Trinity is not the same island that we first encountered in Predator's Kiss. There are no guests. There is no laughing. There is little joy. Things are dark and life is at risk because of the actions of the Alpha Brethren. Crane is a sick and twisted individual and all of his hidden secrets come out to play in this one. Predator's Trinity exposes a lot of information about his past. It also explains his freakish obsession with Suzi. In this one readers will encounter: new shifter types (there is one that will FREAK you the "eff" out), surprise connections, and devastating loss. I can say no more on that *sob*. But, this story will make your heart race and will shatter it into pieces too. Good doesn’t conquer evil unscathed in Predator's Trinity, but it does conquer it.At the end of the day the Gemini Island that remains is a shade of its former self but it is on the mend, as are its inhabitants. We are left with hope for the future in the new generation of shifters and in the new connections that were made. I am chomping at the bit to see what Leo does with the remaining books in this series. I am in awe and impressed by the level of depth and emotion that she conveys in her stories.All I can say is, "WOW!!!" about this series. Excellent job, Rosanna.

I have to give to L.P. Dover. For her very first paranormal romance, she did a stellar job! The characters were well crafted and had amazing stories to tell. I loved Bailey and adored Ryker *swoon*. There are classic villains in this story and some unexpected twists and turns that keep the story interesting and the pace fluid. There are also a ton of secondary characters that you will fall in love with. I especially cannot wait to read Sebastian's story (Bailey's protector). That boy and his brothers promise to bring swoon-worthy reads.

This is my first book by Kym Grosso but it won't be my last. I downloaded the free ebook as well as they Whispersync audio and enjoyed going back and forth between the two. The narrator did a good job conveying the story and it was enjoyable. I was a first cautious because it was a male narrator doing both the male and female parts but it was very well done. I liked the push/pull between Kade and Sydney. It was definitely more pushing and pulling on Kade's side because Sydney was definitely a tough girl who was not easily swayed. My only mild issue with the story was Sydney's oversexed persona. Every man in the story seemed to get her motor running -- her partner, Tony, Kade, the alpha wolf Tristan. They all seemed to make "heat pool in her belly." It made me roll my eyes; however once she and Kade got on solid footing, I enjoyed her character a whole lot more. The plot of the ritualistic killer on the hunt for power was intriguing and kept the story pacing interesting. I can't wait to read Luca's story next.

I loved the story and the different slant it took on with the special operations. The couple was sweet and sexy although Ada was a tough pill to swallow at times; however, I loved how Ranger broke her down. I cannot wait to read the story about Ranger's brother Romer and his cousin. Great storyline.

I loved the story and the eff and flow of Everett and Layla's relationship. They seemed like the most unlikeliest of couples -- her all high class glamor and him with his gamer boy chic. Their differences aside, when they meet, it was kismet. They just knew they were mates and the passion between them was SERIOUS! There is also a bit of drama in the story that keeps it interesting and a crazy Effie who adds a humorous flavor. I'm hoping that North pairs Effie with Stryker. That will be HILARIOUS if it happens.

Once again some amazing storytelling from Bianca D'Arc in her continuing story arc from the Tales of Were/Redstone Clan series. I love how she has integrated the characters so that the series feels comprehensive and fluid. I  adored Matt and Morgan together and their story was a perfect pairing of intense and sexy moments. The plot of the Venifucus continues and their mission to bring back Elspeth the destroyer remains the primary driver of their actions. Although there are new players in Matt/Morgan's story, the arc connects beautifully with the other Redstone/Were books. There is a shocking reveal at the end of the story that had me screaming NOOOOOOOO!!! I cannot wait to see what's in store next. It's gonna be good!

I finished Cocky Bastard by Vi Keeland and Penelope Ward on Wednesday and I struggled with book afterglow so I couldn't read anything new yesterday. *Sigh*... it was just that good! Although I've now loaded two new books on my Kindle, the glow is still riding me pretty hard. I absolutely adored the story. It was funny. It was sweet. It was very sexy. And LAUGH OUT LOUD funny! This story contained the best of  everything that you love in a romance and more.You will instantly fall in love with Chance and  Aubrey....oh and Esmeralda Snowflake. Cocky  Bastard was a romance gem of 2015!

Paige Tyler does not let her fans down in the second installment of the SWAT series. Quite to the contrary. She even kicks it up a notch by adding a female werewolf to the story as the love interest of my most beloved Xander Riggs, senior corporal of the unit. Khaki Blake wasn't just Riggs "The One," although it took him a reallllllly long time to accept that, she was a member of his unit which everyone knows is a no-no because of that no fraternization rule. Regardless of that fact, I love how Tyler worked the story -- conflict, sexual tension, and draHHHma in the form of a stalker ex. Everything worked out for Riggs and Khaki in the end but their happily ever after was full of bullet wounds and very clandestine loving. I cannot wait to read Becker's story but Cooper is definitely THE MAN to get a hold of :D.

I have enjoyed each of the books in the Dare series thus far. Each one provides a unique set of characters and interesting challenge(s) they must overcome as a couple to secure a happily ever after for themselves.In this respect, Avery Dare and Grey Kingston were no different.  Avery and Grey were high school sweethearts whose hearts called to like.  Grey and Avery were loners  -- both for very different reasons -- but that similarity is what connected them to one another.  Grey was a musician and a dreamer.  He was just waiting for the day he could leave his working class family (mother and stepfather) who he was actually ashamed of, and make a name for himself in the music world. He wanted to prove to his father,  whom he had a very strained relationship with before he died,  that he could in fact "be somebody." Although Grey's father didn't live to see his success, he achieved it and in a very big way.  Unfortunately,  his quest to outrun hid personal demons also caused him to run away from Avery in the process.  He left her...COLD...and never have her the chance on the choice to come along with him in his climb to the top. And,  it tore Avery up. Already having extreme abandonment issues due to her father's selfishness, Avery was heartbroken and closed herself off to serious relationships. But time does not dull the light of love. Grey was still very much in love with Avery and he wanted her back.  Only the adult Avery was more guarded and careful with her affections. But Grey was intent on having his girl back -- mind, body, and soul. However, things are never easy in the journey to happily ever after. Grey's swarmy record producer and a seriously crazy stalker almost thew a permanent wrench in Grey's plans to permanently reconcile with Avery.  Fortunately for him,  the adult Avery was also willing to fight for what she wanted, that is once she finally made up her mind about it.I absolutely adored Avery. She was actually one of the most muted Dare's in all the other Dare books. Sure, she had presence because she was the one who saved her half-sibling, Sienna's  life by donating bone marrow when she was a child.  We also knew that there was a story between her and the sexy rocker, yet she didn't stand out UNTIL THIS BOOK! Phillips did an exceptional job crafting a character that would tug on your heart strings and make you cheer for her, especially when you read her interactions with her father.  It broke my heart for her. But, I love how she confronted him when she found her strength, or rather tapped into her strength.  Although plagued by frequent panic attacks, Avery was stronger than she knew and it only took Grey's presence in her life to nudge that strength to the forefront.This book is definitely a Book Chick favorite!

This was an okay read but very similar in form and tone  to many of Dwyer's other books. I was hoping for something mildly different from her other work when I started the series but the -- woman in trouble with dominant men "claiming" her -- trope is apparent in this one as well. I may continue the series as some point to read about the heroine's friends with the understanding that the stories quite possibly will be very similar.
Short and sweet read Worth a little bit of drama and action and a good amount of steam. As a short, it missed making a good build up of the Gunner angle but all in all an enjoyable story.

Rating: 3.5 🌟I am definitely enjoying the direction that Michele is taking with the series. It's full of twists and turns and super sexy. Although I enjoyed Max and Kenly's journey to a happy for now, I have to confess that I enjoyed Xavier and Zara's journey a bit more. Oh, don't get me wrong, I really liked the story and the connection between Max and Kenly. I suppose that I felt at times that TOO much was going on -- wolves, magic, a hidden identity, a lost crystal with powers,  a secret heritage. Normally, all that wouldn't be bad normally but because the story isn't terribly long it felt as if the reader was thrown a lot of detail with not a lot of time to absorb it. I suspect that will learn more in book 3 now that Nana O, Zara's grandmother and Kenly's grandmother's bestie, is back on the scene. Thor has been a fairly muted character so far but I look forward to reading his story.

I typically prefer more contemporary romances but my one weakness and exception is stories about brawny Highlanders. I just adore them when they are well written -- the imagery,  the passion...the brogue *shiver*...all make for wonderfully engaging stories.  Fans of Karen Marie Monings Highlander series will fall in love with York's  Dundragon Time Travel Triolgy. You get a little bit of the old and a little bit of the new and they work in perfect harmony to create an amazing read. The story is not long at just under 150 pages but what IS there is a story with an intriguing plot line, multidimensional characters,  and a love that is potent enough to cross time and space. I loved the relationship between Dominic and Maggie. It was humorous, sexy, and intense...especially when the nefarious plot was revealed. There were some pretty close calls toward the end of the story but definitely work out in the end and there is most assuredly a happily ever after. I cannot wait to see what York has in store for Dominic's brother and Maggie's cousin.
A lighthearted, quick, easy, and fun story with a sexy bear shifter in search of a curvy woman to love. I love how Logan sought Dina out at the mixer. It was sweet.

The trope if this story will not be unfamiliar to romance readers. A sexy billionaire who is jaded by love but secretly wants it finds it with an unlikely and understated beauty. Throw in the elements of a secret wager and a well intentioned (and sweetly meddling) grandmother and you have this story.I enjoyed Nathan and Chloe together as a couple and their journey to finding love was rather sweet, although it felt a bit contrived. The powerful CEO in a haze of sickness becomes fixated on his one-day old temp. Chloe somehow equalled 'coolness' to Nathan's fevered mind and he wanted her near him. Chloe's temporary assignment of executive assistant morphs into nursemaid, and we all know what happens within close quarters in a romance right? Sparks begin to fly and passion heats up. Nathan and Chloe's working relationship quickly grows into more and soon enough they give in to the attraction between them. But as in any good tale, the road to a happily ever after is wrought with obstacles. There is a little wager that Chloe knows nothing about, Nathan's relationship with his father that is an albatross to him, and Chloe's reluctance to giving such a powerful and influential man her heart. Oh, there are other elements at play too but I recommend reading the story for yourself to discover all the other dynamics.All in all, the story was sweet and a good read overall, but for me it was missing that 'something' that would make it special.

B.N. Toler continues her Holly Springs series with Nikki and Parker's story. Nikki and Parker are best friends of the protagonists in The Suit. I have to confess that although I enjoyed The Suit, I adored The Anchor. It was something about Nikki and Parker's relationship that was just so painfully sweet. I think Toler did a beautiful job expressing the passion, connection, and love between the couple. There were certainly ups and downs, thanks to Nikki's background, but when she let go of her past and her reservations, she embraced the relationship and the love between she and Parker wholeheartedly. I love how she handled the office trollop. I can't wait to see what Toler does with Joey. He is the strong, silent type and Parker's sister will definitely give him a run for his money.

It was a decent story with an interesting plot, there was just a lot happening in this story with the plot points at the beginning with Eric and toward the middle-end with Dorian. The plot points weren't connected in any way and it made the story feel disjointed to me. I would have rated it higher had Eric somehow been in league with Dorian to take over Sleuth. As it was, the plot points felt randomly added for story drama.

I didn't quite like the format of this story because of the trailing end. I wasn't expecting that I guess...even with a short. And although hot, I just didn't care for Jameson at all. Bad, yes. Crude, double yes. He is defined not on my favorite list of anti-heroes.

Chelle Bliss starts her ALFA series off with bang! Sinful Intent is deliciously sexy and absolutely thrilling from beginning to end. This book is sure to be your next best read.Men of Inked fans will fall in love with Chelle Bliss's new crop of hot alpha men in the ALFA series. There will be cameo appearances from our favorite Gallos, including Izzy, but they are not the focus of the series. Never fear! Bliss doesn't let her fans down. Although the Gallos are in the background, you will not be disappointed with who takes the forefront. In Sinful Intent we meet Morgan DeLuca, favorite cousin to the Gallo clan. Morgan is a former troubled youth who was given a choice: military or jail. Opting for door #1, Morgan turned his life around to become a responsible adult and dedicated soldier. The story opens with Morgan and his mother Fran enroute to Izzy and James's wedding. The entire trip, Fran is reading Morgan the riot act about...well...everything. She is a sweetheart and you'll love her to pieces but she definitely stays on her boys back (which actually works out for Morgan toward the end of the story). The wedding reception lends itself to a good deal of family ribbing and fun times, but it leaves Morgan with a job offer from Thomas to join them at ALFA Investigations -- the PI business started by him and James. Morgan deliberated his decision for only a little while before deciding to accept the offer. Confident in Morgan's skills, Thomas assigns him a case right away. The client is Race True (you'll adore the meaning of her name) and she has a bit of a problem. Someone, an anonymous someone, is threatening to go very public with something very personal to her. She hires ALFA to see if they can help to unmask her blackmailer.Morgan and True have potent chemistry between them at their first meeting. Morgan is very attracted to Race, and she is as equally attracted to him; however, her professional ice princess mien reveals nothing to the effect. But that doesn't last long. Morgan and Race quickly yield to their passion for one another and through that passion their feelings for one another grow exponentially. As with any good story though, it's never that easy. Love doesn't conquer all without a few battle scars. Morgan is desperate to reveal who is blackmailing Race but the blackmailer plays some serious games with them that almost costs Race her life.The story is thrilling from beginning to end and I love the byplay and interactions between the characters. Bliss creates characters with strong voices that are similar yet so very different, too from her typical characters that we know and love. Sinful Intent definitely needs to be on your auto-buy list this summer!At the end of Sinful Intent we are introduced to Frisco, a new PI and a transplant from San Francisco. I cannot wait to get grabby hands on his story.

I love a good PNR, and I've enjoyed many of Celia's books in the past. Unfortunately, this one was a miss for me. It was an intro to a new series so it was chock full of information. Almost too much so because there was quite a bit happening toward the latter half of the story. It wasn't chaotic but it did feel....crammed, is the best adjective I can use to describe it.

I love this series and Brenda Rothert has a truly amazing gift for story telling. Although Mason's story was MUCH different than Reed's it was no less an amazing read. And the pairing between Mason and April was absolutely superb. I cannot wait to see what she does with Kyle. My prediction is that his ladylove will be Alyssa, April's sister. I am going to love his story either way :D.

Just when I thought I wouldn't love an of the Inked Menace boys more thanLucky, Hawk makes me turn my affections over to Oliver. I adored his character and the connection that he had with Amara. Lord, will her story break your heart. I felt her pain at the hands of the vile scientists who used her as a human/shifter lab rat. Despite Amara's PTSD, Oliver...dear sweet Oliver wooed her to the point that she could not resist the mating pull between them. Beyond the many smexy times in this story, Hawk brings the heat with an intensely dramatic storyline as well. This one will make you bite your nails and cheer for the good guys! I love the little teaser that we got about Flip at the end and I cannot wait to read his story. Each one of these books just keeps getting better and better!

Wow! This story will most definitely test the range of your emotions. The highs and lows are abundant in Deep Down but they are woven together masterfully to create one beautiful story.  I fell in love with the characters and the sweet little town of Lovely. Ivy will certainly break your heart. Hard. But it was so heartwarming to see her fight her way back from such a great tragedy. This book nerds to be on every contemporary romance lovers TBR list.Be warned though. There is very sensitive subject matter at the end of the story. If you can, press through it because the story ends on such a beautiful note.

Seriously, the cliffies are KILLING, and Desperate Domination doesn't come out until the end of July. I've pre-ordered it...but still. I hope that is the last in the series because I don't enjoy too many cliffies in a series. Although well written, there definitely needs to be an end to the Jackson-Hannah, and Deep Domination ended just when it was getting good. Jackson FINALLY figured out that Hannah and Harley were twins instead of one woman with an alias. But the story ends with Hannah escaping as she spies one of Jackson's punishments. One that would certainly and irrevocably break her.

Oh man. This quick read, ending in a cliffy is the WORST case of mistaken identity. Hannah is confused with her conniving sister, Harley, and ends us having a night of exquisite passion with Harley's boy-toy of the moment, Jackson. Hannah offers token protests to Jackson's sensual assault but totally gives into his mastery of her body. That one night changes Hannah forever, in more ways than one. She finds out things about her family from her aunt Sybil that cause them to go on the run, changing their identities. Unfortunately for us readers, we don't discover the family secrets in this book but we know they involve her father, who is also a schemer.Fast forward a few years and Jackson finds out that Harley is still alive. Only it's not Harley, it's Hannah, the woman he remembers the night of explosive passion with, thinking it was Harley. Doesn't that just make your brain hurt?!? But the Jackson we meet night is no longer the considerate but dominating lover who played her body masterfully. This Jackson is bent on revenge because Harley duped him, crushed his heart, and landed him in jail. Again, we don't know the how or why of the jail stint by Jackson is serious about payback. He intends to use Harley (really Hannah) for his sexual demands for one month. He buys her submission with the offer of a million dollars because Hannah and her aunt desperately need the money. And man...when it's revealed who Jackson is, Hannah's reaction isn't as expected. Far, far, from expected.Dang cliffy! I'm moving on to book 2 now.

Interesting start to a new series. Zara was put through the ringer by her evil, power-hungry father. Fortunately for her, the fates were kind and sent her her true mate in the form of Xavier. Loved him because he absolutely slayed every one if her demons for her. Little Natalie's plight will break your heart and you'll just want to love her and take care of her yourself. I liked the epilogue teaser at the end about Max. Can't wait to read book 2.
I really enjoyed the story and the characters and look forward to seeing what North does next with the series. Cassie needs a hot shifter boy, too :).

I loved the slant on the story. Rich billionaire lion shifter vs the sassy human female who makes him purr. The only reason I didn't rate the story 4 stars was because I wanted to see more alpha-ness from Arik. He was quite the Prima donna alpha and the only time we really got to see him in his full alpha glory was when it came to dealing with his ex. More rawr from him would have certainly put the story in the 4 star category but I did enjoy it and look forward to reading the next one in the series.

Admittedly, I was hesitant about reading The Last Dragon. As a lover of romance, specifically the paranormal or contemporary variety, I just didn't know if the story would have would it would take to keep my attention. But, the concept of the story seemed unique and I love series like the Black Dagger Brotherhood and Lords of the Underworld and felt that this story just might be something similar. And, I have to confess that I'm glad I took a chance. As with any new series, the first book contains a good amount of world building and that fact was no different for The Last Dragon. The world building is hard (for any series) and you have to stick with it to get to the meat of the story. And boy did this story have MEAT. I was impressed how Milchon seamlessly wove together paranormal and fantasy elements without overburdening the story. Basically, we have shifters, elementals, and other types of fantasy personas that we get glimpses of but are not able to understand the true scope of their abilities...in this book. But the setup is definitely there for us to know more about them.Now a little about the story itself. There really is a lot happening in the story and to do any recap of it will be totally insufficient. But understand this, the characters and the storyline worked very well together to create an amazing read. I loved Drake and Sally together. You will feel for Sally because of her horrible family situation. I mean, her siblings were AWWWW-ful to her. She was Cinderella and The Ugly Duckling rolled into one and they never let her forget it. So when she meets Drake and encounters his desire for her, she has a very difficult time accepting it. But Drake isn't alone in his feelings for her, the men who are his "brothers", called Omegas, at the beginning of the story, but become his BROTHERS by the end, all end up having feelings for Sally as well. Of course all of their feelings are different, save for one of the brothers, but Sally endears herself to them very quickly. But a LOT is happening in the background that neither Drake or Sally know about. Sally is more than any of them could have ever expected and she is the first piece in a very long riddle that could lead to the ultimate salvation of the Omegas.The story had moments of sweetness and serious moments of intensity toward the end that will absolutely keep you "IN" the story. I definitely look forward to seeing what happens next as Milchon set the stage for the next Omega to find his love and salvation.

Until JulyI discovered Aurora Reynolds recently and devoured the 4 books in the Until series with the Mayson books. I was SO looking forward to reading the nextgen story and was not disappointed with July and Wes' journey to love. The #BOOM works for the girls too. I adored how Wes and July met and even more how he inserted and then became a fixture in her life. We get to see glimpses of the now-older Matson men and they are still as bada$$ as ever. I appreciate how Reynolds writes strong female characters. When the chips are down and the girls need to get themselves out of jams they do. They love their men but are not damsels in distress. July certainly proved her metal at a critical point in the story, saving not only herself but someone else as well.And the jump to their lives in the future...I LOVED IT. It was so sweet seeing their happily ever after!I cannot wait to read Jax's journey. That one should be so interesting.

I love Joanna Wylde and was looking forward to reading Silver Bastard. The story was had moments of sexy intensity but the characters just didn't do it for me. I didn't exactly care for Puck and Becca as a couple. Apart they were fine; however, when thrown together as a couple they felt disconnected and their relationship felt disjointed...even more so than other biker relationships. And Becca's gullibility concerning her mother was sigh-worthy. I understand a child's love for a mother but the disfunction in that relationship was at a premium -- even at the end when Becca was still holding out hope that her mother would be more. All-in-all, this wasn't my favorite MC book by Wylde but I still look forward to seeing what she does next. I hope we get more Reapers...think I like them the best :).

I'm sad to see the conclusion of the Men of Inked series and I was glad that Anthony finally got his HEA. The toughest of all the Gallo's, manwhore, Anthony was the one I never guessed would be felled by a woman as sassy as Max. Max was definitely time enough for him from the minute of their introduction up unto the point where she said, "I do" but the journey was well worth it. I loved Max's backstory and the fact that she made Anthony "work for it" with her." But, sometimes, I just felt that Max was too acerbic. I definitely felt for her once I discovered the reason why she put Anthony on the emotional roller-coaster that he couldn't seem to get off off. However, there were times when I felt she was just too.......extra. Her attitude definitely rivaled Izzy's in the sass department but she was stubborn at times when she just could have relented. Poor Anthony had to battle out even the little things with her. I'm sure that was Bliss's intent because Anthony DESERVED it because of how he treated all the women in his past. But Max seemed to break him at every turn. The friction between them actually took some of the enjoyment out of the story for me. I didn't hate it but because of it, Without Me was my least favorite in the series. I was happy to see where they landed and the beauty that came out of the fight. As always I LOVED the family and even the connection that Marie had to Max's mother Ruth -- I thought that was sweet. Although I'm sorry to see the Gallo's go, I look forward to seeing what Bliss thinks up next.
As per usual, another sexy read by Milly Taiden. I love that she makes her heroines comfortable in their own skin and she creates alpha heroes who love them just as they are. Rawrrrr.

I'm struggling with my feelings about this book. I loved Lana and Callum but didn't exactly love them together. Well...that's not right. I didn't love HOW they got together. Lana is on the heels of her breakup with Jack and Callum essentially becomes her rebound lover cum boyfriend. Part of her heart still belongs to Jack but then she gives the other half to Callum whom she has always had a strong attraction for. There is still drama in the story and her step brother Brock is still very much a thorn in her life. He has even infiltrated her one sanctuary, her course work, by dating her graduate adviser and friend. Brock uses every opportunity to torment her and even tries to turn her friend against her. Through it all, Callum is in her corner. But Lana finds out something that absolutely wrecks her...and this time completely because now the other half of her heart is broken too. Aaaaaaand, Jack is back...wanting to claim the woman he still loves. But of course it can't be that easy and we are left with another cliffhanger in anticipation for book three *angry sigh*...but I totally want to see how this story ends.

Just when I think D.B. Reynolds has blown my socks off, she releases a new book and proves me wrong EVERY. SINGLE. TIME. Deception  was a fast paced, heart pumping read that kept me IN IT from beginning to action. The story was amazing and the action was intense. You have never seen Raphael and Cyn like this before and you need to drop what you're doing RIGHT NOW to pick up this book. There are revelations in the story that will leave you speechless and wondering...and wanting much more. Amazing read!

I was a little sad to reach the end of the Stage Dive series. I mean, come on, let's be honest here. This series has bought us many sexy times, complete with highs, lows, and laughter, courtesy of Mal. I just wasn't quite ready to let my boys go! But, as the saying goes, "All good things must come to and end." Yet, I give mad props to Scott who did not disappoint with Ben's story.Throughout the series, Ben was always the one band member that I could never quite get a bead on. He was aloof and muted when compared to Dave and Jimmy and completely overshadowed by Mal. That said, I wasn't sure how I'd feel about him being the main protagonist of his own story. Did I say Scott did not disappoint? Well, I really meant it! In Deep she allowed us to see a depth in Ben that didn't feel present throughout the series. Pair a "deeper" Ben with a sassy Lizzy, and the story was a full-on roller-coaster ride. Poor Lizzy though. I felt so bad for her after she discovered her predicament of "being in the family way." She had to tell her sister, Anne, who she was afraid to disappoint *gasp*. More importantly, she had to tell a relationship-reticent Ben who made it quite clear that he was not looking for more *grrr*.I will confess that Ben's wishy-washy indifference/attraction toward Lizzy was maddening. He was sexy as all get out but he made you want to smack his face off because of how hot and cold he ran with Lizzy. But her heart and her body wanted Ben so she endured a lot of his behavior. Yes for the sake of their unborn child, but also because she held out hope that he would change his mind and see her for more than just a human incubator. Sadly, Ben's hot and cold attitude had a good run in the story, but the man does wise up and realize that Lizzy just "might" be the woman he wants. Oh he is plenty attracted to her but his heart was realllllllly slow in catching up with body. Insert a sexy male red-head, and one caustic sister, and the roller-coaster gets even more twisty. But I loved every minute of those twists.Scott did an excellent job taking the reader right up to the end of the story with no happily ever after in sight. I mean my Kindle was at 93% and I absolutely saw NO WAY for Ben and Lizzy to have their happily ever. But I breathed a sigh of relief while reading the remaining 7% of the story, including the epilogue. That 7% was totally worth the cuticle bitten nails.The joy in reaching the end of the Stage Dive series is knowing that it's not completely over. The sexy-redhead, Vaughn, will be starring in Scott's spin-off series Dive Bar, and I believe that we'll also see a reappearance from Marty, Ben's sister, and the security chief, Sam. Already the series sounds promising and it hasn't even been written yet. I cannot wait to get it in my hot little hands.I highly recommend this series to anyone who is in the mood for a romance series that is funny, sexy, and highly engaging.

I have to say that I enjoyed FireStarter quite a bit. I wasn't expecting it to have paranormal undertones to it, but it did. Those undertones morphed the story from a good romance to one that had some heat (pun intentional). I loved Keanu and Cammie...and the unexpected twist with Cammie's parents was well-played. I'm definitely looking forward to reading more books in this series.

I have a confession to make *takes a deep breath*. I started this book with very preconceived notions about what I thought thought the story would be. I was expecting something a little on the Fifty Shades of Gideon Cross side, but I was wrong. Completely wrong.Manwhore was quite an engaging story of Malcolm Kyle Preston Logan Saint or simply "Saint" and Rachel Livingston. This story was a breath of fresh air in that although the protagonists had some baggage from life (who doesn't?!?) they were not the typical broken souls that are often popular in modern romance. Rachel's father passed away at a young age so she does not really understand love between genders. She loves and cares for her mother with a protective fierceness but has no idea how to relate to the opposite sex on a deeper level. Saint lost his mother at a young age and his father is boorish, mean, and jealous of his son. A son who he doubted and reviled. Yet, that same son outpaced his father financially and success-wise. But where Saint's drive in the business world caused him to be a forced to be reckoned with, his salacious drive caused him to be popular among the ladies. So much so that he is known around Chicago for his raw sex appeal and "manwhoring" ways. Women want him and men want to be him. And that's what brings him on a direct collision course with Rachel Livingston.Rachel has always wanted to achieve success and acclaim as a reporter. Working for Edge magazine she has achieved a small modicum of success; however she wants her name to be a household name. She wants the fame to catapult her career and finances so she can give back to her mother, and provide her life a level of comfort they did not have while she was growing up. So, when Rachel receives an assignment to do an exposé on the ladykiller, Saint, she jumps at the opportunity. The mission is simple: Interview him, gain his trust, and find out every dirty detail possible about him and exploit it for the article. If only things were that simple though. The minute Saint and Rachel meet, a completely unauspicious meeting as it was, their fate is sealed. Saint is intrigued by the beautiful reporter who comes to her interview with him wearing paint-stained overalls. After the most awkward of interviews -- a whole 10 minutes -- Saint is whisked away to his next high profile meeting. Although disappointed, Rachel does not let that deter her from gaining access to his life. Her persistence allows her to gain one meeting after another with Saint. Each meeting causing their desires for each other to grow. Saint's interest in Rachel quickly goes from professional to personal. He makes no secret about the fact that he wants Rachel, especially when he calls "Dibs" on her after she sneaks into a party he's hosting at a popular club. Saint and Rachel play the professional role until an steamy first kiss sparks more than just passion. Their feelings for each other grow and the once aloof billionaire lets down his guard with Rachel in a way that he has not with anyone else. They share texts, calls, and visits and lots of sexy times together. You can clearly see that Saint is beginning to have deeper feelings for Rachel. It's really rather sweet the things he does for her -- Ellie the elephant *sigh*.But unfortunately...Yeah, you knew it was coming. Reality invades and Rachel's rival at the magazine, who played the classic frienemy role well, causes her world to absolutely cave in around her. As her feelings for Saint grew, Rachel really struggled with writing the article. She didn't want to write it at all, but a strong directive by the editor-in-charge, Helen, caused a fierce battle of conscious. When Helen discovered that the rival was going to write a tell-all article for a competitor magazine, she advised Rachel to write her story first! Rachel wanted to come clean and tell Saint what was happening because the article came out; however, he was out of town and they wouldn't be able to connect until the weekend. Rachel figured that she had a little bit of time because the rival's article was slated to come out on the upcoming Monday. But, the road to hell is paved with good intentions, right?!?! The rival's revelation came over the weekend. Way too early for Rachel since she never had an opportunity to talk to Saint and now EVERYONE knows about what she did. Rachel is devastated when she calls and texts him with no reply back. She implores him to let her tell her side of the story. After trying to reach him by phone -- unsuccessfully, she decides to show up at his office in hopes of gaining an audience with him. But that doesn't work either because she is summarily dismissed and escorted off the premises by a security officer. Rachel is absolutely heartbroken at Saint's departure from her life. She knows it is her fault; however, the pain of his loss in is immense.The end of the story ends in a major cliffy leaving the reader to wonder: Will they? Won't they? Stay tuned for the next installment of Manwhore in Manwhore +1 in July. I cannot wait to see what happens next for the couple!

I wanted to like this story because it contained many elements that I enjoy. Unfortunately, I had a difficult time getting into the story thus found almost no enjoyment in reading it. I love a PNR that draws me in from the first page and this one just didn't do it. The story felt scattered and the connection between the characters were virtually non-existent when the profession of love came. I know that insta-love is common in PNR but I am used to reading stories where at least some back story is provided to possibly show why the insta-love happened. I just didn't get any of that here. The story had good bones -- jealous she-wolf, crazy ex, two hot protective alphas but they didn't connect well for me. The resolution with Grant came abruptly and the end of the story even more so.

**UPDATE 4/15/15: Turtle Rock has released 2 new maps for free alongside a slew of balances and patches for some minor game issues. Turtle Rock has also hosted some community events and have been giving away prizes and skins for anyone who participates.**4 new characters have launched for Evolve, they all bring something new to the table and work well in unison, they are however NOT over powered nor are they just reskins of the original hunters. Players would not be faulted for skipping this purchase, though the new offerings are varied enough to add quite a lot to an already packed game. For the asking you might want to wait for a sale - but still the characters are great and if you see even 1 you must have then I suggest you go for it! The new characters are all more combat and damaged based and offer less defenses all around. My recommendation is to check youtube for the full character recap. Happy hunting!

**Update 4/14/15: Servers have continued to improve and Visceral has announced the first wave of patches/balances coming soon. I also now HIGHLY recommend the "Blood Money" game-mode as it's very fun and very well designed for most maps; Blood Money is a bit of a mix of neutral Capture-the-flag and base defense. I have logged roughly a hundred hours online across all game-modes and still find the multiplayer enjoyable.**It could be too early to say, but I dare say the verdict is in: BF Hardline doesn't suck (and is fun too). After EA/DICE totally screwed the pooch with the release of BF4, Hardline by some miracle works far better than anyone could have expected. After plopping down around 16 hours in the Beta, 10 hours through EA access, and another 4+ hours last night (release day) I would be lying if I said my experience was anything less than satisfactory. Most surprising is that the single player campaign is actually somewhat decent and focuses more on stealth and gadgets then huge war-like battles, though it's not perfect and a few of the game mechanics are a bit silly (such as flashing your badge to instantly make enemies surrender to you, lol).BFH plays like a Battlefield and Call of Duty crossover, in the best and worst ways possible. Like BF you expect open maps with lots of vantage & entry points with a few vehicles thrown in to add to the mayhem, minus the military vehicles everything is pretty much the same. More to the tune of COD, maps are much smaller with more choke points; run-and-gun game play is key in most situations and you will die very FAST. The game suffers some of the notoriously bad habits of COD in that there are many instances of spawn death. Spawning in your base is ALWAYS safe however. If you spawn on teammates and objectives then you do so at your own risk and can expect to be gunned down if enemies are nearby, this is due to spawning much closer than ever before to objectives. While irritating it's just a side effect of having small maps; large game modes are a bit crowded and the chaos can be a bit too much.The biggest issue about BFH for me is that many matches are over in about 5-10 minutes, and some modes have lower ticket counts pending on the map, tickets also bleed very fast and I found most matches ended before I had a chance to get into it. I imagine this will be addressed if it bothers enough people as there's no reason a game of conquest should end in less than 10 minutes. The second biggest issue is the persistence of a known bug from BF4 where players "trade kills," this alone is absolutely maddening. In 2 separate instances now I was melee'd to death AFTER I shot a guy and he died. I have video of this recorded and it's extremely frustrating when you die in 1 on 1 fights AFTER you kill the other guy; it wouldn't bother me much if it wasn't happening ever 2 or 3 deaths. Screw that!Speaking of the new maps, I'm actually VERY impressed with the new offerings thus far. There are some beautiful new levels that really capture the spirit of the "criminal"locations they represent. Even on smaller levels there are a surprising number of paths around each map, including roads/water for vehicles. Each objective/structure has several doors (many of them interactive or destructible) and there's a lot of variety in map types. I was especially impressed with the use of elevation in some areas having not just 1 or 2 floors, but up to 3 or 4. It should also be mentioned that the inclusion of portable zip lines and grappling hooks is really great and adds a huge amount of traversal power.Some of the new game modes are decently fun too, Hotwire sends players to hop into objective cars and traverse the map at high speeds in order to gain points, it's really fun and the maps support this game mode well. Conquest and TDM return as normal, and while fun, don't really add much new. Heist is an objective mode that pits cops-vs.-robbers around a very specific set of objectives (like robbing a bank, etc): it's a bit hard to learn but is a nice change of pace. There are also a few others but in truth I haven't touch much outside these (I mostly play Hotwire and Conquest).All in all the game is fast paced, challenging, and needs a bit more polish. BF Hardline will be on sale before long so there's no harm in waiting for a price drop, it's not a perfect game by any means, but it does run smooth and has enough content to keep you entertained. My advice: don't buy the Deluxe or Ultimate versions, Premium isn't really worth it until they actually release new maps later on, and the starter "Battle-packs" give you random crap that won't help you (I know b/c I downloaded the Deluxe version and in NO WAY was it worth an extra $10). For those on fence, wait for a price drop as this game will most def be on sale before long.

DO NOT BUY.Microsoft has already said that the Xbox One should not be stood up vertically:"We don't support vertical orientation; do it at your own risk… it wouldn't be a cooling problem, we just didn't design the drive for vertical. Because it's a slot loading drive, we just didn't design it for both". ~Microsoft's Albert Panello, senior director of product mgmt

**Update 4/14/15: I have been playing through with a friend and have had only minimal issues with the online portion of the game, I highly reccommend buying the "Name Engraved Ring" from the cat in Majula, it allows you to easily find specific players for co-op (though you may need to drop your summon sign up to 3-5 times before it works).**Dark Souls 2 has often been called the lesser brother of Dark Souls (the 1st), and while I don’t think that’s entirely fair it’s also not entirely wrong either. They are for certain different games with many similarities; the first DS has a wealth of atmosphere and immaculately designed levels, and will forever hold a place in our hearts as the first time a game kick our collective butts. Along comes DSII with its sharp non-gothic style (boo!), its faster combat & better magic (yay!), and somewhat disjoined levels that aren’t quite as good as the first game but look nice all the same. I for one am more than happy to replaying my favorite game of 2014.Where Dark Souls exceeded in being terrifying, unfamiliar, and difficult DSII sought to twist the knife further by throwing more odd and difficult encounters into the mix. Scholar of the First Sin, meanwhile, gives us the best experience of DSII but ISN’T just a remake, it’s a remix: enemy locations have been moved or changed entirely, new foes roam the world, more traps and surprises throughout the game, new NPCs  give us more lore and help new players through the world. As well, enemies are a bit more aggressive and players may now summon more friends (and foes) to engage in jolly co-operation!DSII:SotFS also includes all 3 of the large DLC’s previously released on last gen consoles (and pc), all of which I HIGHLY recommend playing through as they are quite good and possible better than the whole core game alone. Each of the DLC’s has new bosses, gear, loot, and levels that add to the core game is great ways. FromSoftware has also improved all audio and visual content to help make sure the game looks great at all times, running in 1080p/60fps. It’s an obvious buy if you missed it entirely or just want to have more fun in a semi-new experience; SKIP this game if you hated it the first time, don’t like HARD games, or got your fill the first time around.

This was one of the first games I received for free on Xbox One's "Games-with-Gold." It's a very decently little title and a great buy for kids of anyone who loves puzzle games, some of the challenges are really fun, there's a neat mechanic in the game where "Max" uses his magic marker to change and alter the elements in the environment. The game won’t blow people away but it does look great and it’s fun too. My little nephew has played the whole game when he came to visit and he really enjoyed it. Great buy for the money, you could do much worse!

Child of Light is a sort of retelling or spin-off of the story of Sleeping Beauty but from the perspective of the sleeping princess; somehow COL works and isn't just beautiful, it's also charming and meaningful. I was quite impressed with the lovely piano heavy soundtrack, it sets the mood and is easily some of the best videogame music I've heard in a long time - but it is great music, and is more than just a soundtrack.COL is turn based 2D RPG and you will be flying through levels (quite literally) solving some minor puzzles, listening to dialogue and engaging in turn-based fights through the game. The fights are just challenging enough to keep you interested and allow you to use 2 characters (there's quite a few to pick from) with varying abilities against a good variety of monsters (and bosses too!), there's a number of special attacks and unique abilities pending on the characters you choose. There's also a good little gem crafting system which will allow you to mix up you damage type and resistances per character. You'll also be able to find a swath of armor other equipment to keep your dudes suited up. It's good fun and very enjoyable, defiantly worth the price.

I started using this oil daily to see if my beard would begin to soften up, and after 2 months my beard doesn't feel much softer than before, the exception to this being if the oil is still in my beard. It makes my wife very unhappy when I kiss her and she gets a nice dab of oily residue on her face & I was hoping it would dry a bit faster. It does at least smell very nice but I can’t honestly recommend this product based on the price, quantity and lasting effect (or lack thereof). The oil seems to be a bit strong, many have said this oil is also good for the skin and sooths irritation, and while I didn’t have any problems it did burn a bit if it got anywhere near my eyes. My suggestion is to look for another brand as this one seems to be either hit or miss.

Leon the Professional (“The Professional”) is a beautiful love story/action flick that tells the tale of a hired killer and the young girl he saves. One of my all time favorite movies, it’s very different in pacing and style then your run of the miller action movies, but I quite enjoy what it brings to the table. Great acting from all sides - especially the villain - Stansfield (Gary Oldman) will leave chills running down your spine. This version of the film has a lot of extra content and in my opinion is the most complete and most compelling version available.

Cowboy Bebop is some damn good fun, I watch this show every few years in its entirety. I always find myself completely enamored with the voice work and animation style, the music too is an exceptional bit of pure gold. This Blu-ray version of the show is beautifully redone with a wealth of bonus content. It's a very excellent buy for the money for what is easily one of the best animes ever created, some might disagree, but the wealth of talent on-board this show would beg to differ.

Ori and the Blind Forrest is one of the better games I’ve played in years, especially when you consider the $20 price tag. This game has so many wonderful selling points: a unique fully orchestrated soundtrack, butter smooth game controls, & a to-die-for art style. Ori is a small fox like forest spirit who’s trying to find his way in the world after the forest he’s from begins to die. It plays exceedingly similar to Metroid and Castlevania games, and I can assure you it’s a VERY good thing. It truly is a beautiful, emotional, and challenging game – there’s really no reason not to try it. While a bit simple on the surface this experience is a great selling point for any Xbox owner and simply fun!

Bought this as a gift for the wife and I to cook some easy meals in the Crock Pot; the book has a number of great dishes but you may be scurrying to find some of the ingredients, many of which we never seemed to have on hand. Still, it's a good buy and offers lots of ideas and suggestions to make sure you get something tasty out of your slow cooker. I'm sure you could find these or similar recipes online but it is nice having the guide in hand. This cook book is easy to read with lots of helpful pictures to help you sort things out. I’m satisfied with my purchase.

I have no hate towards this game but of the 4 hours I played this game I was rather bored. Simply put, it does not deliver a very interesting experience. While the game looks great visually and the controls are very tight and responsive, the story is nearly nonexistent and tells the tale of generic space drama, invaders, big metal ball, etc but nothing really stands out. The multiplayer is somewhat interesting and the gun play is smooth enough, but the much touted single player is very barebones, if you like hunting for loot and collectibles look elsewhere. There's only 1 ability per "class" and it leaves much to be desired, they could have crafted such wonderful game but opted instead to go the lazy route. They spent millions and I've played budget indie games better than this. I cannot for the life of me understand the massive following this game has, people will buy anything.

**Update 4/14/15: Servers have continued to improve and Visceral has announced the first wave of patches/balances coming soon. I also now HIGHLY recommend the “Blood Money” game-mode as it’s very fun and very well designed for most maps; Blood Money is a bit of a mix of neutral Capture-the-flag and base defense. I have logged roughly a hundred hours online across all game-modes and still find the multiplayer enjoyable.**It could be too early to say, but I dare say the verdict is in: BF Hardline doesn't suck (and is fun too). After EA/DICE totally screwed the pooch with the release of BF4, Hardline by some miracle works far better than anyone could have expected. After plopping down around 16 hours in the Beta, 10 hours through EA access, and another 4+ hours last night (release day) I would be lying if I said my experience was anything less than satisfactory. Most surprising is that the single player campaign is actually somewhat decent and focuses more on stealth and gadgets then huge war-like battles, though it’s not perfect and a few of the game mechanics are a bit silly (such as flashing your badge to instantly make enemies surrender to you, lol).BFH plays like a Battlefield and Call of Duty crossover, in the best and worst ways possible. Like BF you expect open maps with lots of vantage & entry points with a few vehicles thrown in to add to the mayhem, minus the military vehicles everything is pretty much the same. More to the tune of COD, maps are much smaller with more choke points; run-and-gun game play is key in most situations and you will die very FAST. The game suffers some of the notoriously bad habits of COD in that there are many instances of spawn death. Spawning in your base is ALWAYS safe however. If you spawn on teammates and objectives then you do so at your own risk and can expect to be gunned down if enemies are nearby, this is due to spawning much closer than ever before to objectives. While irritating it’s just a side effect of having small maps; large game modes are a bit crowded and the chaos can be a bit too much.The biggest issue about BFH for me is that many matches are over in about 5-10 minutes, and some modes have lower ticket counts pending on the map, tickets also bleed very fast and I found most matches ended before I had a chance to get into it. I imagine this will be addressed if it bothers enough people as there’s no reason a game of conquest should end in less than 10 minutes. The second biggest issue is the persistence of a known bug from BF4 where players “trade kills,” this alone is absolutely maddening. In 2 separate instances now I was melee'd to death AFTER I shot a guy and he died. I have video of this recorded and it's extremely frustrating when you die in 1 on 1 fights AFTER you kill the other guy; it wouldn't bother me much if it wasn't happening ever 2 or 3 deaths. Screw that!Speaking of the new maps, I'm actually VERY impressed with the new offerings thus far. There are some beautiful new levels that really capture the spirit of the "criminal"locations they represent. Even on smaller levels there are a surprising number of paths around each map, including roads/water for vehicles. Each objective/structure has several doors (many of them interactive or destructible) and there's a lot of variety in map types. I was especially impressed with the use of elevation in some areas having not just 1 or 2 floors, but up to 3 or 4. It should also be mentioned that the inclusion of portable zip lines and grappling hooks is really great and adds a huge amount of traversal power.Some of the new game modes are decently fun too, Hotwire sends players to hop into objective cars and traverse the map at high speeds in order to gain points, it's really fun and the maps support this game mode well. Conquest and TDM return as normal, and while fun, don't really add much new. Heist is an objective mode that pits cops-vs.-robbers around a very specific set of objectives (like robbing a bank, etc): it's a bit hard to learn but is a nice change of pace. There are also a few others but in truth I haven't touch much outside these (I mostly play Hotwire and Conquest).All in all the game is fast paced, challenging, and needs a bit more polish. BF Hardline will be on sale before long so there's no harm in waiting for a price drop, it's not a perfect game by any means, but it does run smooth and has enough content to keep you entertained. My advice: don't buy the Deluxe or Ultimate versions, Premium isn't really worth it until they actually release new maps later on, and the starter "Battle-packs" give you random crap that won't help you (I know b/c I downloaded the Deluxe version and in NO WAY was it worth an extra $10). For those on fence, wait for a price drop as this game will most def be on sale before long.

Conquest and TDM return as normal, and while fun, don't really add much new. Heist is an objective mode that pits cops-vs.-robbers around a very specific set of objectives (like robbing a bank, etc): it's a bit hard to learn but is a nice change of pace. There are also a few others but in truth I haven't touch much outside these (I mostly play Hotwire and Conquest).All in all the game is fast paced, challenging, and needs a bit more polish. BF Hardline will be on sale before long so there's no harm in waiting for a price drop, it's not a perfect game by any means, but it does run smooth and has enough content to keep you entertained. My advice: don't buy the Deluxe or Ultimate versions, Premium isn't really worth it until they actually release new maps later on, and the starter "Battle-packs" give you random crap that won't help you (I know b/c I downloaded the Deluxe version and in NO WAY was it worth an extra $10). For those on fence, wait for a price drop as this game will most def be on sale before long.

Well all I have to say about this trimmer is that it works quite well and it’s very slick looking too. The Trym II comes with a charging base and cord, both of which look good and take up very little room on the counter. There are a decent number of guards for the blade for short and medium lengths, I would like a few more options for longer beard hair but I still found everything included to very satisfactory. The blade/motor seems quite capable and cut through my face pubes with ease and left me with a nice even cut. Great buy for the price; also included: some blade oil for the trimmer and a small brush to clean up with.

There are also a few others but in truth I haven't touch much outside these (I mostly play Hotwire and Conquest).All in all the game is fast paced, challenging, and needs a bit more polish. BF Hardline will be on sale before long so there's no harm in waiting for a price drop, it's not a perfect game by any means, but it does run smooth and has enough content to keep you entertained. My advice: don't buy the Deluxe or Ultimate versions, Premium isn't really worth it until they actually release new maps later on, and the starter "Battle-packs" give you random crap that won't help you (I know b/c I downloaded the Deluxe version and in NO WAY was it worth an extra $10). For those on fence, wait for a price drop as this game will most def be on sale before long.

**Update 4/14/15: Servers have continued to improve and Visceral has announced the first wave of patches/balances coming soon. I also now HIGHLY recommend the “Blood Money” game-mode as it’s very fun and very well designed for most maps; Blood Money is a bit of a mix of neutral Capture-the-flag and base defense. I have logged roughly a hundred hours online across all game-modes and still find the multiplayer enjoyable.**It could be too early to say, but I dare say the verdict is in: BF Hardline doesn't suck (and is fun too). After EA/DICE totally screwed the pooch with the release of BF4, Hardline by some miracle works far better than anyone could have expected. After plopping down around 16 hours in the Beta, 10 hours through EA access, and another 4+ hours last night (release day) I would be lying if I said my experience was anything less than satisfactory. Most surprising is that the single player campaign is actually somewhat decent and focuses more on stealth and gadgets then huge war-like battles, though it’s not perfect and a few of the game mechanics are a bit silly (such as flashing your badge to instantly make enemies surrender to you, lol).BFH plays like a Battlefield and Call of Duty crossover, in the best and worst ways possible. Like BF you expect open maps with lots of vantage & entry points with a few vehicles thrown in to add to the mayhem, minus the military vehicles everything is pretty much the same. More to the tune of COD, maps are much smaller with more choke points; run-and-gun game play is key in most situations and you will die very FAST. The game suffers some of the notoriously bad habits of COD in that there are many instances of spawn death. Spawning in your base is ALWAYS safe however. If you spawn on teammates and objectives then you do so at your own risk and can expect to be gunned down if enemies are nearby, this is due to spawning much closer than ever before to objectives. While irritating it’s just a side effect of having small maps; large game modes are a bit crowded and the chaos can be a bit too much.The biggest issue about BFH for me is that many matches are over in about 5-10 minutes, and some modes have lower ticket counts pending on the map, tickets also bleed very fast and I found most matches ended before I had a chance to get into it. I imagine this will be addressed if it bothers enough people as there’s no reason a game of conquest should end in less than 10 minutes. The second biggest issue is the persistence of a known bug from BF4 where players “trade kills,” this alone is absolutely maddening. In 2 separate instances now I was melee'd to death AFTER I shot a guy and he died. I have video of this recorded and it's extremely frustrating when you die in 1 on 1 fights AFTER you kill the other guy; it wouldn't bother me much if it wasn't happening ever 2 or 3 deaths. Screw that!Speaking of the new maps, I'm actually VERY impressed with the new offerings thus far. There are some beautiful new levels that really capture the spirit of the "criminal"locations they represent. Even on smaller levels there are a surprising number of paths around each map, including roads/water for vehicles. Each objective/structure has several doors (many of them interactive or destructible) and there's a lot of variety in map types. I was especially impressed with the use of elevation in some areas having not just 1 or 2 floors, but up to 3 or 4. It should also be mentioned that the inclusion of portable zip lines and grappling hooks is really great and adds a huge amount of traversal power.Some of the new game modes are decently fun too, Hotwire sends players to hop into objective cars and traverse the map at high speeds in order to gain points, it's really fun and the maps support this game mode well. Conquest and TDM return as normal, and while fun, don't really add much new. Heist is an objective mode that pits cops-vs.-robbers around a very specific set of objectives (like robbing a bank, etc): it's a bit hard to learn but is a nice change of pace. There are also a few others but in truth I haven't touch much outside these (I mostly play Hotwire and Conquest).All in all the game is fast paced, challenging, and needs a bit more polish. BF Hardline will be on sale before long so there's no harm in waiting for a price drop, it's not a perfect game by any means, but it does run smooth and has enough content to keep you entertained. My advice: don't buy the Deluxe or Ultimate versions, Premium isn't really worth it until they actually release new maps later on, and the starter "Battle-packs" give you random crap that won't help you (I know b/c I downloaded the Deluxe version and in NO WAY was it worth an extra $10). For those on fence, wait for a price drop as this game will most def be on sale before long.
