We live on a farm in Hawaii and my wife uses notebook paper for her 3-ring binders of farm stuff.  We got this product at a discount by using a a coupon code we found on the internet. It sits between the desk or counter top and when you press on it with an ink pen or a pencil, your thoughts and drawings are recorded on the paper.  The paper is thick enough that you can write, erase, and rewrite without any problems.  That's of course assuming you are writing with a pencil.  Although I do remember back in the day they would sell ball point ink pens with an abrasive white "eraser" on the end that didn't actually erase anything, it just sanded off the top layer of paper.  I bet this paper would work well with one of those as well but I'd probably have to go to an antique store to find a pen like that because everybody these days use computers.  Remember the "Erasermate" pen?  It was a pen with a regular eraser and you could erase it just like a pencil.  I think it came out in the 1980's.  It seemed like a really good idea unless you were writing a whole page and then your hand would smear the erasable ink.  Also it was not a substitute for the good old #2 pencil required for taking tests.  Oh the memories.  Anyways, I've digressed.  If you are still using paper, you need this product, otherwise you're just writing on your desk or counter top.

I live in Hawaii and despite our best efforts of clothing, sun blocks, and other efforts the occasional sun burn happens.  If its a small sunburned area I just snap off a piece from our aloe vera plans and squeeze it onto the burn and gently rub it in. They are all just chemical gels with aloe vera as one of the last ingredients in insignificant amounts that do no good.  In fact most of these products contain mostly alcohol which feels good during application because gives a cooling effect as it evaporates, but alcohol actually dries the skin and makes the burn worse in the long run.This product is awesome because it is 100% aloe vera gel with just a few natural additives to help keep it fresh and improve the texture.  It has a natural consistency, it SMELLS exactly like the aloe vera I squeeze from our plants (I hate fake fragrances added to aloe vera) and most importantly it soothes the burn and speeds the healing exactly like our plants do.Put this in the refrigerator and next time you or your loved one gets a nasty sunburn, rub some of this onto the burn. I got a small discount on the price of this item by using a coupon code I found online and they asked but not required that if I use the code I would leave a review whether it was good or bad. * UPDATE: 4.9 STARS ** OK I am addicted.  I really like this thing.  You have to take into account the low, low price of this device.  Given that, I'm willing to let slide the little quirks I see.  What this is, is a motivational tool.  Get up - get active - move - drink some water - check up on your sleep.  All that for fifteen bucks??  Awesome.  I've updated my original review below:*-For the shockingly low price of $15 (???) you get a little black band to wear around your wrist, just like everyone else is doing these days.  What's it for?  Well, supposedly it tracks your activity - steps taken, sleep taken, etc.  For it's price point, it does really well.-I would call this a basic activity bracelet.  More on that in a minute.-I've never had one of these things before, so I had no expectations.  After wearing it now and getting used to it, I have some comments.-1) I like the display on the band.  It's really nice for such a low price.  Unbelievable even.  It shows text, little icons with the figures next to them.  Now, I don't normally USE the display; I read what's in the app on my phone.  But you may like it.2) It's super light and you barely notice it.  I've had it on my wrist and you don't even know it's there.  It has a nice metal clasp (Another surprise for it's price point) so it fits snug and feels great.  The button, there's only one, is on the top so it's dead-easy to tap as you use it throughout the day.  I don't even glance at the band; I just tap that button and sync it to my phone's app to get the details.3) You don't always have to leave your bluetooth activated on your phone.  The band stores data, and you can update the app whenever you choose.4) It tracks stuff, but not everything.  You have to manually enter in your weight, along with how many ounces of water you just drank.  That's to be expected - manual entry.  And while it tracks steps taken, there's no accounting for stationary bike usage.  I use the stationary bike at the gym, but get no credit on the band. The band thinks I'm a lazy bum when really I'm a sweaty mess.  One thing I've noticed about what it tracks or doesn't track; you get addicted to the information.  You don't realize how little water you drink until you wear this thing all day and realize all you drank that day was a coffee and a diet coke.  And it's pretty accurate tracking steps; while that's not ALL your activity, it's a great motivational tool!!  And here's one side effect that I bet the makers didn't take into consideration; I don't just try to hit the goal of 10,000 steps a day, I have to be careful not to go OVER that.  Here's why; I have a bad hip. I can't take a lot of high-impact stuff; walking, jogging, lifting stuff.  I noticed on days when I use the treadmill at the gym, I go way over 10,000 steps for the day, and my hip aches.  So, now I know to LIMIT my steps so I don't hurt my hip!  What a great thing!  Now I have some metrics to help me manage the pain!!!  ALSO; I recently read in Men's Fitness that 10,000 steps is a good goal; 8,000 steps isn't enough to get the full benefit of exercise, and there isn't much difference between the benefit of taking 10,000 or 12,000 steps - so really, I need to limit my steps to 10,000 (to save time and save wear and tear on my hip!).5) The app is user friendly, kinda.  I had to google how to enter in the ounces of water I've drank.  And thankfully they uploaded some videos to youtube, so you can learn quickly.  It's a little tricky updating my weight; it uses the same slider-style thing to update, and for whatever reason I can never get it to show 182 pounds.  It's either 183 or 181.  But hey that's close enough.6) The band is a little quirky at times.  This morning I followed instructions to "wake up" my band, but somehow ended up in a stopwatch feature.  No idea it was even there.  I don't even know how I got out of that but I did manage to sync my band after that.  I also looked this morning, and when I updated the app, it didn't track my sleep from the night before.  I know I set it to sleep mode before I went to bed.  Maybe I hit the button by accident or something?  That was disappointing, because as I said, it gets addicting getting this data.  But hey I know I slept fine.  It's fun to see how many times I got up at night.7) The sleep graph on the app is neat.  The band tracks how long it stays still, as well as the amount of movement.  So, if you toss and turn, you'll see dips in your graph.  If you get up to hit the bathroom, you'll see a spike.  The thing thinks I slept for over 7 hours last night.  If I did that, I wouldn't need so many damn doctors.  I can lie still better than most people - so I think it's a bit off in that department.  There's a chance I went sleepwalking; I know I got up ONCE that night, but the graph showed TWO big dips...  weird!  Are you a sleepwalker?  This thing will tell you if you are!!!!!-For the price, it's GREAT.  It's a basic activity band / good motivational tool. The app is nice enough, and the band is cool too.  If you want something to get you off the couch and make sure you drink enough water, start here!!!

If you have a kid with a sense of humor, who enjoys goofy things and active games, then this is for you.-My 2 year old niece (soon to be 3) got a kick out of this game.  We don't really play by the rules (maybe when she's 4?) - we just pull the cards and have her do the wacky steps; walk around the stick thingy backwards while holding the "fishbowl" on your head, etc.-I should back up a minute.  This game involves you (or your kid) drawing cards that tell you to do something, and you get points for doing it.  There are some "props" you have that you can put together - a fishbowl, a cake, etc.  The cards give you instructions like take 3 giant steps or hop 4 times or walk around the stick (that's the big yellow thing you see here) all while holding one of items on your head, on your belly, etc.  My niece is a funny kid, and she liked doing the steps.  She didn't care about the points or whatever, which is good because I didn't understand the game completely anyhow.  But that might be the point.  It IS Cat in the Hat, after all.-My 4 year old nephew wanted nothing to do with it.  I think my niece has a better sense of humor than he does. If you have funny kids who like goofy things, this is right up their alley.

My 2 year old niece loves the Paw Patrol show.  But she likes most anything on a screen.  Kids these days, I tell ya, please limit their screen time huh?  Otherwise this generation is going to have a 2-foot vision span and thumbs that don't stop moving.-Anyway - she's 2 going on 3, and this ride-on toy is similar to many others out there with 2 exceptions:1) No noise.  Which is a good thing I think.  But there's no horn, or buttons, or anything.  For me, that's fine.  For a kid, well, something more woulda been nice.2) No steering.  This thing goes in a straight line.  You can't steer it.  For a 2 year old who likes to steer her trike, this was frustrating.  It's like kids today are too advanced for simple toys like this.  That's not to say she didn't like it; her house has hardwood floors over most of the 1st floor so she can scoot around just fine.  It's a lot harder to do on carpet!-So other than the stickers, there's not much "Paw Patrol" about it.  But for a young kid, they'll like it well enough.

This is the only stuff we use on our dogs.-I worked with an organization when I lived in Texas.  It was a volunteer-driven organization that fostered dogs that were going to be put down by a local shelter, but instead were saved and found loving homes.  For the dogs that are taken home, every single one of them is given this treatment.-I'm totally squeamish about fleas and ticks.  Yet I still work with dogs. My car smells.  Not bad. But I needed this.  See, I had a dog in there once, and he stank.  Like, really bad.  But that's not why my car smells.  I had the car "detailed" which I'd never done before.  I had them shampoo all the carpeting and fabric throughout the entire car.  That was nice.  Until it wasn't.  The car didn't air out properly, and over time, it developed a musty odor.  I took matters into my own hand and re-shampooed the carpets and fabric and used a shop-vac to soak it all up.  I threw a big fan in there overnight and let it air out like crazy.  That helped some, but we aren't all the way there.  While no one has complained about the smell in my car (I'm probably the only one who can detect it at this point) it's had me worried.-So, I got this.  And I threw it in the backseat, on the floor.  It seems to be helping. My car doesn't have a musty smell anymore.  I think I can smell this thing, which is equivalent to having a wool sweater lying in your back seat.  Maybe I am overly sensitive.  My nose is, I mean, not me.  Although maybe I AM a sensitive guy!!!  Anyhow this works well for small spaces.  I don't know if it would help a room, but for a car, it's nice to have.

You can't have enough drill bits.  I am always breaking the tiny thin ones.  And I always seem to need one of those weird "star" type bits or other weird ones.-This would make a perfect gift for someone who owns a home; It's not that expensive, and it's a complete set.  I don't use the included hand-held screwdriver; I use my cordless drill for most anything related to these bits.  It's indispensable!  The set has those weird bits I mentioned, bits for wood, masonry, etc.  What more do you need?-The case is great - it doesn't take up much room and can handle being thrown in amongst my other tools.  I've had similar cases break, but this one seems to hold up well.

Not much of a "playset".-I remember seeing this movie with my nieces and nephews, and I remember wondering how they were going to turn this into a set of toys.  The figures in the movie don't DO a whole lot, aside from staring at a screen and inserting "memories" into a projector.-And that's the main flaw here.  The projector is a joke.  It's surprisingly hard to get that thing to work.  And it's such a lackluster part of the whole set, that there's really not much point to any of it.  Quite frankly, it's a boring playset.  There are no shelves or doors or moving parts.  Sure, you can roll a memory ball down some ramps - my 2 year old niece likes that, but she likes any toy that moves!-It's just not fun.

Invicta watches are an anomaly.  Take this one, for example; the "List Price" is nearly a GRAND, but it costs only a hundred bucks.  I don't know who they think they are fooling.  When people see me wearing an Invicta watch, they like it, and ask me if it costs a lot.  I laugh and say no, it only LOOKS like it costs a lot - then I tell them about how this company labels every watch as I mentioned above.  I think it's a joke.  Or a bad marketing ploy.-This watch comes in this ludicrously large yellow box.  Seriously, it's a joke how big it is.  It's impressive, but also funny.  How much did that crazy box cost and why not put that into designing a watch that isn't so jokingly large!?!-The watch itself - is nice.  It's HUGE - the metal part is as wide as my wrist.  I workout, too - but this thing looks HUGE on my arm.  Maybe if you're like 6'5" and have arms like Popeye, this thing would fit.  It still looks good - it looks manly and tough.  The band is thick, too.  Thicker than any other strap watch you own.-It's an impressive piece, and I like it.  I just don't understand their price and crazy box.  It's a hundred dollar watch - not a Rolex.

I highly recommend these if you have boys.  Awesome stuff!

I have a few different light-blocking curtains throughout my home, but I needed another for a guest bedroom.  It gets a lot of light and it's killer in the morning with the sunrise waking you up.  So I installed this in there, and it's pretty darn good.-It's big - which means you can install this with plenty of room to cover the entire window and then some.  That's what I look for in these things - coverage.  Unless it's flush against the wall, light is still going to get through the sides.  Especially the top; it has big holes for a shower-curtain-sized curtain rod, so light still creeps in the top area.-But overall, it does a good job blocking light.  The two-toned design is nice, but I wonder how dated it might look in a few years.  The two-toned look was popular in the 80s if I recall correctly.-It's thick, it looks nice, it works well.  Go for it!

I use a lot of surge protectors.  Here's what I look for:- Ease of use- Protection- Price---Ease of use: This surge protector comes with a 90-degree angled plug.  That's nice, and it can save space, but if you need to use this on a top plug in a room, you'll block the lower outlet.  This happens a lot in rooms where a light switch controls only one of the plugs in an outlet.  If the bottom outlet controls a lamp used via the wall switch, you can't use this surge protector there, as it can only plug into the top outlet, blocking the lower one.The ability to plug in multiple devices to a power strip such as this is also a challenge.  Many devices today come with chunky plugs; plugging them in next to each other can be a challenge.  A power strip arranged in a singular line like this one makes that difficult, as many plugs will block other ones.  I often resort to using "mini" extenstion cords such as the Coleman Cable 6991 Power Strip Liberator.  They are 8-Inch Extension Cords, and come in a 3-Pack.  Search for them here - they're handy to keep around the house.The safety feature of the sliding outlet covers is a nice touch, but not one I need or look for in a surge protector.-Protection;  This outlet claims to protect up to 1,000 Joules.  I've never experienced a lightning bolt hitting my home, but I doubt this would be able to protect my devices from that.-The price - is OK.  I would expect to pay a few bucks less for a strip like this.  $12 seems a little high.-This is an "industrial" looking power strip.  Also, these products claim to offer monetary protection of your connected devices, but I'm sure to collect on that you need to jump through a million hoops.

I absolutely love green tea. I could live off of it. The organic matcha that Kenko Tea offers is one of the finest quality teas I have had.There are two types of green tea if you are not aware. Tea leaves which you can get in a tea bag or loose leaf. You steep these in water.Then there is matcha green tea which is a powder. You just mix with water or milk similar to hot chocolate. This makes a yummy cup of matcha.This Kenko brand is super smooth and mixes really well in hot or cold liquid. No clumps at all. Some other brands you will have a few clumps floating or when you get to the bottom of the cup there is alot left over. No this matcha. Blends smoothly and perfectly.What I love most about matcha powder is you can bake and blend it unlike leaf green tea. If you have ever spent $8.00 at starbucks on a matcha Frapacinno you will be saving loads of money. This is literally the same stuff. Just blend with ice, milk, and sweetner of your choice. I prefer to use sweetened almond milk.Enjoy to bake? I definitely do. Almost as much as my kids love to eat. I have made lots of chocolate matcha cupcakes with matcha icing. Also for my son matcha pancakes. The possibilities are endless.I received this item at free or discounted rate in exchange for my honest opinions.

I love love love this show! I would never ever want to be on it. But I enjoy watching these crazy people. The title of the show is literally a description of the show. Two people are naked..and afraid. They put two people buck naked. No shoes. No hair ties. Just one survival item each and a bag. Drop them off with a map in the middle of somewhere that sucks to be in and say hey get to this "x" in 21 days and we will pick you up. Have fun. They have to build a shelter, find water, make fire, and find food and not die for 21 days. Trust me they do not put you in the woods near a city. They put you in the middle of the keys surrounded by cayman gators. Or on a beach with 120 degree temps and nothing but salt water. It is crazy. So many people quit but a few stick it out. Great show to watch if you are into survival shows.

This silicone baking mat is amazing! I will no longer cook or bake without one. I am a serial cookie burner. and I am a mom of 3. My kids need good cookies. Sadly they do not get many. The kids are sold on the fact that I'm magic - they have yet to catch me tossing one of these into the fire.  If you want to make your home or camping fires a bit more fun, then you should pick up a brick of these.  Just throw it in, and it starts within seconds.  You fire changes from an orange and yellow to a wicked looking deep blue and green.  I wouldn't really call it a "rainbow" as it really just changes it to a blue/green color.  Now if you had a large enough fire and threw it into the side, then 1 side would be blue and green and the other would be orange and yellow.I usually do an all-out Halloween setup and this year I'm planning on having 2 fire pits - one normal and one blue and green.  The neighbor kids should get a kick out of it.How long it lasts depends upon if you have a small or raging fire - ours lasted about 15 minutes or so before I felt I had to sneak another one in.I bought a brick of 25, and will order the 50 count next.BUY THESE - you won't be disappointed - they are fun.  4 1/2 stars, so I opted for 5.PROS:  Fun, cheap way to add some additional spice to family firesCONS:  Not the "rainbow" I was thinking (no red, purple), but it's still *really* cool.NEUTRALS:  Not the same display packaging as pictured just so you know - what you get is a bunch of the small packets (as pictured) wrapped up in some stretch wrap as a brick.  I'm happy with that as it's less packaging, but some might be disappointed if they wanted the display package.I'll add some pictures soon.

I'm still not sold, as I'm not sure if I have a defective unit or this is how they just are, but it seems that I get dropped more than when directly connected to the router.  It seems like it puts out a VERY loud signal because my laptop prefers connecting to it over the router, even when I'm closer to the router sometimes.  They were a cinch to setup and looks good on the wall.  Hopefully this item won't let me down.  I'll raise my score once I get the problems figured out.##### Updated 13 Sept 2015 #####I'm going to leave this as a 3, but I might not use these anymore.  I'm almost sold on the fact that these are causing some of my network problems.  Once I turned off the SSID matching and renamed the network to something else, most of our issues (networks drops) went away.  It seems like it's happening more on our Macs than our PCs.  Pulling them out of the plug for a few seconds and then back in sometimes temporarily fixed it, but I'm not sure if it was helping or just allowing my Mac to connect to a different device with the same network name.If I could still return these, I would swap them for another pair of the same model and see if the problem persists.  But since I can't, I'll just buy a different brand and hope it works better.

Love it - this is our 2nd DrinkWell.  If you don't have one yet, why not?  Cat appears much happier and healthier from drinking more water. How slow can a stinking cat actually drink?  After getting this, he can drink and play in the water all he wants. The ONLY thing I don't like about it, is that the floor is sometimes wet around it because he plays in the waterfall stream, and that there are always little bits of kitty litter in the bottom of the water that come from his paws while he's playing.  Apparently he must always drink after taking care of business.

I bought these originally to cut off the iron-holder off the end of my wife's ironing board.  The cutters that came with my Dremmel blew into pieces when I tried to use them on this heavier metal.  So I decided to buy a real cutting wheel.I quickly got it installed onto my Dremmel and started it up - it made quick work of the metal brackets in question.  I also used it to smooth down the sharp edges left so that my wife would not cut her fingers opening/closing the ironing board.  When it was all said and done, it took my about 5 minutes of grinding time, and when I compared the used wheel to a new wheel, I had utilized about 10-15% of the wheel.  I didn't think I would use that much, and I'm not sure how far you can go down before the wheel is useless, but in total original size, it used about that much.What was also interesting is that the metal did not seem as hot to the touch as it was when I was trying the other cutting wheels.  Most likely because the cut was quicker and didn't have enough time to build up more heat.Pros:  Cut like a pro, easy to install.Cons:  I felt that the price was quite high for as much cutting as I think they will do.  If it included 1 or 2 more, it would be more inline.  Hence, -1 star.

I was really worried to order a "cheaper" product, but another review here talked me into it, so I took the chance.I was extremely happy when my order came and I pulled this item out of the box of everything else I ordered.  It feels like it is built very solid, and felt good in my hand (important).  This hammer was actually for my 10 year old, so I was worried about getting him something too cheap and ruining his experience.  We took it up into the mountains this last weekend, and we both took turns with it.  I'm a big guy, and it took the punishment like a man.  While it's not the Cadillac of rock hammers, I couldn't be more happy with this item - especially regarding price.Pros:  Great product for the money.  Seems solid.Cons:  Maybe a slightly better material for the grip would be nice.I will update this review if it ever breaks or has other issues.UPDATED ON 16-JAN-2014=================Well we've been beating the heck out of this hammer now since August, and I'm happy to report back that it's still as good as the day we bought it (minus the visual wear and tear).  It's stood up to every rock and hard soil we've thrown at it.  Still very happy with it and recommend it.  It also makes quick work of snow/ice pack when digging out a snow cave -- yipppee!

My missionary asked for some kind of approved music other than "MoTab" and I found him this.  So far he LOVES it.  I did too, as I did not want to send it to him after I received it.  :(Love it, recommend it.  Please do more.

-Dell V525W Printer Cartridges-I was originally worried about this product when the first thing I got was an email trying to get me to cancel my order because they were out of stock.  I was a little ticked off because I ordered it specifically because it said it WAS in stock.  I was in urgent need of blank ink.I had asked if they could just exchange it for any other compatible SKU they had - I didn't care as long as it had black ink.  But they didn't really have any other options for me over email, because they are apparently not allowed to change the order after it's been placed.  Not sure why they couldn't ship out something similar and then just tell Amazon the order was fulfilled, but who knows the rules.... They also had no idea of when their order would arrive.Anyway, I decided to not cancel the order and just waited (mainly because I was too busy/lazy to research another brand at the moment).  Days later, I got an email saying it had shipped.  Woohoo!  In a few more days, I received the package.It was VERY well packaged and protected, and the quality of the shipped product was way better than I had expected.  It snapped right into the printer, but took 2 tries to get the computer to not complain about it not being aligned properly.  No big deal, it was probably my fault.  Once it was aligned, it worked like a charm.  After a deep cleaning, the printout looked identical to the one I made with the last OEM cartridge.The only negative about the product itself is that there is a plastic protective clip on each cartridge.  When I removed it, a bit of black ink splattered out onto my shirt.  Not sure if I was squeezing the cartridge too tight or not when I was was removing the clip, but it almost looked like it had already leaked out and was sitting in the clip before I removed it.  No big deal - nothing lost.Pros:  Excellent protective packaging.  Once it shipped, it got here quick.  Cartridge seems solid - not flimsy.  Seems like a quality product so far.Cons:  Don't tell me something is in stock when it's not - that makes angry customers.  Slight ink spillage when removing protective clip.Suggestion to seller:  Work with your supplier to create eco-friendly packaging.  I don't need the nice display packaging/boxes around each cartridge.  It increases costs, kills trees, increases shipping costs, etc.  The cartridge itself in inside a thick and protective plastic sleeve - I would think that would suffice.  Just my opinion.Overall, I am very happy with the product.  I gave it a 5 star because of the product.  If I included in the backorder BS, I would have dropped a star or 2.I will also try to report back when the ink runs out, and I'll tell you how many "real world" pages I got from it.  (Just black right now)

I shopped around quite a bit for a new after-market charging cable, worried because so many people were complaining about ends breaking off, or being too loose, too long, etc.  I took the chance on this product and I am very happy with it.  The cable adapter fit perfectly, had no issues, and even withstood the wrath of a 10 year old yanking it out, tripping over it etc, and after all this time it's still rock solid for me.  I will definitely be buying another one of these if it's ever needed.Another pro is that is really long, unlike the barbie-sized-cable that came with the device originally.  This allows me to charge it and actually use it without sitting on the floor next to the outlet.When we use it on the road, it plugs into our car converter in the front of the car, and our 10 year old can use the tablet in the back seat very comfortably.I would recommend this product - I think it's a good replacement, especially for the cost.
