Almost all others may find this a rare treat.Oh and based on the places I've personally been such as the great Library in Trinity College in Dublin and New Grange by the Hillof Tara, Stephen Cline nails these with superb descriptions that take us there.  Applause,to the  sailor, singer, author.

With a quack-quack here and a quack-quack there, these Hallow'een ducklings would make an opulent bath-tub flotilla for one super-lucky person or perfect gifties.  Among their five-star qualities are--duckling size: these are slightly bigger than 2 inches x 2 inches x 2 inches, not micro-mini--the soft feel, a nice texture smooth and with no scratchy edges--squeezable to the max!  I have tried every one and they ALL squeeze good as a rubber-duckling should--clever designs!  who would have thought so many different designs could be made from a duck shape & a halloween theme.  The package includes a black cat, a skeleton, a Dracula, a pumpkin, an orange google-eyed duckling, and a red lil devil duckie (I do not know if all packages have these designs but they are cute, cute, cute)  NOTE: two of each design, not 12 different designs--they quack!  well, sorta---not a strident QUACK more ducklingANY NEGATIVES? Not really but I do have an alert. I can't tell ifthe designs are molded in or painted on.  Or a mix,  but in general, I don't think these are chew-toys or for teething. Best I think for three years and older.  The package I got were good quality with no misalignments or smearsFor the price, a very good value and a nice alternative to candy

Gentlemen and Ladies, step right up to an entertaining, informative, and useful guide to pleasures & treasures in the fine state of Nevada, where houses devoted to pleasuring are legal, regulated to help ensure health and safety, and where, according to author , J. R. Schwartz, "the ladies possess all the charms necessary to please."The Guide is organized geographically: Reno area (six entries), Fallon (two entries), Winnemucca (five locations), Battle Mountain (two) Elko (six entries), Highway 93 (three), Las Vegas area (three), and Highway 95 (five entries).  A easily readable map of the state is provided for those perhaps planning a roadtrip, and for each entry, there is a well-drawn, clear, large print map.As a researcher, I find much to admire about J. S. Schwartz's style.  True, Schwartz does not tells us (unfortunately)  how the entries were located (nominated? selected) and what percent of potentially eligible houses were omitted and why.  However. for those reported, his modus operandi was hands on, not word of mouth.  He made time to visit each pleasure palace personally, interview the owners or managers, and then interview the ladies.  How many ladies and how they were selected are unclear but his criteria are splendidly explicit:Schwarz was looking for variables such attitude (playfulness, free-spiritedness), atmosphere (style such as Western, Oriental, Versailles, sense of freshness), amenities such as the Menu of pleasures available, and practicalities (parlour including bar or mostly party-time).  We learn of size (some are over 100 party rooms), number of lovely ladies usually on duty, and their tours of duty.All the ladies met were described as stylish dressed, made-up, and luscious as well as skilled in whatever the party-goer hopes for that is acceptable to the lady (who is an independent contractor).  Some of these Menu items sound delightful and some, such as the "Wind, Rain, and Lava" struck me as "yecch," but might be a specialized choice for my fellow citizens.  The book includes an essay on the history of pros*tit*ution, a several page glossary, and a conclusion.Any Alerts:  Businesses in almost every field go in and out of operation.  These pleasure businesses, so says the book, are not permitted to advertise in detail or with much clearness.  The visitors should call ahead or perhaps check with local knowledge to avoid disappointments.Overall, readers interested in local color may find "The Official Guide" educational and entertaining.  I sure did.  I found this at a library book sale, filed under "Books for Children" along with stories of kitties, puppies, and such.  Most enlightening 25 cents I've spent in while!  Enjoy, enjoy!

Back up for  your back with these excellent firm wedge pillows!  I am using my bed for sleeping by night and a sofa for sitting by day.  I wanted wedges that were--firm, as firm as if there was a real sofa back--can handle some smaller & some larger backs with reliable support and no crumbling--light enough to take off at night without wrassling elephants--enough traction to hold covers in place when these are not individual zippered wedge covers--little or no chemical smells--affordableThis fit the list.  They are very affordable compared to anything I can find locally.  They are exceptionally firm and give my back plenty of support.  I've added three softer pillows for cushiness and color in front of the bolsters, which work fine.  They are light enough to handle easily.  And they have excellent traction for holding a bedspread in place.  I am sorta cheap Charlie and don't want to spend $45-$50 per bolster for a separate pillow cover.  Buyers who can sew could probably find some great material and make their own covers,  I'll applaud and envy them!Any Alerts?  They arrive at warp speed and well packaged.  Each was covered with a large plastic pillow case thingie which kept them snowy white.  At first, yes, these was a chemical odor.  I unwrapped them, aired them out on the porch for several days, and, a week or so later, no detectable chemical aroma.  Buyers who are highly sensitive should be aware of the need for airing.  Everything else was fine.  They are sized as advertised.  Two bolsters will make a sofa back for a twin size bed.  One bolster would fill in the width if wanted.Highly recommended if firm is wanted.

This storage system has six sturdy containers for silver and jewels ranging from the diamond ring size to a set of sterling silver for ten people, five pieces per setting.  It holds a LOT---actually, considerably more precious goodies than I own.The material is heavy, the interiors are smooth & unlikely to (shudder) scratch or mar, and I particularly like the closure systems.  I'd polished the sterling like a Downton Abbey butler & want it to stay bright, untarnished, clean.  The closure for this piece involves double-folded Velcro, grippy not flimsy.  I felt when it was wrapped as if little or no tarnishing air would get into this Gringott's special and that it would no come undone.The closures for the other pieces involved Velcro, zips, and strong ribbons.  For each piece I used, I gave it the pull, tugs, and flip tests.  All of them passes.Buyer Alerts?  If you need more large piece holders, the one biggest holder may not be enough for many good size serving pieces plus your place settings.  For jewelery of sterling, gold, platinum or other precious metals, the assortment of holders could be plenty for most of us.  That is, it is more for anti-tarnish jewelery than flatware or bigger silver serving trays, bowls, and such.  HOWEVER, the anti-tarnish features look as if they will keep your baubles blinging and your glitter glittering.Overall, a good deal for the price and I am very pleased----and now have extras if there's any jewels being sent from the Tower of London for my use.  Could work perfectly for buyers looking for a good assortment of adaptable and attractive storage!

Report from a Satisfied BuyerThe Laundry Bag arrived at warp speed, almost before I bought it.  The material is light, a plus for me because I wanted something I could haul around, loaded, not a canvas mail sack.  The drawstring channel is functional, though not the embroidery for royalty.  The seams are sturdy, not likely to ravel.  And the color I got was a cheerful blue, which I hoped for.All this for a much lower price than I could find locally!Any Buyer Alerts:  30 x 40 inches is big enough for a sleeping bag.  Almost 3 feet wide x 4 feet tall.  This is exactly what I needed so I am pleased---no skimping on seams, fabric, or size!  Buyers should be aware this is LARGE, and not expect a medium or small size laundry bag.  This one holds two sheets, two pillowcases, two bath towels, three hand towels, and a week's laundry for me including jeans and sweats.Highly recommended for buyers wanting a big beautiful laundry friend.

Bach's "The Well-tempered Clavier" offers a balanced array of musical challenges to the`novice player.  Even for the relative beginner. the results can sound good. "Recipes from my Russian Grandmother's Kitchen" is like that, Russian cooking-wise.As a novice, I was looking for--introductory stories of Russian cuisine, eating habits, and ingredients to help understand the context of the recipes--recipes balanced to reflect this tradition--ingredients generally available in the U.S.--step x step directions with some time-saving choices--informative illustrationsThis hard-cover book, published in 2014, delivers the goods nicely indeed--the discussion of the usual Russian dinner involving a robust soup, a main dish, and dessert is reflected in the contents which begin with nine hearty soups, go on to fish and meat dishes, and conclude with ravishing desserts. As stated on the cover, 60 recipes in all--the importance of an hospitable table of zakuski (hearty appetizers) and of religious holidays such as Easter are reflected in a mouth-watering section on appetizers and in preparation of traditional dishes such as the Paschal cake--the excellent photographs by Jon Whitaker make step-by-step preparation easy to follow and all the ingredients listed are available even in the small town where I live;  some time-saving approaches are offered including use of already prepared/purchased puff pastryA bright star in the accuracy of the title.  These ARE grandmother's cooking in recipes chosen, in preparation, and in the more subtle aspects such as using tableware and china from a granny's kitchen.  Catherine the Great's recipes, china, or squadron of cooks this is not,nor is it a "Mastering the art of Russian cooking" tome.  Traditional granny is what I was looking for, and that is what the book delivers.Among the recipes I particularly like are Georgian Meat Soup, Blini, Fish with Mushroom & Dill Sauce, and Sauerkraut Stew with Prunes.  There are a LOT of recipes using sauerkraut/cabbage, preserved cucumbers (who knew?) and sour cream (smetana), ingredients available without high cost and throughout the year in the Russian climate.ANY ALERTS?  A big omission (to me) was not a single recipe for the black or dark rye breads, despite the text emphasis on how this bread is essential to every meal.  If it is that important, how about a recipe or two?  Also, this is a slender book with fewer recipes than some: a sampler of general Granny cooking,not more regional or comprehensive.  Further. as a newer book, expect to pay a new book price as used copies for a few pennies aren;t yet available.Overall, however, a delight for eye and mouth and belly, that a beginner in Russian cooking can achieve!  Thank you, author and production team!

Tried them, love them, and just ordered another set!WHAT I LIKED:-- if real estate is location, location, location, then underpants may be about fit, fit, fit.  The waist band is wide enough to stay put but leaves no garroted red marks.  The silky yet slightly elastic (5% spandex) material fit butt and hip as if these were bespoke.  The elastic leg bands give very high opens without any gaps.  There's a firming effect that is totally comfortable and no muffin tops.  A perfect fit in size 5 for me, can wear all day in blissful comfort without thinking about them.--cute: nice colors, specially the pink like an apple-blossom.  Each waist band has a contrasting color stripe.  A little pizzazz that adds to the waistband width & comfort.--durability.  I wash these by machine but without any hooks to catch or tear. They wash beautifully and can be put in the drier or hung up to air dry.  I am careful with these as I would be with any good lingerie and they are keeping their color, the lustrousness of the fabric, and their shape over several months of washings.--crotch design.  These are unique, in my experience, at having a different textured but smooth, silky crotch which is woven in through the front to the back where there is a strong double seam.  The coverage is excellent from the mons to the glutes without any tell-tale lines or bulk.  Adds to comfort and security, at no loss of well, cuteness.--price: affordability at Amazon prices was amazing, about $3 for each panty.  These would be more than twice the price locally where I live. GREAT value!ANY ALERTS?  Some buyers may want all black or all white or other, brighter colors.  The navy, black, tan, pink, ivory, white are what this set comes in.  The colors work for me but every now & then, it would be fun to have fuschia or turquoise or bright yellow.  Also the fabric while beautiful is without ribbons, lace, ruffles.  Again, every now and then, nothing wrong with a little lacy nothing and these are not fancy!OVERALL, if buyers want a WONDERFUL fit, soft & luxe material, easy care and easy price in usable colors---this set may it a good, better, best buy!

Fun bling!  I wanted a big sparkling notice-my-ankle bracelet. Ideally, I was looking for affordable, fits large & smaller ankles, and with some pizzazz.THIS HAS IT ALL!--sparkling rhinestones all around--nicely proportioned heart, not too large for my ankle--could hardly believe the Amazon price which was less than $5--ingenious design fits 8" ankles to 11" ankles (as measured) by a lobster-claw & links arrangement.  Adjust it yourself to your comfortable size and either clip off the extra links or leave the remaining chain as extra dangleVery comfortable to wear thanks to the ingenious design, not at all heavy but wow-worthy.  GREAT for birthdays, engagement, wedding favors, sweet 16 to sweet 96 parties---bachelor as well as bachelorette gifties: this is a fun piece.  For me, it is sturdy enough to wear to the beach, around the house, parties.  Definitely says, "SEXY!"ANY ALERTS?  I treat this Sexy Lady Heart ankle bracelet as I would one costing many times as much, fitting it with care initially keeping it in its own envelope to avoid tangles, and kitty can not consider the sparkles as a toy! Buyers should be aware this is made and shipped from China.  Mine arrived within two weeks with excellent packaging.  But returning would not be cost-effective, so buyers may want to be extra-sure they like a sparkly heart on their ankle before ordering.  A plus is that I can give it to petite ankled friends or plus size friends, and know it will fit.

Presentation box fit for Her Majesty's diamonds; inside a wee wisp of alternate balls and links.YES:  There's much to make me reach for the phone to order this again, such as--10" is a below the ankle-bone fit for this size 8 woman; no tightness here!  Comfy, not slipping off though. I measured the length & it is exactly 10" including clasp. The smaller size, 9",would be an above the ankle-bone fit without tightness--clasp is lobster-claw style, often considered most secure--clasp is well-designed and easy to use with little danger to finger-nails or squintingPLUS--there are two boxes.  The outer box is strongly made & covered with handsome quality black material-like paper, with a flap to glide out the velvet-like inner box.  That is, one whole long side folds neatly & elegantly down, to reveal the gorgeous inner box--the inner box is crafted of black velvet or velvet-like suede. A blue satin tab lifts up the hinged top.  I expected trumpets it was sooooo Tiffany-gorgeous. Inside two hinged tabs hold the bracelet in place.  I have seen a lot of jewelery box presentations but this one is almost worthy of the purchase price by itselfHOWEVER-- the bracelet feels light to me, feather light almost--a sparkle now & then but not really light-catchinng--rhodium may be a miracle metal that is stronger than iron and I am not asking for ankle chains still I expected Italian rhodium & rose-gold plated links would feel less gossamer. I'd recently ordered a silver & garnet stone (real) ring from Amazon  at about the same price & it has a wonderful feel of quality Irish silver. More substance in the bracelet's feel, and I would have given it 4 or 5 stars.  For a heavy gold ankle bracelet however $200 to $300 might be just the starting price, based on a well-known big box store check.Thus, some buyers may be looking for an ultra- light-weight, elegant style at a low price and this might be perfect for them.  Other buyers might prefer something like a diamond-cut twist chain for more sparkle and more substance. and be willing to pay more or go to all silver.  Both may fall in love, love, love with the presentation box which I could use for the right piece on the right gifting occasion.  Or maybe even keep for myself to feel like royalty.

Back in the 1940s, he authored "Do It Yourself: The Happiest How-to-Do-It Book:  make your own legally tax-free at a fraction of the cost recipes for all kinds of wine!"  When he got a windfall in 1966, he spent it on a barge towed off the Atlantic coast, half his own country (New Atlantis) and half given to the US, the idea being to raise money for oceanographic research by selling stamps.  When author and racounteur Ray Pace knew him, he was nearing his end  from Type II Diabetes. but would still greet women as "My Lady" and the family dog as "Ho, Noble Hound."He was Leicester (pronounced "Lester") Hemingway, the only brother among four sisters who together with 17 years older big brother 'Ernest formed the family of Dr. and Mrs Clarence Hemingway.  Pace met him in Florida, where the two tried this, that, and the other thing to put together a successful sports magazine or radio station."Hemingway, Memories of Les" was published in 2012 about 30 years after Les died in 1982.  It is 91 pages, large type, double-spaced, wide margins, probably about 30 pages of usual margins and type size.  It doesn't matter.  The book is like sitting down with a friendly story-teller who shares his own experiences during those ten years  and how they intersected with Les.  Pace's recollections include some stories from Les's memories and his constant encouragement to go ahead and try whatever Ray had in mind.  A more encouraging man than Les may never lived and the affection that prompted these memoirs is clear.This is Pace's effort to recognize a Hemingway forever over-shadowed by his brother Ernest's Nobel Prize, his sheer output, his life style, and his authorship of some books of heroic stature likely to be long-lived.  Pace's memoir can be thought of as fascinating reading in itself yet also as a worthy contribution toward a future full-length biography of Les.There is space for such a biography.  Apart from Pace's engaging memoir, there seems to be only one other Les-focused book, by Les's daughter, Hilary, based on tapes of Les's recollections of sports stories and adventures he later shared with Ernest. I  also found through the 'Net some fascinating summaries of the Hemingways including Les based on 43 cubic feet of family archives. His mother was an opera-level musician before her marriage and Les was a notable singer who, suggests the archive summarist,could have been successful indeed if voice had been his choice.Until that book comes along, however, readers can enjoy well-told tales of a time (1950s-1960s), a place (southern Florida) and a friendship between a fella named Hemingway and a fella named Pace.Any Reader Alerts?  None other than already mentioned that this is a  memoir, without footnotes or references,  covering about ten years of Les Hemingway's life.  Although structured conversationally rather as stories and thoughts came along, like Mark Twain's Autobiography, and self-published, Ray Pace is a skilled writer with a gift of dialog so the reading is lively, fresh, and engaging.

One, two, three, four----and then there are ten little girl mermaids, with glittering tails frolicking in the turquoise-blue waters of Hawai'i!Follow the 24 full-color, full page watercolor pictures by artist-writer Gill McBarnet number by number up to ten mermaids. On each bright page are the matching number of sparkling scallop shells and other sea creatures such as bright red star-fish, elegant Moorish Idol fish trailing their ballerina fins, conch shells, crabs, and turtles.  Each set of pages has a couplet, leading the reader on, such as"Two Rainbow mermaids see the fishes flee; up pops another one and then there are Three.""The Rainbow Mermaids of Hawaii" is fun to read, designed by a master teacher.  So many parts fit smoothly together.  There are seven easily distinguished colors of a rainbow: red, orange, yellow, green, blue, indigo, and violet that appear on every page and whose colors  shine in each mermaid's tail.  The frequent rainbows are among Hawaii's natural treasures.  The green sea turtles (honu) nest and are protected here.  Humpback whales come to play all winter, and our waters abound in bright-colored reef fish.I particularly like that these little girls are not Barbies. No coconut or sea shell bras or 16" waists, but raindow sleeveless tank-top blouses & glittering raindow tails.  They vary in size from a darling baby-mermaid (or merman) to perhaps 10 years old or so. They are graceful, supple, adorable but only nature has brought the long, wavy hair, bright brown eyes, and sun-kissed skin.  The mermaids are Hawaiian and harmonious with their ocean and islands.McBarnet weaves these into her lovely watercolors, and on the back covers, offers accurate information on rainbows to enhance the readers' knowledge as their own little mermaids ask questions.  AND, best of all, the story ends with a Birthday Celebration, including ten bright candles on the cake!Any Reader Alerts?  Readers should be aware this story is about mermaids. I believe, however, the fish, the ocean, the colors, and the counting are likely to bring pleasure to little boys and girls alike.  This could be a perfect gift for families heading to Hawaii or as a gift from Hawaii, along with Gill Barnett's many other Hawaii related stories such as her "Gecko Hide-and-Seek." and the delightful "Good Night, Gecko."  Also, McBarnet is a self-taught artist. Her pictures have a distinctive style, particularly lovely in color and composition, rather than  an Arthur Rackham precision, that fit the Hawaiian theme nicely.This charming 7 l/2" x 10" hard-cover book is going to a three-year old who adores mermaids and enthusiastically is learning to count.  She can go by memory to 24 but is less successful in (1) recognizing the printed numbers and (2) applying the numbers to enumerating objects.  This Gill McBarnet book could help her and many others enjoy counting & arithmetic.  It's a happy book!

When a kiddo asks over and over to wear your watch at a beach picnic, it may be time to get one for her.  So, she's about three.  I wanted something--purple--colorful so easy to find & establish ownership if dropped--big distinctive numerals--large hands with clear differences between the hour and minute indicators--sized small enough for 3 year old but strap enough to expand to about a 7 year old wrist--plastic and environmentally friendly if lost--cheap--this is a kiddo after all--actually worksI looked through every Amazon listing for children's watches, read all the reviews, and this one stood out as a best match to what I wanted.  It arrives with warp speed, well-packaged, and was even better than I expected on all my criteria.Two aspects get special applause:1.  The strap is great, flexible not stiff, and ample room for expansion but could easily be cut to a smaller length if wanted.The material is sturdy enough that the holes are not likely to tear under use, too.  However, if a replacement band is needed, the design has the spring-loaded bars that permit this, rather than being forever attached to the watch case.2. Cuteness!  The butterflies are multi-colored yellow, red, greens, blues, pinks. Perfect size in proportion to the band, and will coordinate with the outfits of the day.ANY ALERTS?  Purchasers should be aware the days of ticking watches may be over; this one does NOT go tick-tock which was a slight disappointment to a girl who adores "Peter Pan" including the ticking crocodile.  Also, the watch is not sold as water-proof, shock-resistant, and will need to be take off before baths, showers, or swims.  It is a play-time watch not in any way suitable for scuba.  With reasonable care, however, it should last well & at the Amazon price, it is an excellent value.--light

Love  it!  Love it! Love it!  I usually don't wear rings. Actually I have given most of mine away to the next generation.  A year or so ago, I thought it might be nice if I could find a ring that--had a real gem, not glass--was medium size, not flashy nor too small to see--where the setting was graceful & attractive, maybe something a bit artistic and original--very extremely affordable, so I wouldn't clutch if it was "misplaced"I looked around in jewellery sales at quality stores, at artisan markets & craft fairs, and when I travelled, but nothing said "Buy me."This ring came up as an Amazon Deal, and the picture suggested this was it, while the price said, "What value for a .55 carat of real, undyed, natural red garnet."The ring is EVERYTHING I wanted. The color is as shown, the clear red of a quality natural garnet, almost like a ruby or if was a wine, a pinor noir maybe.  The size is perfect, big enough to be noticeable but not gaudy.  And the silver setting is like a fine, a very fine, Irish silver design.  A heart is worked into the swirl on either side, subtly, and the fit is excellent. The workmanship is first-rate, everything smooth, solid, made to last.This would be a lovely gift for almost any age and any stage, and would make a special occasion even more memorable.  A plus is the attractive box, beautifully fitted blue paper with a lovely white ribbon & small ribbon rose; inside a velvet like material into which the ring slips elegantly. Awesome bonus!  Also, the garnet & silver work together well as colors, like a ring for Galadriel.ANY BUYER ALERTS?  The sizing seems to be standard so no need to get larger or smaller than usual.  The price I got (less than $30 including shipping) may not be available, so if you see this & want it, probably best to get it when a good price shows up.Highly recommended with six stars if I could, all garnet

Kevin fell on a wine glass, cut his face considerably, and my granddaughter's friends didn't know where the carotid artery was located (or other pressure points).  I bought "Cardiovascular Physiology" thinking it would be useful reading for the friends.  At the used book price, it was very affordable.This is fascinating reading, an indepth view of the cardiovascular system and how it works, written for a medical text.  The illustrations include diagrams as well as Leonardo-like drawings.  The index is gloriously detailed.  The writing is splendidly clear, and the topic is as good as "War and Peace" if you are interested in how our bodies work and enjoy technical depth.  It is clearly intended as a medical text, marketed as such, and the author's years of teaching experience show in the organization, exposition, use of analogies, and coverage.  The emphasis is more on the heart than the cardiovascular system as a whole or in relation to other systems.However, as an aid to first aid, it isn't.  My expectation was inappropriate for sure. The book is not intended for such a use and is not likely to be appropriately or quickly extrapolated.READER ALERTS:  I am not an M.D., although I do have a Ph.D. in physiology, so my comments should be not be taken as a physician's or nurse's observations.

At least five recent & well-regarded translations of that traveller's tale by Messer Marco Polo & ghost writer Rusticello are now available, making accessible what the imprisoned older man remembered of his youthful adventures in the lands of Kublai Khan. Even before these tales were written down, however, their veracity was questioned, their honesty derided, and the sanity of the narrator suspected.  On one point only was agreement strong: the rubies, diamonds, pearls, sapphires and emeralds sewn in the shabby cloaks Marco, his father Niccolo,and his uncle wore on their return to Venice in 1296.So, asked John Man, what does current scholarship say about these questions?  "Marco Polo: The Journey that Changed the World" gives Man's answers in 15 chapters.  The chapters are organized somewhat linearly in that they include Kublai's empire from Polo's arrival to the Khan's death and  organized somewhat opportunistically in chapters such as Xanadu and Marco's relationships with  women. The overall conclusions are that some of Polo's narrative is consistent with what evidence is available, such as the likelihood Marco actually did spend many years in Kublai's China, the existence of a huge ruc-like bird, and that Xanadu probably was shaped like a stately pleasure dome. along the lines of the Mongolian ger.  Some is also certainly not true and a lot is indeterminable.  What to me makes this book worthy reading is the sorting out of the details and specifics like the number of bridges in Kublai's capitol city and claims Marco made of Kublai's innovations in legal, social, and governmental areas, including that wonder, printed money.Man's modus operandi makes this a traveller's tale about a traveller's tale.  He set out to follow Polo's path, the roads taken, Afghanistan passes threaded, cities and citadels visited, what could still be seen of what Marco said he saw..  These travels, with digressions of Man's wanderings, make up about 40% of the evidence.  The rest is extrapolation of what is possible such as the extended discussion of how to construct Xanadu the pleasure dome, pole by pole (about 30%) and what today's best scholars conclude. I particularly liked how Man handled negative evidence: instances of when Polo did NOT write about a major historical event such as Japan's defeat of Kublai's invasion and apparent lack of Polo's name in historical records such as the governorship of Yangzhou. Some scholars argue the silence indicates Polo wasn't there, but Man refutes this energetically.How believable is Man himself?  Some readers may find this approach to historical analysis vivid, convincing,and appropriate.  Others may wish Man found himself less fascinating & Polo more fascinating. In a few places, such as how literally Ghengis and Kublai Khan took a number such as 10,000, Man plumps for a "large number" interpretation where other recent analysis of the military organization numbers suggests 10,000 meant 10,000, an issue relevant to the size of the armies, herds of white horses, and cities.  Not a deal-breaker but a reminder that while Man has worked heroically at achieving the most believable answers, 700 years bring mists of time not easily dispelled even by many miles, many months, and many millions of words.This is a full book whose almost 400 pages include references, a useful index (thank you, thank you, author & publisher), about 20 good color pictures, and a map.of the roads between Xanadu and Beijing.  More maps would have been welcomed, however.The title?  The world is so interconnected that many events (the spice trade, Columbus reaching the Americas. the discovery of De Natura Rerum, and so on and on and on) have been claimed by various authors as the progenitor of today.  No need to hold Man's last chapter to an excruciating standard of causality; maybe think of Polo's travels as "among the influences" on our world.  "Marco Polo" is a fine read by an experienced writer and traveller..

Awwwww! So young Chick  says,  "I hatched on the beach, dude. The ocean's my turf.  I swim like a duck. Will you teach me to surf?"  Her waaaaay cool Dad gets her a new pink board, gives her the basics, and she's off.  To a butt-bouncing, teeth-jarring wipe-out.  Babe, we can FEEL that one and the marvelously expressive drawings make clear a time-out to fill up again on courage is needed.  What happens next makes for a super chick-dad story, for encouraging perseverance, and let's hear it for the creativity of the new wave of surfers.This is a neat mixture of authentic (I live in Kona near Banyan's & can vouch for those waves, board shorts & expressions) and go for it imagination by author Dempsey & illustrator Cole.  Accompanying the worthy story are colorful full-page illustrations, clever verse, and enough action to hold attention from about 3 to 6 years old chicks & dudes..A little backstory: about 30 years ago, there were not too many surfer chicks, particularly among the top competitors.  Now, go for it, gals and guys!Buyer Alert? The book is a big, glossy-paper 10" x10" super-size square, not a board book in the just-hatched chicks sense.  Also, Dad to me looks more like a mighty well-fed hen than a rooster (no comb,hen-like tail feathers rather than a noble cock tail) although most children probably won't notice.  Not a deal-breaker for me.  A 1 year old who has already been on the board and her ripped surfer-dude Dad are getting this for Father's Day and I feel sure they are gonna LOVE it.

There IS a lot to like about "The German Cookbook," (hard-cover, 1965 edition).  For example--Sheraton has the eye of a travel writer as well as a cookbook writer/compiler, and she excels in describing the many regions of Germany, honoring the characteristic foods of each--she presents 16 topics in separate chapters, such as appetizers, soups, soup garnishes and dumplings, egg dishes and cheese, fish, meat, game and game birds, sausages (perhaps the most informative, exciting chapter), potato, noodle, and rice dishes, and prosit!--the recipes while assuming a medium level of skills are easy to follow--and I liked, personally, that this was all text and no pictures, in the style of Irma Rombauer's glorious "The Joy of Cooking."--this used, older edition was wonderfully inexpensive, less than $1BUT--in no way can this be called a "comprehensive guide to mastering authentic German cooking."  For one horrifying example, there is NOTHING on bread.  Sheraton broke my heart when she indicates that bread is so central to German food, it needs a book of its own and she isn't going to offer any recipes (p. 411)--nor is it "comprehensive" even for 1965, barely touching, for instance, on the glorious varieties of red cabbage preparations and sauerkraut recipes and with only three recipes for noodles, one of which is for spaghetti--how "authentic" is Sheraton?  Laudably, she tells us for a year, she ate at many German restaurants in the U.S., and got their recipes.  Then she visited Germany and ate at a lot of German restaurants and got their recipes.  She states that she tried them in her kitchen which if done completely would have included some heroic efforts such as the calf head preparation.--not for beginners but for cooks who know their way around the kitchen's variety of preparation methods, have a good hand for sauces, and can address foods in their natural states---or as Sheraton indicates, are near to good delicatessens, butchers, fish-mongers, confectioners & bakersOverall, "The German Cookbook" may be primarily of historical interest although in chapters such as "Sausage" Sheraton's among the best of the wurste.  . Perhaps more recent editions are better.  In the meantime, readers seeking a more comprehensive and current German cookbook will find several available, all of which (so far as I know) include some breads.

I am down-sizing to a senior living apartment.  Very nice indeed it is but I needed a flatware set that-- was very affordable but not flimsy--attractive to make me happy when I used it--wouldn't break my heart if pieces went missing--has enough pieces so I could entertain family & guests--if I dropped a piece, wouldn't cling, ring, ding, or breakThis beautiful set for six exceeds my requirements and expectations.  The design has flair in the pearlized ivory handles with the touch of shiny "silver".  It does not look like left-overs from a prison cutlery yard-sale, overly simple.  There's a playfulness that makes me happy!  The edges of the fork, spoons, and knife are smooth and well-polished, except where it should be sharp in the corrugations of the knife blade.  The blade has done fine with chicken, steak, and fish.  And for the low Amazon price for a service for six?  I'm totally delighted!Any buyer alerts?  First, this set is for eating, not supplementary kitchenware.  The fork and knife are plenty strong for eating but would probably not stand up for cutting a big loaf of very crusty bread, lifting a big pot roast, and carving up raw carrots.  Second, the handles are pleasingly rounded which means they do not lie flat.  They stack nicely on their sides but need a drawer at least 3 inches deep.The set comes attractively packed in a container with a handle.  For a just-starting couple, a student, campers, the Novell stainless could be attractively wrapped & presented, and would thoughtful gift.  Me, I'll be using it, hopefully for quite a few years with pride and pleasure.

Ah, so THIS is how these work, and then they work wonders.  The wipes arrive rolled tightly into the container, 20 of them.  First try, I pulled one off the end, like peeling a wealthy roll of $1 bills.  Worked OK but couldn't wrap it around the serving spoon  I was cleaning or get a good grip.  Looked again & saw each wrap is folded in half.  Unfold, and voila! 5.5" wide, 7.9' long, and I could put some sincere energy into cleaning that tarnished spoon.The wipes were tested on a 6 pieces per setting, 10 setting sterling set, medium tarnished, six shamefully tarnished silver-plate & ornate serving spoons, a fairly shiny baroque repousse dish, and several silver plate serving dishes.  I still have 1/2 of the wipes left.  A single wipe shone about 4 pieces of silver---more for a plain item, less if the item is ornate.Pros: --easy to use, no pre-preparation--smelled good to me, neutral-clean not perfumey--handled the tarnished as well as shinier piecesUser Alerts:--energy needed; a languid wipe won't do the trick so those with arthritis or wrist issues should be aware--need to buff energetically with a soft dry cloth to bring up the shine (rinse first)--not for a long time but with energyI'm really happy with results compared to a liquid polish and a pink cream polish both well known.  This is a good value too!

So there's the shipping box.  Emme opens it.  Inside in neon pink tissue paper (added) is this neon-bright fairy ice-skater ballerina princess, who flew right to Emme's heart.  And around the table.  And with open wings then folded shut wings. And performing a leap.  And....This beautiful Barbie-friend flew into my heart too because--the flexible hinging that permits arms positioning from down to fully raised and the legs positioned in jettes, pirouettes, and Cirque du Soleil-like moves so she can be a fairy, a ballerina, an ice-skater, a princess and more--the colors are intense, much better than the pale almost washout picture on the site.  The green wings are really green, the peach wings almost orange and the purple a shimmering deeper color than shown.  So is the dress, happy-making, sun-bright, gorgeous colors.--the quality is fine.  Sturdy transparent plastic (?) wings with charming perforations such as wee hearts.  The multi-layered dress is neatly cut, well put together, and the fairy boots are stylin' orange, not your fairy godmother boots--the figure is  lissome, attractive & good, as a fairy should be but without the overly bosomy, wasp-waisted body.  The facial expression is friendly, warm, smiling & adorably sweet.  Long softer-than-usual hair.--the wing open and shut mechanism holds up to a lot of folding & unfolding by a three year old.  Easy to use.LOVE this doll & at the price, a terrific value.Any buyers alerts?  I am not sure if the boots and skirt come off.  Skirt maybe but probably not the boots so if changing costumes and dresses is big must must must have, then check before buying perhaps.  The wings, says Emme, would fly better with glitter. Glue and glitter could easily be added.OVERALL:  This fairy ice-skater ballerina princess ignites imagination, a doll for adventures and stories.  A passive person to dress & undress, not so much but it sure has opened a wide magical world of possibilities!  Highly recommended if an imaginative fairy would make your perfect person happy.

If you are a guitar player, if you resonate to the music of the guitar greats, if you are fascinated by stories of what created a legendary magazine, or if you just like outstandingly good writing, then "Guitar Player:  The Inside Story of the First Two Decades of the Most Successful Guitar Magazine Ever" may be your book of the year.It sure is mine because-- there are 273 pages of pictures, text, and art that deliver exactly what's promised, the inside story of those 1967 to 1987 years--the story is brilliantly conceived as told by editors Jim Crockett & Dara Crockett, 26 staffers & freelancers, 42 featured artists and monthly columnists, and wonderfully, 15 advertisers.--the photographs include world-class portraits, then and now, as well as more informal shots of jam sessions--the layout and writing meet or may even exceed the spectacularly good "Guitar Player" standard, echoing in some ways that of the magazine.  I didn't find one spelling error, any flinch-worthy sentence, anything but a word I usually hesitate to use--but it's so true here--production perfection--it lives.  This is not dusty-musty, disengaged "history" but it breathes the excitement of those first decades and the impact "Guitar Player" made in shining the spotlight on such amazing talentAny reader alerts?  This beautifully-produced, glossy paper, extensive photographs book costs more, granted, than a Kindle or almost disposable paper-back might.  "Guitar Player" is a keepers book, worth every dollar, and compared with similar books, it is a terrific value.  Will some readers wish Player X, Y, or Z had been included?  Probably, but as authors Crockett (Jim) and Crockett (Dara) make clear, they cast a very wide net.  While almost all artists agreed to be interviewed, a few didn't. And those interviews---wow! In their own words and are those words as memorable as the music. Special thanks to Dara Crockett, who,  writes her Dad, "cajoled, pleaded, begged, and virtually threatened" until Jim Crockett got it together while this living vibrant history was possible.

Bring together one of America's greatest writers (DuBose Heyward, author of "Porgy & Bess") and one of our most loved illustrators (Marjorie Flack, "Make Way for Ducklings") and we get a book which has heart, brains, and beauty. In this lovely story, a small brown country bunny yearns to be one of the five Easter Bunnies; but she becomes a young lady bunny, then the mother of 21 babies.  She cleverly selects a daughter and a son pair for each of the innumerable household tasks including singing and dancing to keep them merry and has a happy productive home. Still she yearns to be one of the Easter Bunnies.  When Grandfather Bunny (old, kind, and wise) see her and the 21 well-behaved small ones, he selects her as a Fifth Bunny.  He gives her a special & supremely difficult assignment: delivering a crystal sugar egg to a sick boy who lives far far away on the top of an ice mountain.  Almost there, poor Cottontail slips, tumbling far far down the mountain just as it is almost a dawn, with an injured foot.  What happens next is pure magic, that a kind wise old Grandfather might bestow on the tired small but great hearted creature....and in so doing, bestows this on us all.Written in 1939, the year before DuBose Heyward died, this story honors the dreams of girls and those with dark skin, those who are mothers first, those who are themselves kind, wise, and clever.  Flack's watercolor paintings in  greens, coral, yellow spring colors bring the world of Cottontail to believable life.  This book is perfect for Easter and throughout the year; reading it,  I believe ,enters gently & beautifully into the hearts and minds of my own little bunnies.READER ALERT:  This is a classic.  If at all possible, get the large format edition.  Readers getting the smaller size have been disappoinmted.  This review is based on the hard-cover large format book.

There could be two take-aways from this enchanting book, one warm'n'fuzzy and the other darker.  Molly Lou Mellon is Thumbelina-size, with a voice like a frog's, buck-teeth so prominent she could qualify as a beaver, and she's a klutz.  What Miss Molly has going for her is a grandma who tells her never-you-mind sayings such as, "Walk as proudly as you can and the world will look up to you," ""Sing out clear and strong and the world will cry tears of joy."  When Mollie Lou moves to a new town, the school bully, Ronald Durkin starts out on her by calling her "Shrimpo" in gym class.  She puts him in his place by running between his legs with the football and scoring a touch-down.  By day five, Mollie Lou is the star of the school in football, cutting out amazing snowflakes, and shouting so loudly Ronald is flattened. "Grandma," she writes, "everything you told me is exactly right."Reading this as the celebration of a different child or of our differences is sweet, heart-warming, and easy.  However, the sub-text is that it sure helps and may be essential if one is this different to be better than everyone else in skills other children value. Mollie Lou's self-assurance may have led to her prowess in football and snowflake cutting, to her daring to do anything, but alone, the Ronald Durkins can prevail.I love this book and it is a favorite with my next generations, but we read it with awareness that Mollie Lou made herself into an exceptionally talented smaller person.  That as well as Grandmother's assurances. can turn the bullies into friends and admirers, even contributing a penny to Mollie Lou's penny-stacking feat on those front-teeth.

Pure magic, the watercolor drawings of this book for 2 to  5 year-olds, bringing to life 22 new friends--24 if I  include the giant potato and the leprechaun.  Set in an Irish-like countryside of about 200 years ago, Tomie dePaola retells an old story that appears in many cultures. Jamie doesn't like to work; his wife Eileen does what's needed for them to eat.  When her back goes out, Jamie fears he'll die from lack of food, so off he goes to get ready for the sad event.  On his way to the village, he finds a fairies' shoemaker (the leprechaun) who outsmarts his captor by giving him a seed for the biggest potato on the world, rather than his treasured gold.  The blessing becomes first a bane (can't get that veggie out of the ground), then a blessing (the curious villagers help), then a bane (ooops! it blocked the road), then a blessing thanks to quick-witted and kind Eileen (every one can have all they want), then a bane (the villagers eat and eat and eat and eat until they never want to see a potato again), and then a blessing as they offer food for life if Eileen and Jamie plant no more giant potatoes...the big pratie for sure.The story has a fine lilt of words and as I mentioned, the drawings are wholly charming in DePaola's much-loved style.  Is there anything more though to reading children this story?To me, this is a classic tale of the apparently not-too-bright person--a schlemiel, a trickster, a lazy person---who by a "fortunate misfortune" and a certain talent for keeping on, brings fortune to her/himself and the community.  I particularly like that the heroine is the hard-working, cheerful, and very bright Eileen who invites everyone to take all the potato they want, and how the community eventually pitches in to deal with the situations. The children with whom I have read this giggled at the turns of the story and loved the gay illustrations and the rhythm of the tale.Recommended with delighted enthusiasm for the humor, imagination, and good things to be shared here.  It seems to me an opportunity for readers, if they chose, to add some history.

Pot-of-gold perfect and here's what's I found to love about this adorable, affordable centerpiece--big enough to make an impression: height including the rainbow is 8", length including the shamrocks is 9', height of the green pot alone is 6" and the diameter is 7"--small enough for talking across the table; any higher, and it would be an obstacle if placed in the middle--color is bright, a true shamrock green with intense rainbow color and gold. No washed-out rainbow here--all-around centerpiece.  The green pot unfolds and the rainbow & clover are printed so this is pretty from all sides--easy to set up.  I almost did not order because I thought "slot-A into slot-B, then tuck slot-C"  kind of construction would be needed.  This is pre-kindergarten simple.  Just one unfold and a small paper-clip is even provided for easy clipping both sides together.  Great engineering here, Leprechauns.--refolds flat easily to store. It arrives flat too which makes it almost zero-space until set-up--stable on a flat surface, no propping up needed--where I live, I could find nothing of this size & quality for such a relatively affordable price.  Got here at warp speed too & I loved the free shippingAny buyers alert?  Buyers should be aware that the coins are printed.  I put a small piece of paper in the top of the pot and added some jelly beans which look cute & taste yummy even if not exactly Irish.  Also, pots of gold are sometimes shown as black wee kettles or golden cauldrons which may be what you want.  This was not a deal-breaker for me and the shamrock color really adds to the traditional St Patrick's Day feeling.

The rain still pummeled Tommi's face and it was hard for her to speak without shouting each word in her questioning."And your chanting?""I need this storm to go before us and hold fast on Mauna Kea, and let the rain become snow and ice.  I have summoned a favor from one of my sisters, Poliahu."  Her teenage persona returned.  "I'm basically chanting, 'Keep it snowing, sis.'"You betcha, girl!  "Atomic Dreams at the Red Tiki Lounge" is a wild, wonderful, no-holds-barred historical-mystery-science fiction novel by Tiki Shark (artist Brad Parker) and writer S. P. Grogan.Set in 1946, initially in Honolulu and ranging from there to Bikini Atoll where the first underwater atomic bomb was tested to the frozen summit of the Big Island's Mauna Kea, this novel has a cast of characters as numerous and richly detailed as Dickens.  Featured first are a severely wounded veteran, Hunter Hopewell, recovering at the bar of the Red Tiki Lounge, his alcohol-fueled life surreptiously funded by a woman of many names, or rather, businesses.  Tommi Chen is a survivor who is determined not only to endure, but to prevail--at any cost, although she is less likely to off the offenders than to shanghai them.A case could be made, though, that the protagonists are Pele, seen as creator and protector of earth and its life, and Ku, King Kamehameha's inspiration, and the god of War.  When atomic bombs explode, the explosions rip the barrier between the worlds, letting in Goya's "The sleep of reason breeds monsters."  Nasty kind of monsters & Ku is out to bring them under his control, an idea Pele opposes with all her skill and might.Or a case could be made that the novel is about the artist Tiki Shark himself, who appears throughout as the sidewalk artist and free spirit he is (and has been), whose sensibilities, actions, and asides drive the events.Whatevah...this is one glorious trip.  The hardcover book includes several full-color paintings by Tiki Shark whose works are collectors' items (see particularly page 146--five WOWs right there) as well as over ten black-and-white Tiki Shark drawings and many well-chosen photos of the underwater explosion and planes including a Lockheed Electra (hint!) and one of the big, beautiful Clippers.  Throughout, there are cameo appearances of now well-known people as they would have been seen in 1946, each convincingly interwoven with the on-going story.The book itself is a collector's item: mine is signed by Grogan and Tiki Shark, number 400 of a printing of 1,000.  Hustle to your indie bookstore or Amazon order site and get a signed, numbered copy if you are early & lucky.  If unsigned, no problem: it is still a great read.Any Negatives?  This may not be to everyone's top ten tastes.  There's romance & sex (hey, it's about Hawaii) but it is not primarily about pant-pant experiences.  The style is more Hunter Thompson and Ken Keasey with maybe a touch of Ray Bradbury, than Jane Austen, but the voice is too original to pigeon-hole. Among the pleasures of "Atomic Dreams at the Red Tiki Lounge" is that Grogan is so skilled a writer.  A master of dialog, with keen attention to literacy: Miss Eva Mae Brown of blessed memory and Lynn Truss and yes, Strunk & White would be appreciative.I sure am.  Thanks a lot, Tiki Shark and S.P. Grogan.  Please keep those brushes wet & the pens or PCs turning!

A sturdy, detailed, small wonder of a globe!Among its outstanding features--it revolves easily without wobbles on the stand--passed my performance test of being ready to "roll and hold" keeping steady on all of the many locations to which I turned it--larger than the diameter (5") might suggest.  The circumference around the Equator (shown as a thin raised black line) measures 17" and the overall height is 8" including the stand--excellent colors, bright but not garish, and particularly effective in showing the blue oceans--as far as I could tell, politically up-to-date in showing the countries recognized by the United Nations--quite a few cities marked--all the U.S. States individually indicated--surface appears to be integral rather than paper which can risk peeling under useHowever, buyers should be aware that--a magnifiying glass may be needed to read some of the small-print countries--no globe or map is likely to satisfy every political perspective in what is recognized and what is not as a country--this is a Northern Hemisphere globe /North Pole on top so the Southern Hemisphere countries are less easy to see than where the South Pole is shown on top or where pages of an atlas can show larger scalesThis is not a scholar's globe but it could be an excellent first globe for a young person, introducing the concept of representing location, showing where friends & relations live, connecting to movies and news stories, and igniting imaginations.  It is light enough to move easily, takes little storage space, comes in a useful box, and at the Amazon price, is a terrific---an amazing---value.

Cute, cute, cute!  These are conversation starter sox or maybe a more original Valentine card.  The fit is good for slender or average legs but might be a little snug after washing for heavier legs.  The Spandex keeps these knee highs up without drooping or sagging around the ankles; unsagging ankles are what I crave in knee-highs!  The design is nicely done with bright colors.These do well hand-washed and line dried, to avoid getting snagged in a washing machine or dried to a crisp.  They are not heavy duty athletic sox.  Being lighter than say ragg wool, these sox could be worn year round.  I like them. am very satisfied, and yes, I'll be your Valentine!

"The Kiss,"  painted by Gustav Klimt, in golds, blacks, and greens, is a gorgeous and an intricate painting.  To see it duplicated well in sox signals a work of art, too.  These are lovely.  Bright colors, good detail in the design reproduction, an attractive conversation starter.  The fit is fine for average legs or more slender legs.  A delightful gift & fun to put on!These sox come in blue or sunflower yellow.  The Klimt original is sunflower yellow & gold, so to my eyes, the yellow is not only cheerful but also more "authentic."  However, other buyers might prefer the blue if it harmonizes better than the gold/yellow with their other clothes or the color choices of some lucky friend.Treated with respect, these wear well. Thus, I would suggest hand-washing in cool water and hanging to dry rather than putting in a washing machine with stuff that might snag threads and drying until crisp. Think of them as wearable art, more than as athletic soxs and they will be a delight. Much to love in "The Kiss" in these sox.

WHAT THIS BOOK IS ABOUT:Carolyn Burke's story of Edith Piaf shines with empathy for a woman whose life was as amazing as her voice.  The voice brought her the love of "her public" so intense her grave at Pere Lachaise Cemetary is among the most visited year after year.  The life brought her money, travels, friendship of men such as Cocteau yet an emptiness her large entourages and an ever-active bed seemed unable to fill.Both make for a fascinating story, vividly told in 16 chapters and 230 pages, organized chronologically and written in a highly readable style.  The table of contents begins with a puzzlement that turns out to foretell Piaf's life.  Chapter 1,1915-1925 covers ten years.  Chapter 2, 1926-1932 covers six years.  All the other chapters cover 2 or 3 years each, not corresponding particularly to what was going on in the world, be it writ relatively small (popular music, for instance) or large.This turns out to reflect how little is known of her early life other than its misery: by ten, she was making her own precarious living and that of her amorous, acrobat papa as a street singer.  During the next years, she was discovered and shaped into Edith Piaf by her mentor, man about the shadier parts of town, called by some a Pygmalion and by others a Svengali: shaped into her musical "realistic songs" style, her black dresses, and confidence as a lyricist.  That she survived at all, this 4'8" waif-like woman, is astonishing.Those 14 separate two-year chapters?  They seem to be the approximate time with which she was enamoured (and vice versa) of a succession of lovers who helped ensure she did not sleep alone.  Piaf, as Burke convincingly documents, lived by and for music, exhausting herself and everyone else until each song was perfected in intonation and gesture.  However, she could not endure being alone, and to that end needed not only the lovers, many of whom she mentored, but also the loyal entourage to whom she was most generous.  She never could save a sous and had to work beyond her strength to earn the livelihoods of all.Exhaustion and auto accidents, drinking and drugs spiraled her to a difficult death, eased by the loyal friends and her 20 years younger fourth husband, Theo, whose pictures suggest an out-of-this-world hunky quotient. Piaf was gone early, and very much not forgotten.WHY READ THIS BOOKIf one loves Piaf's music, Burke's version of the fairly often told tale is well put together.  I liked the quality of writing, the page-turning pace, the focus on Piaf without numerous digressions, and particularly the skillful integration of the numerous lyrics with the developing story.For a more casual reader, the book has the human interest of popular weekly magazines, a story from which a grand opera could be written with something of the scope of Les Miserables and the fascination of Evita,and which left me interested in learning even more.  I was entertained and felt I got great value for my time & money.ANY READER ALERTS?  Readers looking for a profound analysis, examining Piaf more analytically or in the context of what else was happening in popular music or sociologically, may find less in this book than they prefer.  Such readers will however receive a useful bibliography for some of the depth & discursiveness as well as a good index.The tone is non-judgmental with regard to such matters as Piaf's enthusiasm for married men or their attraction to her.  For me this was fine recreational reading----it could make for example a gift for a friend traveling to Paris, a beach book par excellence, or a great way to spend an evening, with Piaf in the background and this book in hand.Burke doubtless worked very very hard to get the story as fully & accurately as possible and I apologize if this seems disparaging.  Far from it: writing a good read that brings to life a complex, often admirable, outrageous & courageous and enormously talented woman takes skill and will.  Thank you, author Burke, and I hope many readers enjoy this as much as I did.

WHAT THE BOOK IS ABOUTWhen a new airport was built in Mumbai, a grotty small area bordering a lake of sewage became a shanty-town in which much that is best and much that is worst in India happens daily to the several hundred people author Katherine Boo studied.  For over three years, she recorded what was happening in this micro-mini-village, following in depth three women and their families.During this time, they use almost every moment to get food to eat, to earn a few rupees, to avoid trouble, and when trouble finds them, get free of its strangling toils.  Far too often, it is their next door neighbors and corrupt institutions who wring their necks and despoil their hopes.  Yet they find friendships now and then, and almost saintly generousity at times.The stories close for this one place, because their shanties are pulled down, and they must find whatever they can, wherever they can to survive.WHY READ THIS BOOKSome readers have seen plenty of the world's suffering, either directly or more indirectly through books such as Rohinton Mistry's  "A Delicate Balance" or glimpses in movies such as "Slumdog Millionaire."  For others, reading about horrors such as the Holocaust or suffering such as "Behind the Beautiful Forevers" is overwhelmingly depressing.Yet others may want to know from a skilled and presumably reliable journalist what makes efforts to relieve poverty and democratize other countries so difficult and the returns to billions spent in aid seem to yield so few benefits to the intended beneficiaries.For such readers, "Behind the Beautful Forevers" may be among the more unforgettable books.  Like "The Diary of Anne Frank,"  like "Uncle Tom's Cabin" Boo brings to individual life those who can otherwise be faceless statistics of birth and death.  In "Death of a Pig," E. B. White's magnificent essay, White mourns the animal's death not as loss of bacon in a future hungry time, but as loss of a fellow being who also suffered in this suffering world. I do not in any way compare those who live such difficult lives to pigs whether suffering or not but believe when we see others as our fellow humans, we may come closer really to caring about them and perhaps moving outside our own comfort zones to helping, as we can, make their lives better.READER ALERTS?  The book is well written indeed, so much so that some commentators believe it is a novel.  It is not.  I've spent some time in India, including Mumbai, and know that while Boo scarcely has told the whole story of this vast, complex and determined country, she has nailed one part of the mosaic.  Thus the four stars. Faulkner said, "I believe mankind will not only endure; it will prevail."  India and its peoples struggle to endure, in spite of everything, hope and dreams can remain in the darkest of times, the bitterest of experiences.  Or such has been my very limited experience in India and the testimony of others, far more knowledgeable.I'd give this book five stars if (1) some space was given to the people in their own voices, (2) more assurance was given about the reliability of the translation since Boo does not communicate directly, and (3) there was much more assurance that the people she met benefitted directly from the extraordinary amount of time she demanded of them and that this is not exploitation. Sadly there are instances of "Our stories, your royalties."

WHAT THIS BOOK IS ABOUT:The story tells what some seriously bibulous party-goers said at a celebration of a big win for the handsome Agathon, in the 416 BC contest amongst tragic playwrights.  He'd feasted his performers the night before, and wine did not run short.  The more select group he invited for a following banquet thus decided not to drink after practically every sentence, but as they pleased.  Symposium means literally, "drinking together" ---not for the abstemious!  Drinkers took it in turn to improvise on a topic suggested by the Master of Ceremonies, who selected in this case, the praise of Eros.  A symposium was a celebration not only of an event, but also held to honor a god or gods, bringing together the sacred and more profane.Six of the praises are reported by a narrator, Apollodurus, who is telling a companion what he heard from someone who was actually there, Aristodemus.  Aristodemus, however, had plead intoxication and the capacity to recall only what he considered the high points.  So enter into the spirit of the tipsy occasion and into the purposes of Platon who probably made up the whole of it.AMONG THE HIGHLIGHTSThe six speeches wonderfully reflect the characters, voices, and quirks of the men. Phaedrus the philosopher, he of the silver-gilt hair, most handsome himself, speaks well, imaginatively, and proposes Eros is a god who inspires the lover to the heights of devotion, even unto death, as Alcestis died for Admetus.  Young, we might think, he imagines an army of lovers, each striving to win honor for his beloved and, inspired by Eros, ready to die to defend his beloved.He's followed by Pausanias, whose speech could be a Swiftian satire of how lawyers from 2300 years ago to today, can think, a selfie of his own argumentive cleverness in differenting types of Eros and explaining the fine points of Athenian laws on pederasty. Read aloud, it is LOL funny.OK, on to Eryximachus, a physician, who advocates temperance in all things and elaborates on the dual nature of divine and profane Eros, extending Eros beyond sexual desires to the love of the Beautiful. Knowledgeable, yet no poet he, this encomium can inspire readers of today perhaps to avoid sharing a couch with an Athenian physician if you want a good time.Now at last the magnificent comedic writer Aristophanes speaks, beginning with a story on how male and female were once one body, spherical in shape, what happened and with what consequences.  Aristophanes is speaking of the human condition, with Eros as a single healing force, a speech of great beauty & power.  Agathon's in comparison is eloquent but flat----and then Socrates weaves the best from each, reveals the limitations of each, and raises us mortals to the divine in Eros as a devotion to the good, the true, the Beautiful.Socrates claims only to be sharing what he learned from Diotima, the Wise Woman, about love & Eros.  Diotima's  final spine-tingling sentence reads in full, "In begetting true virtue and nurturing it, it is given to him to become dear to god, and if any other among men is immortal, he is too."  Almost 2,300 years later, we know as did the first readers of Plato's "The Symposium" that while Diotima refered to those who contemplate the Beautiful, beholding the divine Beauty itself, single in nature, she could be speaking of Socrates himself.  Which is why, says editor Allen, Plato put the speech as Socrates telling what Diotima said, rather than speaking in his own voice, Socrates who claims not that he is wise, only that he is a lover of wisdom and beauty.Then Alcibiades lurches in, and gives a strange speech in praise of Socrates, including an erotic but more detailed report than might be expected of how Socrates ignored Alcibiades' efforts to seduce him one cold Athenian night. More revelers arrive breaking up the Symposium.  Finally only Agathon, Aristophanes and Socrates are awake, discussing tragedy and comedy, until the first two have been vanquished by Dionysus.  Socrates arises, goes as usual to debate all day long, unvanquished by Dionysus or, in debate, by any other.  The Symposium, like Woolf's "Orlando," seems a gift of deepest love from Plato to the memory of Socrates.WHY THIS EDITION OF "THE SYMPOSIUM"I agree with the scholarly reviewer who compares six editions, concluding if only one would be read, Allen's would be the choice for the quality of the translation and the value of Allen's comments Hear! Hear!I also agree with the reviewer who suggested beginning with the translation itself (76 pages including footnotes), then reading the over 110 pages of Allen's commentary.  The translation and footnotes are readable as they are.  Allen's fine commentary greatly deepens and enriches our understanding of the context----a defense of Socrates against charges of corrupting the youth of Athens.  This is valuable, but not essential to reading "The Symposium" in its own voice first.OVERALL:  "Truth is beauty, beauty is truth" may have its roots in Plato's "Symposium".  This is a fine edition and at used book prices, a great, almost piratical, value.There is a niggle. The arc of The Symposium is from Eros as physical sex to love of divine Beauty.  The cover drawing displays only the lustful but not exactly as this translation's notes say.  The picture of the satyr and maenad suggests she has a choke-hold on him, rather than the other way, as the Allen edition states.  Granted his hand is way beneath her gown, but one wouldn't mess against her will with a robust woman holding a spotted panther by the tail & a huge thyrsus in the arm around one's neck.  The picture is from a drinking cup of the period.  Perhaps the drawing was selected as a quiet thanks to whoever Diotima may have been and to Plato's selection or creation of her as the wise woman to whom Socrates attributes his education in matters of love.The Symposium draws us into a world of possibilities and attentive thought.  Eros, life, and love says this edition as a whole in this robust, forthright translation, are more complex, affirmative, and joyous than they may seem. Bibemus!  Highly recommended.

In February 2004, Nikki, a fellow survivalist, Micah. and a cat were dropped off at Native Anchorage on Village Island in Alaska's Queen Charlotte Strait.  Nikki was pissed off because Mom told her to work to buy an expensive jumper (horse) she wanted for her Olympic dreams---in addition to horses Mom already had given her.  She worked in a stables for two weeks, then quit, and decided to follow a childhood dream inspired by "The Other Side of the Mountain.""Becoming Wild" is based on her journal of 18 months living primitively.  Perhaps unexpectedly, "Becoming Wild" shines with candour and humor, the stories interspersed with this young woman's growing insights into herself in relation to others, to the Alaskan island world, and to her sense of the Divine.  Her thoughts on the centrality of love, on the nature of things, and on eternal mysteries and values have great honesty in the context of the hard work, deprivation, and determination needed for survival.It seems amazing that a woman whose essential supplies included nail-polish and a teddy-bear and who was utterly lacking in any knowledge of boats (they had a small rowboat) and fishing survived at all, although she tells us about four years of formal wilderness school training. What were they thinking of when they picked an archipelago where seafood would be part of eating? They did have an extensive library, to which they probably owe great thanks.Along the way, van Schyndel tells us--her ratings of the adequacy of toilet paper au natural (hint: seek out young thimbleberry leaves)--starving on clams (hint: not enough fat calories without the butter sauce and no fat salmon around)--killing, butchering, preserving, and cooking a bear (two bears, for food, paleostyle)--far too close encounters with the cougar kind--managing the essentials---building  a shelter, finding water, getting enough food for two scanty meals a day, if they were lucky.  In later months, they ate more reliably and abundantly, having learned to preserve, preserve,preserve.  Plus care packages from home.--and living with MicahShe writes vividly and cleanly, with 27 mostly brief chapters in this 237 page book, including some recipes that I hope tasted better than they sound such as mouse en brochette.Reader Alerts?  Micah's voice isn't heard except as reported dialog & experiences.  We tend to be the heroes of our own lives and I wondered how he would tell the story, what the months meant to him.  We do get some charmng pictures of Scout, a feral cat who probably helped keep them from murder or madness, and definitely kept them fd on song birds and rodents.Overall:  A thoroughly engaging story in itself, and a journey with a woman whose wit, spunk, determination, and spirit are likely to make readers grateful, gratefuller, and gratefullest she decided to go for her wilder dreams and then share them so honestly with us.  Thank you, Nikki, and good luck with your visitors lodge and recovery from that human predator.

Both old age and illness have approached.  This book has been indispensable in knowing from a practical and legal perspective what the possibilities are.  It has helped with conversations with physicians, hospice staff, my friends and family, and lawyers.  This is no "Dr. Kervorkian light," in that Humphry tells it straight re the self-deliverance experiences and options, most of which are pretty unattractive from my point of view for a loved one or myself.  However, he also explains how to work with health care staff to reach palliation and a passing with dignity, pain free, should one choose.The book is in some ways out of date, referring, for example, to the Hemlock Society rather than to the (2014, current & excellent) organization, Compassion & Choice.  It is also somewhat out of date in federal and some state laws, particularly laws ensuring a patient's right to comfort and palliative care, as far as I can tell.However it is straight, yet compassionate in style and covers just about everything I wanted to learn about this difficult topic.If you or a loved one needs a good general book to supplement discussions with clergy, doctors, and family, you may find this excellent. It gives a solid  foundation for these discussions and further research.  I think it an fine value specially at used book prices for the most recent edition.

A cold laid me low; I was sneezing, wheezing, miserable.  My son bought this from COSTCO, plugged it in, switched on the UV option and almost instant relief.  This handles a 20 x 15 ft bedroom well, and has been cooling as well as clearing the air.  It is easily moved by a convenient on-the-top handle.  Three options for the fan strength (high, middle, low); UV on or off; lights out option for night.  About 2 1/2 ft tall, 8 inches diameter column, not obtrusive at all.With regard to noise, my house is carpeted, and this is positioned about 3 ft from my bed.  It is quieter than my overhead fan on low and medium levels; about the same at high levels.  Since the hum is steady, for me it is soothing.  As an unexpected bonus, this cleans the air so thoroughly that this room is now totally dust-free.  I expected pathogens would pack their bags and leave---I am sure happy about the absence of dust.  Effectiveness might vary depending on atmospheric dustiness and allergens as well as individual needs.  For me, it has been handling volcanic vog which is pretty wicked stuff to breathe.Any alerts?  Buyers should be aware this unit needs to be about 2 to 3 feet from walls for good intake airflow.  Also, it probably would be better to put it on wood or tile than on carpet, although the carpet may help keep the fan hum so quiet.  The color is black with a silver top, which fits my bedroom,  Some buyers may want white or a more colorful case but I don't know if this is available.  Cleaning has been easy by following the clear directions step by step.  No special skills needed, as far as I can tell.Overall:  I am totally pleased and happy to report since it arrived about six months ago, no sneezes at all!  An excellent value and worth every penny of the price, for me.

Ok, this was my own fault for not listening to the other reviewers of Yehuda Matzo-Style Squares Gluten Free.What arrived was a box exactly as shown.  Very handsome. Inside was instant matzoh brei.  The pieces were too small for a schmear of charoset.  The taste was good:  light sweet crackery.  However, Elijah almost passed us by. This is not a matzoh, not Kosher for Passover, and at almost $13, for 10 ounces, this is spendy for me for gluten free matzoh meal.So, if what you want is ready-made gluten free light cracker pieces, non-Kosher, this is your product.We're adding milk and eggs to the pieces for matzoh brei this Sunday with maybe some maple syrup.Perhaps this is a good as it gets for a gluten free matzoh-like cracker that's fine right out of the factory, but should not go far from home?  I want to be positive & encouraging.  Maybe I just got an off-box but I was disappointed.

"Spring, spring, spring," sang the frog, from a pond by fresh green grasses and flowers. "Spring," said the groundhog, his arms raised in celebration.So begins this lovely book, telling how a small brown bunny goes down the road and down the road one day when the butteflies are swaying on stalks and a flora botanica of the brightly colored small flowers  are unfolding in the warm sunlight.  The bunny meets three baby robins still wearing bits of their blue shells, a somewhat inhospitable ground-hog, and the frog in his bog.  In none of their homes can this sweet-faced bunny find his home.  UNTIL.....The Little Golden Book is a poem, written like a small song by Margaret Wise Brown and illustrated by Garth Williams with the precision and color of the millefleurs tapestries of the Middle Ages.  It is loving, friendly, unfussy, and perfect, a  beloved book since 1956---reprinted fresh and sparkling new as children, parents, and grandparents remember it.The book boards are sturdy, heavy cardboard, the pages are strong enough for years of turning by small hands, and the Amazon price is unbelievably low.  I have just purchased five copies as Easter-spring greetings for family & friends and yes, one for myself.No reservations or reader alerts.  "Home for a Bunny" is a heritage gift at a peeps price.

WHAT THE BOOK IS ABOUTWriter Malia Collins and ilustrator Kathleen Peterson have created one of the loveliest, most powerful embodiments of which I know of goddesses Pele and Poli'ahu.  This story is a re-telling of ancient explanations of what we in Hawaii see for ourselves every day.  Snow & ice can cover Mauna Kea (White Mountain) where the snow queen, Poli'ahu, rules while new land is being created through the fire mountains of Mauna Loa (Long & Large Mountain) and Kilauea where the fire goddress, Pele, reigns.  Pele's white hot lava creates new land; Poli'ahu's waters wear them away.Once, the story tells us, Poli'ahu was playfully racing with her friends on the white mountain on a swift, narrow sled. A strange woman appears, dressed in scarlet-orange.  Then....This large-format 23 page book should delight children of all ages.  The story-teller has the cadence and eye of a poet:  "When it was her turn to race, she leapt on to her sled and flew down the hill, quickly passing her friends."
