Overall, a satisfying product line.

The Fisher-Price Little People toys are some of the favorites in our family. The Disney Princess ones are especially popular for obvious reasons. Our original castle and figures have survived 12 years of playing and are still the first toys pulled out of our closet when visiting children play in our home, even children who have technically aged out of the Little People intended age range. So the figures are a slam dunk in this set--we already owned all three but having seconds is always nice, especially to facilitate sharing. The castle is already beloved by the kids as something new but I prefer our original castle with its nooks and crannies and less, well, pinkness. This version will happily entertain and please the kids for more years to come though, for hours at a time. Whenever the house is filled to the rafters, there is always at least one child playing with the Little People sets in our closet. The "dancing" element may be too complicated for the intended age range, but these toys are predecessors to Imaginext so the kids in that are older age range are good at manipulating the mechanics unlike the toddlers for whom the set is really intended. This is up to the usual Fisher Price standards so overall a reliable and happy making toy that will last for years judging on the previous iterations we own.

I got this book--along with the earlier titles in the trilogy--for my 12-year-old niece for some of her summer reading. She is currently obsessed with everything Japan, manga, and anime and is reading less traditional novels as a result. I thought this series would make a great compromise. So far, she has been happy with the series which is a challenge since the siren call of watching anime and reading fan fiction taunts her every day. She is an advanced reader and reads everything at her fingertips but is picky right now due to her new obsession. The unusual plot and special skills of the characters as well as the inserted artwork and settings make it appealing and a series she was eager to try and enjoy. Once I can get her to commit to her own review in her own words, I will come back and add it to mine here.

This is an excellent caddy for more than the shower, water resistant. I got this one with the intention for my niece to use it while visiting this summer for a few months. But I may be buying more as my brain comes up with other uses for it, especially in the garden and kitchen. But I also llike it for crafts since it is sturdy and essentially see through, too. The price is great, too, for a caddy of this size.

This is a handy device for a few uses, primarily backing up photos, such as while traveling. It is a backup drive, with a 4 gb limit per file, not something to play movies, music, etc. from. So it is recommended depending on what your needs entail. It is also rather pricey with less expensive options available although SanDisk is a trusted name in our household. In the end, it's not something we have a daily use for but it's nice to have around for if and when we do.

Overall, these are really great disposable razors. We use refillable and electric razors in our house but keep disposables around for house guests or our own travels. These have a comfortable handle and nice heft for a disposable. I am not especially sold on the five blades--I get a fine shave with  three and prefer the smaller surface area of three vs. five blades. My husband has a beard that he shaves around so he feels the same. Yes, these provide a close shave and didn't nick us but we were careful. There is more potential for nicks with the five blades. I will consider these when I buy our next round of disposables.

These are more like 3.5 stars for me. They are bright. They are fun. The erasers are the better white ones standard to many pencils these days, but not as big as I would like. They erased these pencils well enough.However, the family consensus is that these do not write as well. The hardening effect on the lead means that the pencil doesn't "flow" as well onto the paper. Now with some kids that is a bonus--less smeary pencils, less breakage of the point and a lead that sharpens more reliably without shattering or breaking. These pencils deliver those benefits for you. But I found myself pressing harder for a darker line than I am comfortable with. It felt like the pencil would skip if I didn't--actually it did skip when I first wrote with it before I determined the pressure I needed to apply--the same way some ink gel pens will skip and leave tiny gaps in your lines. So it is matter of what is important to you. Durability vs. ease of writing.I am also not sure about the price point here. I am seeing a first listing price that seems rather high at an average of 67 cents a pencil.

First, I am a HUGE fan of EcoTools brushes. You can't beat these brushes for the quality and price. I searched for years for brushes like this and spent lots of money on other brands that didn't perform or feel nearly as nice as these do. My favorite is the EcoTools Domed Bronzer Brush which I use for loose powder. This brush is different from the others I have used and I wasn't sure about it over my bronzer. The verdict is that I like both for different reasons. Not sure which I will end up ordering again soonest. This particular brush is also just pretty and the white brush is nice for helping me see when a cleaning could help. But to be honest, I tend to replace these pretty often due to the price point. I am still coming out cheaper with these than when I use to buy those shedding, rough expensive brushes touted at the makeup counters. And after using EcoTools, most brushes feel to rough. I have developed rosacea in recent years, too, and these brushes do not irritate it but help me softly cover when I need to.

I am a HUGE fan of EcoTools brushes. My favorite is the EcoTools Domed Bronzer Brush which I use for loose powder. This Kabuki brush has all of the same great traits of that one as a makeup brush with its own characteristics, the angled brush and shorter handle. I still prefer my bronzer brush for my own personal needs but this is an excellent brush if this is the style and angle you need. The bristles are soft and blend powder well. I don't need blush since I have rosacea but this brush works well with my red reducer powder from Clinique, the way I need it to work. You can't beat these brushes for the quality and price. I searched for years for brushes like this and spent lots of money on other brands that didn't perform or feel nearly as nice as these do.

This is a very intuitive and convenient laminator. I don't need one very often, so it's nice to have one that works and is easy to use without a refresher course when I do need it. It is inexpensive, too. Overall pleased with it. Do remember that it is plastic and inexpensive so it's not really suited for high volume jobs when it will overheat and be perhaps even dangerous to use. I'm not testing it that far to make sure though.

Love the concept. Like the design. Not impressed with the weight of the cardboard. Which leads to me being very unimpressed with the price. The giant boxes we receive for other items are just as sufficient for the price and similar weight if not heavier. This is nice as a double sided option and of course the white side is much more fun for art. But the age of the kids using this would also benefit somewhat for some lines or inspiration. Still, would consider this again for half the price, but not for the current price considering the size, weight, and other options available to us. The kids loved it and it made for a fun afternoon which is sometimes worth any price.

This has earned a permanent place in my office, a third stapler to sit between my standard small desk stapler and my heavy duty Bostick stapler which is overkill for under 30 pages. This stapler does nicely for stapling stacks of papers in the 10-30 page range. It can do more but that is my usual capacity need. I don't think it is significantly easier to use than my heavy duty stapler which still works like butter through tale stacks after 15 years; the hubby has even used that one on thin plywood to mount some fabric with ease, This stapler is much smaller profile and doesn't take up as much room on my desk as the big one that I only pull out for the heavy duty jobs. The usage is intuitive, it is a good price, and it fills a need, so overall a fine choice and I won't be looking to replace it.

Really this is more of a 3.5 stars for me but I'll round up out of affection for Imaginext. There are the usual cool elements like light up eyes, working elevator, dart shooting and fun detailing in the plastic molding. But there is only one figure with this set which is disappointing for the price and for play. This will not make a good entry into the DC Imaginext toy universe and would be one of the last sets I would consider buying when there are more figures to be bought instead. We have the Batcave in our house which has supplied hours of fun and still looks almost new. This is a fine supplement to that but it won't really enhance the fun of the other sets very much nor will it add fun characters to your arsenal. Still, it is well made, sturdy and the usual Imaginext quality. Still prefer this line over many other brands.

This is my favorite flashlight. This flashlight is very bright; it is brighter than my car's low-beam headlights. The PD35 has five brightness settings, as well as a strobe setting. The setting is selected by pushing a switch on the side of the flashlight. The flashlight is turned on (and off) by pressing the pushbutton switch at the back end of the flashlight. I typically set the brightness at the third setting. This flashlight is impressively effective at supporting inspections of equipment in large industrial facilities, even at a distance.If you perform an Amazon search for "Fenix PD35," you can find several "package" deals where a PD35 flashlight has been bundled with batteries and battery chargers. There are two one-cell batteries made by Fenix for this flashlight: the ARB-L2 (2600 mAh) and the longer-lasting ARB-L2S (3400 mAh). Fenix sells two chargers for these batteries: the ARE-C1 and the ARE-C2. The PD35 uses one 18650 battery or two CR123A batteries (I am told by a battery fanatic that it is better to use one ARB-L2/ARB-L2S battery than two CR-123A batteries).The size and weight (3 ounces) are perfect for someone who will equip this flashlight (in its holster on a belt) in a work environment for hours and hours.IF YOU THINK YOUR PD35 IS DOA:My flashlight appeared to be DOA (dead-on-arrival). After fully charging the battery, I inserted the battery into the flashlight and pushed the button to turn it on. Imagine my disappointment when nothing happened. I tried other batteries and checked battery voltages with a multimeter; the batteries were fine, but the flashlight would not turn on. I had (sadly) decided to return the flashlight for a refund when a friend made a suggestion that solved the problem. The cylindrical body of PD35 can be separated at two locations by unscrewing; this is how you open the flashlight to insert and remove the battery (or batteries). If your PD35 appears to be DOA, try completely unscrewing the flashlight at BOTH locations, then reassembling the flashlight. You may need to do this several times to remove some of the coating material. During my initial efforts to get my new PD35 to work, I had unscrewed the connection at the rear end of the flashlight to insert the battery; however, I did not unscrew the second connection at its front end (since I did not know of its existence at the time). After unscrewing and reassembling both connections a few times, the flashlight worked just fine.

The TP-LINK Archer C5 wireless dual band 802.11ac router provides quality and functionality at a reasonable price. It is very easy to install and setup and it has all of the functions I will ever need. I am very pleased with this router.If you are considering purchasing this router, I recommend that you go to its product page on the TP-Link website and read through the "Quick Installation Guide" (so you know what is involved). If you want lots and lots of details, you can also download the 147 page "User Guide" from the website. The TP-LINK Archer C5 is considerably larger than my previous router: the dimensions are 9.6 by 6.4 by 1.3 inches (243 by 160.6 by 32.5 mm).The following items are included:- Archer C5 router- DC power adapter- Ethernet cable- "Quick Installation Guide"- Resource mini-CD, which includes the "User Guide"I recommend that you take a photo of the label on the back of the router before you get started. It may be useful to have this photo displayed on your computer as you first setup your new router. Information on the label includes: wireless password; default access URL (http://tplinklogin.net); default user name; and default password. It might also be good to have the information on this label if you call customer support, since the label has the product's model number and serial number (which they will want).Notable features:- Supports 802.11ac, as wells as 802.11n, 802.11a, 802.11b and 802.11g- Simultaneous 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz wireless connections- Gigabit WAN port, four gigabit LAN ports, two USB 2.0 ports- SSID broadcast control, 64/128/152-bit WEP encryption, Wi-Fi protected access (WPA2- PSK, WPA- PSK), firewall protections- Wi-Fi Protected Setup (WPS), Guest Network access, parental controls- On/off switch (I never before had a router with an on/off switch)Most folks will only need to use the "Quick Installation Guide" to setup this router. A hardcopy of this guide comes in the package. If you want a PDF version of the guide search for: TP-LINK Archer C5 router and go to the "Download" tab on the product page of the TP-Link website. For setup, you will probably only need to use the "Quick Installation Guide" guide and the configuration wizard [accessed by CD or a web browser (http://tplinklogin.net)]. The default IP address is 192.168.0.1. You should definitely change username and password (from defaults) for the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz networks. I also turned off the SSID broadcast. Lastly, you may need to update the firmware.A copy of "User Guide" is provided on the included mini-CD. You can also download the "User Guide" (as a PDF) file from the vendor's website. The "User Guide" is thorough, step-by-step (with lots of screen shots), and easy to understand. If nothing else, I suggest that you look at the explanation of the front panel lights. The examples in the "User Guide" are for Windows XP; this is not a problem, since all of the required Windows functions can be accessed in a similar fashion in Windows 7 and Windows 8.1.Speaking of the front panel lights: the "System" light is on (solid) during initialization, then starts flashing when working properly; it would make more sense (and be less distracting) to have this status-light flash during initialization then turn solid.My home has a whole-house (hard-wired) Ethernet system with cables routed to a central junction box. The TP-LINK Archer C5 router has one input port and four output ports: my cable modem is plugged into the router's input port; I have three Ethernet cables and one four-port switch plugged into the router's output ports.If you are having a problem with a multi-port switch communicating with the router, try cycling the power on the switch (e.g., unplug it for at least five minutes, then re-energize it and give it time to establish communication).This router has six antennas: three internal antennas for the 2.4 GHz band and three (attachable) external antennas for the 5 GHz band. You will probably find that the 2.4 GHz band is better than the 5 GHz band. If you want to improve 5 GHz signal strength, you can try altering the location of the router in your home (trying to minimize walls, ceilings, and floors between the router and wireless devices) and the position of its antennas.I recommend this TP-LINK Archer C5 router to folks who want to upgrade to the faster 802.11ac standard but who do not want to spend a lot of money. For considerably more money, you might consider the ASUS (RT-AC68U) Wireless-AC1900 Dual-Band Gigabit Router.

"Doctor Who" was a British television show that was produced from 1963 to 1989. While "Doctor Who" was specifically developed for children, folks of all ages have been enjoying the show for more than 50 years (i.e., it was a "family show"). The title character (The Doctor) is a Time Lord from the planet Gallifrey who can travel through all space and time in his TARDIS (which, due to a broken chameleon circuit, is stuck in the form of a blue police box).During the show's 26 seasons, there were seven different actors who played The Doctor. I have seen every episode for the third (Jon Pertwee), fourth (Tom Baker), fifth (Peter Davison), sixth (Colin Baker), and seventh (Sylvester McCoy) Doctors. I have seen most of the available episodes for the first (William Hartnell) and second (Patrick Troughton) Doctors (many of the episodes are not available because the BBC reused the video tapes on which they were recorded).I recently watched all of the "Doctor Who" episodes featuring Sylvester McCoy (the seventh Doctor) in order. Overall, these episodes are bad. As Verity Lambert (the first producer of "Doctor Who," from 1963 to 1965) said, "You've got to be able to suspend your disbelief, and with Sylvester McCoy it got so camp. It was ridiculous, and I think that's why people stopped watching it." Most folks hated seeing The Doctor over-acting, behaving like a clown, and rolling his Rs (e.g., "Rrrrrrrrrrobot"). Sylvester McCoy was not responsible for the poor quality of the "Doctor Who" shows during his years; producer John Nathan-Turn (J N-T) and script editor Andrew Cartmel were entirely to blame for the horrible shows made during the McCoy years.Time and the Rani is the first episode of Season 24 from 1987. This episode is important because it features the first appearance of the seventh Doctor, played by Sylvester McCoy. Of the 159 stories in the original Doctor Who series, I would say that "Time and the Rani" is among the 20 worst. The "Mighty 200 Poll" conducted by Doctor Who Magazine (which rated 200 episodes from the old and new Doctor Who shows) rated "Time and the Rani" 198 out of 200 (third from the bottom). The same poll rated Sylvester McCoy as the second worst Doctor (with, of course, Colin Baker being the worst).In "Time and the Rani," The Rani (an evil renegade Time Lord whom we met in "Mark of the Rani") causes the TARDIS to crash-land on the planet Lakertya. At the very beginning of the story, the Doctor "regenerates" into his new form (Sylvester McCoy). Very shortly, we learn that The Rani has kidnapped the Doctor to repair equipment she needs for some evil plan. As is customary following a Time Lord's regeneration, the Doctor is very disoriented and confused and not quite himself (neither his old self nor his new self).Pros:- Excellent video quality.- The original story by Pip and Jane Baker is pretty good, although it has way, way too much "filler." Pip and Jane Baker also wrote "Mark of the Rani" which was shown in Season 22. Unfortunately, their original story was vitiated by changes mandated by the new story editor, the producer, and a BBC exec.- Good first-time use of digital special effects.- Good supporting cast.- Interesting costumes and makeup.- Good outdoor scenes (which were notoriously difficult to shoot).- Witty dialog here and there.Cons:- Criminally bad portrayal of The Doctor by Sylvester McCoy. Mr. McCoy plays The Doctor as a buffoon. While the Doctor had sometimes been whimsical and funny (as with the Patrick Troughton's second Doctor and Top Baker's fourth Doctor), he had never before been portrayed as a clown. This ruined the series for me. When The Doctor played the spoons (including Kate O'Mara's breasts as a percussive surface) I knew that the show was doomed.- The Doctor's companion, Mel (Melanie Bush, played by Bonnie Langford), is dreadful. Before producer John Nathan-Turner, Doctor Who had some truly great companions; after J N-T took control of "Doctor Who," he originated the most annoying and hated companions in the series. For example, compare Mel to Leela (a companion of the fourth Doctor): when confronted with a monster, Mel (like Peri before her) screams and screams and screams and screams; in contrast, Leela might turn to the Doctor and (with a gleam in her eye) says, "Doctor, we must make weapons and kill the beast!!!" In fact, Leela might just pull her knife and plunge it into the heart of the monster without saying a word.- The portrayal of The Rani was not as good as it was in "Mark of the Rani."- Horrible background music.- The question-marks on The Doctor's costume. This was an idiotic idea of producer John Nathan-Turner, started in the last season of the fourth doctor. J N-T is also responsible for dressing the sixth Doctor, Colin Baker, in that ridiculous clown suit.In summary, you should skip this story until you have seen the episodes for Doctors 1 through 5. With a few exceptions, the Sylvester McCoy years were rather bad in comparison. Even so, I am glad I got this DVD because I liked the Special Features.

This is my favorite flashlight. This flashlight is very bright; it is brighter than my car's low-beam headlights. The PD35 has five brightness settings, as well as a strobe setting. The setting is selected by pushing a switch on the side of the flashlight. The flashlight is turned on (and off) by pressing the pushbutton switch at the back end of the flashlight. I typically set the brightness at the third setting. This flashlight is impressively effective at supporting inspections of equipment in large industrial facilities, even at a distance.If you perform an Amazon search for "Fenix PD35," you can find several "package" deals where a PD35 flashlight has been bundled with batteries and battery chargers. The Fenix PD35 can also be purchased by itself (Fenix PD35 2014 Edition 960 Lumen CREE XM-L2 U2 LED Tactical Flashlight with holster, lanyard and Four EdisonBright CR123A Lithium Batteries).This bundle includes the following:- Fenix PD35 flashlight- Fenix ARE-C1 battery charger, which supports either AC or DC (e.g., car) charging- Fenix 2600 mAh ARB-L2 rechargable lithium-ion battery- Two CR123A lithium batteries- Belt holster for the flashlightI purchased two of these PD35 bundles. I now wish I had purchased the bundle that includes the 3400 mAh ARB-L2S battery, instead of the 2600 mAh ARB-L2 battery: Fenix PD35 2014 Edition 960 Lumen CREE XM-L2 U2 LED Tactical Flashlight, Fenix ARE-C1 two bays Li-ion battery charger, Fenix 18650 ARB-L2S 3400mAh rechargeable battery with Two EdisonBright CR123A Lithium BatteriesThere are also bundles that include the superior Fenix ARE-C2 charger. The ARB-L2 and ARB-L2S batteries are also sold separately (if you want spare batteries).The size and weight (3 ounces) are perfect for someone who will equip this flashlight (in its holster on a belt) in a work environment for hours and hours.IF YOU THINK YOUR PD35 IS DOA:I ordered two of these PD35 flashlight kits. Both flashlights (BOTH) appeared to be DOA (dead-on-arrival). For both flashlights, I inserted a fully-charged battery (voltage verified with a multimeter), pushed the button to turn it on, and nothing happened. I had decided to return the flashlights to Amazon for a refund when a friend made a suggestion that solved the problem. The cylindrical body of PD35 can be separated at two locations by unscrewing; this is how you open the flashlight to insert and remove the battery (or batteries). If your PD35 appears to be DOA, try completely unscrewing the flashlight at BOTH locations, then reassembling the flashlight. You may need to do this several times (five to ten times) to remove some of the coating material. During my initial efforts to get my new PD35s to work, I had unscrewed the connection at the rear end of the flashlight to insert the battery; however, I did not unscrew the second connection at its front end (since I did not know of its existence at the time). After unscrewing and reassembling both connections a few times, both flashlights worked. Dear Fenix, Please fix this problem.

The Audio Technica ATW-1501 is a professional-grade system that allows you to wirelessly connect your guitar to an amplifier. I am using it with electric and acoustic-electric guitars.WHAT'S IN THE BOX:- The transmitter (UniPak® body-pack transmitter): the digital transmitter that converts the electronic output of the guitar to a digital wireless signal. Has a sturdy clip that allows you to fasten the transmitter to a belt or the waist your clothing. It could also be placed in a pocket.- The receiver (in the form of a stompbox): the remote device that receives the digital wireless signal from the transmitter, decodes it, and converts it to an analog signal for your effects pedal(s) and guitar amplifier.- Connecting cable: has a standard 1/4-inch jack to plug into your guitar and a 4-pin UniPak® connector to plug into the bodypack transmitter.- Power supply (AC-to-DC converter) for receiver: 100-240 VAC (50/60 Hz) to 12 VDC 0.5A (center positive) switched-mode external power supply.- Two hook-and-loop fasteners to attach receiver to effects board.WHAT YOU WILL NEED TO PROVIDE:- Two AA batteries for transmitter.- A cable to connect the receiver to your amplifier or first effects-box (standard guitar-style cable with 1/4-inch jacks at both ends). I am using a sturdy cable intended to daisy-chain effects-boxes.Since the receiver uses standard 9 to 12 VDC power jack, it can be powered from a common effects-pedal board power supply, as long as the input is isolated.PROS:- It works! As far as I can hear, wireless performance is no different than on the cable.- Simple to setup and use. After unpacking the box, it took me less than five minutes to get the system operating. The most difficult part of the initial startup was figuring out how to turn on the transmitter (you need to push the button for several seconds to get it to turn on).- Digital instead of analog. No noticeable interference, static, distortion, clipping, or frequency changes. Audio Sampling: 24 bit / 48 kHz.- Two outputs (Output A and Output B). Using a slide-switch on the receiver you select how the stomp switch functions: (1) Switch between Output A and Output B; and (2) Mute/Unmute Output A. With the first option, you could switch your guitar between two different effects-chains or amp systems (for example, if switching between lead guitar and rhythm guitar). The second option (which I am using), allows me to connect my Peterson strobetuner to Output B and my Line 6 POD X3 Live multi-effects pedal (which goes to the guitar amp) to Output A. With this setup, pushing the stompbox switch mutes Output A (guitar signal to amp), while still allowing me to use the strobetuner. The default position of the switch is to Mute/Unmute Output A.- The receiver is designed to be mounted to a pedal (effects) board.- Long transmission range (up to 60 feet).- Metal construction for durability.- Excellent user manual. A printed manual comes with the product. You can download it in PDF format from the manufacturer's website (Audio-Technica dot com, search for "ATW-1501" or System 10 Stompbox).FACTS OF LIFE:- The receiver can be paired with up to eight transmitters. However, at the receiver, you can only select one transmitter (instrument) at a time. In other words, the receiver cannot receive the signal from more than one instrument simultaneously. From the Audio Technica website: "If you would like to use multiple transmitters with one receiver for the System 10 Stompbox, up to 8 transmitters can be paired with a single receiver, provided that each transmitter has a different System ID. However, only one transmitter can turned On at a time; all other transmitters must be turned OFF when not in use."- A special instrument cable (provided) is required to connect the transmitter to the guitar. For spare or replacement cables, search Amazon for "guitar transmitter cable" or go to your local guitar store. Audio Technica and Shure make such cables.- Battery life of the AA batteries in the transmitter is about 6 to 8 hours. You can use rechargeable batteries. There is a "Transmitter Battery Power" indicator on the stompbox receiver; also, the LED on the transmitter will flash if batteries are low. Keep plenty of spare batteries on hand. (And, of course, you should still carry an old-fashion cable or two.)- I did not change any settings on my equipment; however, do not be surprised if you feel the urge to make minor tweaks after switching from cable to wireless (similar to what you might do when changing cables or cable length).SETUPFor the receiver:- Place the stomp-box receiver where you want it.- Connect the receiver to your amp or first effects pedal with a standard guitar cable. In my case, the receiver's Output A is connected to the input of my Line 6 POD X3 Live, which (in turn) is connected to my guitar amp.- Plug the power supply into the receiver stompbox (use the little rubber grommet at the plug to help prevent damage to the plug).- Plug the power supply into an AC outlet. If outlet is switched, turn on outlet when ready.- You do NOT need to set channel number. The receiver and transmitter are already "paired" (right out of the box). If you want to change the "System ID" for the transmitter, or if you wish to "pair" additional transmitters to the receiver, instructions to do so are in the user manual.For the transmitter:- Insert two AA batteries.- Attach the provided cable to the transmitter.- Plug the transmitter's cable into your guitar. Hook the transmitter to your belt or clothing, or put it in your pocket.- Turn-on the transmitter by pressing the POWER/MUTE switch for a few seconds.- You do NOT need to set channel number. (See above.)The On/Off and Mute/Un-mute functions of the body-pack transmitter are accomplished with the same switch (POWER/MUTE switch). To minimize user errors, I would prefer two different switches: one for On/Off and the other for Mute/Un-mute. Also, I would like the On/Off function to be a slide switch that locks into position, instead of a switch that must be depressed for several seconds.MISCELLANEOUS:- The transmitter has both a high-impedance input for instruments and a low-impedance input with bias connection for use with dynamic and electret condenser microphones.- The receiver receives its DC power input from the provided AC-to-DC converter that plugs into a wall outlet. There is no On-Off switch on the receiver. As with all electronic equipment, you should probably unplug or switch off the power supply when the system is not in use.- The user manual states: "For best performance, some routers and Wi-Fi-based wireless systems may need to be up to 30 feet away . . . ." I have not noticed any interference problems; however, it might be a good practice to routinely verify performance (while moving around) during sound checks at a new location.- So far, I have had no problems with reception; however, if you encounter reception problems, try repositioning the transmitter (on your body) or the receiver so the antennas have a better line-of-sight between each other.

All in all, I am very happy with the performance of this Remington XR1350 shaver. This Remington product line also includes the XR1330 and XR1370 shavers. The XR1350 provides up to 50 minutes of shaving time per charge, while the XR1330 provides 40 minutes and the XR1370 provides 60 minutes. I charge this shaver approximately once per week.As with all electric shavers, the shave is not as close as a razor cut; but that is just the nature of these devices. I have been using Philips Norelco shavers for many years. Even when the shaver is new, or has had new blades installed, the Norelco shavers have performed disappointingly. This Remington shaver performs better than my Norelco shavers. Shaving takes less time and is closer; also, the cutting system is far less irritating to the skin. Shaving is improved by having the shaving heads pivot to allow them to follow the contours of the face. This shaver is also very quiet.The shaver is designed for "dry" or "wet" shaving. It can be used in the shower (which is why it has a charging stand, instead of a direct AC plug). The shaver's shape and texture make it very easy and secure to hold when wet. It can be used with a shaving gel.The cutters can be removed and rinsed under the faucet for cleaning.This shaver compares favorably to my Panasonic ES-LT71-S Arc3 Men's Electric Shaver Wet/Dry with Flexible Pivoting Head and Automatic Cleaning System. The Panasonic provides a closer shave (I give it a five-star rating), but it requires an added monthly expense for the cleaning-system supplies.The shaver charging stand features a "quick charge" mode that will give the shaver a partial charge in roughly five minutes, for three minutes of shaving. Hopefully, this would be sufficient to get you shaved and out the door.Check with your state, county, or city to find out if they have any restrictions on the disposal of lithium (LiFePO4) batteries. The "Use and Care Guide" provides instructions for removing the battery for disposal, if required.

This version of Windows 8.1 is for installation on a new computer (with no operating system installed) or on a computer that is NOT currently running Windows 8, Windows 7, Vista, or XP. This product is NOT for upgrading; if you are upgrading from a previous version of Windows, then get the upgrade package.This is the "Full" version of Windows 8.1: this means you can get technical support from Microsoft; it also means you may have the option (later on) to transfer the license to another computer. If you don't want/need technical support or the potential to transfer the license to a new computer, then look at the "OEM" version (Windows 8.1 System Builder OEM DVD 64-Bit). Perform a web search for: Windows 8.1 OEM license. According to Microsoft, if you are building a computer for personal use, then the "Full packaged retail product is needed."This is NOT the "Professional" version of Windows 8.1. Make sure you are selecting the version you need/want. To learn more, just perform a web search for: Differences between Windows 8.1 and Windows 8.1 Professional. Windows 8.1 Professional also comes in an "OEM" version and a "full" version: Windows 8.1 Pro System Builder OEM DVD 64-Bit and Microsoft Windows 8.1 Pro - Full Version.I just installed Windows 8.1 on a newly-constructed computer. It loaded very quickly (approximately 20 minutes). Loading Window Updates took roughly another 30 minutes. I gave Windows 8.1 a five-star rating because it is much faster and much more stable than the Windows 7 that I use every day on another computer. My Windows 7 machine crashes at least five times per week; in contrast, my Window 8 Professional machine and my Windows 8.1 machine have never crashed, frozen, or reset.I did have one mishap as I loaded software on my new Windows 8.1 machine. As I went to load an old version of Roxio, Windows 8.1 warned me that it was not compatible; but I loaded it anyway. Upon rebooting after that, Windows 8.1 was somehow compromised, and its Auto Repair function initiated a complete wipe and reload of Windows 8.1. Lesson learned: I will not attempt to load old software and hardware on my new Windows 8.1 machine.Windows 8.1 has many powerful features that were completely new to me. The easiest way to learn about these new features is to read a book (just search Amazon books for "Windows 8.1"). I liked Windows 8.1 Inside Out, but it is more in-depth than most people probably want.THE "DESKTOP" IS STILL THERE:A lot of folks I know HATE the new "Start" screen ("metro style") user interface. I spent several weeks learning how to use it; but in the end, I abandoned the Start" screen in favor of the (old familiar) "Desktop" app. So, to all you folks who hate the Start screen: Just use the Desktop instead. You can switch to the Desktop simply by pressing the key combination [WINDOWS key]+D. Or, as I did, you can setup Windows 8.1 to boot to the Desktop instead of the Start screen. Simply (1) go to Desktop; (2) move the cursor to a blank area of the Toolbar at the bottom of the screen; (3) right click and select "Properties"; (4) select the "Navigation" tab; (5) place a tick mark in the box next to "When I sign in or close all apps on a screen, go to the desktop instead of start."You can setup up your Windows 8.1 Desktop to be just like your old Windows 7 Desktop, except there won't be a Start button. (Quite frankly, those Microsoft folks made a huge mistake taking away the Start button.) On the Desktop, you can also setup the Tool Bar (Quick Start icons) and System Tray just like you did in previous versions of Windows. In short, you can make your Windows 8.1 look just like Windows 7, but the underlying operating system will be much quicker and a lot more stable.Speaking of the Start button; Windows 8.1 adds a modified Start button of sorts (a Windows-Flag) at the lower left-hand edge of the Desktop toolbar. If you left-click on it, it opens the "Start" screen (the same effect as pressing the Windows key on your keyboard); if you right-click on it, it opens the "Power User" menu (the same effect as pressing Windows Key plus X simultaneously). Once on the "Start" screen, if you click on the little arrow at the bottom left, you will get a listing of your programs/apps.I found it helpful to add the following icons to my Windows 8.1 Desktop: Computer (formerly "My Computer"), Control Panel, and Network. To do this, right click on any clear area of the desktop and select the Personalize option. In the left pane of the Personalize window, click Change desktop icons. Tick the boxes for the icons you want displayed on the desktop (Computer, Control Panel, Recycle Bin, User's Files, Network). Click the Apply button.I have read that "Windows 8.1 Update 1" will boot computers without touchscreens to the desktop by default and will use desktop apps by default. Of course, Microsoft (OBVIOUSLY) should have had this feature in the original Windows 8.That's enough about how to set up the Desktop. Once you get Windows 8.1 working on the Desktop app, take some time to learn how to use the new "metro-style" user interface. On my dual monitor system, I have the Desktop on my center monitor and the "Start" screen (TileWorld) on the side monitor. You should probably get a book to help you customize the Start screen by learning how to add (pin), delete (unpin), resize, move, and group tiles. I think most non-business users will prefer the new Start screen interface.WINDOWS 8.1 IS EASY - BUT ONLY AFTER AN HOUR OR SO OF TRAINING:Let me just say: Microsoft made a huge mistake by not including a very simple and obvious tick-box to provide users with the option to "Use Classic Windows." Now, it only takes about 10 minutes to get Windows 8.1 to look and function just like Windows 7; but that's 9.5 minutes longer than it should take!It takes some effort for the new user to learn how to setup Windows 8.1; but after you get it setup, your Window 8.1 machine will be very easy to use (you won't even think about it). You should probably get a friend, grandchild, or book to help you on your first day. Just about everybody should get some Windows 8.1 training, even if that training is nothing more than watching some youtube videos. Obviously, Microsoft should have produced some videos (maybe eight 5-minute videos) to orient the new user! The user interface is so different most folks will get angry with it if no one has explained it to them first. You see, very little is obvious or intuitive; all of the menus are initially hidden, and there is no clue as to how to display them. But don't get angry! Just spend a short time (less than an hour) learning some basic Windows 8.1 tricks and secrets. When I built my new gaming computer fifteen months ago, I read the book Windows 8 Secrets in its entirety before loading the operating system. It's a good thing I did, otherwise I would have been lost (and, yes, probably angry). Luckily for new users, lots of nice people have posted some great youtube videos that can potentially teach you most of what you need to know. You could also go down to your local computer store and play with Windows 8.1.You can save yourself a lot of (first-day) anger and frustration by immediately configuring Windows 8.1 to use the Desktop user-interface instead of the new Metro-style user-interface (per the instructions above). Do this immediately after your computer boots to Windows 8.1 for the first time. If you do, you'll find yourself in a (relatively stress-free) familiar environment . . . something that looks and behaves just like Windows 7, but without the "Start" button. Other than that, printout and use the Windows-Key shortcuts discussed below (especially Winkey+C and Winkey+I).WINDOWS-KEY SHORTCUTS MAKE LIFE EASY:Memorize and use the "Windows Key" (Winkey) keyboard shortcuts! (The Winkey is the key on the bottom row with a depiction the Microsoft flag; my Winkey is just to the right of the CTRL key.) For example, if you hold down the Winkey and press C, the "Charms" bar will be displayed. The "Charms" bar is perhaps the most important interface in Windows 8.1. If you learn the Winkey keyboard shortcuts first thing, you will be able to get most things done in Windows 8.1 right away!Helpful Winkey keyboard shortcuts:Winkey: toggles between Start Menu and last appWinkey + D: opens DesktopWinkey + C: opens "Charms" barWinkey + E: opens file explorerWinkey + F or Winkey + W: searches for filesWinkey + I: opens the Settings charm (to shut down your computer, for example)Winkey + Z: opens "app bar" (the menu user interface that is normally hidden when interacting with a Windows 8 app)Winkey + X: opens the "power user" menu (which includes programs and features, power options, event viewer, system, device manager, network connections, disk management, computer management, command prompt, task manager, control panel, file explorer, search, run, shutdown or signoff, and desktop)Winkey + R: opens run-program window (like when you used to go to Start, Run)LESSONS LEARNED ABOUT WINDOWS ACTIVATION:Windows 8.1 activated over the internet just fine. I had read that Windows 8.1 activation was tied to the specific motherboard; but, apparently, Windows 8.1 loses its activation if you change the memory or hard drive. When I changed out the memory modules (for larger capacity), Windows gave me a message that I would need to re-activate within three days. When I decided that I wanted a larger hard drive in this new machine, I cloned the smaller drive to the larger drive; in the process, Windows activation was lost on the larger drive. Lesson learned: Your life will be easier if you finalize your hardware installation BEFORE you activate Windows 8.1.LOCAL ACCOUNT VERSUS MICROSOFT ACCOUNTYou can setup Windows 8.1 user accounts to be either a "local account" or a Microsoft account. Just perform a little web research for: Difference between local account and Microsoft account. There are pros and cons associated with each option.Quite annoyingly, it is NOT obvious how to choose "local account" during the installation of Windows 8.1. Understandably, some folks are angry because they feel that Microsoft is FORCING their new Windows 8.1 machine to be linked a Microsoft account. Actually, it is simple (but not at all obvious) to setup Windows 8.1 with a "local account" (so the operating system is not linked to Microsoft).During installation of Windows 8.1, when you get to the "Sign in to your Microsoft account" screen, don't enter the log-in information (account and password), instead: (1) at the bottom of the screen click "Create a new account"; (2) on the resulting "Create a Microsoft Account" screen, just skip over all of the empty fields and select "Sign in without a Microsoft Account"; (3) on the resulting "Your Account" screen, setup your "local account" user name and password.To switch from a Microsoft account to a "local account": (1) Get to the "Start" screen (toggle Windows key); (2) type "Users"; (3) select "Add, delete, or manage other user accounts"; (4) on the resulting "Accounts" screen, select "Your Account"; (5) select the "Disconnect" option and then setup your "local account" user name and password. To switch from a "local account" to a Microsoft account, perform Steps 1 through 4, then at Step 5 select "Connect to a Microsoft account."You can also setup Windows 8.1 to use a four-digit PIN.

I really appreciate this product. I used it to make a backup drive for my laptop computer. Cloning was surprisingly quick. The newly cloned hard drive booted the computer and everything worked just fine. I next used the product to clone a (jam-packed) desktop drive to a larger hard drive. Again, everything worked great. This product is unbelievably easy to use. A recommendation: Read the product manual before you clone.MICROSOFT DE-ACTIVATION:I discovered that a new hard drive causes Windows 8.1 and Microsoft Office to become deactivated ("activated" status might be lost on the cloned drive). Your Microsoft products might re-activate over the internet; but you might need to call Microsoft (and convince a real person) to re-activate Windows or Office. This deactivation is NOT a fault in the Apricorn software; it is a function of the Microsoft software detecting that the drive has been changed. By the way, Windows 8.1 also deactivated itself when I added more memory to my computer.YOU MAY NEED TO RE-LOAD DRIVERS:After I installed the cloned drive, the computer's LAN connection did not work until I reloaded the motherboard's LAN driver. You might want to have a flash drive loaded with your computer's drivers (at least the LAN and/or Wi-Fi driver) before you clone.A FEW TIPS AND HINTS:Before you clone, backup your important files to an external hard drive, a flash drive, a network drive, cloud drive, DVDs, etc. (Just in case something goes wrong.)You can download the product manual from the Apricorn website (as a PDF file). It is really worth the time and effort to read through the manual first.On the Apricorn webpage for the kit, you can find some troubleshooting tips (frequently asked questions).You can also download the latest version of the cloning software (EZ GIG IV) as:(1) The Windows-based program to load on your computer, and(2) A disc image (ISO) file that you can burn to CD to produce a bootable disc ("burn to CD," not copy to CD).I chose to boot the computer to the Apricorn CD. To do this, you may need to go into your computer's BIOS to set it to boot from CD.The Apricorn software won't work unless it senses the Apricorn "SATA Wire" adapter.This product will make an exact (sector-by-sector) copy of your hard drive. Therefore, it would be good if you did two things before you clone:(1) Instruct Windows to perform a "disk check" of the hard drive to be cloned(2) Defrag (or "optimize") the hard drive to be clonedBefore you start cloning, you need to instruct windows:(1) Never go to sleep (never hibernate)(2) Never turn screen off (turn off screen saver)Don't use the full-auto cloning option unless both the "Source" drive and the "Destination" drive are exactly the same size. If they are NOT the same size, I would recommend that you enter the manual setup ("Advanced Options") part of the software to set the desired partition sizes. For example, if you are going to clone to a larger drive, you'll want to enter "Advanced Options" to specify the size of each partition. You can also specify files and folders to omit from the cloning.The instructions state that you should connect the new hard drive to the "SATA Wire" adapter. Actually, the cloning software will work no matter which drive (old or new) is connected to the "SATA Wire" adapter and which is in the computer. You will identify which drive is the "Source" (old) drive and which is the "Destination" (new) drive in the software.CLONING 3.5-INCH DRIVESThis product is specifically designed to be connected to a 2.5-inch drive; however, it is possible to use it to clone a 3.5-inch drive.You can easily clone a 3.5-inch drive to a 2.5-inch drive (or vice versus) by attaching the 2.5-inch drive to the "SATA Wire" socket and having the 3.5-inch drive installed in the computer. In this case, you just instruct the software that the 3.5-inch drive is the source and the 2.5-inch drive is the destination (or vice versus).To clone a 3.5-inch drive to another 3.5 inch drive requires an adapter cable to connect the 3.5-inch drive's data port to the data socket on the Apricorn "SATA wire" adapter. Also, you must provide power to the 3.5-inch drive to be cloned (since the 12 VDC it needs cannot be supplied via a USB cable). You can do this in one of two ways: (1) with your computer unplugged, you can connect one of your computer's SATA power supply connectors to the drive; or (2) you can connect a SATA power supply from a kit like the SABRENT USB 3.0 TO SATA/IDE 2.5/3.5/5.25-INCH Hard Drive Converter With Power Supply & LED Activity Lights (USB-DSC8).  I used the NSI LK-13526 7-pin internal SATA Male to SATA Female Extension cable - 7 pin SATA M/F - 20 inch (50 cm) to connect the Apricorn "SATA wire" adapter to the 3.5-inch drive's data port. To make this work, I had to snip off the hard plastic locking pieces on either side of the male end of the connector.You can also use the Apricorn "SATA Wire" adapter (without the software) to read and write to 2.5 inch (notebook-sized) hard drives via a USB connection. That means, you can use this device to recover data off of an old hard drive. Just connect the drive to the adapter, plug the adapter into a USB port, and use file manager to copy files.

I recently built a new home-office computer with the G2030 Pentium processor and the following:- ASUS P8H77-M/CSM LGA 1155 Intel H77 HDMI SATA 6Gb/s USB 3.0 Micro ATX Intel Motherboard- Corsair Obsidian Series 350D Performance Micro ATX Computer Case with Windowed Side Panel CC-9011029-WW - Black- Corsair RM Series 650 Watt ATX/EPS 80PLUS Gold-Certified Power Supply - CP-9020054-NA RM650- Corsair XMS3 4 GB 1333MHz PC3-10666 240-pin DDR3 Memory Kit for  Core i3 i5 i7 and  CMX4GX3M1A1333C9- HGST Travelstar 2.5 Inch 500GB 7200 RPM SATA II 16 MB Cache Internal Hard Drive (0S02858)- LG Electronics DVD- No video card (I am using the on-board video)As you can probably tell from this list, I was trying to build a very "cheap" computer. The total cost, not including the operating system, was 500 dollars. If I had used an i5 processor, it would have raised the price of this build by approximately 130 dollars. Obviously then, you can save a lot of money by purchasing the least expensive processor that will still get the job done.This new computer is replacing a nine-year-old office computer. It will not be used for games; instead it will be used for professional and academic software such as Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Access, Project, Photoshop, drawing programs, math and statistics programs, system models, and proprietary science and engineering programs. For these applications, this Pentium processor works fine. For a gaming computer, I would recommend an Intel i5 processor instead of this Pentium. For video editing or animation you might be better off with an i7 processor.Since this computer will not be used for games, I did not install a video card; instead I am taking advantage of the integrated video processor in this Pentium. The on-board video is fine.CPU Cooling:To save money, I used Intel's "stock" cooler assembly that was included with the Pentium processor. My other home-built machines use Corsair H100 CPU coolers (forced liquid flow coolers). Based on temperature readings, Intel's "stock" cooler seems to work just fine (100 dollars saved!).This was the first time I ever installed the "stock" cooler. I am very glad that I watched some youtube videos before I tried it myself; it can be just a little bit tricky if you've never done it before.You might want to consider getting a tube of "thermal compound" (Arctic Silver 5 Thermal Compound 3.5 Grams) just in case you don't succeed on your first attempt to install the cooler. The cooler comes with thermal compound already applied; but if the installation goes wrong, you'll need to remove the compound and reapply a small amount of fresh compound. The thermal compound improves heat transfer at the point where the CPU contacts the bottom cooler plate. Luckily I got the cooler installed okay on the first attempt; but I had a tube of thermal compound just in case.

The "System Builder" version of Windows 8.1 is for installation on a new computer (with no operating system installed) or on a computer that is NOT currently running Windows 8, Windows 7, Vista, or XP. This product ("System Builder") is NOT for upgrading; if you are upgrading from a previous version of Windows, then get the upgrade package.This is the "OEM" version of Windows 8.1. Perform a web search for: Windows 8.1 OEM license. According to Microsoft, if you are building a computer for personal use, then the "Full packaged retail product is needed." With the OEM version, you cannot get technical support from Microsoft; also, you can activate it on one and only one computer (the license is linked to the hardware). If you want technical support and/or the potential to transfer the license to a new computer, then look at the "full" version (Microsoft Windows 8.1 - Full Version).This is NOT the "Professional" version of Windows 8.1. Make sure you are selecting the version you need/want. To learn more, just perform a web search for: Differences between Windows 8.1 and Windows 8.1 Professional. Windows 8.1 Professional also comes in an "OEM" version and a "full" version: Windows 8.1 Pro System Builder OEM DVD 64-Bit and Microsoft Windows 8.1 Pro - Full Version.I just installed Windows 8.1 System Builder on a newly-constructed computer. It loaded very quickly (approximately 20 minutes). Loading Window Updates took roughly another 30 minutes. I gave Windows 8.1 a five-star rating because it is much faster and much more stable than the Windows 7 that I use every day on another computer. My Windows 7 machine crashes at least five times per week; in contrast, my Window 8.1 Professional machine and my Windows 8.1 machine have never crashed, frozen, or reset.I did have one mishap as I loaded software on my new Windows 8.1 machine. As I went to load an old version of Roxio, Windows 8.1 warned me that it was not compatible; but I loaded it anyway. Upon rebooting after that, Windows 8.1 was somehow compromised, and its Auto Repair function initiated a complete wipe and reload of Windows 8.1. Lesson learned: I will not attempt to load old software and hardware on my new Windows 8.1 machine.Windows 8.1 has many powerful features that were completely new to me. The easiest way to learn about these new features is to read a book (just search Amazon books for "Windows 8.1"). I liked Windows 8.1 Inside Out, but it is more in-depth than most people probably want.THE "DESKTOP" IS STILL THERE:A lot of folks I know HATE the new "Start" screen ("metro style") user interface. I spent several weeks learning how to use it; but in the end, I abandoned the Start" screen in favor of the (old familiar) "Desktop" app. So, to all you folks who hate the Start screen: Just use the Desktop instead. You can switch to the Desktop simply by pressing the key combination [WINDOWS key]+D. Or, as I did, you can setup Windows 8.1 to boot to the Desktop instead of the Start screen. Simply (1) go to Desktop; (2) move the cursor to a blank area of the Toolbar at the bottom of the screen; (3) right click and select "Properties"; (4) select the "Navigation" tab; (5) place a tick mark in the box next to "When I sign in or close all apps on a screen, go to the desktop instead of start."You can setup up your Windows 8.1 Desktop to be just like your old Windows 7 Desktop, except there won't be a Start button. (Quite frankly, those Microsoft folks made a huge mistake taking away the Start button.) On the Desktop, you can also setup the Tool Bar (Quick Start icons) and System Tray just like you did in previous versions of Windows. In short, you can make your Windows 8.1 look just like Windows 7, but the underlying operating system will be much quicker and a lot more stable.Speaking of the Start button; Windows 8.1 adds a modified Start button of sorts (a Windows-Flag) at the lower left-hand edge of the Desktop toolbar. If you left-click on it, it opens the "Start" screen (the same effect as pressing the Windows key on your keyboard); if you right-click on it, it opens the "Power User" menu (the same effect as pressing Windows Key plus X simultaneously). Once on the "Start" screen, if you click on the little arrow at the bottom left, you will get a listing of your programs/apps (essentially providing the functions of the old Start Button, and more).I found it helpful to add the following icons to my Windows 8.1 Desktop: Computer (formerly "My Computer"), Control Panel, and Network. To do this, right click on any clear area of the desktop and select the Personalize option. In the left pane of the Personalize window, click Change desktop icons. Tick the boxes for the icons you want displayed on the desktop (Computer, Control Panel, Recycle Bin, User's Files, Network). This is a review of the NOCO Genius G750 6V/12V 0.75 Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer.I have many 12 volt batteries in the 20 amp-hour (Ah) range that require periodic charging so they will always be ready when needed. Having recently had good experiences using the NOCO GENM1 battery charger, I was curious to try NOCO's lighter-duty chargers/maintainers. For the past few years, I have been using Battery Tender products (which are also five-star products).I am completely satisfied with the performance of the NOCO G750. It is certainly the equal of my Battery Tender 021-0123 Battery Tender Junior 12V Battery Charger.You should definitely read the User Manual before using this charger. The User's Manual that comes with this product has very, very tiny print; luckily an easier-to-read User's Manual can easily be found online (in PDF format).If you are looking for a higher-capacity charger, check out NOCO Genius G1100 6V/12V 1.1 Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer. Between the NOCO G750, the NOCO G1100, and the Battery Tender Junior, I would recommend the NOCO G1100 due to (1) its higher charging current (quicker charge); (2) better indications; and (3) additional charging options (e.g., the G1100 has a specific charging mode for AGM batteries). However, the G750 would be perfect for smaller lead-acid batteries (like a lawnmower battery, for example). I use the NOCO Genius G3500 6V/12V 3.5 Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer for the battery in my car.For a 4-amp, waterproof charger check out:- NOCO GENM1 GEN Mini 4 Amp 1-Bank Waterproof Smart On-Board Battery ChargerThe G750 is suitable for all types of 6 volt or 12 volt lead-acid batteries, including wet (flooded), gel, MF (maintenance-free) and AGM (absorption glass mat) batteries.The NOCO Genius G750 is a 0.75-amp "smart" charger. However, it is not fully automated; you have to initially use the MODE button to select one of two "Charge Modes" (6 V or 12 V). So far, I have only used the "12 V" mode.The NOCO G750 charger/maintainer comes with two sets of quick disconnect cables that allow connection of the charger via: (1) wires with ring terminals or (2) wires terminated with battery clamp connectors (see the product photos). You can purchase additional quick-disconnect connectors (NOCO Genius GC002 Eyelet Terminal Connector). This makes charging multiple batteries with a single charger easy; you simply leave a quick-disconnect eye-terminal connector attached to each battery, then move the charger from battery to battery. The positive charging wire has an inline fuse (10 amp automotive blade fuse) close to the battery-side termination. Also check out NOCO Genius GC003 12V Plug Connector.The G750 can charge battery sizes from 1.2 to 30 amp-hours. In contrast, the G1100 is rated for battery sizes from 2.2 to 40 amp-hours, while the GENM1 charger is rated for battery sizes from 20 to 120 amp-hours. The NOCO G750 takes roughly twice as long to charge a battery as the NOCO G1100, and roughly nine times as long as the NOCO GENM1. The NOCO G750 would be perfect for those smaller (1.2 to 10 amp-hour), non-AGM batteries; personally, I would select the G1100 to charge batteries greater than 10 amp-hours.A charging times comparison is provided below:-  30 Ah battery: 33 hours with G750; 18 hours with G1100; 3.7 hours with GENM1The G750 can charge batteries larger than 30 amp-hours, it will just take longer. The charger will go into an ERROR condition if it is in "Bulk" charging mode for greater than 120 hours.The G1100 converts an input of 85 to 130 volts AC (alternating current) to a DC (direct current) output suitable for charging a 12 volt lead-acid battery. The charger controls DC output during a seven-step charging cycle, with a peak voltage of 14.4 volts DC in "12 V" mode (or 7.2 volts for the "6 V" mode).The G1100 weighs only 0.5 pounds. Its dimensions are 4.5 x 2.7 x 1.3 inches. Unlike the NOCO G1100 and GENM1, the G750 has no AC power cord (i.e., the AC plug is an integral part of the charger's body). You can use an extension cord with this charger; there is a table in the User Manual to determine the minimum AWG size of the extension cable.  NOCO includes the exact same table in the User Manuals of several different charger models; instead, the User Manual for each charger should explicitly state the requirement for that specific charger.The charging process (from the NOCO user's manual):- The battery charger will begin in the STANDBY mode, indicated by a GREEN LED. In the STANDBY mode, the battery charger has no current output.- The user starts the charging process by pressing the MODE button to toggle to the appropriate charge mode (6 V or 12 V). Upon selecting the charging mode (6 V or 12 V), a RED LED will light the selected charge mode and the CHARGE LED (Red) will light indicating the charging process has started.- When the battery is fully charged, the CHARGE LED will change from RED to GREEN, indicating the charge process is complete.- The battery charger can be left connected to the battery at all times to provide maintenance charging. However, it is good practice to check the battery periodically.The five-step charging cycle (from the NOCO user's manual):Step 1 (Diagnostics): Checks the battery voltage to make sure battery connections are good and the battery is in a stable condition before beginning the charging process.Step 2 (Soft Start): Begins Bulk charging process with a gentle (soft) charge.Step 3 (Bulk): Continues Bulk charging process to 90% of battery capacity.Step 4 (Absorption): Brings the charge level to 100%. The battery charger will deliver small amounts of current to provide a safe, efficient charge and limit battery gassing.Step 5 (Maintenance): Continuously monitors the battery voltage to determine if a maintenance charge should be initiated. If the terminal voltage falls below 12.8 volts (or 6.4 volts for a 6 volt battery), the charger will start the Maintenance cycle until voltage reaches 14.4 volts (or 7.2 volts for a 6 volt battery) and then discontinues the charge cycle. Maintenance cycle is repeated indefinitely to keep the battery at full charge, without overcharging. The battery charger can be left connected indefinitely.

I have a wide selection of batteries and associated battery chargers. For small chargers, I have been using the "Battery Tender" line of products (I particularly appreciate the quick disconnects that are available for the Battery Tender chargers). I wanted to try this NOCO GENM1 4-amp charger because: (1) it is specifically designed to be mounted, and (2) it is supposed to be waterproof (not just water resistant) and spark-proof.If you want a charger with battery terminal clips, this is NOT the charger for you. This charger is specifically designed for spark-free operation; therefore, there is no ability to connect and disconnect energized leads (which could cause a spark). If you want terminal clips, check out these other NOCO chargers:- NOCO Genius G750 6V/12V 750mA Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer- NOCO Genius G1100 6V/12V 1.1 Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer- NOCO Genius G3500 6V/12V 3.5 Amp Smart Battery Charger and Maintainer- NOCO Genius G7200 12V/24V 7.2 Amp Smart Battery Charger and MaintainerIt really helps to read the instructions and safety precautions for this charger. The supplied user manual is difficult to read due to very tiny print. The product manuals for most NOCO products are pretty easy to find online in PDF format. For the GENM1, perform a web search for NOCO Gen Mini User Guide (it helps to limit the search to the geniuschargers website).The NOCO GENM1 is a 4-amp "smart" charger (i.e., it is fully automated). Therefore, you can leave this charger continuously plugged-in without any worry of overcharging your battery. For example, you can leave your boat or RV unattended for weeks or months with the charger in continuous operation. Up until now, I have been manually charging low-use batteries every one or two months; this fully automatic charger is much more convenient.NOCO states that the GENM1 is suitable for all types of 12 volt lead-acid batteries, including wet (flooded), gel, MF (maintenance-free) and AGM (absorption glass mat) batteries.The NOCO model GENM1 is for one battery bank, while the model GENM2 is for two battery banks (i.e., the GENM2 model has two sets of charging leads). The GENM1 and GENM2 are rated at 4 amps (charging current) per bank. If you have a boat with a 12 VDC starting battery and a 12 VDC trolling motor battery, you might wish to consider the NOCO GENM2 or the NOCO GEN2.The NOCO GENM1 charger is the "mini" version of the NOCO GEN1 charger (the word "mini" is even printed on the charger face). If you want a charging current greater than 4 amps per bank, check out NOCO's line of 10-amp chargers:- NOCO Genius GEN1 12V 1-Bank 10 Amp Smart On-Board Waterproof Battery Charger- NOCO Genius GEN2 12V+12V 2-Bank 20 Amp Smart On-Board Waterproof Battery Charger- NOCO Genius GEN3 12V+12V+12V 3-Bank 30 Amp Smart On-Board Waterproof Battery Charger- NOCO Genius GEN4 12V+12V+12V+12V 4-Bank 40 Amp Smart On-Board Waterproof Battery ChargerAs alternatives, check out:- Battery Tender 022-0157-1 Waterproof 12 Volt Power Tender Plus Battery Charger.- MinnKota MK 210D On-Board Battery Charger (2 Banks, 5 amps per bank)The GENM1 charger can be used on battery sizes from 20 to 120 amp-hours. In contrast, the NOCO Genius GEN1 12V 1-Bank 10 Amp Smart On-Board Waterproof Battery Charger is rated for battery sizes from 25 to 230 amp-hours. The GENM1 takes approximately twice as long to charge a battery as the GEN1. For my applications (maintaining low-use batteries), this is not a concern.A charging times comparison is provided below:-  30 Ah battery: 3.7 hours with GENM1; 1.9 hours with GEN1-  50 Ah battery: 6.2 hours with GENM1; 3.1 hours with GEN1- 100 Ah battery: 12.5 hours with GENM1; 6.3 hours with GEN1- 120 Ah battery: 15.0 hours with GENM1; 7.5 hours with GEN1The GENM1 can charge batteries larger than 120 amp-hours, it will just take longer. The charger will go into an ERROR condition if it is in "Bulk" charging mode for greater than 80 hours.The GENM1 converts an input of 70 to 130 volts AC (alternating current) to a DC (direct current) output suitable for charging a 12 volt lead-acid battery. The charger automatically controls DC output during an eight-step charging cycle, with a peak voltage of 14.4 volts DC. You should probably verify that this is an appropriate charging voltage for your specific battery. For example, some gel batteries have a recommended charging voltage of 14.4 VDC, while others recommend 14.1 VDC. Similarly, some batteries might recommend 14.7 VDC.The GENM1 is designed for permanent installation (e.g., in a boat, RV, or truck). It is very easy to install, although I can imagine installations that could be challenging due to difficulty in routing wires, locating a mounting position, or in having insufficient wire length. It meets ISO 8846 Marine standards and is ignition protected (US Coast Guard 33 CFR 183.410).The GENM1 does NOT come with quick disconnects. I suspect NOCO wanted an unbroken connection between the GENM1 charger and the battery terminations to reduce the possibility of sparking (which would be really, really, really bad around engine fuel or hydrogen in a boat). For models with quick disconnects, check out the previously mentioned G750, G1100, G3500, or G7200 NOCO chargers.The GENM1 comes with four 1-inch Philips-head screws to mount the unit. It might be advisable to use stainless steel screws (or bolts) for mounting, with silicone sealer to waterproof the screw holes. The charger weighs 3.3 pounds, so make sure to connect it to a sturdy surface. Its dimensions are 6.6 x 2.2 x 3.8 inches. The AC cord is 6 feet in length. The two DC output leads that connect to the battery are 6.3 feet long (NOCO recommends allowing 1 foot of "slack" in the charging wires). For a simple "shore power" connection, check out NOCO Genius GCP1 Black 13 Amp 125V AC Port Plug.The charging wires come with eye terminals for connecting to the battery: the eye terminals have an inside diameter of 1 centimeter (a little more than 3/8 inch). If need be, you can find battery terminal adapters such as Shoreline Marine Battery Marine Terminal Kit (Red/Black). The positive charging wire has an inline fuse (15 amp automotive blade fuse) close to the eye terminal (i.e., close to the battery-side of the connection, where it is supposed to be).The GENM1 charger has only two indications: (1) a CHARGE LED (which can light either green or red), and (2) an ERROR LED (which lights orange).- When the battery is charging, the CHARGE LED will light red. This LED will remain a solid red color (not blinking) until the battery is fully charged.- When the battery is fully charged, the CHARGE LED will light green. This LED will remain solid green (not blinking) until either the battery charger is disconnected or the battery becomes discharged.- If a reverse polarity condition exists, the orange ERROR LED will light.- If an "Error" condition exists, both LEDs will flash. There are several reasons an "Error" condition could exist; for help troubleshooting "Error" conditions, see the TROBLESHOOTING section of the user manual.When you connect this charger to a battery, the AC power connection is unplugged (as a very important electrical safety precaution). Therefore, the charger has been designed to light the ERROR LED for a reverse-polarity condition even when the unit is connected to a battery with the AC power disconnected.So far I have used this charger to charge three lead-acid batteries of various sizes with no problems. I really appreciate the fact that this charger is fully automatic. The charger has now been permanently installed. I have not yet had the chance to see how this charger operates unattended for months and months.

This is a review of "Be Dangerous On Rock Guitar" by Richard Daniels.I purchased this great guitar course in the late 1980s directly from The Heavy Guitar Company (they now have a website). At the time, I also ordered the associated (six) cassette tapes, the "Be Dangerous Wall Poster," and the "helpful fretboard dots." The large wall poster illustrated the guitar fretboard, showing the pentatonic scale patterns and associated "blue" notes (I had the poster mounted on hard board at a framing shop). The fretboard dots (an inspired idea) could be applied to the fretboard at the locations of the scale pattern notes to help the aspiring rocker learn the pentatonic and blue scales. To be clear: The cassette tapes, the poster, and the fretboard dots are NOT included with this books; they had to be ordered separately (I don't know if you can still get them, or not).This course came out in 1984 (I think). At the time, it was one of the few courses available on rock guitar. I certainly learned quite a lot from this course (back in the day). Richard Daniels did an excellent job explaining, organizing, and illustrating concepts from music theory directly applicable to rock guitar. I am extremely impressed with this book: I'm doubly impressed that it was written and illustrated by just one guy. His explanations of scales and intervals are the most accurate I have read in any consumer music book. Richard Daniels, you did a great job!This was a great course back in the 1980s. These days, some thirty years later, there's a lot more at-home training available for guitarists, including books, DVD courses, and internet videos. Even with all of these new and wonderful training materials, Richard Daniels' book still does a better job teaching some subject matter. Therefore, even if you are a veteran rocker, you might learn some new and interesting guitar concepts by reading this book. If you are a beginner looking for just one at-home guitar instruction program, I recommend John McCarthy, Learn Rock Guitar Mega Pack. For a book on basic music theory, I recommend The Complete Idiot's Guide to Music Theory, 2nd Edition. However, no matter what other method you chose to initially learn rock guitar (including a guitar teacher), you should eventually add "Be Dangerous On Rock Guitar" to your music library to bump your knowledge and skills up a notch.This product does not include the original cassette audio tapes. If you are interested in acquiring these tapes, maybe you can get them from The Heavy Guitar Company (I don't know). Quite frankly, I had some issues with the cassette tapes. Richard Daniels chose to make the tapes with very wild sound effects: I suppose he thought guitarists would find it amusing and interesting. I found such effects to be distracting: I would like to see new audio tapes produced in MP3 format in a more straight-forward (less weird) manner. I converted the tapes to MP3 files which I play through the guitar amp with an iPod.Here are some of the topics touched upon in this book:- The characteristics of sound (frequency; wavelength; frequencies of the six open strings; intensity; the envelope curve; protamento; vibrato; timbre).- Theory of the major scale (the tonic, octaves; the monochord; the dominant; harmonics; the mediant; just intonation; equal temperament; tuning the guitar so it can play all keys).- The great staff, intervals, consonance and dissonance, triads, other combinations (major, minor, dominant 7th, major 7th, minor 7th, augmented, diminished, major 6th, minor 6th, 9th, 11th, major add 9, minor 9th, major 6/9th), inversion, range, time, form, definitions.- Chromatic scale, fingering principles.- Scales (E major scale, A major scale).- Chords (theory of chord construction; major triads; CAGED movable chord forms; complex chords; chord charts).- Rock structure and the chords of rock (4/4 beat; how to very easily determine the guitar chords to use in any key using the fretboard; the turnaround).- The blues scale (universal blues fingering patterns).- Octaves on the guitar.- String techniques (bending, pulling, hammering, slide, vibrato).- The relative scale (the relative scale sound; three part circle - major, blues, relative).- Enhancing blues scale with filler notes.- Primary lead guitar patterns in E and A.- Lead runs.- Rock's two primary chords - E and A.- Notes in and around the open D, G, and C chords.- Position and use of sixth and seventh.- Inversions of the suspended fourth chord.- Inversions of the augmented ninth chord.- Position, cause and effect of power chords.- Position and use of harmonic overtones.- Fretboard positions used in rock.- Guitar tricks (the tip off; hammer on; wild bends; right hand on board; open string harmonics; artificial harmonics; hammer on fret harmonics; running harmonics; bent or slide harmonics; tri-pack technique; string rake; against the stand; rapid picking; hit back; the power slide; creative wa bar technique; chuga; pinky pull offs).- Deciphering recordings.- 40 great rock passages.I would love to see Richard Daniels (perhaps in partnership with "Rock House") produce a set of modern instructional DVDs to go along with this book.Thanks to Richard Daniels for this book! I learned more about rock guitar from this book than from any other source. My copy has been used so much it is falling apart; I suppose it is time to buy a new one.

This is a review of "Learn & Master Fingerstyle Guitar" with Steve Krenz.This DVD-based training program is produced by the same folks (Legacy Learning) who publish the popular "Learn & Master Guitar" course. Both courses feature Steve Krenz. He is a very effective guitar teacher; he obviously has many years of experience teaching students of all ages, interests, and abilities. See the Legacy Learn & Master Guitar website for more details about their various courses.With guitar lessons from a guitar teacher costing between 40 and 120 dollars per hour, this course is quite a bargain. Many years ago, I once spent a year with a guitar teacher going through Mel Bay Guitar Melody Chord Playing System. That year of instruction cost 1,500 dollars (not adjusting for inflation). While I felt the cost was worth it, I am very happy that much cheaper DVD courses are now available as an alternative."Fingerstyle" is a technique of playing the guitar by plucking the strings directly with the fingertips, fingernails, or picks attached to the fingers, as opposed to "flatpicking" which involves plucking the guitar strings with a single pick. When playing "fingerstyle," the thumb typically maintains a rhythm (usually playing alternating bass notes on the lower three strings) while the remaining fingers pick out the remaining chord notes (or a melody) on the higher strings."Learn & Master Fingerstyle Guitar" with Steve Krenz would probably be best for someone who is new to "fingerstyle" guitar. Even if you are not a beginner, you might benefit from this course; completing the lessons (including the "advanced workshops") could potentially fill in gaps in your prior education and experience. Also, if you are a guitar teacher, going through this course might give you ideas that could improve your instruction of this material. Actually, I am a little disappointed that they did not add three more lessons (DVDs) to this course to raise the level of instruction (and playing) just a little.This is a thoroughly professional product: the training is well designed, the video and audio are outstanding. You don't need to know how to read sheet music to use this course.This course is not for the absolute beginning guitarist; I suggest that you first finish any one of the following before starting this course:(1) Six to twelve months of lessons with a guitar teacher(2) At least lessons 1 through 10 of Gibson's Learn & Master Guitar(3) Fender Presents Getting Started on Electric Guitar - DVD or Fender Presents Getting Started on Acoustic Guitar - DVD(4) The Rock House Method: Learn Rock Guitar - Beginner ProgramThis course will work best if you can already play open chords and barre chords, with no hesitation between chord changes.
